PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: BANKING (STATE BANK OF SOUTH AUSTRALIA AND OTHER MATTERS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 30 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The primary purpose of this bill is to facilitate South Australia's compliance with some of the principal conditions attached to the special assistance package which the Commonwealth is providing to South Australia over a period of three years. These conditions relate to the sale of the State Bank of South Australia—SBSA—subjecting the bank to Commonwealth taxation, and the transfer by legislation of prudential supervision powers over the bank to the Reserve Bank of Australia.

PARA.TAB: On 17 February 1993, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) issued a press release stating that the government was prepared to provide special assistance to South Australia, with a present value of $600 million, in recognition of the extraordinary financial burden imposed on the people of South Australia as a consequence of the losses incurred by the SBSA. The severity of this financial burden was such that, in the absence of the special assistance package, South Australia's ability to participate in the economic recovery now under way would have been severely constrained.

In return for the provision of the assistance, South Australia gave certain undertakings to the Commonwealth, including thatthe SBSA be sold as quickly as practicable consistent with achieving a fair market price; that the SBSA be brought into the Commonwealth's tax net free of tax losses from 1 July 1994; that the SBSA be subject to the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia no later than 1 July 1994 by legislation; and that a debt management strategy designed to restore South Australia's finances to a more sustainable position be implemented. The South Australian government is moving to comply with these conditions.

The process of preparing the SBSA for eventual sale involves the creation of a new corporatised entity from 1 July 1994 to be named the Bank of South Australia Ltd, or BankSA. BankSA will carry on the core business of the SBSA, including housing loans, credit cards, deposit facilities, and rural and business lending, and will continue to operate some interstate business in areas such as small-scale leasing and commercial lending. These activities are being transferred to BankSA under South Australian and complementary interstate legislation.

At the time the conditions of South Australia's special assistance package were being agreed to, the previous Commonwealth Treasurer undertook to facilitate South Australia's compliance with the conditions through Commonwealth legislation where necessary or justified. In this context, amendments to Commonwealth legislation are required to accommodate the referral of banking supervision powers over the bank to the Commonwealth and to facilitate the process of subjecting the bank to Commonwealth taxes. In fulfilment of this undertaking, the bill contains amendments to the Banking Act 1959 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The bill also contains a number of other minor amendments to various acts, which will streamline and reduce the administrative costs associated with the transfer of assets from the SBSA to BankSA.

Amendments to the Corporations Law will allow bulk notification to the Australian Securities Commission of the change of chargee of a group of registered company charges, and to enable the Australian Securities Commission to deregister subsidiaries of SBSA which have been dissolved under South Australian legislation. These amendments have been approved by the Ministerial Council for Corporations for introduction into parliament.

Amendments to the Privacy Act 1988 provide relief from the provisions relating to the passing of customer information from the SBSA to BankSA. The modifications are designed solely to facilitate the corporatisation of the SBSA and do not otherwise affect the operation or interpretation of the Privacy Act.

Amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, the Fringe Benefits Assessment Act 1986 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No. 2) 1992 address transitional issues associated with the transfer of assets from the SBSA to the new bank, including to allow the transfer of SBSA customer tax file numbers to BankSA, and the imposition of Commonwealth taxes.

Amendments are also proposed to the Financial Transactions Reports (FTR) Act 1988 and the Proceeds of Crime (POC) Act 1987. These acts impose an obligation on banks and other financial institutions to maintain records relating to the opening and operation of accounts. The proposed amendments to these acts provide for the transfer of this obligation where accounts are transferred from one bank to another. The amendments are not limited to the SBSA but are of general application to all banks where accounts and records are transferred. Without the proposed amendments, the SBSA would be criminally liable for not complying with the provisions of these acts where it transferred such account records to BSAL.

The amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 include provisions to deny deductions to BankSA for superannuation contributions or eligible termination payments in respect of unfunded liabilities accumulated as at 30 June 1994.

The government is determined to ensure that the banking system is the most efficient possible. Accordingly, this bill includes a number of minor amendments to the Banking Act 1959 to streamline its administration. These include amendments to:

SPEECH.PARA: .require branches of foreign banks to notify the Treasurer of any proposed arrangements, agreements or reconstructions of a foreign bank. If the Treasurer and the Governor-General are satisfied that these arrangements would not be in the national interest, this amendment gives the Governor-General in Council power to revoke the foreign bank's licence; and
.remove the need for the Treasurer, under section 70, to formally agree to the institution of proceedings against an offence under the Act.

PARA.TAB: The bill also amends the Reserve Bank Act 1959, so that the responsibility for granting leave of absence from Reserve Bank Board meetings passes from the Treasurer to the Reserve Bank Board. In the past the responsibility of granting leave of absence to Reserve Bank Board members fell to the Treasurer. The arrangements served little useful purpose and were an unnecessary ministerial burden. Mr Speaker, I know this bill would be of considerable interest to you, as it would to other members of the House. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Banking (State Bank of South Australia and Other Matters) Bill, I would like to put in some context why this action is necessary to resuscitate, as far as possible, the remnants of the State Bank in South Australia. It is easy to look at the bill which the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) has just detailed at the dispatch box as an exercise in a technical sense. But we have to look in the long term at the reason why we are discussing this bill and we have to look at the reasons why the State Bank of South Australia became such a financial wreck.

PARA.TAB: The reasons for this go back some years to the stewardship of this Labor government in Australia. I remember the heat and argument that surrounded a vote in this House some years ago which was aimed at facilitating the action of the entrepreneur Mr Holmes a Court in his takeover offer for BHP. At that stage, we reached the apex of this government's involvement in the paper machinations of the entrepreneurs in Australia.

The Hawke government was working hand in hand in developing that entrepreneurship in Australia. In fact, it was an active partner, as was illustrated by the admission of the government at the time that seven ministers had conferred with Mr Holmes a Court in relation to his adventures in moving in on Australia's biggest company. May I say how pleased I am that he failed in his attempt—an attempt which, if it had been successful, in the wreckage that ensued out of the recession caused by this government, would have resulted in the splitting of Australia's major company and selling it piecemeal to overseas owners.

That is all part of this background of the Labor Party in Australia, which was determined in its first rush of deregulation of the financial system to assist and encourage the activities, which brought so much ruin to this country, of entrepreneurs such as Skase, Bond and Holmes a Court. They borrowed simply on nothing more than the value of the shares they were purchasing with those borrowings, thoroughly and utterly encouraged by the Hawke Labor government and the ministers.

Mr Bannon is a very prominent member of the Labor Party in South Australia and was at one time its federal president. Certainly he was one of Labor's much touted younger premiers around Australia. He was thoroughly infected with that same entrepreneurial attitude fostered by the Hawke government—the attitude of which you, Mr Speaker, know full well, having been a very effective chairman of the committee which investigated banking in Australia; and may I pay tribute to you, sir, on your leadership of that committee.

We found one of the gravest derelictions of duty by managers of Australia's financial institutions that we could ever expect to find. Upon questioning as to why they entered into these ventures and supported the paper investments in Australia, they simply had nothing more in answer than a schoolboy's retort, `We thought it would be okay. We just did it. We didn't know any better. There was too much competition.' All the charts on the walls and all the economists in their back rooms did nothing to dissuade this schoolboy attitude of `Let's go for it'.

That is what the former Premier of South Australia did. His attitude to his State Bank was that it would make him millions, if not billions, of profits so that he could be the wonder Premier of South Australia and distribute these profits during his stewardship and management of South Australia. He would provide all these great things for his electors by these huge profits, which he, as a fellow government entrepreneur in parallel with the Holmes a Courts, the Skases and so on in this country, would also get.

What happened? The bank was unleashed and encouraged to lend overseas, to lend anywhere—take the bank of last resort. If people could not get a loan from the already overstretched private banks, they could go to the State Bank of South Australia. Of course, when it crashed it was found that so many of these billions had ended up overseas. They have never been repaid. South Australian money ended up overseas, and we had the greatest corporate-government failure in Australia's history.

This government stands responsible, make no mistake about it. It fostered this attitude. The main person in this, as I have said, is the former Premier of South Australia. The South Australian Treasurer simply failed to supervise the bank. He let it run and he encouraged it to run. It was supposed to have some unofficial supervision by the Reserve Bank. That too points to the failure of that institution to do its duty in looking fully at the situation in South Australia. But the main failure was political: it was failure of government administration, failure of a cabinet to question its Premier and failure deeply rooted in the outlook and policy decisions of the federal Labor government.

I make that point with some vehemence because today South Australia has a government—it is a little over six months since it took the reins of office—having to do things which are difficult to sell to the community, having to take action, following an audit report which will hurt some members of that community, which is utterly necessary for the survival of the South Australian economy. Why is it doing so? Because of the failure of this bank. The Labor government in South Australia was recently defeated because of the failure we are now discussing and to which the minister brings this bill in as some partial remedy. Because of that failure an audit report is in place and the government now has to take tough action. Yet such is the hypocrisy of politics that this government and the very individuals in the Labor Party who caused this problem can turn and criticise the remedies that are now being put in place in South Australia.

There is no fairness in politics, I suppose. Whoever can explain the best and has a run of luck can survive the longest. But let the people of South Australia make no mistake that the reason for this bill and for the tough decisions that are being taken by the government in South Australia goes back deep into the soul of the Labor Party; it goes to the immediately defeated government in South Australia and it runs back into the Hawke government in the national parliament and to the very actions it took in this parliament, such as the bill that I referred to which was passed to assist in the takeover of BHP by Mr Holmes a Court. There was no mention of the rescue of Holmes a Court by the Western Australian government. If it had not bought from the then financially derelict institution at a hugely inflated price the property in Perth, that company would now be alongside the Skases and the Bonds in the many failures that were left behind when the recession burst.

I will not go to the detail of this bill, except to say that it must be seen by itself as a desirable action. The government is to be commended, in a technical sense, for coming so far to the rescue as it has in this instance. A decision was made to assist to this degree. Without this assistance it would be very difficult to have the bank put into a position where, evolving from the wreckage, it can be sold and, hopefully, maintained largely, depending on the course of that sale, as a South Australian institution. South Australia has lost too many of its head offices over previous years. I hope in the sale of the bank that the head office does remain in South Australia.

I would like to refer to the minister's statement that, by this bill, the government is determined to ensure that Australia has the most efficient banking system. He referred to the supervision of foreign banks. I have always been doubtful of the ability of the authorities in Australia—the Reserve Bank, the federal Treasury and the government itself—to properly understand the financial details of a foreign bank operating in Australia. It is all very well for the minister to say that, if the government or the Reserve Bank is doubtful of the credentials and the financial stability of a foreign bank operating in Australia, it will revoke the bank's licence.

Just in passing, I express my extreme doubt that any authorities in Australia will be able to ascertain the finer details of a foreign bank to the degree that they would know whether it should be allowed to continue in Australia. History, especially in relation to the BCCI bank, has proven that regulatory authorities are at an extreme disadvantage in many cases in knowing the ramifications of international transfers and international ownership. Therefore, if the government proceeds along this line, I expect that there will be further difficulties some time in the future. But that is another factor that the government, or the Labor Party in opposition in the future, will have to place alongside its political conscience.

As you would know, Mr Speaker, the history of the State Bank in recent years has been a very unpleasant one. The banking inquiry had before it an annual report, which was signed by the deputy chairman and of a most optimistic nature, for seven or eight days before the dam burst and the announcement was made that the bank was in extreme difficulty.

If a bank within Australia can put up such a deliberate deception to a parliamentary institution, God knows what a foreign bank can do in its reporting to an Australian government. But I must again put on record reference to a simple deception which was part of the whole report placed publicly before the banking inquiry. For the management of the bank to proceed to adopt such an optimistic report knowing internally that the bank was in a shambles and facing ruin without rescue—although rescue in the first instance was provided by the state government and ultimately by the taxpayers of South Australia—was probably the lowest thing it could have done.

I certainly endorse this bill. I commend the government for its assistance to South Australia and for the stability it will enable the state government to bring to this institution. But let me say that the greatest burden is being met by the new managers of the South Australian government. The measures that that government has to take to preserve the financial integrity of my state are being met by the taxpayers and the electors of South Australia.

I trust that those electors will always understand who is and was responsible for this great adventure of financial deregulation in Australia—an adventure that went too far and created a recession and so much unemployment that the employment numbers in Australia are not yet restored to those held prior to the recession. South Australia will take its medicine knowing that that situation was imposed on it by the philosophy of Labor in the 1980s which said, `Go for it, regardless of the result,' and by the inevitable crash of the paper entrepreneurs.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) for his contribution to the debate on the Banking (State Bank of South Australia and Other Matters) Bill. I will just briefly make one or two points. First of all, given your interest, Mr Speaker, the interest of the honourable member for Boothby and my interest in matters to do with the banking inquiry, we should look at the period involved and the inquiries that we undertook in relation to the State Bank of South Australia. Hopefully, we can all then see some of the major issues that arose and some of the shortcomings that occurred involving the owner, the board and so on of the State Bank at that time. Everyone would acknowledge that there were major deficiencies, and they have been identified in our reports and in other reports.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the broader issues of banking supervision, it is worth noting that none of the banks that were under the supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia and where the Reserve Bank had formal powers have seen one cent of depositors' money lost no matter how deep the recession might have been or what other financial difficulties both the banking and non-banking financial sector might have got into. That certainly is still the case today.

One of the things recommended in that parliamentary committee report was that all state-owned banks be removed from state ownership over time. That is occurring. We also wanted to ensure that supervision powers were transferred to the Commonwealth of Australia through the Reserve Bank under the Banking Act. That has been completed with the various state banks as well.

The bill before the House ensures that there will be Reserve Bank supervision of the new arrangements in South Australia. Going back to the parliamentary reports and other reports of inquiries that have been conducted into these issues, I think that is fundamental to effective supervision in the future. The Reserve Bank has to take its role in that new process very seriously. I know that is what is occurring.

The honourable member for Boothby has been absolutely consistent in his view on foreign banks. I will grant him that. He certainly did maintain that view about foreign bank issues through that parliamentary inquiry process. Everyone would share the observation of the need to maintain the strongest supervisory arrangements with foreign banks, particularly in the broader arrangements that have been outlined since that parliamentary committee report. Equally, the competitive opportunities foreign banks bring need to be balanced against those conditions. This was what the parliamentary committee recommended, as you would recall, Mr Speaker. All members of the parliamentary committee supported those recommendations, with the exception of the honourable member for Boothby.

People would acknowledge through that parliamentary inquiry process that a fairly steep learning curve occurred in the mid- to late-1980s. I think we can now be confident about the arrangements set in place by the Reserve Bank with its supervisory and prudential arrangements. We also now have a council of supervisors that coordinates with other financial supervisors in relation to their role. That process is also working effectively.

We have changed the conditions relating to foreign banking to give foreign banks a competitive but well-scrutinised role in our banking and financial system. A process has now been adopted with the state banks to set those processes on a sound financial footing.

This package of bills is a recognition by the Commonwealth of the continuing need of the state of South Australia to be able to play its part in the economic recovery in a sustainable financial way. That is why the assistance package was developed. It is urgently sought not only by the people of South Australia but particularly by the government of South Australia. It is important that these arrangements come into effect from 1 July this year.

I believe this package is a fair and realistic one that has been adopted by the Commonwealth in response to those measures which will set South Australia on a sound financial footing to have the services that the people of South Australia require, at the same time ensuring that neither in South Australian or in the broader nation is there financial adversity that cannot be met through competent financial management. With those remarks, I would ask the House to support the second reading motion. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Elliott) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 30 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 will amend 10 acts coming within the Attorney-General's portfolio. The bill contains amendments of a minor policy nature, makes minor technical amendments to existing legislation and corrects a drafting error. None of the amendments involve major policy proposals. They are explained in the explanatory memorandum circulated with the bill.

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendments will not have any significant financial impact. However, the amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 may lead to some minor savings in the administration of delegations. The amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 will ensure that a delegation to a class of offices will include offices created after the instrument of delegation was made.

The amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 will enable a judge to be appointed as President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal during the period that Justice O'Connor, the current President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, is appointed as President of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The amendments in the bill to the Cheques and Payment Orders Act 1986 will improve procedures for the physical and electronic presentment of cheques. The amendments will facilitate greater use of electronic presentments. The amendments were sought by the Australian Payments Clearing Association.

The Cheques and Payment Orders Act currently enables a demand for the payment of a cheque—presentment—to be made electronically by the collecting bank to the drawee or paying bank without the physical movement of the cheque itself between the two banks. However, electronic presentment has not been widely used. This has been partly because the banking industry, in considering how to implement electronic presentment at the practical level, has concluded that the act should clearly distinguish between electronic presentments within the one bank and those between different banks. Therefore, the proposed amendments will provide for a distinction between the internal and external presentment of cheques. This will enable a drawee or paying bank to present internally to itself, without the restrictions set out in the amendments as to places, times and means of communication, which will apply to external presentment between banks.

The new provisions applying to internal and external presentment will also apply to the presentment of payment orders drawn on non-bank financial institutions. The amendment to the Family Law Act 1975 will correct a drafting error in section 22. The bill will amend the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 to widen the powers of a single judge in appeal procedures. The bill will confer upon a single judge the power to join or remove parties of an appeal; make orders by consent disposing of an appeal, including orders for costs; and give directions relating to the conduct of an appeal generally.

The bill will also amend the Federal Court of Australia Act to give the Federal Court the ability to take evidence by video link, telephone or other appropriate means. The bill will also provide the Federal Court with a discretion to take unsworn evidence by video link, telephone or other appropriate means from a person in another country. This will allow the Federal Court to overcome the difficulty of taking foreign evidence, particularly where the laws or conventions of other countries prevent the administration of an oath or affirmation by Australian courts. Where unsworn evidence is taken, the court can give such weight to that evidence as it thinks fit in the circumstances.

The Federal Court of Australia Act will also be amended to enable rules of court to be made so that the court will have a discretion to amend documents in a proceeding even though the effect of the amendment would be to raise a new cause of action that would, if proceedings in relation to it were commenced at the time of the amendment, be out of time. The amendment is intended to overcome the rule in Weldon v. Neal (1887) 19 QBD 394, which prevents such amendments being made.

TALK.START.PARA: —It took us only 107 years to fix it, didn't it?

—Yes, I know. We are slow at it. Comments by the Hon. Justice Toohey in the decision of the High Court in Wardley Australia Ltd v. Western Australia (1992) 175 CLR 514 suggest that an amendment to the act is needed to enable rules of court to be made to overcome any doubt there may be about the court's rule making power. It will put the Federal Court in a similar position to most other state and territory supreme courts which already have this power.

PARA.TAB: The amendment to the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 will give the director of the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre, or Austrac, the powers of a departmental secretary in relation to certain matters. The director will be provided with equivalent powers to those which a departmental secretary possesses under the Public Service Act 1922. This amendment will also allow Austrac to be prescribed under the Audit Act 1901 so that it will be responsible for the management of its funds and financial reporting.

The bill also contains a number of amendments to the Freedom of Information Act 1982, or FOI Act. In 1991, section 27A of the act was amended to remove a precondition to the requirement to consult individuals where an application was made under the act for a document that contained personal information that related to that individual. The precondition was that the individual to whom the information related might reasonably wish to contend that the document was exempt. The requirement to consult has become unduly onerous. The bill will provide for the reinsertion of the precondition and will contain guidance on matters to be taken into account in making the decision whether an individual might reasonably wish to object to disclosure.

The bill will amend the sections of the FOI Act which provide for the internal review of decisions and appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to overcome a difficulty raised by a decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which denied an applicant a right of appeal where the agency claimed that it had given access to all the documents requested but the applicant claimed that there were further documents.

Part II of schedule 2 of the FOI Act will be amended to include specified documents of the Australian Statistician and documents in relation to the competitive commercial activities of Comcare and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, or CSIRO, amongst those which may not be obtained under the act. The bill will amend part III of schedule 2 to delete a reference to the repealed Honey Marketing Act 1988. The bill will include CSIRO in schedule 4 of the act, with the effect that certain research documents of CSIRO will be exempt from applications under the act.

The bill will consequentially amend the Privacy Act 1988 to ensure that the information privacy principles in that act will continue to apply to the Australian Statistician in the collection, storage, use and disclosure of information collected in the census and other surveys. The protection given by sections 91 and 92 of the FOI Act will be extended to situations where agencies are required to consult third parties before releasing documents to applicants. Section 91 of the act provides protection against specified civil actions where applicants are given access to documents in accordance with that section. Section 92 of the act provides protection against prosecution for criminal offences in the same circumstances.The FOI Act will also be amended to extend the exemption under the act for information which identifies confidential informants to persons protected under the national witness protection program.

The bill will also make miscellaneous amendments to the FOI Act to improve the administration of the act. These include the clarification of the requirement that agencies publish a statement of the categories of documents that are in their possession; applying the act to `official documents of a parliamentary secretary' to the same extent that it applies to `official documents of a minister'; extending the requirement on an agency to give reasons and other particulars to decisions on reducing or not imposing charges and on remitting application fees; further standardising time limits for various actions under the act at 30 days; and making specific provision for forwarding notifications and documents by post.

The amendment to the Judiciary Act 1903 will allow judgments of the full court of the High Court of Australia to be delivered by one justice. The amendments to the Bankruptcy Act 1966 will exclude payments under the rural adjustment scheme, or RAS, from the property which is divisible among creditors of a bankrupt. The amendments will also remove the distinction between property purchased with exempt money—that is, non-divisible money, such as RAS payments—before the person becomes a bankrupt and property purchased with exempt money after the person becomes a bankrupt. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) says, the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is an omnibus bill which amends a number of acts covering amendments in a wide variety of fields—hardly holding people at the edge of their seats—
—Riveting.

—Hardly riveting—nevertheless, it is essential for the good order and administration of justice and other elements touched upon by the parliamentary secretary this morning, the bill having already passed through the Senate. The bill amends seven acts within the portfolios of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr). The bill is stated by the government to contain amendments of a minor policy nature to make minor technical amendments to existing legislation and to correct a drafting error. We accept this, and we do not oppose the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The bill amends the Acts Interpretation Act to enable an instrument of delegation to apply to a class of officers to catch offices created after the instrument of delegation was made. This is a non-controversial amendment. There are amendments to the Cheques and Payment Orders Act 1986. These amendments have been requested by the Australian Payments Clearing Association and will implement different procedures for internal and external presentments. We support these amendments. We also support the amendments to the Family Law Act, which simply correct a numbering error in the act.

Amendments to the Federal Court of Australia Act are also supported by us. The bill will broaden the power of a single judge to make certain orders rather than such orders only being exercised by the full court. The bill once enacted will also allow evidence to be obtained by video link, telephone or other means. The bill also gives the court the ability to make rules allowing the court to amend documents in a proceeding, even if that would have the effect of raising a new cause of action that, if the proceedings in relation to it were commenced at the time of the amendment, would be out of time. The amendments overcome the concerns of a High Court judge in a 1992 decision. They are procedural improvements and are supported by us.

The Judiciary Act will be amended so that when the full court of the High Court delivers a judgment only one justice need be present. It is currently the situation that, when the full court delivers a judgment, two judges must be present. That concludes the acts that are dealt with by the Attorney-General's Department. The amendments are all fairly straightforward and non-controversial.

Two pieces of legislation are dealt with by the Minister for Justice. It is the amendments to the Freedom of Information Act that have been somewhat more controversial in the other place. Firstly, the amendments to the Financial Transaction Reports Act are non-controversial. The changes to the Financial Transaction Reports Act will enable the Director of Austrac to have the powers of a departmental secretary under the Public Service Act 1922, so far as the act relates to Austrac, as if that branch were a separate department of the Australian Public Service. This is not a contentious amendment. It will ensure that the Director of Austrac will have not only increased responsibility and accountability but also broader powers.

The amendments which have caused some controversy in the other place are those that amend the Freedom of Information Act. This bill tries to undo something that was done some time ago which amended the provision for consultation. The original amendment would have provided that consultation with a party about whom information is sought will no longer be mandatory before releasing documents unless the person mentioned in the documents might reasonably contend that the documents are exempt. The minister indicated that the requirement to consult has become unduly onerous. The provision will now mean that the minister will be required to consult only where it appears to the officer or minister dealing with the request that a person might reasonably contend that a document is exempt.

As I understand it, factors which will need to be taken into account include the extent to which the person to whom the personal information relates is well known; whether the person to whom the personal information relates is known to be associated with the matters dealt with in the document; the availability of the personal information from publicly accessible sources; and any other matter that the minister, officer or reviewer considers relevant.

Concerns about this matter were raised in the Senate. However, after some discussion, my side did not have any serious concerns with the clauses, as it was felt that the balance had been appropriately struck between, on the one hand, ensuring that the government had not been left with an unnecessary burden to consult and, on the other hand, providing the opportunity for people to realise that information about themselves is the subject of an FOI request.

The amendments to the FOI Act will also mean that the grounds for review to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will be broadened. Effectively, the amendment will mean that there can be review of an agency's decision where an agency alleges that it has given the applicant copies of all the documents. Under the amendments, officers and agencies will be protected from certain civil and criminal actions while undertaking their duties. As I have indicated, we support these amendments.

Amendments were moved in the committee stage of the bill in the other place. The government moved amendments to the bill relating to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act. The amendments numbered 1 to 4 are not controversial and, as I understand it, were not opposed in the Senate. These amendments will provide for the fact that the president of the tribunal, Deirdre O'Connor, has accepted an appointment as President of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The amendments will enable a judge to be appointed to the position of President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal during the period that Justice Deirdre O'Connor, who is currently president of the tribunal, is President of the Industrial Relations Commission.

There is an amendment to the Bankruptcy Act which I should mention. As I recall, the minister touched on this. This amendment will mean that grants made under the rural adjustment scheme cannot subsequently be sequestered by the trustee in bankruptcy when those who receive the grants become bankrupt. If such a situation were allowed, this would mean that taxpayers would be paying for the RAS grants only to have that money suddenly taken by the trustee in bankruptcy to pay off creditors.

Section 116, as amended, will now specifically exclude amounts paid to the bankrupt for re-establishment support under the rural adjustment scheme within the meaning of the Rural Adjustment Act 1992. The coalition has been concerned about this amendment for some time. I believe that the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) has raised this issue in the House in the past. We support this amendment along with the other amendments which the government moved. The legislation and the amendments are fairly non-controversial, and the coalition therefore does not oppose this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to see that the opposition is supporting the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill. It is an omnibus bill that makes a number of changes to acts within the portfolio of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch). In particular, I note that this legislation will allow a judge to become President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I do not want to go over the same ground covered by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) in his contribution. However, I note that there are some changes to the Family Law Act. The principal change removes a drafting error from the 1992 omnibus bill, and I am pleased to see that.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to make a few comments about the family law area, in which I am taking a particular interest. Firstly, I want to commend the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) for their report entitled Access to justice: an action plan. By and large, I think it has been pretty well received. From my perspective, it seems to me that access to justice is not an issue of better competition policy or even micro-economic reform at the fringes. I think the real test is whether or not we are going to afford the citizens of Australia the ability to exercise their legal rights.

I know there are some people who are very concerned about the amount of money being spent on legal aid and suggest that governments should dramatically increase this amount in order that citizens can exercise their rights. It is fair to say on both sides of the House that governments are not going to have access to that sort of money. Therefore, just funnelling more money into legal aid is not going to be a solution to the problem.

I have suggested that in the family law area it is worth while considering not only the present judicial system that we have through the Family Court but also a no-frills family tribunal. It would be a tribunal from which members of the legal profession would be excluded and where the emphasis would be on either ratifying agreements previously arrived at or conciliating agreements. Finally, where it is not possible to have all areas conciliated then the court would arbitrate a decision. A feature of the tribunal would be that it would not have the restricted sitting hours of the family courts but would sit at times convenient to the clients. I can readily imagine that it might sit from 9 o'clock in the morning to 9 o'clock in the evening.

I believe it is these types of approaches that will really start to address the principal issue of allowing citizens to exercise their rights. I note that the Chief Justice of the Family Court feels that instituting a magistrates court in the family law area would go a long way towards achieving some of the objectives I have announced. A good example of this system is the small claims tribunal in my own state, where the participants to the tribunal do not have legal representatives and there is an upper amount of money that can be decided. That tribunal has an excellent record of producing results that citizens can afford. So where the citizens do have rights they are able to exercise their rights and have access to justice. I feel that that is very much the way to go.

The Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues has a reference to inquire into the funding and administration of the Family Court of Australia. I believe that the committee will have an opportunity to ensure that those persons appearing before the Family Court are actually able to exercise their rights or, more particularly, get some handle on the latent number of citizens who do not have the ability to argue or present their case before the court.

Given that there has been a great deal of interest on both sides of the House in the child support inquiry, and whilst the Auditor-General tabled his report yesterday, I am pleased to advise honourable members that I will be giving a draft report on the child support scheme to the committee. This report will go much further than the Auditor-General's recommendations, valuable as they were.

I remind honourable members that it is no longer just a question of wishing to fix the administration of the scheme, bad as that has been, but that very significant policy areas also need to be considered. Those areas will not be dodged in the draft report. I have every confidence that the committee will improve on those recommendations and will improve on the consideration of the report. When that report is tabled—by no later than August this year—it will give the committee the opportunity to pursue the reference of the funding and administration of the Family Court. I trust that that will be a very productive exercise. I know that the Attorney-General is anxious for the committee to get on with it and I know that the chief justice is anxious to get on with it.

As I said, the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill addresses a number of areas and I do not want to reiterate the points that the honourable member for Kooyong has already elaborated to the House. I conclude by saying that I support these changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition's position in relation to this legislation has been outlined by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), and I do not propose to add to it. I seek to comment on only one particular aspect of the legislation, and it relates to its course through the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The bill was introduced in the Senate. Senator Spindler of the Australian Democrats had some concerns regarding the amendments proposed to the Freedom of Information Act. These concerns related to privacy matters. Senator Spindler wrote to the Privacy Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor. The response Senator Spindler received from Mr O'Connor was to the effect that Mr O'Connor had provided advice to the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) and indicated that it was his practice not to canvass concerns about bills with non-government members or senators. Senator Spindler then wrote to the Minister for Justice, and I understand that the minister provided Senator Spindler with the advice Mr O'Connor had given to him.

Senator Spindler was rightly of the view that this was an unsatisfactory situation and, in the Senate, he moved amendments to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 and the Privacy Act 1988. The objects of the amendments to the former act were to enable parliamentarians to request the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to report on proposed Commonwealth, state and territory enactments, and to provide that reports to a minister or a parliamentarian by the commission be laid before parliament. The objects of the amendments to the Privacy Act were to enable parliamentarians to request the Privacy Commissioner to report on proposed Commonwealth, state or territory enactments, and to provide that reports to a minister or a parliamentarian by the commissioner be laid before the parliament.

The coalition did not support those amendments. They were considerably detailed and were proposed at the last minute, not giving adequate time for consideration, by either the shadow ministry or the party room. However, the coalition's position in the Senate, which remains, is that consideration needs to be given to securing the independence of the Privacy Commissioner. There should be a way for the parliament to have the benefit of the Privacy Commissioner's advice.

There is currently under way—and there has been for some time—a review of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. In the course of that review, it is appropriate that consideration be given to the concerns expressed by Senator Spindler. I add that concerns have been expressed not only by Senator Spindler. I have previously encountered the policy of the Privacy Commissioner in relation to his not providing non-government members with his advice on a bill. After Senator Spindler had given notice of his amendments, but before they were moved, I wrote to the Privacy Commissioner seeking his views on his role. He wrote back a helpful letter with which he enclosed a copy of a speech he had delivered in New Zealand, which dealt in part with the provision of advice to parliament. A relevant part of that speech states:

SPEECH.PARA: A related pressure that my office has faced is whether my confidential advices should be made more widely available to interested members of parliament. The practice I have followed, in line with usual conventions that apply to the giving of advice to government, is to decline requests for access to my advices. The requests often flow from non-government members at the time a bill is tabled. I have indicated that my advice is given to the relevant Minister in confidence, and that they should address their queries to him or her in order to gain access. The non-government members have indicated their dissatisfaction with this state affairs. Once pressed, the government usually, but not always, makes available the advice. I have declined to make my advices available directly, as, one, my statute only gives me a power to advise the government and, two—and more importantly—my ability to participate effectively in the deliberative process would, I believe, be hampered if Ministers thought that their political opponents might be given that advice unbeknown to them or while policy was still being developed.

The Privacy Commissioner indicated that there had been in operation in the Senate in the period 1989-90 a practice referred to as the `Macklin procedure'. He indicated it was the convention of the then Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, to table or make available advices from the Privacy Commissioner. He was not aware whether this was an understanding between Senator Tate and Senator Macklin of the Democrats or something more formal. But he does make a positive suggestion as to what might be an appropriate procedure to follow. He said in his letter to me:

You may be also interested to note that cl. 22 of the Privacy and Data Protection Bill recently introduced into the NSW Parliament is not as restrictive as my Act in relation to the Privacy Commissioner's advice role. Clause 22, functions (g) and (n) allow for advice or reports to be given to `any person'. No doubt the proposed NSW Privacy Commissioner would have to develop some conventions in relation to the exercise of these functions.

This seems to be a sensible and pragmatic approach that should be endorsed and implemented by the government. Before concluding, I want to express one further concern in relation to the Privacy Commissioner. It is a concern that relates not only to him but also to other commissioners within the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

PARA.TAB: In the course of the internal review, several of the terms of office of commissioners have come to an end. The government has seen fit to extend those terms of office for 12 months in the case of continuing officers or officers who seek to continue but has left open what might occur after the expiry of a 12-month period pending the results of the review. Given the important and sensitive roles played by each of the commissioners within the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, to have those commissioners exercising what are meant to be functions independent of government while subject to a 12-month extension of contract is most unsatisfactory. The limited term of office provided, with no promise of either reappointment or termination, means that the appearance of independence is seriously jeopardised.

I urge the government to take steps to bring the review to a prompt conclusion and to take steps in accordance with the appropriate results of the review, subject to legislation, to ensure that not only are the commissioners within the commission independent under statute but they appear in the performance of their functions to be independent as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I formally congratulate you on the attainment of your half century yesterday. The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is one of an increasing number of omnibus bills which are being introduced into the parliament. I suppose we can argue one way or the other as to whether this is the appropriate means for amending a very large number of acts when quite often those acts are totally unrelated and apply to different portfolios.

PARA.TAB: The bill we are discussing today amends 10 bills, seven relating to the Attorney-General's portfolio and three relating to the justice portfolio. As was mentioned by the shadow minister representing the shadow Attorney-General, the opposition is not opposing what the government proposes. Included in the acts to be amended is the Acts Interpretation Act 1901—one of the very early acts of the Commonwealth parliament. The bill amends this act to enable a delegation to a class of officers to catch offices created after the instrument of delegation was made. There has been wide consultation in relation to this matter and I understand that there has been no adverse comment. Consequently, the amendments proposed to the Acts Interpretation Act are not being opposed by the opposition. I understand that there is no major concern in the community in relation to these proposed changes.

The Cheques and Payment Orders Act 1986 also attracts the attention of this bill. The bill modernises rules about the presentment of cheques by banks. It is designed to improve the procedures for physical and electronic presentment of cheques. Although the act currently allows for this to occur electronically, those provisions have not been widely utilised because the Australian banking industry has considered that the acts should clearly distinguish between electronic presentment within one bank and those among different banks.

The amendments, which have actually been requested by the Australian Payments Clearing Association, or APCA, implement different procedures for internal and external presentments. The provisions also apply to the presentment of payment orders drawn on non-bank financial institutions. The specifics, which have arisen from a very close consideration of the Cheques and Payment Orders Act 1986, are detailed and complex, and I suppose that is understandable.

In summary, the bill amends the act to enable a drawee or paying bank to present cheques internally to itself as drawee or paying bank, whether the bank is the collecting bank of a cheque or is acting as agent for other collecting banks which have handed cheques to the drawee or paying bank at the clearing house, without the restrictions in the act applying to external presentment.

The amendments enable the drawee or paying bank to specify to another bank the place, times and means of communication which the other bank must use when presenting cheques by exhibition or by particulars. The amendments further enable the collecting bank to specify to another bank the place, times and means of communication which must be used by that other bank when requesting exhibition or further particulars of a cheque, and provide for the internal and external presentment of payment orders.

When these amendments were proposed, there was widespread consultation by the coalition and, I presume, also by the government, and I understand that there has been no adverse comment received by either the government or the opposition in relation to the amendments. The Australian Bankers Association has noted that the provisions are consistent with the requests of the association's previous cheques committee and the requests of the APCA. Consequently, as I mentioned earlier, the coalition is not opposing these very complicated amendments to the Cheques and Payment Orders Act 1986.

As referred to by the previous government speaker, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), the Family Law Act is also being amended. It is very much a technical amendment, correcting a subsection numbering error in the act. Unfortunately, quite often, too many of these errors are made and not picked up prior to legislation passing through the parliament. It is better to consider properly and closely look at the numbering and wording of acts to make sure that we are not put in the position of having subsequently to rectify an error. The error having been made, it certainly has to be fixed up; the coalition does not at all oppose this amendment. We do, however, comment that the government should be very much more careful in ensuring that legislation is right before it is pumped through the House.

The next piece of legislation to be amended is the Federal Court of Australia Act. This bill broadens the powers of a single judge to make interlocutory or consent orders in relation to pending appeals. Currently, the enumerated powers may be exercised only by the full court of the Federal Court. This bill allows evidence to be obtained by video link, telephone or other appropriate means. If the witness is present in Australia, the evidence must be sworn; if the witness is overseas, the testimony may be sworn or, in limited circumstances, unsworn. Power is given to enable rules of court to be made dealing with the way evidence is given in this regard.

While we are not opposing this legislation, I do have some concerns to ensure that we have in our court system fairness and equity. One of the basic tenets of the British and Australian court systems has been that witnesses should be present in court wherever possible; that they should be available to be cross-examined. Of course, when a witness can be seen in person, it enables everyone in the court to assess the witness's reliability. The demeanour of a witness can often tell you whether he or she can be believed and trusted. I understand that, on occasions, it can be helpful to be able to use video link evidence, but I certainly hope that this evidence is used only as a last resort. Once we start to chip away at the guarantees of justice in our court system, ultimately our courts will not have the confidence of the public—the confidence that they have largely enjoyed since this nation's inception.

The legislation gives the court the ability to make rules allowing the court to amend documents in a proceeding, even if that would have the effect of raising a new cause of action that would, if the proceedings in relation to it were commenced at the time of the amendment, be out of time. The ability of the Federal Court to make such rules was questioned by the Hon. Mr Justice Toohey of the High Court in a 1992 decision. The amendments overcome these doubts and bring the Federal Court into line with most other Australian jurisdictions. That is eminently appropriate, given the very high regard in which the Federal Court has been held in this nation over the time since it was formed.

Again, these amendments to this act were widely canvassed in the community. There was ample opportunity for people who had any concerns at all to come forward. My understanding is that there has been no adverse comment in relation to the amendments, and that the amendments properly facilitate procedural improvements. Consequently, the opposition is not opposing this portion of the bill either.

The next act to be amended by this bill is the Judiciary Act. The act currently provides that, when the full court of the High Court delivers a judgment, at least two justices must be present. The bill allows such a judgment to be delivered by one justice. The amendments are for administrative convenience. While we are not opposing them, I feel that, when the full court delivers a judgment, it is better that there should be more than one judge in attendance, but that is only a personal inclination. I understand that the court should be allowed to organise its affairs as best conveniences it. When a full court judgment is being handed down, one would imagine that, if there were a dissenting judgment, the dissenting judge would have to be present. Presumably, judgment by one justice would be delivered in cases where there was no dissent.

Two other acts being amended are the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 and the Freedom of Information Act 1982. The amendments to the Financial Transaction Reports Act are non-controversial. A change to that Act will enable the director of Austrac to have the powers of a departmental secretary under the Public Service Act 1922, as far as the act relates to Austrac, as if that branch were a separate department of the Australian Public Service. This is not a contentious amendment. It will ensure that the director of Austrac will have not only increased responsibility and accountability but also broader powers.

The Freedom of Information Act 1982 has some amendments which have created a little more controversy than some of the other matters which are the subject of this particular legislation. The bill seeks to undo something that was done some time ago which amended the provision for consultation. The original amendment would have provided that consultation with a party about whom information is sought would no longer be necessary before releasing documents, unless the person mentioned in the documents might reasonably contend that the documents were exempt.

The minister has indicated that the requirement to consult has become unduly onerous. That is the minister's conclusion and, of course, the amendments we have before the House have resulted from it. The provision will now mean that the minister will be required to consult only where it appears to the officer or minister dealing with the request that a person might reasonably be able to contend that a document is exempt. Factors that will need to be taken into account are the extent to which personal information is well known, whether the person to whom the personal information relates is known to be associated with the matters dealt with in the document, the availability of the personal information from publicly accessible sources, and other matters that the minister, officer or reviewer considers relevant.

I understand that the Australian Democrats have had a number of concerns with the provisions requiring the agency or minister to consult with the persons concerned where there may be a disclosure of personal information and the person concerned might reasonably wish to contend that the document was exempt from disclosure. The Democrat concerns revolved around the amount of discretion which could be applied in deciding whether to release information. However, the coalition does not have the same concerns as the Democrats in relation to these clauses, as it was felt that a balance had been struck between ensuring that the government had not been left with the unnecessary burden to consult and the opportunity for people to realise that information about themselves is the subject of an FOI request.

The amendments to the FOI Act will also mean that the grounds for review at the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will be broadened. Effectively, the amendments will mean that there can be review of an agency's decision where an agency alleges that it had given the applicant copies of all of the documents. Officers and agencies will be protected from certain civil and criminal actions while undertaking their duties under the amendments, and that is certainly understandable. The result is that the coalition supports what the government is seeking to achieve in this area.

A lot of people criticise the opposition for opposing everything all of the time. I think most opposition members of parliament would occasionally receive phone calls from people saying, `You people always oppose what the government is doing. It doesn't matter about the rights and wrongs of the situation. You simply are there to oppose. You're always being negative and, indeed, you don't consider matters on their merits. The suggestion is that whenever a piece of legislation comes into the parliament the government members strongly support it and opposition members strongly oppose it.'

The legislation before the House today indicates that, when reasonable legislation comes into the parliament, members on this side are prepared to look very closely at the legislation and, where the legislation is good legislation, we are prepared to support it. Consequently, I am very pleased to join with the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock)—the shadow minister representing the shadow Attorney-General—and other opposition speakers in supporting the omnibus bill before the House. On that basis, I trust that the House will support what the government proposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank honourable members who have contributed to this debate this morning. I thought it was a pleasant change to have such constructive contributions from both sides of the House. It certainly shows the parliament working at its best when people can make the sorts of positive, sensible and thoughtful contributions that we have heard this morning.

PARA.TAB: I thought a number of issues were raised which are worthy of a response. I want to deal with them more or less in order of their being raised. The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), who I think it can be said has been a great visionary in the area of family law, raised a number of issues and I thought his contribution to the debate was thoughtful and interesting. The government certainly looks forward to receiving the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues into both the administration of the Family Court and the child support scheme.

The contribution that that committee has already made in the area of reforming family law is well known. The government's response to its report was wholly supportive and positive. We will be introducing legislation to the parliament in the near future to give effect to the work of that committee. I am sure that the honourable member for Chifley will look forward to that with some enthusiasm as the government looks forward to receiving his committee's report into the administration of the court and the child support scheme.

The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) raised a number of issues in what was his usual thoughtful, sensible and sensitive contribution to any debate. The issues that have been raised about access to the Privacy Commissioner's advice to the government are important and they need to be considered carefully by the parliament. I have some sympathy for the point of view that he has expressed, but it is a complex issue and it has important policy considerations. As such, I do not think it is the sort of issue that ought to be dealt with in this type of omnibus legislation. It is the sort of major policy change that ought to be dealt with in a separate piece of legislation.

I said that it was complex. The government does see it as a complex issue because it would have potentially important resource considerations for the Privacy Commissioner. If each member of the House of Representatives and the Senate were able to approach the Privacy Commissioner directly for advice on a wide range of matters, the Privacy Commissioner could well find that he was weighed down and bogged down in such responses. So it does need to be thought through carefully, and it does need to be resourced properly if any changes are made.

At present, the commission is subject to an internal review—not just the Privacy Commission but also the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I have no doubt that that matter, having been raised in the parliament, will be brought to the attention of the human rights commission. I am quite sure that, as a result, consideration will be given to the suggestions that were made.

The other matter that was raised by the honourable member for Tangney—again, raised in his usual thoughtful manner—involved his concerns about the fact that a number of commissioners or officers of the human rights commission have been appointed for short terms rather than longer terms whilst the internal review of the human rights commission is being undertaken. He raised the point that this could be seen to be an interference with the statutory independence of the human rights commission.

In response to that, anybody who knows Commissioner Brian Burdekin would think that the idea that he would brook any interference with his independence was a laughable proposition. I cannot think of a more feared person, in terms of propriety, than Mr Burdekin. Whilst I appreciate the concerns that the honourable member for Tangney has expressed, I think no-one should have any concerns that the independence of the human rights commission will be compromised in these circumstances. I think the commission is basically working well. I look forward to the internal review, which I am sure will lead to the commission being able to operate more effectively and more efficiently, thereby providing better services and even better protection for the human rights of citizens of this nation than possibly has been the case to date.

This legislation, whilst it may be of minor concern in policy terms, is important to many citizens of this nation. Many of the things that are dealt with in this legislation, whilst they do not have wide policy implications, quite obviously have important repercussions for individuals: for example, the references to the rural adjustment scheme in relation to bankruptcy. I am sure that each and every member of the House would know that some individuals have been sadly affected by the situation at present. That is one of those classic examples of unintended consequences of legislation. I am sure that no one member of this House who turned his or her mind to the issue would have wanted RAS payments to be absorbed in bankruptcies. But that was an unintended consequence, and it has now been corrected. There are many other examples of that sort, but I will not go into detail now.

In conclusion, one honourable member raised his concern that so many matters were being dealt with in one piece of legislation. This is an excellent example of the sort of legislation that will be dealt with in the second chamber in the future so that possibly more detail can be taken into account and more time can be made available for discussion. I think it does provide a good example of the sort of legislation that will benefit from the time that will be able to be made available in the second chamber for debating the detail of this type of legislation which, while it may not be particularly sexy, nonetheless is important in terms of the rights of individuals in this nation. I commend this bill to the parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Duncan) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 9 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill proposes the payment of a bounty on the production of certain fuel ethanol in Australia to assist in the development of a competitive, robust and ecologically sustainable fuel ethanol industry. The bill is part of a package of lead abatement measures announced in the 1993 budget which will complement initiatives announced in the environment statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of December 1992 relating to a guarantee of the excise free status of alternative fuels for a further four years, as well as support for new ethanol production technology.

PARA.TAB: Ethanol can be blended with petrol and diesel to extend transport fuel and therefore reduce our dependence on fossil fuels. Its octane enhancing properties may offer some potential benefits towards the reduction of lead in petrol as well as increasing the sustainability of the energy sector through the use of a fuel based on a renewable resource. Ethanol also has the potential to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases.

The bill proposes that $25 million be provided over the next three years for bounty payments at a rate of 18c per litre. Some $6 million will be dedicated to the first year of the bounty, $8 million to the second year and the remaining $11 million will be used for the third and final year. Where the money apportioned for either of the first two years is not paid out as bounty, it will be rolled over to the next year.

To be eligible for bounty, producers must be registered under the scheme. Registration will be effected according to specified criteria under the legislation which will ensure that all registered producers will be able to make a significant contribution to the desired competitive, robust and ecologically sustainable fuel ethanol industry. Under the proposed scheme, all registered producers will be granted a production allocation which will guarantee them an amount of bounty on the condition that they maintain certain production levels and satisfy other specified criteria. The allocation process is intended to provide existing producers with incentives for capital investment whilst also allowing new producers to enter the market.

The government is confident that the measures in the proposed bounty scheme will encourage the establishment of a competitive ethanol transport fuel industry in Australia, developed on an environmentally sustainable basis. The government will also assist in overcoming the technical and administrative barriers to the use of ethanol as a transport fuel with a $3.94 million research and development program over the next two years. That program will develop an ethanol fuel standard, extensively trial the use of ethanol blended fuels in vehicles and develop further improvements in ethanol fuels.
The measures contained in this bill are expected to result in outlays of $6 million in 1994-95, $8 million in 1995-96 and $11 million in 1996-97. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will not be opposing the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Bill 1994. Listening to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) summing up the debate on the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill, it seemed ironic that he spoke about the opportunities that exist with the second chamber starting today for bills like the previous bill to be allowed to be more extensively debated. The reason I found it ironic was that the bill we are debating now and the previous one are under the guillotine. We have an extraordinary situation where the government on the one hand is saying, `Isn't it great that we have a second chamber?' but on the other hand is saying, `We are going to guillotine the legislation through anyway.' I do not think that point should go unnoticed.

PARA.TAB: The opposition will not be opposing this bill. Nonetheless, there are a few things that I would like to say about it. This bounty is part of the government's lead abatement strategy, and we support attempts to try to reduce the amount of lead in our atmosphere. Clearly, this is a major problem which has been well recognised. Obviously these attempts will be supported.

I draw the attention of the House to some of the difficulties that may arise from this bill. By way of background, it is worth noting that the use of ethanol to extend petrol and diesel is not new. It is being done in a number of countries overseas. For example, both the United States and Canada use ethanol blended with petrol and diesel to extend fuel and to help reduce the amount of lead emitted into the atmosphere.

In the United States, where ethanol blends have been used since 1970, over 3.8 billion litres of ethanol is blended with petrol each year in the ratio of 10 per cent ethanol to 90 per cent petrol. In the United States, these fuels are sold throughout the country and over 39 major cities are required by law to use what is known as oxygenated or ethanol blended fuels in certain months of the year when the air quality standards fall below those required by the United States Clean Air Act. This procedure has been well and truly trialled in the United States.

Brazil has the world's largest alcohol fuel program, which is aimed at substituting ethanol for fossil fuels. Brazil adopted a mandated ethanol program as early as 1985. Brazil's alcohol fuel program has been subsidised by its very high petrol prices, its favourable taxation and its direct government subsidies. Brazil has gone very heavily down this path of reducing its reliance on petrol. In Brazil, the ethanol is manufactured from domestically produced sugar cane, resulting in the production of approximately four billion gallons—that is, 4,000 million gallons—per year. It is quite a major industry in Brazil.

Ethanol is a colourless, highly flammable liquid which is generally produced from the fermentation of agricultural crops, including cereal grains, sugar cane, sugar beet, sweet sorghum and casaba. It is fairly obvious that a 10 per cent blend of ethanol and petrol is preferred—that is why the United States has gone that way—because no modifications are required to the standard car engine. This blend increases the octane rating and hence the efficiency of the engines.

It is also important to note that the inclusion of ethanol reduces the emissions and the lead levels in the atmosphere, with a 10 to 30 per cent reduction in carbon monoxide emissions. This is very significant because 90 per cent of the lead in the atmosphere today comes from petrol. Ethanol also has the advantage that it is a renewable energy source. This is another very strong reason for encouraging this development.

Currently in Australia the majority of ethanol that is produced is for use in the chemical industry. It is worth noting that the Manildra Group has recently opened a plant at Nowra in New South Wales with the potential to utilise 100,000 tonnes of wheat in the production of 28 million litres of ethanol for fuel annually. It is also very important to note that there are enough agricultural crop residues in the Macquarie, Gwydir and Namoi valleys to produce 820 million litres of ethanol annually—significantly more than is currently being planned.

It is also very important to note that blended fuels are already being trialled in Mackay, here in Canberra in the buses and in other parts of southern New South Wales. The Manildra Group, together with Caltex, is selling blended fuel, with 95 per cent of motorists stating that the car runs as well as, if not better than, it does on straight leaded fuel.

One of the problems is that currently ethanol is expensive to produce in Australia, mainly due to the low volumes being produced and the lack of existing infrastructure. The industry says it expects that, once the economies of scale are reached, ethanol production could cost as little as 24c per litre, which is very comparable with the cost of producing petrol. Caltex believes its trials have been made economical because the ethanol currently being produced by Manildra has been a by-product. As well, to its credit the New South Wales government has forgone the 5c a litre fuel excise that it is currently levying on petrol. Obviously the whole thrust of this bill, which is a move for a bounty, is to encourage the production and blending of ethanol for car fuel.

The basis of this bill is to give additional support for what is an infant industry and at the same time offer a very useful and significant benefit for the environment. It puts in place, quite simply, a bounty for producers of ethanol. As has already been stated, this bounty is to operate over the next three years, beginning on 1 July this year. The rate of payment will be 18c a litre for bountiable fuel ethanol and a total payment of $25 million. This is to be spread over three years, as I have said: $6 million in the coming financial year, $8 million in 1995-96 and $11 million in 1996-97. It has also been pointed out that the bill allows for a rollover of this bounty if it is not all utilised in each of the first two years.

It is clear that the bounty is payable only for new, non-existent production in Australia. It is also obvious, then, that those existing producers—that is, mainly the Manildra Group—will receive a bounty only for production that is above the levels they currently have. Those existing levels are assessed by averaging the last two years, 1992 and 1993, to set a base.
