It is also stated in the bill that there is a maximum per producer, but this maximum can in fact be increased if the minister accepts an application to do so. The bill ensures that proper commercial records are kept. An annual return will have to be tabled in the parliament each year on the amount of bounty paid.

There is some irony, not only regarding the guillotine but also in the fact that at the same time this bounty is being offered for the production of ethanol—the coalition will not be opposing this—the excise the government is charging motorists is to rise by 13 per cent this year. That is on top of an 18 per cent increase last year. So, while there is encouragement to produce ethanol, at the same time the government is not running short of money when it comes to taxing fuels. The government is increasing taxes on fuel at the same time as it is introducing this bounty.

I will briefly mention a couple of concerns the opposition has. One is the fact that the bounty is to be paid over three years. The Manildra Group has made it clear that it believes this is too short a period. It believes that the bounty should be paid over five years because by the third year the industry will only just be starting to come into proper production because of the long lag times associated with building the new infrastructure for the production of ethanol. That is the first concern that I raise with the government in this debate. The second concern is that the bill, because of the way it has been framed, appears to handicap the existing large-scale producer of ethanol. I think it is important that those points be raised now and put on the record.

Nonetheless, this bill is part of the government's lead abatement strategy and therefore is to be encouraged. The total funding for the lead abatement strategy will be $36 million over three years. Obviously, part of that strategy includes the $25 million for the bounty on production of ethanol fuels. On top of this there will be the national lead education program. There will be funding for research and development of ethanol based fuels, and there will be a survey to determine lead levels in the community.

Part of this strategy includes development of a national environment standard for petrol. Clearly this is to be commended, but I hope that at the same time the government will take into account the fact that overseas countries such as Brazil, the United States and Canada have extensive experience in ethanol additives to fuels and I would hope that we look very closely at some of that experience and some of the research that has been done so that we do not have to duplicate it here. I again say that the coalition does not oppose this bill, and we look forward to seeing the progress of the development of ethanol in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great sense of excitement that I support the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Bill 1994. This is the sort of legislation through which everyone is a winner, and I certainly congratulate the opposition for its support of this legislation. The $25 million that will be paid out in the bounty for the production of fuel ethanol should be seen as an incentive, as seed capital that will give new technology the opportunity to develop a highly desirable industry on a scale that we have not previously had.

PARA.TAB: I am excited because this bill represents one of the more progressive steps taken by the government since I became a member of parliament. This bill shows the government's genuine commitment to establishing a sustainable fuel system and at the same time protecting our environment by the reduction of lead levels and greenhouse gas emissions.

I would like to spend just a little time explaining the advantages of an ethanol fuel industry for Australia. Ethanol is a renewable fuel that can be used as a replacement for liquid hydrocarbon fossil fuels. It is currently used as an extender and as a total replacement for such fuels and has achieved some enormously beneficial results. When mixed with petrol, it enhances the octane rating. Seven per cent ethanol will boost performance by three RON points.

Ethanol has the potential to reduce the lead in petrol. This is a stated objective of the government. If mixed with diesel in an 85 per cent to 15 per cent mix using an emulsifier, it produces a new fuel called diesohol which dramatically reduces the sooty emissions of diesel burning engines. However, performance of motors is not reduced, and the technical specifications of diesel motors do not have to be modified to enable them to use this fuel. The great advantage of ethanol as a fuel is that it uses biomass or living plant tissue as its source. It uses a renewable resource. This can be any vegetative matter that can be fermented—a natural process—with the ethanol recovered from the resultant ethanol water mix.

Currently ethanol is being produced in Australia by the fermentation of wheaten starch at the Manildra plant at Nowra. APACE Research is completing a feasibility study in my electorate of Paterson to produce ethanol from forest wastes and other woody or fibrous materials known as lignocellulosics. The great thing about this project is that it is capable of using a wide spectrum of source materials. It does not have to use forest wastes; it can be cotton stubble or sugar mill waste bagasse. Wastes such as grain hulls and sawdust can be processed—even wastepaper and other municipal solid wastes.

A report in this week's newspapers indicates that a firm in Tasmania intends to establish a plant adjacent to a potato processing plant where 100 tonnes of peelings a day will be converted into ethanol. Already the bounty is creating windows of opportunity for investment and employment. But the good news keeps coming in. Australia is a world leader in ethanol fuel technology. APACE Research holds the world patent for the chemical emulsifier that allows the blending of ethanol with diesel. This is a real breakthrough technology on a world standard.

Residents of Canberra would be aware that ACTION buses were used to trial diesohol only last year. It was a trial that was very successful and ACTION buses are keen to continue the use of this fuel. A similar trial is ongoing with the State Transit Authority in Sydney. Buses taking tours to the Olympic Games site at Homebush are using diesohol. On World Environment Day, a bus using diesohol was a feature of the New South Wales government display. How fantastic it would be in the year 2000 if we had developed the ethanol industry, with this fuel infiltrating into all forms of transport, so that visitors to the Sydney Olympics could be transported with a fuel developed by Australian technology.

Currently the Swedish government is trialing diesohol in Stockholm. In March this year garbage trucks and street sweepers started using diesohol because of its environmentally friendly properties. Everywhere in the world where diesohol is trialled an Australian company is involved.

The legislation before the House today is exciting and innovative. It gives us the opportunity to move into a completely new dimension of fuel technology. Under the bounty scheme that will operate for the next three years, we will see new uses for ethanol. Because of this subsidy, industry will automatically experiment with this new generation fuel. Research and development will be carried out into the ethanol-petrol and ethanol-diesel blends on a grand and practical scale. The $25 million will be paying for results.

Over the next three years internal combustion engines in Australia will consume some 140 million litres of subsidised ethanol. Data will be collected on the performance of the fuels used and, at the end of the period, we will have collected a large amount of valuable information. At the same time, we will see ethanol producers expanding—whether it be from wheaten starch, potato peelings, or forest waste. But we will see new technology come on line. I am also confident that the new technology being developed for the production of ethanol, particularly from ligno cellulosics, will be able to produce ethanol at a price that will be competitive with fossil fuels. I have spoken about Australia as a world leader in ethanol fuel technology and I have touched briefly on the environmental advantages of this fuel. Let us compare ethanol with traditional fossil fuels.

As most school children are aware today, fossil fuels are storehouses of carbon that has been held either as solid carbon or liquid or gaseous hydrocarbon for millions of years by geological processes. When they are burnt, however, carbon dioxide is released into the atmosphere. In this way the world has been steadily increasing the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere since the Industrial Revolution, with alarming consequences of climatic change and global warming. The volume of carbon dioxide has increased in our atmosphere by 25 per cent in the last 200 years and it is currently increasing at about 0.5 per cent per annum.

Scientifically speaking, nature can respond. Carbon dioxide can be taken out of the atmosphere by an increased rate of plant growth. The process of photosynthesis will lock the carbon dioxide away again as cellulose or starch. Records show that the response cannot keep pace with the increased production of carbon dioxide by human activity. The continuing rapid destruction of forests in the world is also not helping the situation. The ocean is also a major absorber of carbon dioxide but does not appear to have the capacity to absorb the greater quantities that we are producing. That is why the conversion to ethanol fuels is vital.

Biomass, the source of ethanol, is renewable. It can be converted to ethanol and lignin with no net release of carbon dioxide. The development of such a biomass fuels industry also has important positive implications for the agricultural economy, for the treatment of land degradation and for reafforestation programs. Currently in Australia sufficient waste biomass is available for the immediate production of ethanol. Many food and fibre production industries have a waste stream, be it peelings, fibrous tissue or leaf matter. It is something to be disposed of—often at high cost. By treating such material as a potential source of ethanol, it is possible for it to become an asset with associated economic and environmental advantages.

The payment of bounty on the production of ethanol will encourage the development of such a rethinking. The government has structured the bounty scheme so that existing producers are provided with incentive for capital investment and new producers will be able to enter the market. Australia is well positioned to draw from the extensive experience of ethanol fuel industries in the United States, Sweden and Brazil.

I cannot emphasise enough the benefits to Australia of the use of a fuel based on a renewable resource. In Australia the use of diesel fuel for road transport is expected to rise. Australia is incapable of producing sufficient diesel from its own crude oil sources to satisfy its demand. Immediately diesohol replaces pure diesel as a fuel we as a nation reap enormous savings in foreign expenditure, for no loss in performance and at the same time we gain significant environmental advantages. The 15 per cent ethanol component in diesohol immediately reduces the demand on diesel by the same amount.

As I said when I began to speak, this bill initiates an exciting process. Ethanol technology gives our nation the opportunity to develop a sustainable fuel industry of our own; to move towards self-sufficiency in fuel; to maintain our world leadership in this technology; to make a global contribution to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions; to reduce our dependence on lead additives in petrol; and to create jobs in an industry that lends itself to decentralisation. I will expand on that point, because this is an industry that can locate on the forest industry, the sugarcane industry, the vegetable growing industry and the cotton industry. The waste stream from any industry that processes vegetative matter can be used. Such industries are spread all over the country, depending on geography and agricultural practices. That is where such an ethanol plant would obviously be favoured to be located.

I have never believed that something is too good to be true. But it would appear that ethanol certainly comes close to being such a substance. I am extremely pleased to be supporting this bill, which helps us take a giant leap forward. I congratulate Australian scientists such as Dr Russell Reeves from APACE Research, who has spent many years in painstaking research to perfect the diesohol technology. He had the faith in his research. It is now time for us to have faith in him and the many other Australian researchers who are helping us to lead the world in developing a competitive, robust and ecologically sustainable fuel ethanol industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to address the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Bill, I must preface my remarks with an examination of the government's failure to properly address the greenhouse issue, as this is particularly relevant in the context of the legislation before the House. It is common knowledge that the government was rolled at the recent Basel conference on hazardous wastes. The government's delegation went into that conference with a carefully prepared position which had been discussed and agreed to by all members of the delegation. When it came out of the conference, the government had agreed to a completely different outcome.

PARA.TAB: I do not dispute that there will be times when Australia will fail to persuade other nations of its position on a sensitive international environmental issue. What is of concern here is that the government did not maintain its position through the negotiations and, eventually, actively agreed to a position at odds with its original views. In the complex world of international diplomacy, I accept that there will be times when it is desirable to give ground on one issue in order to preserve a reputation or gain ground on another issue.

It is not my intention to delve deeply into this issue or pass judgment on the government's performance in Basel at length today. But there are real implications and lessons to be learnt for the upcoming greenhouse conference in Berlin in March next year. This will be the first crucial conference of the parties to the United Nations framework convention on climate change.

The convention recently came into force following ratification by the 50th member. The international community will be watching with intense interest as the Berlin meeting considers progress on the greenhouse issue and discusses the setting of targets for greenhouse gas reductions by the parties at the conference. The debacle at Basel has heightened concern throughout Australian industry that the government will give way in Berlin and will agree to an outcome seriously damaging Australia's trade competitiveness.

Australia, as a resource rich nation, has attracted and developed industry based around fossil fuels. Agreement to a worldwide cut in greenhouse emissions would undoubtedly fall harder on Australian industry than the industry of almost any other country. Worse still, Australia will be under severe pressure at the Berlin conference because of its record of failure on domestic greenhouse measures.

The federal government has a dismal record of reducing greenhouse emissions. The failure of the domestic greenhouse measures has been a running sore for the government for some time, with a series of investigations demonstrating that insufficient resources have been applied. No leadership is being provided by the federal government for industry to fall in behind with regard to energy consumption reduction. It is these no-regrets measures which have been identified as having a net benefit in terms of cost savings, efficiency improvements and greenhouse reductions that will be of interest to the Berlin conference.

The conference parties will be critically examining Australia's in-house greenhouse outcomes to confirm Australia's credibility on environmental issues. Sadly, the government's failure to implement an adequate domestic greenhouse program will put Australia on the back foot right from the start of the Berlin conference. It must not then try to appease the other countries, as it appeared to do in Basel, and agree to greenhouse reduction targets which hit Australia hardest.

The recent admission by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) that cabinet is yet to consider Australia's approach to the Berlin greenhouse conference is jeopardising the opportunity to develop alliances with other countries with similar views. It is up to the government to take a lead in this area. To date, all we have are bland generalised assurances from the Minister for Foreign Affairs that the matter is in hand and that cabinet will finally reach a position in plenty of time. That is simply not good enough, because time is slipping away.

As I say, at the moment we are squandering an opportunity in the lead-up to the Berlin conference to build alliances with countries that share Australia's views about the no doubt extremist positions of a lot of participants at that conference. The government, in handling the international aspects of greenhouse policy, is showing the same ineptitude—in fact, outright negligence—that it has shown with regard to domestic policy on greenhouse gas emissions.

The government must involve effective domestic greenhouse programs, encouraging the no-regrets measures. As I say, they satisfy all parties because they result in savings of cost to industries by the introduction of, for example, the best type of plant and machinery, be it motors or drives, as well as at the same time benefiting the environment by reducing greenhouse emissions. So the government must encourage these no-regrets measures whilst at the same time internationally ensuring that Australia's trade competitiveness is not affected by international agreements.

In the context of the government's appalling performance in implementing domestic greenhouse reduction measures, there is some merit in the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Bill. The bill before the House provides for the payment of a bounty on the Australian production of certain types of fuel ethanol. The rate of payment of the bounty will be 18c per litre. This will be payable on defined new production of fuel ethanol, where it is produced in Australia from biomass feed stocks sourced from plants grown in Australia and where production exceeds 350,000 litres per annum.

An amount of $25 million has been allocated to the bounty scheme with an expected payment of $6 million in the 1994-95 financial year, $8 million in 1995-96 and $11 million in the 1996-97 financial year. It is important to note that the scheme will only run for three years commencing on 1 July 1994.

Encouragement in the use of ethanol for fuel will be one way of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. In view of the government's terrible record with other measures, this benefit may well outweigh the negative aspects of this bill. Let no-one be under any misapprehension: very important implications for sound and consistent economic management are contained in this bill. So while the coalition will not oppose the bill, a number of aspects merit serious consideration and provide some concern as to government actions in the future.

It is well known, and not disputed by government members, that this bill arose from the government's negotiations with the Democrats and the Greens over the 1993 budget. Let me be perfectly candid: the coalition would not have initiated this proposal. I am quite certain that the government would not have put up this bill either, except for its desperate need to get the 1993 budget through the Senate. It was part of the horse-trading that went on as the government saw its 1993 budget collapsing around its ears because of a hostile Senate. However, having said that, the coalition is willing to give this scheme a trial, partly in the hope that it can bolster the government's dismal record on domestic greenhouse measures. Interestingly, the second reading speech stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is confident that the measures in the proposed bounty scheme will encourage the establishment of a competitive ethanol transport fuel industry in Australia developed on an environmentally sustainable basis.

The theory behind this is that the ethanol industry is viable by itself but just needs a kick-start to get it going. Unfortunately, experience in the United States and Brazil has shown that ethanol is not cost competitive with petrol where crops are grown specifically for ethanol. It is clear that the same situation, the same economies and the same practicalities would apply in Australia.

PARA.TAB: To state the obvious, petrol is derived from crude oil. So the price of petrol is fundamentally dependent on the cost of oil, bearing in mind that in Australia over half of the price of petrol or diesel is tax. Crude oil would have to be in the region of $US50 per barrel for ethanol to be cost competitive. Over the last several decades, the long-term price of oil has stayed significantly below this figure, even taking into account the various oil shocks and the Gulf War of 1990. These thankfully rare events only temporarily pushed the price of oil sky-high. Otherwise, the price of crude oil has never got within striking distance of $US50 per barrel.

I am anxious to make the point that I do not discount technological innovations which may significantly reduce the cost of ethanol production in the future. It is certainly encouraging that the United States is looking at halving the cost of production of ethanol in the medium term. However, inescapably, with the price of crude oil unexpectedly low and likely to stay under $US20 per barrel for the foreseeable future, there is no reason to expect that ethanol can be produced cheaply enough to be cost competitive with petrol. This is not the only problem.

In 1993, demand for petrol in Australia reached 17,000 megalitres. Due to the different chemical properties of ethanol, some 26,000 megalitres of ethanol would be required to match the demand for petrol. Australia simply does not have enough suitable agricultural land available to produce anything like this quantity of ethanol. Estimates of the land available indicate that some 6,000 megalitres of ethanol could be produced annually, or about a quarter of the existing requirement to completely replace petrol. We can, therefore, rule out ethanol as a complete petrol replacement on cost and availability

SPEECH.PARA: grounds. To be fair, I do not know that anybody makes an argument that ethanol could ever completely replace petrol in Australia—or, for that matter, in any other country.

PARA.TAB: Given that we can rule out the total replacement of petrol with ethanol in the foreseeable—and long-term—future, it is worth considering how best to use the ethanol that Australia already produces. Vehicles with engines dedicated to ethanol are not currently commercially available. As such vehicles could only sensibly be used in regions where ethanol is produced, there is little or no incentive for commercial development of these vehicles.

As many members of the House would know, however, it is possible to blend ethanol with petrol without major engine modifications being required or performance and maintenance requirements being significantly altered. Petrol with up to 10 per cent ethanol by volume does not require extensive modifications to be made to a vehicle. This raises the considerable, but not overwhelming, difficulties of blending petrol and ethanol. While a number of these issues are highly technical, I shall indicate a few of the less involved issues.

Blending outside the refinery is not simple, as there are a number of variables, including the purity of the ethanol, which affect the quality of the blended product. Petrol refiners and ethanol producers are rightly proud of their product and seek to maintain the reputation and quality of their products through strict quality control. However, it could be difficult to maintain reliability of the product where blending occurs outside of the refinery. On the other hand, blending within the refinery is also subject to complications.

Most important, refineries would need to be reconfigurated to accept ethanol into their production processes. Once this had occurred, the refineries would not be able to accept variations in the ethanol content without further time consuming and expensive reconfigurations. They would then be susceptible to shortages in the ethanol provided for blending. Additionally, there could be complications involving spillage, handling and storage. None of these difficulties are insurmountable, but they indicate that blending is not a straightforward process and would involve some cost penalty over petrol.

Any extension of the bounty beyond the three-year period will need to be very carefully considered. There can be no advantage to anyone in the industry of replicating the experience in Brazil, where massive subsidies became necessary when the oil price dropped to its present level in 1990. In the United States a significant subsidy is provided at state and federal levels. In Australia, ethanol is already free of the 31c per litre excise burdening petrol and diesel consumers. A trial under way by Caltex has also been assisted by the New South Wales government forgoing the five per cent franchise tax usually levied.

The government must be very careful not to create an industry that needs large subsidies to exist but does not provide an appropriate environmental benefit. Having said that, there is a niche market for the use of ethanol as a fuel in Australia. This market is supply driven at the moment because ethanol can be produced at a reduced cost from other industrial processes. For instance, ethanol is produced from sugarcane in Queensland and as a by-product of the production of wheat starch and gluten by the Manildra Group at Nowra in New South Wales. This company is likely to receive most of the bounty payment over the next three years.

Manildra's experience with ethanol plants dates from the acquisition of a plant in Iowa in the United States in 1988. In 1991 Manildra began recovering the waste from the operation of its wheat starch plant at Nowra to produce ethanol. In this way, what otherwise would be considered waste is transformed into a worthwhile by-product. Importantly, the cost of the process is significantly lower than if a special crop were grown only to be used to make ethanol. Naturally, such production is to be encouraged, as there is a clear efficiency gain from value adding to the entirety of an industrial feed stock and, as well, eliminating waste.

At the same time, there has been a tremendously exciting development in this area with the use of Australian technology to combine ethanol and diesel. Unlike petrol and ethanol, diesel and ethanol will not mix by themselves. They need the addition of an appropriate emulsifier. Such a mixture, containing 15 per cent ethanol, has proved very successful in the limited trials undertaken so far. It is developments such as this which point the way to an expanded use of ethanol in the future. In that regard, I am pleased that another strand of the lead abatement strategy will see increased funding for research into the use of ethanol as a fuel.

If the proposed bounty does help this industry to become viable, then that will be of considerable benefit to Australia. However, the government must be mindful not to extend this bounty beyond its three-year time frame and not to enter into any uneconomic subsidies for an industry which is not providing sufficient environmental return.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Bill 1994. I am pleased that the opposition has decided that it will also support the bill. I think it is important. As the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) indicated in his final remarks in the House this morning, it is important that policies that promote the use of alternative sources of fuel for fuel production are followed, not just by the government but by the whole of Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is true that the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Bill will be implemented for only three years. It will provide the payment of a bounty to producers of new fuel ethanol. For this reason, the whole process is to be commended. I was surprised that the honourable member for Gippsland was so forthright in his demand for the government not to extend the payment of a bounty at some future stage, even if the industry should require a little more propping up. It is true to say that the industry requires some encouragement, and that is what this bill is all about. Rather than putting all our eggs in the one basket—to use the old cliche—the country is moving away from relying totally on fossil fuel as our main source of energy.

I refer to the development of this industry in Australia. It is true that our present supply stock will not support an industry which would, to a large extent, substitute for fossil fuel. However, it is true that in certain areas sources of biomass feed stock can be made available to produce substantial amounts of fuel ethanol. While on a national basis this might not be seen as a significant amount of the total energy consumption in Australia, it does mean that we have industrial knowledge and are capable of expanding, when necessary, this industry.

During World War II, during the oil crisis and even when there have simply been low sugar prices, there have been calls for the fuel ethanol industry to get going. But it does take things such as an oil shock for us to look a little further afield than the ready availability of the fossil fuels that we use as a source of fuel today, particularly for our transportation industry.

This bill is certainly putting in place a springboard for this industry. Hopefully, in three years we will see an industry of sufficient size which will have the momentum to continue to grow. In those three years, we can gather a greater amount of knowledge about this particular industry. The industry will have its own head of steam and will be able to grow from there.

As members of the government, the honourable member for Gippsland and no doubt other speakers recognise, we are not about trying to produce an industry that is the same size as that developed in Brazil, and I have already mentioned the reasons for that. Growth which is achieved through the provision of a vast number of subsidies to industry has its own inefficiencies. As was indicated by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Gippsland, when the price of oil per barrel decreases, we run into problems. That particular subsidy has to be increased in order for the industry to compete with other competitors. If we can get industry to the point where it can stand on its own two feet, compete and be an overall part of our sources of energy and fuel, then we will have a viable industry. We hope to achieve this in the three years that the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Bill will provide the payment of a bounty to the manufacturers of new fuel alcohol.

As a representative of a sugar growing area, I am certainly pleased to support the bill proposed by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook). Whilst a number of sources other than sugarcane could be used for the production of ethanol, I intend to concentrate on the production from this crop as it is of direct interest to my electorate.

Ethanol has been talked about for many years as an alternative source of energy, especially as a replacement for diesel and petrol. Ethanol has been used on and off in Australia for most of this century as a source of fuel—not as a source of beverage. World War II, the oil crisis and low sugar prices, as I mentioned, have at separate times led to fresh calls for the expansion of this industry. However, because of the economics involved and the relatively high costs in comparison to fuels produced from oil, extensive use of ethanol has never been achieved. Current estimates put the cost of producing a barrel of ethanol at double that of producing a barrel of oil. As I said before, it does not take much of on oil shock for the price of oil to skyrocket. Conversely, in the case of world peace, particularly in the Middle East, it does not take much for the price of oil to come down.

With our nation's growing realisation that the environment has to be looked after if we are not to suffer a major catastrophe, there has to be a renewed interest in alternative clean fuels, which is what we refer to this one as. With its potential to limit dangerous emissions from exhaust systems, as well as being a renewable energy source, ethanol offers just such a choice. This bill dovetails well into the federal government's lead abatement strategy. It received some criticism from the opposition speaker preceding me, the honourable member for Gippsland, but I am delighted that the bill has come before the House. The allocations were foreseen in the previous budget of 1992-93. I was delighted to be part of a group assembled by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) to look at ways to reduce lead in petrol through the lead abatement strategy. There were very good reasons for that, particularly the health of children and the ongoing impacts of higher blood lead levels nationally.

I return to the sugar growing industry in my electorate. In my area of northern New South Wales, several studies have already been undertaken into the production of ethanol for fuel purposes. In a proposal investigated in one of the studies, the Condong Sugar Mill looked at setting up a two-megalitre Biostil to supply the needs of the mill's vehicles as well as farmers who are shareholders in that company. The Biostil process is currently used by CSR at the power alcohol plant at the Plane Creek Mill near Sarina in Queensland. Due to problems in obtaining the necessary equipment, the venture was unfortunately never undertaken. I also understand that, due to the present costs involved in the technology, the amount of biomass available in my area would probably preclude the building of a particular plant. Let us hope that, with the gathering of information and scientific knowledge on this process over the next three years, the costs of production will come down so that the amount of throughput available from the Northern Rivers area in New South Wales would permit the mill to move into this alcohol production.

As I mentioned, despite the promise shown in these studies, large-scale production of ethanol in northern New South Wales would at this stage be hindered by that lack of molasses. Molasses is a by-product of sugar production which is utilised for ethanol production. The Sarina plant, which I mentioned, is in a better position to take up the Commonwealth's offer, as it has a large molasses pool to draw from, with a number of mills in the Mackay area as well as the potential to transport large amounts from Proserpine and the lower Burdekin. I am reliably informed that it is planning on producing about five million litres of power alcohol so as to participate in the scheme. The plant currently exports a major component of its product overseas and uses the rest for domestic industrial uses, such as methylated spirits and ink. I am sure that honourable members will be aware that Bundaberg utilises alcohol from molasses in the production of that fine drop known as Bundaberg Rum.

Some earlier environmental problems which have been experienced as a result of the production of ethanol have, to a certain degree, been overcome. Much of the effluent can now be pumped back onto sugarcane fields and other crop fields as a fertiliser. Bagasse, which is the husk of the sugarcane left over after the juice is extracted, is a very valuable fuel which the mills utilise in their boiler rooms to generate electricity and to power machinery. I believe that some sugar mills are currently having discussions with the Queensland government over the sale of that excess electricity produced by sugar mills when they burn the bagasse.

I now turn my attention to the economics involved in producing alcohol. As I noted earlier, it is estimated that the cost of producing a barrel of ethanol is almost double the cost of producing a barrel of fuel from oil. Technological demand has aided in lowering the costs of ethanol production.

I am sure honourable members who have experimented in brewing their own beer would be familiar with the old process of ethanol production where basically molasses, yeast and water are added and fermentation allowed to take place, thus producing alcohol. Whilst not having the technical expertise of some in the brewing game, I am reliably informed that this process is somewhat cumbersome. The Biostil process, which I referred to earlier, utilises vacuums and other mechanisms to increase the yields whilst saving time, thus cutting costs in the production process.

The principal elements of the bounty scheme are to operate from 1 July 1994 until 30 June 1997, a total of three years. It will involve a total of some $25 million, with annual caps in the three years of $6 million, $8 million and $11 million consecutively. The bounty itself is to be paid on a new production basis in Australia of ethanol from biomass feedstocks sourced from plants grown in Australia.

I realise that production does not rely just on feed stock from the sugarcane industry and that, as has been mentioned by previous speakers, some of those feedstocks will include the grain industry. We are all probably aware of the plant that has been started up at Nowra by Manildra Feeds which relies on gluten and starch. That plant is in a fine position to capitalise on this bounty. We will no doubt see that plant obtain a large amount of the bounty. I wish it well. I am not making any allegations, but I hope that the technology and the information that the Manildra plant gains are made available at not too high a cost to new players in the industry, for the reasons that I have mentioned. The sugar industry in my area, despite the very large and considerably beneficial income which it derives from sugar, is not able to participate in something like this. The amount of feed stock available through the molasses pool does not at this stage allow the building of this type of plant.

The bounty is to be paid at 18c per litre of bountiable fuel ethanol. Any unused funds from a bounty year will be carried over to the following year. The bounty is to be payable to the producer of bountiable fuel ethanol provided that the producer at the time of production is a registered producer who has been granted an allocation and the production for which bounty is being claimed is within that allocation. During any particular year of the bounty the payment of bounty is subject to and payable from money appropriated from the parliament for that purpose.

The honourable member for Gippsland surprised me in his almost strong call that we not renew this particular bounty. The honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) obviously also heard the remarks of the honourable member for Gippsland, who indicated that the opposition would be supporting the bill. I was surprised at his grasp of what the greenhouse gas emission issue is all about. It was surprising that the honourable member for Gippsland turned around at the end of his speech and actually called for this to be a one-off bounty. I call on the government to be more strongly involved not just in this type of bounty but also in other areas of energy production.

It is only with good initiatives like this from the government—where it is actually supporting, if you like, sunrise industries to make sure the technology is available and developed in Australia so that we can own the technology and it can be available for other businesses within Australia—that we will have diverse sources of energy available and we will not have to rely solely on the fossil fuel industry as our energy source.

While the honourable member for Gippsland was painting his party in great shades of dark green, I was a little disappointed that he finished his remarks in that way. Nevertheless, I appreciate the fact that the opposition is supporting this bill. Like all members, I certainly hope not so much that this bounty will be extended three years hence but that it does achieve what it is aimed to do—that is, kick off the industry and get it going. That is what it is all about.

We all understand the danger of having an industry such as this start off with a bounty. There is the danger that it will become dependent upon government subsidies. The bounty is paid on a production basis. In a sense, the bounty does not restrict production. While the measure can be lightly criticised, it does not mean that the industry will be wholly dependent upon the bounty.

Any industry, obviously, needs some government assistance. The honourable member for Gippsland and members of the National Party would, no doubt, like to see the government involved in putting money into industries in country areas. This certainly has a benefit for country and regional Australia. We are all aware of its dependency on fossil fuels, and anything that can go towards finding an alternative to fossil fuel, which the ethanol industry if it is developed will be able to partly replace, is a good thing. It also means that industries in regional Australia can have a further source of income. Essentially, molasses is a waste product. In some places, and particularly in my area, it goes into producing stockfeed, which is an excellent source of energy for stock. In other areas—I have mentioned North Queensland—the molasses waste by-product actually goes into producing industrial products such as ink and methylated spirits.

With a better industry on the ground in regional Australia—Nowra and mid-Queensland will probably be the two areas that will benefit straightaway—country areas will be much more economically independent and the industry will give them another source of income. I think Australia is particularly well suited not so much to see a big industry grow up but to have a section of industry which can operate and utilise what essentially have been waste products and by-products and cash in on those.

This bill will enable ethanol producers, once again, to start producing ethanol for fuel purposes. While the immediate potential for wholesale production and sale of power alcohol is not that great, I am sure that this bill will be interesting to those companies with the capability of supplying fuel ethanol to the marketplace. Successful penetration of alcohol into the market will lead to less petrol and diesel usage and a cleaner environment, which can only be beneficial to us and to our children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak on the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Bill. Being an environmentalist many years ago, I am extremely pleased that our government has taken this step. In the 1993-94 budget, the Commonwealth committed funds to establish a lead abatement strategy. Part of the strategy included the provision of a $25 million bounty to support the production of ethanol for use as a transport fuel, and $3.94 million to support research and development of ethanol-blended fuels.

PARA.TAB: We have heard quite a bit this morning about how various parts of Australia are starting to produce ethanol. Ethanol has been used in New South Wales for a couple of years now and it is starting to take off. I will give a little history about ethanol and then discuss how I believe it can enhance the lifestyle of all Australians.

Ethanol has been used for fuel in the past in Australia. During World War II, sugarcane was used to produce ethanol as a petroleum substitute. This happened quite extensively. The interest in the fuel at the moment is derived from a range of environmental import replacement and waste product utilisation motives. The words `waste product utilisation motives' are very important. Not enough focus has been given to this part of the ethanol debate.

I do not know what is done with sugarcane waste. I imagine it is just put on the ground and burnt. Wheat stubble is usually burnt. I can recall it being burnt in South Australia and New South Wales. However, farming practices are changing, and I think wheat stubble is now being ploughed back into the ground. Just recently, we have been informed that Tasmania has huge volumes of potato peelings and is looking to use them to produce ethanol. I can recall alcohol from potato peelings being drunk at various establishments in Victoria and New South Wales. I have never drunk it but I know people who have—when they have been desperate.

Ethanol is usually considered as an adjunct or extender to be added to petroleum or diesel fuel rather than a complete fuel source. When ethanol is added, it is usually added at a rate of around 10 per cent, and no carburettor or exhaust modifications are required. Thus, the fuel can be readily slotted into existing fuel supplies. I believe that ethanol was added at a rate of about 10 per cent in New South Wales. However, there was a bit of a problem with Ford Falcons. It was found that, if ethanol were added at a rate of 10 per cent, it would affect the fuel gauges. That level has now been dropped to about 7 1/2 per cent and it is working quite well.

Ethanol is replacing fuel—a lot of it is imported, so import replacement is important—and it is using up waste products. Ethanol is also an octane enhancer. The addition of around 10 per cent ethanol to fuel results in an approximate octane increase of three RONs. We have all heard of lead being phased out in petrol, but ethanol can also be used as an alternative to benzene. Benzene is becoming a very great issue. I think everyone knows that it is carcinogenic and causes all sorts of problems. I think that, as more focus is put on petrol companies around the world, benzene will be phased out. There is a market here for ethanol which, at the moment, is being filled by a product which is very bad for our health.

An environmental reason for using ethanol is that petroleum products are fossil fuels which have accumulated naturally over millions of years, and this bank of fossil fuels is decreasing very rapidly. No-one knows the current amount of oil reserves but they are finite—they are not making any more oil as far as I am aware; it is all in the ground now—that is, what reserves there are will no doubt run out. However, ethanol can be replenished all the time. That is an excellent reason for us to look at it, include it as an additive, do more research on it and make more use of it.

The consequences of releasing carbon dioxide into the atmosphere are well known. The greenhouse effects have been mentioned. The levels of carbon dioxide have increased from around 280 parts per million in 1750 to 350 parts per million in 1994. Some honourable members might wonder how we know what the level of the greenhouse effect was in 1750. This has been determined by drilling ice cores in Antarctica. The atmosphere has been trapped in little air bubbles in those ice cores and, when analysed, have given that result.

Ethanol is derived from sustainably grown biomass and, theoretically, produces no net release of carbon dioxide. This is another good reason for using it. Assuming there is a renewable biomass, ethanol has the potential to reduce net carbon dioxide emissions by 100 per cent, thus impacting upon the emissions of greenhouse gases. The implementation of the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Bill will go a long way in arguing that Australia has gone a step towards meeting its commitments to the Earth Summit in Rio.

Ethanol is used in diesel fuel, and other advantages include a reduction in carbon monoxide emissions by about 40 per cent, a reduction in visible smoke and particulates by about 50 per cent, and a reduction in the oxides of nitrogens. If we follow a diesel truck or a bus, we can see black smoke coming out of it. If ethanol were used, it would reduce the smoke by around 50 per cent.

Traditionally, ethanol has been produced by using sugarcane, such as in Brazil at the moment or in Australia during World War II. This method of production utilises a valuable resource which may be better applied elsewhere for other products. New technology being developed in Australia produces ethanol from lignin and lignocellulosic biomass—that is, forest waste—without producing another waste stream. This new technology is being developed by APACE in the Hunter Valley—this has been mentioned before—and a planned pilot ethanol plant at Raymond Terrace plant near Newcastle is currently undergoing a feasibility study at a cost of about $50,000. Pilot scale work on this type of technology has also been carried out in the United States and in Japan.

Acids are used to break down the fibres to produce sugars which are subsequently fermented in the same manner as conventional feedstocks. The biomass means that anything from rice husks, cotton stubble and ginning trash, woody weeds, forestry wastes and thinnings can all be processed into ethanol. The cost and supply limitations of conventional ethanol production from sugarcane are overcome by utilising this waste product.

Brazil has been using sugarcane as the base for ethanol production for quite some time now. About six months ago there was a big debate going on in Brazil about whether the subsidy should be stopped. An article which appeared in the New Scientist in relation to ethanol states:

SPEECH.PARA: The world's biggest experiment in alternative fuel, Proalcohol was set up in 1975 as a response to the oil crisis of the 1970s, and now provides ethanol from sugar cane to power around one-third of Brazil's 12 million cars. It produces fewer pollutants than petrol and does not contribute to the greenhouse effect.

PARA.TAB: The project's problem is not basic costs or space. Making ethanol from sugar cane has become about 40 per cent cheaper since the program got under way in 1979, and sugar producers say there is potential to reduce them further. But world oil prices have fallen so far as to make ethanol too expensive without substantial government subsidies.

SPEECH.PARA: This problem will impact on ethanol production here in Australia. One of my concerns on this bill is that we have got the oil companies involved. For many years now in speeches I have made in this House I have not been an advocate of the oil companies. I have had a go at them. I believe there is collusion between the oil companies; they have formed an oil prices cartel. They set the prices and dictate exactly what you and I have to pay. We all know that, and we all know that they dictate to the government. These oil companies have quite immense power.

PARA.TAB: The Premier of Victoria recently visited a small town in south Gippsland. Before he arrived the oil companies told all the oil distributors in that town to drop their prices. Within one or two hours before the Premier's arrival all the prices displayed on the price signs were dropped by about 10c per litre. After the Premier left they put the prices up again. No-one can tell me that BP, Caltex, Ampol and Shell all had this great thought at the same time to drop the prices. A company representative rang up and said, `Drop the prices. The Premier is coming. Let us make it look as though there are lower prices in this town.' That sort of thing goes on and that worries me with this bill.

At the moment, some of the petrol companies in New South Wales are taking ethanol from the bowsers. It is being blended and then sold in special pumps for about the same price as petrol. If the petrol companies decide not to distribute ethanol—a direct competitor with their product—I wonder what will happen. Who is going to stand up against these petrol companies? Who is going to start another distribution supply so that people can go and get ethanol blended fuel? I am worried that these companies might use some of their huge monopoly powers to restrict the sale of ethanol, and we cannot do anything about it.

I am also concerned that this bounty will last for only three years with the provision that, if there is any money left over, the bounty will continue until that money runs out. I would like to see the government review the situation after about two or 2 1/2 years. If it were found to be working, we could extend it further. Let us give some of these monopoly petrol companies a bit of competition. Let us force them to take this blended fuel. Instead of having it only in the smaller markets, let us get it into the Sydney and Melbourne markets. Let us set up ethanol producing plants. In Victoria there is plenty of potato peel waste and plenty of wood fibre that could be converted into ethanol. Let us get it into the major markets so we can make a strong contribution to the reduction of greenhouse gases and pollutants.

Ethanol has been economical only in countries which have had substantial subsidies. That is what the bill we are dealing with at present is about. However, I am quite certain that if waste product utilisation of ethanol were developed further, we should be able to make it work without subsidies. The United States has converted 10 million tonnes of grain into 40 billion litres of ethanol per annum. A huge amount of ethanol is being produced over there. It is equivalent to about 10 per cent of the total US fuel consumption. The benefits derived are enhanced due to the reduced carbon monoxide emissions during cold winters, as ethanol is a fuel oxygenate. The European source is called rape methyl ester and is derived from oilseed grape. Countries in which the fuel is used include Austria, France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the United Kingdom. There are many more countries using this particular fuel, and there are many more people benefiting from it.

As the technology improves, the prices of ethanol will drop, it will be available to more people, and it will be able to better compete with oil. No doubt, oil prices will rise again. There will be another resources shock somewhere along the line. If we have moved into ethanol production in a big way, we will be able to ride out that shock a lot better.

A 10 per cent reduction in the amount of petrol or oil that goes to Tasmania could be a huge saving for that island state. This new idea in Tassie of using potato peels should be encouraged. The government should put more money into making certain that Tasmania has an ethanol production unit. It would be situated near the Edgell-Birds Eye potato processing company at Ulverstone—the Southern Hemisphere's largest potato processor. There must be a huge amount of peel there that could turn into a valuable fuel.

Ethanol is a good fuel. It is a clean fuel, a fuel that does not create problems for our atmosphere. This is an excellent bill. We should have implemented the measures it contains years ago. I am very proud to be able to speak on this bill. I am quite certain that in the Senate, the Australian Democrats and the Greens will be exceptionally pleased about this bill. They have been advocating the measures contained in it for some time. I am disappointed that the opposition has said that if it ever came into power, the bounty would cease after its three-year period of operation.

The farmers of Australia should have access to this type of technology. They should plant crops in the knowledge that the by-product from the waste of those crops can be used, thereby enabling them to get more dollars per acre of ground. This is an important piece of legislation. I am pleased I am a member of the government that has brought the legislation into the House. The Australian public will be able to use ethanol in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Bill, I will take the opportunity of indicating to the House the experience we had as a National Party touring team in Brazil, where we looked very thoroughly at the sugar industry and at ethanol production. The bounty in this bill has a three-year term. The opposition has quite rightly said that, after that three-year period, we would want to see how the bill had been implemented, what money had been spent and what profit had come from it.

PARA.TAB: When we strip away the veneer and all the good things it has been proven that ethanol can do, we have to come back to the basis of the cost of production. I understand that one of the conditions a licensee must fulfil is to prove, after the expiration of the three-year term, that it can sustain the production of ethanol without the 18c bounty. While the licensee has the encouragement of two things, that 18c per litre bounty and also the exemption of 30 to 31c per litre on the fuel excise, of course, ethanol production in Australia can be profitable. What it needs, more than anything else, is a long-term commitment by the government that fuel excise will not be charged on the production of ethanol. That gives the production of ethanol a huge advantage over traditional oil products which are being used at the moment.

This $25 million is being spent because of the pressure brought to bear by the Australian Democrats and the Greens on the passage of the budget 12 months ago. But this does not prove ethanol is viable or that it can work profitably for the amount of money being spent. In fact, in my own industry, the sugar industry, which I know so well, many comments have been made to me such as, `Of course, you'd be very thrilled with this $25 million program.' The fact is I do not believe that the sugar industry will benefit to any great extent, because that industry already has a factory in place producing ethanol for industrial purposes. In the past, about seven or eight years ago, it produced ethanol as an experiment to be mixed with petrol and, I think, called the resultant blend `petranol'. It knows the techniques, technology and conditions under which it can manufacture ethanol, but it also knows the other side of the equation: what is required to change production from sugarcane in Australia to ethanol, as a major product as against sugar. It comes down to dollars and cents.

As I have said, this industry requires an indication of how these people who will be licensees can prove, in the space of three years, that they can successfully produce ethanol without that subsidy. It also has to have the guarantee of the fuel excise. To compare it with the other uses to which these products can be put is a matter of interest to me.

I cannot speak with authority on wheat. But already, I understand, some 100,000 tonnes of wheat has been put aside for the production of ethanol. This is mainly benefiting one company in New South Wales, the Manildra Group, which has just recently opened a plant. There are certain suggestions that the $25 million could quite easily be absorbed just by this one licensee itself. If that is the case, I think it would be a major disadvantage to other interested people. So the application of these funds will be very important as will, at the end of the day, the proof that manufacturing can continue without the bounty and also without the fuel excise.

I have been a great stalwart over many years of the production of ethanol for the very good reasons that people indicate here: it is known to be a clean source of power and is certainly far better for the environment than the oil produced product we have at the moment. It also has great advantages for engines not only because the exhaust emissions are cleaner but also because the engines have a better torque, a better capacity for power. But, as I said, the technology is known. The $25 million has yet to be proven to me to be worth while and well spent, when we think of competing needs in this country and how that amount of money could be better spent in other regards, particularly in cleaning up the environment.

I now have the opportunity to speak about what I referred to earlier: a visit we made to Brazil, where my major interest was in the sugar industry. I will quote a few figures. Brazil is certainly set up to produce ethanol, with major encouragement coming from the government, which sets the quotas for ethanol production in any one year; it also sets the price. Of course, the price which is set determines the price at the bowser. So the subsidy is one from the individual motorist.

In the city we visited, Sao Paulo, the air environment, in Latin American terms, is probably as clean as that in any city in South America. The Brazilian government has refined its assistance to the production of ethanol to a great extent in the manufacture of vehicles. At the moment, all petrol, where it is used, has an enhancer of a 22 per cent ethanol mix. That is the maximum which can be used in coordination. Over that amount there is a problem of water penetration in the petrol, which makes the engine inefficient.

In addition to that, the Brazilian government is also committed to the use of pure ethanol engines, with a major production of motor vehicles and engines in Brazil by the four manufacturers. While we were there, we went to GMH and saw two engines: one with a blend of 22 per cent, and one with a pure ethanol mix. The pure ethanol mix engine is more expensive than the traditional gasoline engine. But, again, the government has seen fit to make sure they are manufactured by giving a subsidy. The additional requirements for pure ethanol increase the price of the vehicle by one or two per cent, which the government meets by way of subsidy.

We came away with the belief that Brazil is so committed to the production of ethanol that we should have no fear of a transfer of its massive cropping to sugar production and, hence, onto the world market. With the type of production Brazil has—eight times the size of Australia's—if Brazil were to put that into the export market, onto the world market, we could say goodbye to the Australian industry; efficient though it is, we could say goodbye to it. So it is of encouragement to us that the Brazilian government is so committed to ethanol production that that event is not likely, although the individual producers of sugar, the sugar mills, with the discipline that is exercised on them, sometimes break ranks. When the price of sugar on the export market is favourable, it would be a simple process to transfer from ethanol production to sugar production. If it ends up as sugar, the ethanol production is lost.

These are some of the figures we were given. A tonne of raw sugarcane produces about eight litres of ethanol. With molasses, it is considerably enhanced to about 25 litres per tonne of cane. That is what CSR is doing at Plain Creek Mill at the moment. But, if we take the cane juice straight from the cane and convert it to ethanol, it would produce about 81 litres of ethanol.

We went onto properties and talked to people in Brazil. The price that they have arranged for ethanol in Brazil allows it to be sold at the equivalent of $US40 a barrel. When compared with oil at $US27 a barrel, it becomes competitive. We can also look at other aspects of the Brazilian industry, where the price per tonne of cane—that is in the field—is about $US12, or $A16 or $A17. In comparison, the Australian ethanol producers would have to pay about $30 or $32 per tonne of cane.

So there is a huge difference in the price that makes it acceptable for the Australian sugar industry to start changing from its normal production of sugar to the production of ethanol. When we look at the size of the Brazilian industry, as I said, we are looking at an industry eight times the size of the Australian industry and two-thirds of its production is converted to the production of ethanol.

In Australia it has been estimated that it would take the total Australian sugar industry to supply a 10 per cent enhancer through ethanol to petrol. Obviously, the Australian sugar industry will not be looking at that, even in spite of the bounty incentive of 18c per litre. I know that the sugar industry is not unsympathetic to the approach of the government to look at the subsidy arrangement as supported by this bill; the sugar industry, the Sugar Research Institute and all relevant bodies in Australia know all about the technology. If it were profitable at this stage, they would be producing ethanol instead of sugar. I believe that the 18c a litre incentive will not encourage somebody to start a product that in three years time will lapse because there is no subsidy.

The honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), who spoke before me, made great play about the fact that we have said as an opposition that we would not encourage the continuation of the subsidy in three years. In actual fact, the government itself is not that enthusiastic about its own legislation. It has not guaranteed anything beyond the three years in any case. I see that as a bit of a mischief in terms of the reason for the legislation. As I mentioned earlier, I believe that the money could have been spent elsewhere. The money could have been spent more profitably on cleaning up the environment than on encouraging people to take out licences, which unfortunately in three years time, unless the price of oil skyrockets to about $60 a barrel, they are going to be left with.

As I said, I can talk about sugarcane, but I cannot talk about what to do with the spare cropping of wheat and what price a bushel of wheat has to be before it is better converted to ethanol. Obviously, some New South Welshmen see that profit at the moment. But the question is: how do we guarantee a regular supply unless we do what they do in Brazil, and that is set down quotas, give guarantees and provide the subsidies that are necessary, not on a one-, two- or three-year basis but on an ongoing basis? As I said, there is no doubt that the commitment by government and industry in Brazil is total. Let us hope that, for the sake of our own sugar industry, it remains that way in Australia.

Quite a few of the conditions that people have to comply with are mentioned within the package. I have already mentioned—and it is my understanding—that there has to be proof that in three years time the particular licensee can continue to produce without the advantage of the subsidy of 18c per litre. The bounty will only be payable to a producer and the bounty will not be payable unless a producer is registered at the time of production and remains so until the claim is made. The bounty will also not be payable where the Comptroller-General of Customs is satisfied the fuel ethanol was or will be exported directly or indirectly to New Zealand. In respect of the other conditions, I believe that if the department is fair dinkum it will make sure that the conditions are adhered to and will not let the money out in some fashion or other that advantages an already existing supplier as against a supplier in other places of the Commonwealth.

It is a great pity that more encouragement was not given to the production of ethanol. We will find in Australia, as has already been mentioned, a great objection by the major companies that provide fuel—motor fuel at the moment—that know the techniques, that have experimented with the blend but are still persevering with and controlling the current pricing of petrol. Until those major companies are encouraged to do something about their production and become involved with the production of ethanol, I believe that at the end of the day the $25 million will be seen to have not been well spent. It was spent only in the interests of getting last year's budget through. I think any government member would acknowledge that.

I thank the House for the opportunity to put on the record what I believe is the production and efficiency of an Australian industry that I feel will not be taking advantage of this because there is no advantage to be taken in comparison to the manner in which it produces sugar. I wish the government well. I will be looking forward with great interest to the outcome of this legislation to make sure that the money is properly applied and well spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and my good friend the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) in contributing to this debate. I will just pick up the last point of the honourable member for Dawson. Whatever the government may have said about last year's budget, the increase in the excise was all about getting extra revenue. I regret that we did not suggest to the Australian people up-front that that was our approach.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, I also think there were some good environmental reasons for doing so. Had we adopted that approach I think we may have had a little less bother and aggravation than what we actually had. I think I am going halfway to agreeing with the honourable member for Dawson. I would certainly like to thank him for informing the House first-hand of his experience in Brazil. The Brazilian approach to what I think it calls gasohol—a blend of petrol and ethanol, which allows them to extend petrol use over there—has always been of great interest to me. It is certainly a very successful operation.

I want to acknowledge the interests of one of my constituents, Mr Peter Van der Ryden. He takes a great interest in the issue of ethanol, as I do. I know that he will be very pleased to see this legislation coming through the House. As has been mentioned by previous speakers, $25 million will be provided over the next three years for a bounty payment at the rate of 18c per litre—$6 million in the first year, $8 million in the second year, $11 million in the third year, and whatever moneys are unexpended in one year will be rolled into the second year. I think it is very important that Australian industry remains in touch with this. I have no doubt that in the future, given our concerns about the environment and the possible volatility of fossil fuels, we will increasingly see other countries, as well as Australia, resorting to ethanol as a way of extending their limited reserves.

I thought the contribution of the honourable member for Dunkley, in particular, highlighting the plight of Tasmania and its dependence on fuel being shipped from the mainland and the potential Tasmania may provide in terms of converting some of its waste products, was very interesting. Ethanol, as the honourable member for Dawson suggested, can be produced from sugarcane, wheat and a whole variety of primary products. I think there is an opportunity for us, particularly given the high point of sale costs in places like Tasmania and also in rural and remote Australia, to be a little more imaginative and think in terms of value adding some of the things that are done locally as a way of containing those relatively high costs and providing value adding to primary producers.

I accept the point that the honourable member for Dawson made that it would be nice to see a longer time on this bounty bill. But, again, like the honourable member for Dunkley, I would like to think that the government, prior to the scheme ending—I am sure that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), would agree with me—would want to review the situation and the success of these measures and also to ascertain whether or not there is a need for their extension.

The honourable member for Dunkley was speculating whether or not at some future date petrol companies, the established oligopolies in Australia, might wish to pick up ethanol or, indeed, whether or not we need to compel them to do so. I have spoken on the issue of distribution a number of times, and I have no reason whatsoever to change my stance—that is, if proponents are happy to force down competition policy in so many areas of our activities in the economy and if we are to realistically address the issue of petrol distribution we need to get the petrol suppliers out of the distribution chain. It should be impossible for the petrol company oligopolies to actually own the retail sites; that is the only way to get proper competition. That used to be the case but, unfortunately, past federal governments allowed petrol companies to buy independent retailers. As a result, they now hold the whip hand.

I totally reject the conclusion of the Industry Commission and of the commissioner of the Prices Surveillance Authority about the reality of competition. If there were one thing that frustrated people in metropolitan electorates, or even regional electorates, it would be the fact that the price of petrol goes up and down for no particular rhyme or reason. In fact, someone suggested that there is a distinct pattern of a decrease in prices at the beginning of the week and an increase in prices at the end of the week. Ordinary people find that rather incomprehensible and suspect that they are being diddled, and I think that there is some truth in that.

One of the reasons there is not a greater take-up of ethanol is the low cost of oil. In fact, the cost of oil has just fallen to about $17 per barrel. It is a significant fall because it was up around $28 or $30 per barrel during the oil crisis. When I happily go back to my electorate I try to convince my good voters of a couple of things. I point out to them that if they compare the cost of petrol—notwithstanding all the government changes, both federal and state—it is still relatively cheap. They do not perceive the cost of Australian petrol as cheap; in fact, they feel it is very expensive. If any honourable members in this House have some clues about how to convince people that Australian petrol is relatively cheap, I would be most grateful if they would pass them on.

Given the tyranny of distance that Australia has, people feel that cheap petrol ipso facto must be a good thing for Australia. I can understand and relate to that argument. However, it is true to say that whilst you have a very cheap commodity and whilst you develop many new uses for it not all of those uses will be most efficient. There is a very strong argument that perhaps the cost of petrol needs to go up in Australia. I am not foolhardy because if I said to the Australian people in an election campaign, `We need to increase petrol by 10c or 20c a litre,' I know exactly what their reaction would be.

The point of all this is to pick up the points that the honourable members for Dawson and Dunkley were making: the low price of petrol makes the introduction of alternative and more sustainable fuels such as ethanol much more difficult. I hope that in the foreseeable future we will see a commitment by the government, even though it requires a commitment beyond these three years, to significant ethanol production in this country.

Australia has quite a number of advantages vis-a-vis world competitors. In all forms of agriculture our relatively pristine environment is seen as a significant advantage, and our use of solar energy is seen as a significant advantage also. Australia can have a significant advantage in energy efficient industries. A very important issue is our dependence, maybe even overdependence, on the motor car, which makes it the best vehicle to use alternative fuel. It also reinforces the other point I would like to make: we cannot get into industries without there being a legitimate role for government policy and, in some instances, government money. I know this goes against the fashion, and I apologise for advancing it. Some may argue $25 million is not a lot of money but I would argue that it is a significant commitment by the government. I would like to see the government undertake a review of the bounty prior to any decision being made to completely phase it out. Even if after the review the government were to say it should be phased out, I would argue that it is worth while having an independent review.

An important issue for Australia is the fossil fuel reserves because they are running low. We have significant shale deposits in Australia, which were at one stage exploited for the production of kerosene. There may be a case for the government to consider not only funding some research but also ensuring that Australia has the technology to exploit its very vast shale reserves.

In summary, I am very solidly behind the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Bill 1994. I regret to say that the low price of petrol, from its highs of $28 or $30 a barrel, makes the introduction of alternative energy sources much more difficult. Be that as it may, all members of the House should be supportive of this initiative. I can only hope that those producers that take advantage of the bounty will be able to demonstrate some breakthroughs in technology such that the cost disincentive that exists with ethanol may in the future be removed. I would like to see a commitment by the government for a review.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I would like to thank the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne), the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell), the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) for their excellent contributions. It is clear that each of those speakers recognises that there will be substantial benefits from the scheme proposed in this legislation. The fact is that studies both in Australia and overseas have demonstrated the adverse health effects that occur at even lower levels of lead exposure than were considered previously to be a cause for concern. This legislation therefore is recognition by the government that it shares these concerns and is committed to a lower and safer lead content in petrol in the short term and an eventual phasing out of lead from petrol completely.

PARA.TAB: This ethanol bounty scheme is designed to complement the lead abatement strategy by supporting the development of potentially more environmentally benign alternative fuels. It will, therefore, contribute to alleviating the health problems attributable to lead emissions. We all know that the aim of the bounty scheme is also to encourage a commercial ethanol transport fuel industry in Australia that will eventually be able to compete on a viable economic basis with established petroleum fuels. We know that this will eventually happen through advances in technology.

The bounty scheme complements other measures such as the petroleum product excise exemption for alternative transport fuels, which was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his statement on the environment of December 1992. Queries have been made, particularly by some of the opposition speakers, as to why there is a bounty on ethanol production. We all know that there are a number of barriers to the widespread use of fuel ethanol, including its cost, the lack of standards in fuel ethanol and its non-compatibility with some vehicle components. Some speakers have addressed those issues.
