When ethanol is produced by conventional technology, production costs are estimated to be around 70c per litre compared to 20c per litre for petrol. The issues of compatibility and lack of standards are being addressed in a fuel ethanol research and development program associated with the bounty scheme. While the costs of current non-renewable petroleum based transportation fuels are low, there are few incentives to seek environmentally friendly alternative fuels. As a consequence, the very valid concerns expressed by speakers during this debate and by other members of the community with respect to health issues may not be adequately addressed in the absence of some form of government assistance. The honourable member for Richmond, in particular, addressed those issues.

Therefore, as ethanol fuel blends are currently being used, the basic vehicle technology and fuel distribution infrastructure make ethanol an attractive alternative to the non-renewable fuel sources currently available. The blending of ethanol with petrol is being trialled, as other speakers have said, by Manildra at Nowra in New South Wales.

In respect of the potential for contribution of ethanol production compared to Australia's overall transportation fuel requirements, it is important to acknowledge that, assuming that all of the bounty funding is allocated, the volumes of domestically produced new ethanol entered for consumption as a transportation fuel should total approximately 33 megalitres in the first year, 44 megalitres in the second year and 61 megalitres in the final year.

In terms of current ethanol production, these new volumes represent increases of between 100 and 300 per cent. That is a significant increase in the volumes of new ethanol produced. New South Wales, as was said by a number of speakers, is by far the largest domestic producer of fuel ethanol, with current production levels of about 17 megalitres per annum, but with the capacity to increase production to 50 megalitres per annum, principally through the Manildra plant.

As a comparison, current annual consumption of leaded and unleaded petrol totals approximately 17,500 megalitres and, therefore, the new ethanol production arising from the bounty scheme can have only a limited impact on current transport fuel consumption patterns. This, in itself, indicates the experimental nature of the ethanol bounty program and a recognition of the large production cost differential between the existing transportation fuels and ethanol. The ethanol bounty scheme can, therefore, be seen as a pragmatic approach by the government to the pursuit of an ecologically sustainable, renewable resource based transportation fuel.

I should mention Manildra's production capabilities and some other aspects in relation to that particular company, as a number of speakers have already alluded to that company. Manildra is the only fuel ethanol producer at the moment which is in receipt of the lion's share of the funds from a $3.94 million research and development federal government program. This in itself will contribute greatly to the establishment of a commercial market for fuel ethanol.

It should also be stated that the Manildra company made a commercial decision to produce fuel ethanol before the bounty was envisaged. Accordingly, there is no way that the company will be handicapped in any way by the introduction of this legislation. As is acknowledged by other speakers and indeed in the legislation, it is a bounty to encourage new production in Australia, including production by existing producers that exceeds their average level of production for the calendar years 1992 and 1993.

The bounty is certainly not a subsidy to existing producers. Although Manildra's production is presently relatively small, as I said earlier in my remarks, Manildra is considering a major expansion to 50 megalitres per year. That is approximately more than 10 times the current production.

Virtually every speaker mentioned what would happen when the bounty ended. The government considers that three years is sufficient time for the industry to show that it can compete with petrol and diesel. The bounty scheme will be evaluated in mid-1996. By that time, producers of fuel ethanol will have received a substantial proportion of the bounty assistance of $25 million that will be made available. By the time this scheme ends on 30 June 1997, those producers which have effectively managed their business and reduced their production costs may well be on track towards being able to compete with established petroleum based transport fuels without the need for government subsidy. Only time will tell. Others may be less viable and may have to make a commercial decision whether or not to stay in the industry.

All applicants for bounty payments must recognise, from the outset, that there is no commitment to bounty subsidies after the three years of the scheme. This government is not going to proceed down the irresponsible path of subsidising uneconomic ethanol production indefinitely. We believe that this legislation provides a realistic trial of this program to enable this technology to advance much further than it has at present.

It is an exciting time for ethanol producers. I know that even in North Queensland Tully Sugar Ltd, for example, has been trialling ethanol production for a long time, and I am confident that that particular mill will look at this legislation to see if it can participate in it. As many speakers have said, it is an historic piece of legislation. I commend it to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Lindsay) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH LEGISLATION (POWERS OF INVESTIGATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 30 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill 1994 gives effect to the undertaking given in the 1993 budget to strengthen the capacity of the Health Insurance Commission to pursue fraudulent claims under Medicare. It represents the second instalment in a series of measures being taken by the government to minimise abuse of Medicare.

PARA.TAB: As was the case in the development of the measures to combat overservicing—that is, the measures that are specified in the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Amendment Act 1994—the amendments outlined in this bill are the product of a close consultative process with the Australian Medical Association. Once again, the AMA has demonstrated an admirable willingness to come to grips with the issues and to offer positive suggestions for resolving current deficiencies.

The new measures in this bill are necessary because the current arrangements for dealing with fraud have proven to be deficient. The Australian National Audit Office, ANAO, found in its Audit Report No. 17 1992-93: Medifraud and excessive servicing: Health Insurance Commission that one of the principal impediments to an effective level of prosecutions was the inadequate investigative powers available to the Health Insurance Commission.

The ANAO expressed concern about the length of time for completion of cases referred to the Australian Federal Police and the Director of Public Prosecutions, and noted that in Victoria the average time taken by the Australian Federal Police after the referral of a case was 224 days and that taken by the Director of Public Prosecutions was 324 days. The ANAO also noted that some prosecutions had failed because of the length of time it had taken to get the cases to court.

While concerned that the Health Insurance Commission was dependent on the priority allocated to cases by the Australian Federal Police and the Director of Public Prosecutions, the ANAO did acknowledge that it had recommended in a 1990-91 audit report on the efficiency and effectiveness of fraud investigations by the Australian Federal Police that the investigation effort be directed to frauds that justified police resources.

The ANAO concluded that the investigative powers of the commission should be significantly enhanced, and recommended that consideration be given to the Health Insurance Commission being given the power to deal directly with the Director of Public Prosecutions. The government has accepted that recommendation, which is given effect in this bill.

This bill provides for Health Insurance Commission investigators to be given reasonable powers to obtain relevant evidence. Those powers are progressive in nature in that the power to seek warrants to search for and seize relevant documents represents the extreme end of the powers to be given to the commission. Other, less intrusive, methods will be adopted whenever possible. Only if it appears that cooperation in obtaining relevant information is impossible, or if there is a serious risk that evidence may be destroyed, will the right to search and to seize documents be sought. Moreover, to ensure that there is consistency in decisions to seek such warrants, those decisions will be made centrally and will be limited to no more than a few senior commission officers.

In the event that some observers see the legislation as a sign by the government of a lack of confidence in the Australian Federal Police, it should be noted that this is not the case. The Australian Federal Police is expected to make its own judgments on what is the most effective way of using its investigation resources.

It is one of the features of the Medicare benefits arrangements that individual instances of abuse of the system frequently involve relatively small amounts of money. It is often not appreciated that the real extent of abuse is considerably more than would be suggested by the cases that have been brought to court. The same may be said about cases of overservicing that have been referred to the medical services committees of inquiry.

Another problem in dealing with fraud cases under Medicare is that the nature of the activities that are subject to investigation is such that they are often technical medical ones, subject to complex legislative provisions. This makes understanding the intricacies of certain cases particularly difficult. It is an unfortunate, albeit unavoidable, fact that many of the measures that have had to be taken in recent years to tackle abuse of the Medicare arrangements have served to add to the complexity of the legislation governing the payment of Medicare benefits.

The result is that, apart from the practitioners affected and the officers in the Health Insurance Commission who are required to have a detailed understanding of the technical and legal issues, many persons find it difficult to understand the health legislation.It is the government's view that it takes an adequate understanding of the Medicare Benefits Schedule and a sound understanding of the relevant legislation to effectively investigate Medicare fraud and to determine precisely what evidence is needed. Only the Health Insurance Commission is properly equipped to do this. Furthermore, unlike the Australian Federal Police, the Commission is in a position to direct its endeavours exclusively to the investigation of Medicare abuse and thus to reduce significantly the time currently taken to put a case to the Director of Public Prosecutions.

The bill now before the House has already been the subject of considerable debate in the Senate. During a public hearing on the bill by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on 11 February 1994, it became evident that certain provisions in the original bill were of serious concern to both the committee and certain organisations and individuals. The principal concerns were that the powers granted to the commission were not sufficiently restricted to the investigation of Medicare fraud, and that there was insufficient protection for the privacy of patients' records.

As there was a consensus that there was an imbalance between the powers of the investigators and the rights of the investigated, the government proposed a series of amendments to the bill, designed to redress that imbalance. A majority of the committee subsequently recommended that the bill be enacted, incorporating the amendments proposed by the government. During the debate on the bill in the Senate, the government accepted a number of further amendments. I commend the bill, as amended, to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Mrs B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill has been a long time coming to the House of Representatives and, as I shall make clear in the course of my speech, its final form owes a great deal to the efforts of the coalition. The genesis of this bill can be found in reports in the mid-1980s by the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts. More recently, in December 1992, the Auditor-General produced a report calling for legislative reform to address Medicare fraud and overservicing. The Auditor-General found that there was a lack of prosecutions and of disciplinary action taken against unethical practitioners and that there had been little improvement since the early 1980s. A bill was finally introduced into the Senate in mid-December last year. I would like to reiterate the comments made by Senator Newman in the other place regarding this need for reform. These were that the coalition strongly supports the need to address legislation shortcomings highlighted by the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: Last year we supported legislation specifically dealing with the issue of overservicing. Such support, however, does not mean that we are uncritical of the legislation itself. Indeed, in its initial form the legislation was entirely unacceptable. It proposed the transfer of investigative powers from the Australian Federal Police to the Health Insurance Commission. However, the commission was to be granted powers in excess of those available to be exercised by the Australian Federal Police. As well, the bill appeared to take no account of privacy of individual records. One of the matters discussed in the Senate was a constant complaint, indeed an important issue that we in the opposition raise consistently, and that is that the Privacy Commissioner is accountable to the executive and not to the parliament. If he were accountable to the parliament, I believe we would have much better protection for individual privacy.

In the light of these concerns, the bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in February. Perhaps anticipating the barrage of criticism which the bill ultimately received at the committee's public hearing, the government announced, 48 hours before facing the music, that it would be drafting amendments to the bill. These were not ready in time for the public meeting. The hearing itself produced almost universal criticism of the bill, from representatives of the Australian Medical Association, the Australian Association of General Practitioners, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, the Australian Federal Police and the Queensland Council for Civil Liberties.

Two principal concerns were highlighted. The first was that the bill, as presented in the Senate, gave the Health Insurance Commission sweeping compliance powers. It allowed authorised officers of the Health Insurance Commission to enter the premises of a doctor or pharmacist and search the premises, take photographs and take extracts or copies of books or documents. For all intents and purposes, as the Privacy Commissioner pointed out, these were search and seizure powers without a warrant.

As well, under the bill as presented, the Health Insurance Commission would need no justification for entering the premises. That is an extraordinary situation, given the history of parliamentary and community concern on this issue on so many other occasions. Indeed, I am reminded of the concern that we showed in the inquiry into the Midford Paramount affair, where search and seizure procedures did result in an injustice being brought about.

The second principal concern with the first version of the bill was that no regard was paid to the confidentiality of individual patient records. The government came up with a series of amendments on 21 February. These were sent out for comment to witnesses who appeared before the Senate committee. These amendments address the issue of confidentiality of private records in a way which satisfied the Privacy Commissioner, the medical profession and the coalition. However, we were not satisfied with the amendments directed at the compliance powers of the Health Insurance Commission or with the accountability of actions of the Health Insurance Commission under the proposed legislation.

We highlighted these concerns in a dissenting report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The government responded with further amendments but still failed to go far enough. In particular, we believe that if a Health Insurance Commission officer was unable to obtain access to desired information by way of agreement with the occupier of the premises then a warrant should be obtained to conduct the search. In the end, the government had 34 amendments to the bill. We had seven proposed amendments and the Democrats six.

A very important coalition amendment was the inclusion of a sunset clause in the bill. Such a clause is absolutely appropriate, given the sensitive nature of the bill. It will allow the parliament to evaluate, after a reasonable period of time, the effectiveness of the legislation and of the Health Insurance Commission in administering it. This amendment was accepted by the Senate.

We also sought to amend the bill so that it was restricted only to fraud occurring in the present sense. This was particularly important if Health Insurance Commission officers did not need warrants to enter premises. The Australian Federal Police are able to enter premises without a warrant only if they reasonably believe that some offence is being committed, not if they believe some offence may have been committed in the past. The government was not prepared to accept these amendments. The Democrats put forward compromise amendments, which were accepted by the Senate. The Health Insurance Commission officers will be able to enter premises to investigate fraud which is being committed, which it is thought is being committed or which has been committed within the last 60 days.

The Democrats also successfully put forward an amendment requiring the Health Insurance Commission to report in detail on its activities in its annual report. The coalition has already won a concession from the government that this would occur, so we were happy to support this amendment. Easily the most contentious amendments considered by the Senate were those moved by us. They were seeking to achieve two things: first, that pursuant to section 8S the Health Insurance Commission would be compelled to obtain consent of the occupier before entering premises; second, that in the event that consent was not obtained the Health Insurance Commission would be required to obtain a warrant from a magistrate. These amendments prompted considerable debate in the Senate. The issues were substantive, with concern being expressed that without these amendments yet another step was being taken in the diminution of civil liberties.

In the end our amendments prevailed because Senator Crowley was unable to convince the Senate that the significant encroachment on fundamental civil liberties could be justified. And this is despite the government seeking, at the last election, to radically overstate the level of savings which will flow from these reforms.

At that election the Labor government claimed that its new spending promises on health could essentially be met from savings flowing from a reduction in fraud and overservicing. It suggested that there were savings of $400 million to be made over four years and that in the first two years savings would be around $160 million. We immediately challenged that figure, and with some justification.

At the time of the August budget last year the estimated savings for the first two years had amazingly been pared back to $90 million, and this amount was identified in the explanatory memorandum to the bill. It stated that measures to reduce fraud and overservicing—that is, this bill and the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Amendment Act 1994—will save $25 million in 1993-94 and then $64.9 million.

It is very important that the government's figures be challenged so that we get nearer the truth of the matter. The only hard evidence we have comes from the Auditor-General's report No. 17 of 1992-93. There it states that in 1991-92 four successful prosecutions took place—only four—and that $1 million was recovered, a far cry from the election promises made and, indeed, the pared down figure.

As far as the government is concerned, the larger the estimated cost of fraud, the easier it is to take this figure and argue for quite significant legislative provisions that have serious implications for civil liberties. In other words, we are told it is in the public good and we should give up a little bit of our freedom in order that this aim can be achieved. When we look closely, it simply cannot and must not be allowed to occur.

Another fatal flaw in the government's argument was that, without the Health Insurance Commission being granted powers greater than those exercised by the Australian Federal Police, it would be severely hampered in successfully investigating fraud. But the real problem has not necessarily been that the Australian Federal Police did not have adequate powers to investigate; it was just that the AFP did not give Medicare fraud a very high priority.

Support for our amendments came from Senator Harradine and the Greens senators. There was also a brief but very timely contribution in the debate on these amendments from Senator Cooney. Senator Cooney chaired the committee which examined the bill. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: What we are really saying to the people we represent who are listening to us today is this: what do they think is the right balance between these things? It is my view in regard to a lot of legislation coming through at the moment that the balance is going too far in the direction of detection. If we wanted to bug every bedroom, if we wanted to examine every household, there is no doubt we could suppress a lot of crime, but at what cost?
Implicit in these comments is the view that without the coalition's amendments the bill before us would simply have gone too far and would have removed an important freedom.

PARA.TAB: There can be no doubt that present arrangements for the investigation of Medicare fraud are inadequate, but there can be no doubt that this bill raises fundamental questions in regard to civil rights. In protecting the interests of the taxpayer we must not violate the rights of patients, health care professionals and health care organisations. That is why the coalition has approached this bill in a very serious and very rigorous manner.

We had the bill referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitution Affairs, and we have consulted widely. We have pressed the government to address shortcomings identified in the original bill. Where the government was not prepared to meet us on outstanding issues, we successfully moved our own amendments in the Senate.

I was very pleased to receive from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) assurances that the government was prepared to accept the bill as it was amended, in its entirety, by the Senate. I welcome this decision. However, I must say I find it interesting that in this place we seem to have a practice where the minister who is responsible for legislation chooses not to attend and sends instead the Parliamentary Secretary. I think every time that we diminish the institution of parliament we do our citizens a disservice. I think it is a shame the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) has not attended.

However, there has been considerable cooperation in the progress of this bill. As a result, a better piece of legislation will ultimately be enacted. It will allow the Health Insurance Commission to immediately begin the task of investigating Medicare fraud. The commission will be able to do this with its new powers—powers that have rightly been moderated out of a need to respect the civil liberties that are still and must remain of high priority. The coalition and the parliament generally will be closely watching the effectiveness of these new powers and the way in which they are exercised by the Health Insurance Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haviland Mr C.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in support of the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill 1994. This bill is the second leg of the government's legislative reform measures, announced in the 1993-94 budget last August, to combat medical fraud and excessive servicing. The first leg was the passage of the Health Legislation (Professional Service Review) Amendment Act, which put in place new measures to deal with excessive servicing and inappropriate practice by doctors, and that included the establishment of professional services review committees.

PARA.TAB: This second part of the government's measures deals with improved measures to combat medical fraud, as opposed to excessive servicing. It is important to draw the distinction, of course, between fraud and overservicing. Medical fraud is a practitioner billing Medicare for a service on the medical benefits schedule which was not actually provided—in other words, straight-out fraud—or billing Medicare for the wrong item number. Excessive servicing, on the other hand, occurs when the service is actually provided but is an inappropriate service or a service that is not reasonably necessary for the adequate medical care or the clinical needs of the patient. It is important to understand the distinction.

Speaking to this bill, which of course is the second leg dealing with the fraud side, I might repeat some of the points that I made in the debate on the professional services review amendment bill last year in relation to the history of attempts by successive governments and by various government agencies to deal with abuses of Medicare and indeed with abuses of the predecessors of Medicare, the previous health insurance systems that existed under coalition governments.

Honourable members might be aware that I have had a long interest in and involvement in this particular issue, having worked in the relevant section of the then Department of Health back in the 1980s and also having been involved in preparing submissions to the public accounts committee inquiries that the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) referred to.

The issue of medical fraud and overservicing first came to public notice in the early 1980s during the term of the Fraser coalition government. Prior to 1982 very little priority had been directed to the problem of abuse of the various health insurance systems by doctors. There had been no official recognition of the magnitude of the problem, despite various warnings by concerned officers within both the then Department of Health and the Health Insurance Commission, going back as far as 1976.

Two basic reasons can be advanced for the lack of activity in addressing this problem. Firstly, the Fraser government was unwilling to offend its friends in the medical profession, upon whom it relied for political support. Secondly, the medical profession itself had an historically very strong influence within the then health department's administration in those days. Of course, one had to be a doctor to be director-general or a state director of health in those days. Those officers had a very big influence within that department, which had responsibility for controlling abuses of the various systems.

The first public acknowledgment of the extent of medical fraud and overservicing came in February 1982. It was reported that a leaked health department document received by the then shadow health minister, Dr Blewett, estimated that the level of abuse for the financial year 1980-81 was $100 million. This figure represented about seven per cent of total Commonwealth and fund benefits paid in 1980-81 under the previous health system. It is important to stress that that figure applies to the time before Medicare was introduced. It was under the Fraser government's health system, which involved private health insurance, subsidised to a significant extent by the Commonwealth.

The estimate was about seven per cent of the total dollar figure. It is important to stress that figure of $100 million, because that was before there was universal bulk-billing. The coalition on the one hand often wants to say that doctors are all honest people and do not rip the system off and on the other hand it says that yes, doctors do, but it is all because of Labor's socialist, ideological bulk-billing. Of course, the facts do not bear that out at all. As I said, there was an abuse figure of seven per cent before Medicare was introduced.

The AMA at the time, in 1982, immediately issued a press statement which supported that figure. The figure was based on a formula calculated with the aid of the fraud and overservicing detection system, known as FODS, a highly complex computer based system which produced statistical data showing servicing patterns of medical practitioners. It is extremely significant to note that the AMA endorsed the estimate of that time and that its endorsement was based on analysis by its own actuaries in 1982.

Two important points need to be noted about this matter. Firstly, the AMA, through its then president, Dr Lionel Wilson, supported the department's estimate of $100 million. This is particularly interesting when one looks at the AMA's position on this same issue in later years, after there had been a change of government and Medicare had been introduced. Secondly, as I have already said, the estimate of $100 million, or seven per cent of the total, was in relation to a time well before the introduction of Medicare—at a time when bulk-billing was available only to social security beneficiaries.

Following public concern arising from these announcements, the public accounts committee initiated an inquiry into medical fraud and overservicing. Public hearings commenced in July 1982, and an interim report, tabled in parliament in December of that year, was extremely critical of the performance of the health department. It expressed the view that the level of abuse was likely to be even higher than the official estimate; that the seven per cent may well have been a conservative estimate. This report also resulted in the immediate sacking of the then Director-General of Health, and the inquiry had already led to the resignation of the Victorian Director of Health. The report was truly embarrassing to the Fraser government, as it closely followed the release of the Costigan report into tax avoidance and came at a time when the Fraser government was planning an early election.

Notwithstanding the very valid criticisms of the health department, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts also found that there were problems caused by the fact that several federal agencies were involved, particularly in cases of medical fraud. Suspected fraud cases were referred to the Australian Federal Police and prosecutions were carried out by the then Deputy Crown Solicitor's office. I can recall the frustration expressed in those days by health department investigators at the delays and inefficiencies this caused and the criticisms of the performances of the AFP in dealing with medifraud cases.

I do not wish to be too critical of the role of the AFP, especially as my experience was of a period some years ago. Indeed, as the parliamentary secretary has pointed out, this bill does not seek to criticise the role of the Federal Police at all. However, it is fair to say that there was a perception that medical fraud cases were not exactly regarded as high priority matters for the Australian Federal Police, who were responsible for dealing with a wide range of crime. Many of the medifraud cases referred to the Australian Federal Police were for relatively small amounts of money when compared with others forms of crime. Of course, many Medicare fraud cases are for small amounts of money, though the small amounts do add up. The nature of the system and legislation was that each separate item number had to be prosecuted separately, which caused some problems. Consequently, it was probably true that medifraud cases were not always afforded high priority, although there were notable exceptions. That situation has remained until today, which is one of the reasons why this bill is so important.

One of the most significant aspects of the bill is that the Health Insurance Commission will now assume those investigative powers which are currently the responsibility of the Australian Federal Police. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) pointed out, this step is being taken not because of lack of confidence in the AFP but in order to bring better coordination and greater effectiveness to the investigation of fraud against Medicare.

The Health Insurance Commission has since 1985 had the main carriage of investigation of medifraud and excessive servicing. At that time, following continuing criticisms of the performance of the then Department of Health, that department's surveillance and investigations program was abolished by the government and the functions transferred to the Health Insurance Commission.

I have spoken about that in this House previously. There were many reasons why it occurred, not least of which was the incessant and politically motivated attacks by the AMA at the time, after the introduction of Medicare. The association objected to any suggestion that there was something wrong or that there could be too many doctors who were ripping off the system. So it continued to attack the surveillance and investigation program of the former Department of Health just at the stage when it was starting to bring some results and embarrass the medical profession.

That program was transferred to the commission in 1985. As has already been pointed out, however, the Auditor-General's report No. 17 of 1992-93 examined the Health Insurance Commission's performance in combating fraud and overservicing. It concluded there had been little, if any, improvement evidenced since 1985, when the function was transferred from the former Department of Health.

Furthermore, the report suggested that the estimate of seven per cent of medical benefits as the extent of abuse may still be appropriate. Although the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) pointed out that only $1 million was recovered, the Auditor-General's report says also that the level of abuse of seven per cent, estimated back in the early 1980s, could still be a valid figure. Medicare benefits—medical benefits only, not including pharmaceutical benefits—for 1991-92 were over $4 1/2 billion. At seven per cent, this would put the estimated level of abuse at over $300 million. For 1992-93, with Medicare benefits of $5 billion, this would represent abuse of over $350 million.

In addition to the audit report in 1992, at that time the Health Insurance Commission commissioned a consultant, Mr Harvey Bates, to review its investigation unit. His report dealt with investigation of medical fraud in particular, rather than overservicing. It is interesting to look at statements in that report:

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the need for a significant cultural change in the attitude of several management levels within the Commission. Secondly, that the level and seriousness of medifraud is likely to have increased since the investigation function was transferred to the Health Insurance Commission. In part this could be attributed to a reduction in effort and lack of expertise currently allocated to this task since the function was transferred from the Department of Health in 1985. Thirdly, that the function and responsibility for detecting and prosecuting medifraud had never been successfully integrated into the Commission's operations.

Given the public statements made by the commission in 1985, including those before the public accounts committee, I guess it is fair to say that both the Auditor-General's report and the Harvey Bates report gave the government, and indeed the community, cause for legitimate concern.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to say that this concern has led, first of all, to the passage of the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Amendment Bill, dealing with excessive servicing, and now to the expected passage of this bill, which will occur because it has already gone through the Senate.

I am pleased to support this bill, although I note the comments of the honourable member for Mackellar about what happened in the Senate, with the Senate examination of this bill and the examination by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Although I have concerns about some of the issues raised there, I am assured that the amendments that the government has agreed to will not in any way damage the ability of the commission to investigate successfully and to prosecute cases of medical fraud.

Although civil liberties are important, it does sometimes worry me that the coalition has a different attitude on civil liberties when it is talking about the protection of some of its more wealthy supporters, such as doctors and other groups, than it does when it is talking about other members of the community. I would be very pleased if the coalition took a consistent line on this and had the same attitude to civil liberties when it was talking about social security fraud or when it is alleged that the less well off in the community are ripping off the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have no commitment to civil liberties. You will not let people go to work until they have a union ticket.

—I will not respond to the interjections. I think it is pretty clear that, when it is the rich and powerful who are under threat from legitimate investigations from government agencies, suddenly civil liberties are being mentioned. Having said that, unlike the honourable members opposite, I will stick to the issue of health and medical fraud. While I have some concerns about the need for the amendments, I accept that they are the reality and that they will go through. I am also assured that the effectiveness of the Health Insurance Commission will be much enhanced by this legislation, amendments included.

PARA.TAB: The two main points that were raised in the Senate, as has been pointed out, were the powers of search and the access to confidential patient records. Certainly civil liberties are important and we only need to have access to records when those records are needed to assist in an investigation or a prosecution. I would point out that this is about abuse of taxpayers' money. The civil liberties of the taxpayers who fund Medicare to the tune of $5 billion a year also need to be taken into account. Honourable members opposite, who are very interested in tax and who reckon that we pay too much tax—which is a nonsense—should be equally interested in how that money is spent.

Medicare is the best health system in the world, but it does risk being placed in jeopardy when a small percentage—and it is a small percentage—of practitioners are allowed to rip off the system. It needs to be accepted that, like any other group in the community, the majority of medical practitioners are honest people, but there are some who are not so honest, and so we need to be able to deal with them in the most effective way.

The record shows, both under the Fraser government and under this government that, while successive federal agencies might have made an effort, the results have not been too flash. Indeed, the figures have been quoted and there were very few prosecutions. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) pointed out, it has taken a great number of days for an average case to go before the DPP and to be processed by the Australian Federal Police. That is deplorable. It has not changed much since about 1982, and it is time that it did.

Hopefully, the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill and the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Act in relation to excessive servicing, and the new committee that has been set up to replace the old Medical Services Committee of Inquiry, will finally enable the commission, which has the responsibility, to do its job and to ensure that Medicare, which is one of the cornerstones of the Labor government's policies for families and for social justice, is able to deliver and is not being ripped off.

As I said, it is of concern that the level of abuse might be around seven per cent, which would be in excess of $300 million or $400 million a year. Nobody is suggesting—and I do not want to be misrepresented here—that these measures will recoup $300 million or $400 million a year. Of course they will not. That would be like saying—as I think I have mentioned before—that, if the fine for speeding on the F5 Freeway between Sydney and Canberra were $150 and a million people speed along there in a year, then there would be a revenue of $150 million. You will not get that amount because very few people ever get caught. The same applies to this situation.

However, I think it is at least appropriate, after all this time, for the government to have decent legislation and for the commission to be given its best chance, through this legislation, finally to be able to apply the appropriate amount of resources to this issue. I think it is fair to say that it has not happened in the past. Medicare has, in terms of its culture and its role, seen itself as a paying office. The priority has been to pay bulkbilling claims quickly.

However, Medicare also has a compliance side. It also has the responsibility to ensure that claims are legitimate and that the taxpayer is not being ripped off by doctors, or by anybody else for that matter. I commend the bill to the House. I look forward to seeing much better results being attained by the Health Insurance Commission, both as a result of this bill and as a result of the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Act that was passed last year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I have followed the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) at other times, following similar legislation to the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill. He said at the end of his speech that there were only a few doctors ripping off the system. But, if we had listened to the rest of it, we would have thought that they were nearly all crooks, and that there were none of the caring and conscientious ones around that so many of us know. I am sure, if we were to believe him, it is just all the rich and powerful—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I think that is a clear representation. There is nowhere in my speech that I implied that most doctors were crooks.
—There is no point of order.
—The figures speak for themselves.
—There is no point of order. Please resume your seat.

—I also join with the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) in expressing my disappointment that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) is not here today to take part in this debate and to listen to what others might be saying.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—What is your point of order? Which point of order are you drawing on?
—I am raising a point of order in relation to misrepresentation of the issue under the standing orders relating to the roles of the parliamentary secretaries of ministers—
—Order! There is no point of order. Please resume your seat.

—I was really just expressing a sincere point of view that, because this bill has been long in coming, has been much heralded and has had quite a bit of public attention, it would have been good if the minister had been here. It is no way demeaning the role of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous). It would have just seemed appropriate, given the importance of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: The opposition supports moves to protect the public purse and to ensure that dishonest operators do not have their snout in the Medicare trough. Medicare operates as a system which provides health care to patients at no obvious cost to them. That is understandably attractive but it also creates an environment or fertile ground for activity which may not always be desirable. In protecting taxpayers' money, the rights and liberties of patients and health care professionals must also be protected.

That is why the coalition has tried to give this legislation fair scrutiny. There have been four coalition amendments, six Democrat amendments and 34—or six pages—of government amendments. This debate was originally scheduled on the day that the former minister, Graham Richardson, announced his resignation. The government amendments in their entirety were received only that afternoon because the minister's office had not signed the release any earlier. I confess to having wondered at the time if they were not on a whiteboard. Of course, we now know that the then minister had other things on his mind. It is of real concern to me that the government, in drafting the original legislation, totally failed to make privacy provisions.

From time to time, government members in this place have made derogatory comments about our colleagues in the Senate. This legislation is a classic example of how close scrutiny and amendments will very much improve legislation. I pay tribute to my colleagues in the other place for the improvements they have made—improvements that now mean the coalition is in a happy position to support this legislation. The work of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, and submissions from peak bodies such as the AMA, Private Doctors of Australia, the Australian Association of General Practitioners, the Royal Australasian College of General Practitioners, the Australian College of Nutritionists and Environmental Medicine, the Victorian Medical Practice Defence Committee, the Australian Association of Pathology Practice and the Health Issues Centre, all have drawn attention to the shortcomings of the original legislation.

It is interesting to note that in the former minister's second reading speech he spoke about the close consultation with the medical profession. This claim has been denied by the AMA, which met only once with the minister. The legislation at that stage did not reflect the content of that conversation. Senator Newman summed up the coalition's position very well when, in the Senate on 4 May this year, she said:

SPEECH.PARA: With this particular piece of legislation, for example, it was not until the opposition looked carefully at this bill and alerted the medical organisations to some of the hidden difficulties that they started to realise that the rights of both their practitioners and their patients could be in jeopardy under the bill as originally printed.

We alerted them to the concerns which we had. They then took the bill to legal advisers, and they were advised that our concerns were reasonable and that there was a need for improving this act. While we all support the purpose of the act, there are genuine concerns as to civil liberties. The privacy issues have been addressed. It remains to be seen in practice whether they are adequately addressed, but it appears on the surface that those issues have been improved.

However, we are concerned, as I said yesterday, that people are being given police authorities without the controls which the police in this land are subject to. We do not believe that we can rely on the doctors' wish to clean up the fraud as being so overwhelming that civil rights concerns can be ignored. We are committed to cleaning up the fraud in the medical area, where it exists. In fact, the opposition has been keen, and expressed its views, on this issue long before this legislation came in. So there can be no way in which it could be suggested that we are soft on crime in connection with medical fraud.

I am sure that Senator Newman speaks for all of us in the coalition. Key issues are the protection of the public purse while protecting the traditional rights of citizens against the arbitrary use of power. Questions arise as to how we protect the Medicare trough. There is no question that we need to do so. This legislation has been long heralded, so let us hope it works.

PARA.TAB: It would seem that the present arrangements for the investigation of Medicare fraud are inadequate. In the mid-1980s there was a Joint Committee of Public Accounts inquiry into fraud and overservicing. In December 1992 the Auditor-General found that there was a lack of prosecutions and disciplinary action taken against the unethical practitioners and that there had been little improvement since the early 1980s.

The government has claimed, interestingly, before the last federal election, that there would be savings of $400 million over a four-year period if fraud and overservicing could be dramatically reduced. These figures have not stood up to scrutiny and now the claim is $25 million in 1993-94 and $64.9 million in 1994-95. It is also just possible that there are more ethical practitioners than the government imagines and that these savings will not be made.

Through my own consultations on this legislation I have received the crystal-clear message from ethical practitioners that any fraud should be dealt with so that collective reputations would not suffer further. So often, powers are introduced and the good, honest players get hurt and the strong and powerful who can buy expert legal advice still outwit the legislation. In fact, the Medical Director of the Health Insurance Commission, Dr John Nearhos who, I note, is here in the chamber today, said in relation to fraud in the pathology industry:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is clear that legislation is not enough in this area. We can patch the legislation, and there will always be someone there who can find a way around the legislation and particularly with the power that some of these pathology companies have. In terms of legal representation, they are able to circumvent the intentions of legislation fairly quickly.

Small general practices will be exposed to the new full powers of the Health Insurance Commission in the same way as the more powerful. In my consultations I have heard of a Dr Peverill who owns a large pathology set-up in Brisbane. He has gone all the way to the High Court to defend what he perceived as his rights.

PARA.TAB: Officers of the Health Insurance Commission who will be significantly empowered with this legislation have not always acted reasonably. The Health Insurance Commission should not just go for the easy targets so as to be seen to have runs on the board. Several years ago women general practitioners in Adelaide—and, I understand, in other parts of Australia—were called on by the Health Insurance Commission to explain why they were ordering too much pathology. It was later discovered, after many of them had been very upset, that there was a good reason for this. These women practitioners saw more women patients who had tests associated with pregnancy and pap smears. Interestingly, the government was at the same time running a campaign encouraging women to have two-yearly pap smears. Commonsense had not prevailed. It had not even been recognised that women patients were more likely to seek out women doctors for such care and testing.

If there are real crooks—and I have been advised in my consultations that there are—then they must be caught. The point has been made to me that it takes two to tango where general practitioners and the pathology companies are involved in transactions which are against the law. As this legislation and other similar acts do not make light night-time reading, the Health Insurance Commission should embark on an education program for general practitioners. It would be sensible for the AMA to do likewise.

The effect of this legislation is to give to public servants the same powers as the Federal Police. In its submission to the Senate committee of inquiry, the Federal Police Association stated the following:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . expresses a deep and growing concern over the increase of public service investigators who are far less accountable than police with very few guidelines as to appropriate investigational behaviour.
The submission continues:

Accountability to the community, to the Government and to the Ombudsman is a matter that the Association has always been keen to see implemented. The Australian Federal Police has two divisions exclusively deployed to ensure members of the Australian Federal Police's integrity. Couple this with stringent disciplinary regulations, fixed term appointments and performance management programs and it can be seen that members of the Australian Federal Police are heavily accountable. This is not the case with public service investigators generally, and specifically those attached to the Health Insurance Commission.

Accountability is important and that is why Senator Newman's amendment to make this sunset legislation is so important. In passing this legislation, we as a parliament are in effect saying to officers of the Health Insurance Commission, `We are trusting you to guard the public purse but do not abuse these powers and do not hurt innocent individuals.' That is asking quite a lot and we must be able to monitor these operations closely. They must be required to report specific statistical details of the use of these new powers.

PARA.TAB: Like the AMA, we do not want to see the health insurance officials having more power than the Federal Police. It would seem essential that specific guidelines be developed to govern the way in which searches are conducted. The precedent of the guidelines established by the Australian Federal Police and the Law Council of Australia is a good one. Amongst other things they should provide, as the ones regarding lawyers do, procedures whereby documents can be held in safe storage while any legal issues regarding whether or not they are properly subject to inspection, for example on the grounds that they contain clinical details, are resolved.

This bill provides also for the retention and production of pathology records, to bring the pathology services provision of the Health Insurance Act 1973 into line with those applying to diagnostic imaging services. In practical terms, this is a requirement to keep such records for 18 months. There are some quite good arguments for keeping such documents for a longer time. NATA, for instance, requires that results be kept for five years. Many pathology services would keep them longer and see benefits in matching the original request form with those results.

In summary, the opposition supports this legislation. We are anxious to see that the taxpayer's money is guarded carefully. We have certainly had concerns about how the legislation will be implemented. We will be keeping a close eye on this legislation but we certainly hope that it works very well. I am happy to support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the provisions of the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill 1994, which provides the Health Insurance Commission with powers to monitor compliance with and investigate breaches of requirements relating to medical and pharmaceutical benefits. The bill also incorporates in the Health Insurance Act 1973 requirements aimed at reducing Medicare benefits fraud.

PARA.TAB: This bill fulfils the government's announcement in the 1993-94 budget to introduce, in cooperation with the Australian Medical Association, an enhanced peer review scheme with powers to investigate the practices of medical practitioners suspected of overservicing and the capacity to apply effective penalties where overservicing is found. It is difficult to cite accurate data on the extent of overservicing in Australia. In 1992-93 the Australian National Audit Office estimated fraud and overservicing at seven per cent of the Medicare budget, but this figure was based on estimates from the early 1980s.

Accurate statistics are available only on the number of medical practitioners prosecuted for Medicare fraud and the moneys recovered. Between 1985 and 1992, 50 medical practitioners were prosecuted and $5.6 million was recovered in Medicare benefits. The measures set out in this bill are estimated by the government as saving $64.9 million in 1994-95. Clearly, overservicing and fraud in the Australian medical system are issues of considerable importance, both ethically and financially. They need to be set in a broader context, however, of structural reform of medical services and insurance arrangements.

Health policy has become one of the most difficult issues in Australian public life, and the shadow minister, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop), is just finding that out. Scarce resources are expected to meet the growing health demands of a community accustomed to the highest standards of medical care. No aspect of public policy has higher public expectations. Most Australians expect access to first-rate medical services at all times under all conditions.

Just as much, no party has failed the challenge of health policy formulation in the 1980s and 1990s as thoroughly as the Liberal Party has. The honourable member for Mackellar is the eighth Liberal spokesperson on health in 10 years, inheriting the policy legacy and failures of—among others—Peter Shack, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), Michael Baume, Jim Carlton and Senator Bob Woods. Like her predecessors, she has a barren ideological obsession with strengthening the private sector and reducing the role of government to a minimum. The honourable member for Mackellar measures all issues in the extreme, either individualist or collectivist. While black-and-white simplicity may be popular among the Tory matrons of her electorate, it is hardly the basis of effective health policy in the 1990s.

The Australian health system blends the interest of the individual and the collective. All hospitals, public and private, are the product of individuals pooling their resources, through either the taxation system or private health insurance, to facilitate the collective provision of services which individuals then use on a needs basis.

For a decade, the Liberal Party has failed to develop policies which attract customers back into the private sector without unacceptable outcomes in cost, coverage and equity for the public system. Only Labor, and only this government with a pragmatic view on the role of the public and private sectors, can further reform the Australian health system around the twin principles of equity and efficiency—the all-important twin principles ignored by the shadow minister.

Managed competition—and the shadow minister should listen to this—can produce enormous efficiency and equity gains in the Australian health system. Medical services should not be exempt from modern management methods to make the public sector more responsive to client needs. Health should not be exempt from the separation of the demand and supply functions of government into a purchaser-provider split.

Internationally, health policy makers have grappled with the problem of securing greater efficiency and cost control in the delivery of services, while maintaining universal insurance. In many cases, this has resulted in the national government establishing service contracts with both public and private hospitals for the provision of core services—and I am glad to see that the shadow minister is taking notes. A single national insurer offers a range of options for health coverage linked to the principle of capacity to pay. This system could be used to integrate the public and private hospital systems in Australia, just as the federal government two decades ago ended the distinction for funding purposes between public and private schools.

The development of public beds in private hospitals would address the problem of underutilised resources in our national hospital system. The direct funding role for hospitals would be administered by regional authorities, allowing the federal government to allocate funds on the basis of need. The service provider role would involve competition between public and private health institutions to win performance based contracts from the regional authority.

By taking up the responsibility which the 1946 referendum conferred on this parliament to provide medical services, the government can establish a national health system. All Australians, no matter what their income or location is, can have equal access to essential health services under the universal coverage of national health insurance. Managed competition would address three inadequacies within the Australian health system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I would draw your attention under standing orders to the fact that this bill is the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill, and it deals with powers of investigation to be conferred on the Health Insurance Commission. It is not a general health bill. I would ask you to ask the honourable member for Werriwa to direct his attention to the subject of the bill.
—I have been listening to the debate. As in all cases like this, it has been a fairly wide ranging debate. What the speaker is saying is that he is covering those issues and he is following—

PARA.TAB: Mrs Bishop interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are going to argue with me, I remind you that you asked for a ruling, and I am giving you the ruling. I find the honourable member for Werriwa in order. There is no point of order.

—I can understand the sensitivities of the shadow minister when anyone debates health policy, but she will find that the issues I am addressing relate to the efficiency of the national health system, of which overservicing is a very important component—
—Perhaps you will get to the bill.
—Order! We will not have a debate across the table.

—Managed competition would address three inadequacies within the Australian health system. The first is overlapping federal and state responsibilities and programs. In the current system the coordination of planning and service delivery is difficult, efficiency gains are inhibited and cost shifting remains a substantial problem. Secondly, the lack of coordination between public and private sectors has fostered incentives for cost shifting, recurrent cost increases and risk selection. Thirdly, there is an absence of financial incentive for efficiency gains in both the public and private systems. In all states except Victoria, the system of global hospital budgeting is unrelated to the efficiency of service delivery.

PARA.TAB: Managed competition and the purchaser-provider split would bring the functions of the private sector into the national system and promote three important efficiency features. Services for every individual would be covered by one budget holder or purchaser, thereby preventing cost shifting. Government subsidies would take the form of risk related capitation payments to service providers, thereby limiting risk selection. Most importantly, the income of all service providers would consist of payments by budget holders at prices reflecting the rigour of competition and full costs of efficient production. In a more efficient system you would have less overservicing and fewer unnecessary medical procedures, which is the objective of this legislation.

Casemix or output related payments are essential to quantify the concept of cost under a regime of managed competition. Case payment and managed competition involve complex aspects of data collection and use which have become feasible only in the last decade through advances in health information technology. My interest in the true significance of a casemix approach was aroused by the last speech in this parliament by the founder of Medicare and former member for Bonython, Neal Blewett, on 10 February, one day after I was sworn in as member for Werriwa. Dr Blewett had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The central issue for the health system is the working of the public hospital system . . . I believe that the hospital reforms introduced by Mrs Tehan in Victoria are the most imaginative set of reforms to deal with the hospital system in this country in the last half a dozen years. I notice that they are now likely to be taken up by other Liberal and Labor governments around the country. Those reforms will do much to sustain the public hospital side of Medicare, provided they are not used simply to save money, and one always has to watch that danger. By using the casemix approach, Mrs Tehan has inaugurated a whole new development in hospital systems in this country. The Commonwealth has always supported that casemix approach and I hope we as a government will continue to work with Mrs Tehan and other reforming state health ministers in supporting the casemix approach.

Case payments represent a simple but effective change in the financing of hospitals. The traditional method of funding, fixed annual allocations unrelated to output, simply institutionalises hospital inefficiency. Casemix funding, which pays hospitals according to the services they perform, provides a strong incentive to increase activity and cut waiting lists.

PARA.TAB: The introduction of case payments should not be a matter of partisan politics, and I am sure even the shadow minister could agree with me. It is a commonsense and practical measure to provide the necessary incentive and management motivation for improved hospital efficiency. The Australian health system can cope with increased demand and community expectations only through either increased revenue or efficiency gains. The success of case payments in Victoria shows that an increase in the Medicare levy is unnecessary provided the other states no longer ignore such obvious measures for cost efficiency.

Following the introduction of case payments by the Victorian government, waiting lists fell by 10 per cent, from 28,618 in July 1993 to 25,850 in April this year. Waiting lists for urgent cases fell by 78 per cent, while overall hospital productivity or efficiency rose by 10 per cent.

We can all learn from the Victorian experience. The federal government has tendered for an independent assessment of the implementation of casemix in Victoria, with a final report scheduled for the end of October. Hopefully, this report will bring to a head the government's incremental consideration of this issue. Let me provide some of the history. In 1987 Neal Blewett established the casemix development program to secure case payments, based on the diagnosis related groups, direct to state public hospitals for the treatment of Medicare patients. The Department of Community Services and Health commissioned a study—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. This is a very interesting adjournment debate speech, but it just happens not to be an adjournment debate. We are debating the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill. —I think that if you glance through the bill, which I have had the opportunity to do, you will see that it is a bill covering amendments to the Health Insurance Act and that it is quite wide ranging. —I thank the honourable member for Tangney for that. I also make the point that the chair is always placed in a difficult position when there has been a wide ranging debate and then one starts interpreting the rules very narrowly. When there has been a wide ranging debate for earlier speakers, I allow that to continue. It is a bill with very wide ranging clauses.

—I would have thought that, after 10 years of policy failure, and with a shadow minister who is an absolute embarrassment to her party, the Liberal Party would be thankful to have some hints about the development of health policy.

—Order! There have been two points of order taken, so I suggest that this time speakers stay with the bill and do not start arguing other issues. We have just got out of a difficult situation, so let us not talk ourselves into another one.

—Overservicing, which is the main subject of this broad-ranging legislation, is an issue. (Quorum formed) Effective health reform in the 1990s does not imply or require confrontation and disputation with doctors. That is very much the sentiment expressed in this legislation. PARA.TAB: I am, Mr Deputy Speaker, linking this important issue of overservicing to the question of the administration of public health in Victoria, and even saying some praiseworthy things about the actions of the Victorian government, things that the shadow minister—the failed and embarrassing shadow minister—does not want to hear. This legislation supplements the reforms that are being undertaken by a number of state governments in their health policies, and conclusively addresses the problems of overservicing and Medicare fraud.
