I condemn wholeheartedly the way in which the shadow minister for health is not willing to have a meaningful debate about policy. Her whole political world is about rhetoric and empty cliches. As soon as anyone goes into a spot of detail, she is straight into the points of order and methods of trying to gag honourable members. She cannot avoid debate forever. She will have to put up a health policy, which will be debated on this side with vigour. We look forward to that day. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to talk about this bill, which is something the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) did not do.
—It was a good speech.

—There are occasions for good speeches and there are other occasions. This is an occasion for a speech about the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Bill. I want to refer to a limited area in relation to this bill: matters of general principle. I want to refer to what I call the powers of coercive discovery and interrogation that this bill gives to the Health Insurance Commission. The term `discovery' refers to the requirement for the production of documents, the term `interrogation' refers to the compulsory questioning that is authorised under the bill, and the term `coercive' obviously indicates that it is done under compulsion. In this context, I want to mention broader issues concerning the powers of coercive discovery and inspection in legislation generally.

PARA.TAB: Upon the introduction of the bill in the Senate, a number of libertarian and privacy concerns were expressed. As a result, the bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. During the course of the public hearings, the government supplied to the committee draft amendments which the government indicated it proposed to move in order to satisfy a number of the concerns raised during the hearings.

The majority of the committee recommended that the bill be enacted, incorporating the amendments proposed by the government. However, the coalition members of the committee were not satisfied with the proposed amendments and dissented, raising a number of outstanding concerns. The then Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, subsequently proposed further amendments to satisfy most of those concerns, but the minister did not accept all the points made in the dissenting report. As a result, coalition members moved a number of their own amendments at the committee stage of the bill. With the support of the Greens and Senator Harradine, those amendments passed in the Senate. In addition, a number of amendments were moved and passed by the Democrats.

The history of this bill to that point is an absolute disgrace. It resulted from a lack of concern on the part of the government for the privacy and civil liberties of those who were to be investigated. We had in this House just recently an example of legislation dealing with a serious social issue involving criminal offences and dealing with procedures for the trial for those offences. I refer to the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill. That was brought to this House in what may only be described as an unsatisfactory state. It was referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which effectively, unanimously on a bipartisan basis, made 37 recommendations. The effect of those amendments, if implemented, will be to incorporate a fair trial into the provisions of the bill.

What we have had to seek to do outside this House in relation to this bill is to incorporate provisions that provide for a fair investigation. There is no doubt that on both sides of this House there is concern for what is referred to as medifraud, which costs the community a lot of money. But on both sides of this House there should be—but it seems it is on only one side—a concern that any means of investigating alleged criminal offences should be done fairly.

The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) made the puerile suggestion that on this side of the House we were concerned to protect the rich and the famous. Fair trials and fair investigations are for the rich and for the poor. Fair trials and fair investigations are for the famous and for the infamous. The difficulty which appears not to be recognised is that fair trials and fair investigations will result in conviction of the guilty; that fair trials and fair investigations will not result in conviction of the innocent. Any means we have for coercion in an investigatory process must adequately protect the innocent.

The bill contains comprehensive provisions relating to coercive discovery and inspection. Those powers are in part IID of the bill. That is divided into five divisions, one dealing with preliminary matters, the second dealing with a general power to obtain information, the third dealing with searches in relation to possible offences and the fourth dealing with offences relating to searches and seizures. Finally, division 5 contains provisions relating to execution of search warrants. Divisions 2 to 4 contain the substantive coercive powers of discovery and interrogation, and with each division the progressive powers become more significant.

Division 2 authorises the managing director of the commission to give notice to anybody to give information or to produce a document where the managing director believes that there are reasonable grounds that an offence has been committed and that the information is relevant to the offence. The information is not limited to written information and the division requires persons to answer questions.

It is important to note also that the common law privilege against self-incrimination that would allow a person to refuse to hand over self-incriminating documents or disclose self-incriminating information is specifically abrogated by the division. However, a safeguard is provided in that any self-incriminating evidence obtained may not be used against that person in a criminal proceeding. This is not an uncommon provision in the obtaining of information by investigatory authorities, and is applicable, for example, in relation to evidence obtained by the Australian Securities Commission pursuant to its act.

Division 3 goes a step further and allows officers of the commission to enter onto premises in order to search the premises. The original scheme of the division was to facilitate searches without warrant and without the specific need to obtain the consent of the occupier unless the premises were a residence. In amendments moved by the coalition and passed in the Senate, the scope of the division has been significantly curtailed. The amendments require the consent of the occupier to be obtained. If consent is not obtained, the commission must obtain a warrant to enter the premises.

Under the division, officers may, amongst other things, take photographs and take samples of pharmaceutical benefits. Items may not be seized, nor may copies of documents be taken. The search may be undertaken only if the officer has reasonable grounds for believing that a relevant offence is being committed or has been committed in the previous 60 days. The 60-day reference results from an amendment moved by the Democrats, consequent upon an amendment moved by the coalition which would have required that the offence was in the process of being committed.

Division 4 contains the most extensive category of powers. It allows for search and seizure with a warrant. The prerequisite for obtaining a warrant is that the commission officer has reasonable grounds for suspecting that there may be evidential material on the premises. Once the warrant is obtained, or if the occupier consents, the premises may be searched and evidential material seized. Division 4 and division 5 are modelled on the search warrant provisions in the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Act, which has just been passed by this parliament.

In terms of the protection of individual rights, the current bill is a distinct improvement on that originally proposed. Another safeguard that now exists as a result of a coalition amendment in the Senate is a sunset clause which will allow the operation of the bill to be reviewed after a two-year period of operation.

One might ask: how is it that so much legislation—this is just an example—is brought to this parliament without the appropriate protection within its terms of individual rights? It is understandable that a government department would want to be able to investigate breaches of legislation under its administration and it is understandable that for that purpose it would seek the widest possible powers. But the onus must be on a department to ensure that the proposals it prepares for a minister adequately protect the privacy of those involved and, if investigation or trial is involved, adequately protect the right to a fair trial, the right to a fair investigation. A minister should not be bringing to cabinet a proposal for legislation that does not contain appropriate provisions.

The coercive discovery and interrogation contemplated under this bill is very intrusive. It was much more intrusive under its previous form without adequate protections. That safeguards are not put in seems to be a regular failing of legislation emanating from the health area.

It was really only as a result of the process in the Senate that the crimes search warrant arrangements were incorporated in the sort of detail that they now appear. It should not be up to the Office of Parliamentary Counsel to rewrite a bill in a manner not consistent with its instructions because it does not contain appropriate safeguards of the relevant type. Failing any duty on the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, it is incumbent upon the Attorney-General's Department and the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) to ensure that all legislation meets the appropriate standards of privacy protection and investigation and trial protection.

In this case, a bill came to us via the minister and the cabinet without a word from the Attorney-General as to the interests of those who were to be investigated and, more relevantly, the interest of their patients. The time seems to be coming when the subject of coercive discovery and interrogation by government departments investigating allegations of breaches of legislation needs to be the subject of a thoroughgoing review. The fact that this legislation came in the form it originally did highlights the need for that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill has taken so long to reach this stage in the parliament. In my short address on this bill today, I want to cover a couple of issues: the intent of the bill to beef up powers of investigation and the investigative powers and the actions that the Health Insurance Commission has taken over the years. Earlier this year I made a speech during the grievance debate. In that speech I referred to a Health Insurance Commission investigation of a particular pharmacist who was allegedly selling generic brand drugs illegally. I also referred to the way in which the Health Insurance Commission went about that investigation and ultimately served a summons at the end of last year. I will refer to that speech a little later.

PARA.TAB: This bill has had a long gestation period. It was based on the back of a report of the Auditor-General of December 1992 and an accompanying consultancy report of June 1992. Before that, hearings of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on fraud and overservicing were held in the early to middle 1980s. Since that time there has been very little improvement in combating fraud and overservicing, and the bill has been in the Senate for some time.

At the outset, the coalition strongly supports the addressing of fraud and overservicing which, as I said, was based on the back of the Auditor-General's report and the Bates report. The Auditor-General, for instance, found that there was a lack of prosecutions and disciplinary action taken against unethical practitioners and that there has been little improvement since then. The Bates report found that the responsibility for detecting and prosecuting fraud has never been successfully integrated into the commission's operation. It also found that existing legislation does not support any positive approach to fraud control. So there can be no doubt that fraud is a problem and that a legislative response from the government is necessary. There is considerable doubt, however, as to how much would be saved by the measures outlined by the government.

The government intends to beef up the powers of the Health Insurance Commission. What sort of watchdog will be placed over that? What monitoring and accountability will there be in the exercise of those powers? In my grievance debate speech I mentioned that just before Christmas last year a pharmacist in Wingham in New South Wales who was providing generic drugs—we all know that they can be sold at a cheaper rate than schedule drugs—was investigated by the Health Insurance Commission and subsequently issued with a summons. I am not sure where that court case is up to. I suppose it is not really up to us to deliberate about that here; it is a matter for the court. I am drawing attention to the way in which the Health Insurance Commission investigators dealt with that situation and with the pharmacist involved.

As I said in my speech in the grievance debate, it was ironic that on one occasion when the health insurance investigators turned up at that pharmacy to investigate those allegations my father was acting there in a locum capacity. He was certainly dealt with in a far less than professional manner.

We are talking about the bureaucracy and investigators operating within the bureaucracy. It is apparent that on many occasions they deal with professional people in different circumstances on the basis that those people are already guilty. The officers have already made up their mind that those people are already guilty without giving them the opportunity to put their case before a court. So it is very important that we do not see a recurrence of what has happened to Mr Keen.

Following those investigations and the fairly poor treatment that the investigators dished out to not only Mr Keen but also my father when he was there is the issue of the way that the summons was ultimately issued. It was drawn up at least two or three weeks prior to Christmas and was served on Mr Keen either on Christmas Eve or on the day before that, when he had no hope of getting any advice from counsel for probably at least three or four weeks. It will be interesting to see the result of that case. It is important that the officers of the Health Insurance Commission operate in a professional manner and do not prejudge what has been going on. They should not go along with a preconceived idea as to whether someone is innocent or guilty.

I will diverge for a moment. We have seen a number of other cases where officers of the Commonwealth have acted on that basis. Look at the Midford Paramount case. What officers of the Commonwealth perpetrated on those people was disgusting. They broke a business and the spirit of a number of people.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! I am loath to interrupt the honourable member, but there was a point of order taken on a previous speaker for ranging away from the bill. I do not see what the Midford Paramount case has to do with the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it does.
—If you give it, you have to take it.

—I am talking about the actions of Commonwealth officers in investigating some of these circumstances and how they sometimes arrive with a preconceived idea of who is guilty and who is not. Mr Deputy Speaker, I appreciate the point that you raise. I will get back to the bill.

PARA.TAB: A number of other cases are floating about where officers of the Commonwealth have acted in a less than prudential manner. This needs to be addressed. We need to be far more mindful of it. In that regard—Mr Deputy Speaker, you have drawn me back to the bill—we should be very mindful that those circumstances, which are now recorded in history, do not occur in this area by increasing the powers that are being issued here. We are mindful of the accountability and transparency that are needed in this exercise.

Nobody is decrying the fact that we need to look at this area or that we are spending a lot more than we need to in this system at the moment. There are areas where compliance can obviously be tightened up and savings can be made. But let us not forget that the basic tenet in this country is that a person is innocent until proven guilty, not the reverse. If we bear that in mind in the carriage of this legislation, we will be satisfied that those changes will have been made when we get to the stage of the Commonwealth officers implementing it.

History tells us that it does not always happen that way. Ultimately, when it does not happen that way, who wears the cost? The Commonwealth—which means that the taxpayer bears the cost. It is recorded in history that it has happened that way in a lot of cases. The taxpayer has borne the monetary cost, but the people in the community of Australia bear the personal and the physical cost.

I reiterate what I said about the very ordinary treatment that Mr Keen received at the hands of the officers of the Health Insurance Commission in the dispute over generic drugs last year. In my speech in the grievance debate, I said:

I simply cannot believe the bureaucratic heavy-handedness that Mr Keen has had to put up with throughout his solo campaign to improve the health care system in Australia. Mr Keen has been subjected to extraordinary intimidation and abuse by members of the bureaucracy, by members of the Health Insurance Commission. I instance this one story which, only by a strange coincidence, I have been able to hear. On 12 January 1993, two officers from the Health Insurance Commission—one by the name of Owen Moore—stormed into Stuart Keen's pharmacy at Wingham, and began verbally abusing the man they thought to be Mr Stuart Keen. After realising that the man was not Stuart Keen, but the pharmacist in charge of the pharmacy at the time, they stormed out of the pharmacy as quickly as they had arrived.

The strange twist to this story is that Wingham, being a small town and also being my home town, the locum in attendance that day just happened to be my father. He received the verbal abuse from the officers of the Health Insurance Commission. It was he, as I say, who copped the tirade of these officers. They should not be allowed to do this.

SPEECH.PARA: They should not be allowed to conduct themselves in this unprofessional manner. My speech continued:

The taxpayers in this country pay their taxes to pay these people their wages. It does not take much to act in a civilised manner. These officers certainly have not acted in a civilised manner in the way they have dealt with this issue. Such bureaucratic heavy-handedness should never take place in Australia, regardless of the circumstances.

The ultimate outcome of this exercise was that the summons that was ultimately issued was drawn at least two or three weeks prior to its serving. I believe that the timing of the serving of that notice was to inflict as much discomfort on Mr Keen as possible. I urge the government, in presenting this bill and the measures that are contained therein, to be mindful of the conduct of the Commonwealth officers in this regard—that they act professionally; that they do not prejudge people whom they are investigating; and that they conduct their investigations on the basis that those people are innocent until proven guilty.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not—any more—oppose this legislation, simply because, as other speakers have drawn to the attention of the parliament, over time we have managed to restructure the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill 1993 in a way that guarantees the fundamentals of human rights and justice as we understand them in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, too frequently, under the guise of protecting the revenue—and it is a peculiarity of our system that we seem much more inclined to override the rights of people when we are protecting the revenue—we are inclined to put much larger fines on people when we are protecting the revenue than when we seek to protect public or personal property.

There should never be an occasion when this parliament seeks to empower our bureaucracy beyond the rights it has under our justice system. When we do that, we go back to the circumstances which we have discussed and recognised in this parliament this week and for which our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is overseas; that is, the circumstances which caused people to cross the English Channel to liberate countries which by power of arms had come under the control of a totalitarian regime.

A person who enters someone's premises without a warrant should be labelled a commissar. It is totally improper that any parliament in this country should consider at any time empowering bureaucrats in this fashion. Unfortunately, we have done this to a degree. We have heard about it being done in the customs department. I read in a recent issue of the Business Review Weekly that, unfortunately, it was also done in the tax department. A business was sent broke, through garnishee, because the tax office never managed to get the issue to a Magistrate's Court. Surely, in all of these cases, the right to enter premises, the right to garnishee and the right to confiscate should be authorised only by our courts. In this case, we are referring to the right to investigate. We require that this be authorised by proper warrant.

I would also like to touch on the issues of fraud and overservicing. The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), who has general amnesia, probably forgot that this bill was being debated today. We in Western Australia know of her amnesia. When the parliamentary secretary—

TALK.START.PARA: —You know what the rules are.
—Let me tell you why the minister should be here.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—No, you will not tell him that at all. You should just stick to the bill. You will address your comments through the chair—not across the table.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have every right to tell you why the minister should be here. First, she might learn something. She might learn what 51 per cent of the population who voted for our party at the last election demand of their politicians. I hope that I get the opportunity from time to time to compare the minister with Alan Bond and his son, who also have a shortage of memory. Neither they nor the minister can remember when she went before the royal commission. That is a matter of record.

PARA.TAB: I will get back to this bill because I have a great interest in it. When we talk about overservicing, we must consider exactly what it is. Is a local GP who would probably prefer to reject a lonely pensioner who makes regular visits to him considered to be overservicing? It is use of the GP's valuable time, but he has a family to keep. Is that considered to be overservicing because that lonely person has nowhere else to go and, if you like, abuses the goodwill of the general practitioner? We know it happens. Before I get to my next point, let me say that I accept that people abuse this system genuinely and determinately. Schemes of this nature always cause great problems in our society. There will always be somebody who sees it as easy money. That is the tragedy. But there are other people who find themselves `overservicing' simply because people demand that overservicing.

I refer to a tragic case that was decided in the courts the other day. A woman who is dying of cancer managed to prove to the court that people had been negligent. They had not done enough tests. They had not identified properly her cancer, which was curable. How many tests should a doctor order to be sure? I do not know, but it is an oversimplification to argue that, because the doctor orders too many tests, he is deliberately overservicing or has some dirty deal with the other providers.

TALK.START.PARA: —But many do.

—The government has to make a decision about that. I do not think a couple of blokes who are not even armed with a warrant should be the deciders of that. We have a court system, and that is what that particular fight was all about. In the few minutes left to me, I also want to consider why the government is paranoid about this issue. In its original legislation, the government was proposing to give powers to public servants well beyond what is acceptable in the Australian context.

PARA.TAB: The reason is that Medicare has become a tiger for the finances of the government. At one stage, I had the opportunity to be shadow minister for health.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did a great job!
—I had a better understanding of the problems than most. If you had the same understanding, you might not have the situation where people cannot get into hospitals. This is a fundamental issue.

PARA.TAB: At that time we were spending similar amounts of money on health, education and defence. I do not say that we should necessarily have done it that way, but that was how the money was distributed and that is how the costs added up. I look at the present budget and find that we have gone from a situation in 1984-85 when we spent $4,500 million on education and a bit over $7,000 million on health to a situation today where we are spending $10,000 million on education and $17,000 million on health. All budgets are finite. I think in the process some kids are missing out on education. The balance is starting to get out of hand and I believe that behind closed doors the government is equally concerned about its costs.

I remind the House of an eminent public hospital administrator from New Zealand, a keynote speaker at one time, who said on one occasion that New Zealand had 50,000 people on its public hospital waiting lists and that waiting lists were the means by which public hospital services were rationed. That is a universal fact where these systems operate.

Prior to the introduction of Medicare, private health membership was of the order of 70 per cent. The March 1994 figure is 37.6 per cent. When one measures the private health contributions in those days, one can see where some of the $17,000 million is coming from. The simple fact is that the government has continuing and increasing waiting lists, it is not servicing the community with its scheme, it is now worried about the money and it is therefore proposing a universal attack on the provider. The government is going to send the commissars in. The opposition has prevented the government from doing that by demanding that it meet the normal standards of justice. I remind the House that it is only this week that we celebrated 50 years of preventing that sort of activity in most of Europe. We do not want commissars and legislation that will send the commissars in—be it to protect revenue in the health arena, the tax arena or anywhere else.

I am pleased that the government was convinced—only because we got the support of the minor parties in the Senate—to change its legislation. The government was not convinced to change because it believed in it. It was convinced to change because it knew that it otherwise could not win. It is a great pity that a system that was brought down in good faith by the other side of politics is now struggling because it is running out of money. The facts are carried by the statistics I have given.

The government has problems with Medicare. It will not recognise some of those problems. The parliamentary secretary told us that the age profile is changing. That is correct, but the government's system does not recognise the varying demands. In this system people can forum shop. They can sit out of the process during those years when statistically they are not likely to need the services of Medicare and enter it when, for instance, women become of child bearing age or people get into their older years.

Another tragedy is that forum shopping—that is, people going in and out of the private sector only when they think they are going to need its services—is forcing up premiums. A lot of old people who paid into funds all their working lives find they cannot afford health care when they go on the pension. This is the time they really need it. Something needs to be done about that. The government has to look at the issue of people paying—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are doing it.
—You are not. I have not seen anything that will help those elderly people who pay private health insurance all their lives and then cannot afford it in later life.
—Order! It being 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.
—My question is directed to the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations.
—Where's Brereton this time?
—He is unwell.
—He's been roughed up by the caucus.
—And he's been roughed up by the Caucus.
—And the question!

—The Assistant Minister may recall my question to the Prime Minister last week. I asked the Prime Minister whether changes to the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act announced by the minister were final, to which the Prime Minister replied, `that . . . is a notion you do not have to worry about.' In light of reports this morning that the caucus has strongarmed the minister into changing the unfair changes yet again, is it not a fact that the Prime Minister was wrong again and that he has overestimated the consultative power of the Minister for Industrial Relations to the extent that the minister not only ignores the opinions of the business community but also now ignores the opinions of his own caucus?

—The opinions of the business community were such that our court was being flooded by some very large claims which were never intended to end up in our court. We established a court to which individuals could go when they had no other remedy on the question of unfair dismissal. The situation has occurred that individuals on very large incomes have sought to leave state jurisdictions where they had a perfectly good remedy and hop over into our court; to block our court and to deny individuals who have no other remedy access to our court. They were subverting the very purposes for which we established our court under the act.

PARA.TAB: We have now sought to amend the act—we will debate this tomorrow with you; I am perfectly happy to do so—in order to allow the persons intended to gain access to our court, that is, those who had no access to any other remedy, to now get access, and those who had a remedy that was useful to them can go back to their state jurisdictions and use that. That is a sensible proposition. It is one that employers who are worried about uncapped remedies have suggested to us, and it is one that we wanted to ensure so that our court will be used for its express purpose—the original purpose—which was to allow those who do not have a remedy to use our court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations. Given that the government has a history of successful labour market reforms—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Chifley has the call!

—achieved in a way that protects the basic rights of working men and women, can the assistant minister inform the House of the contribution to these reforms through Australia's association with the International Labour Organisation, and whether Australia is in danger of surrendering its sovereignty by participating in this organisation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Johns The Hon G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for that question. It is true that the Commonwealth government does have a strong record of reform in the area of industrial relations and an equally strong record, I might say, in protecting employees from exploitation and the erosion of their basic rights. I am proud to say that we are continuing that process of reform.

PARA.TAB: It is also true—we have said it many times—that the Industrial Relations Reform Act has introduced minimum entitlements which will ensure Australian workers some basic protections, and that they are based on ILO conventions. But the point is that those ILO conventions are carefully considered by any Commonwealth government—particularly ours—before we use them, before we write Australian laws. We carefully consider conventions, whether ILO or other, before we use them in Australian law.

Australia has been a member of the ILO since 1919, and we have been on the governing board of the ILO for 44 of the last 50 years. So the recent criticism by the honourable member for Bennelong that somehow there is a recent move to rely on ILO conventions when we write Australian law seems strange to me. The honourable member for Bennelong's criticism of the ILO does not seem to slow him down when it comes to taking a trip to Geneva to go to the ILO. For the last four years in a row the honourable member for Bennelong has taken his little trip to Geneva to attend ILO conventions. The only reason you did not go this time is that you wanted to be at home to make sure that you were left on the frontbench when they knocked off the former Leader of the Opposition. That is the only reason you did not attend the ILO convention for the fifth year in a row.

Just to understand how much the honourable member for Bennelong hates the ILO and its conventions, I will quote from an interview with Meet the Press on 29 May. When asked about the ILO, the honourable member for Bennelong said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the Government has used the external affairs powers to import ILO conventions into Australian laws. I don't think foreigners should dictate Australian law . . .

What a terrible thing it is that he accuses us of importing ILO conventions. One of the problems here is that the Leader of the Opposition said today at the National Press Club that he agrees with the honourable member for Bennelong about how terrible it is that we should use ILO conventions and somehow impose them on Australian laws. That is his view. He expressed it today. Yes, he confirms it. He hates the ILO.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition also said today, `I want to begin today by asking you to cast your minds back to where we were 11 years ago.' I am going to cast my mind back 11 years and quote from an article headed `The future of Australian industrial relations' by Alexander Downer, Australian Chamber of Commerce. This is the same Alexander Downer who today berated us for introducing ILO conventions into Australia. Having told us today to cast our minds back 11 years, I will cast them back 10 years when, in the context of a discussion on wage flexibility and productivity, Mr Downer said:

ANSWER.PARA: The obstacle to making such amendments to the Act is thought to be constitutional. We believe that obstacle can be overcome by the use of the Commonwealth's corporations power, its trade and commerce power and (more controversially) its external affairs power (based on the Conventions of the I.L.O. to which Australia is a party).

I have cast my mind back 11 years. The Leader of the Opposition is trying to jump on the honourable member for Bennelong's bandwagon, thinking it would be a great idea if we suggested that the ILO conventions are a terrible thing. That is not what you wrote 10 years ago when you thought it was absolutely critical to change the industrial relations system in Australia by reference to the ILO and its conventions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations. I acknowledge his newfound concern for the rights of workers. I draw the minister's attention to a policy developed within his department entitled `Union participation and membership—human resource policy guide' of 8 March 1994. Is the minister aware that this document provides for departmental officers to give union delegates access to information about staff for the purpose of recruiting them into the appropriate union? Does such information include name, designation, status—whether full time or part-time—and work location? Is the minister also aware that to provide such information to a third party, such as a trade union, without the approval of the employee concerned is in breach of principle 11 of the Privacy Act 1988?
—I do not know of the document, but keep this in mind—
—Cast your mind back 10 years.

—The document is only months old; I do not have to cast my mind back 10 years. Keep this in mind: there is no preference for unionists and there is no discrimination on the basis of whether or not you are or are not a unionist. That is the position we will adhere to, and I am more than happy to have a look at those guidelines.
—Mr Speaker, I seek leave to table the departmental minute.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware of claims that Australian society has become more unequal over recent years? Does the government believe that family payments have a role in income redistribution?

—There has been some discussion in recent times about trends in terms of income and equality in this country and in other countries. A lot of that discussion has been rather misleading, particularly in this chamber. It is an area where international comparisons and comparisons over time are difficult, because a whole range of factors have to be included. As well as earnings and cash incomes, we have to take into account social security transfer payments, the effect of the tax system and the effect of the social wage. Compiling internationally comparable statistics in those areas is extraordinarily difficult.

PARA.TAB: But many of the figures that have been quoted are just thoroughly misleading. A couple of days ago in this House, the Leader of the Opposition referred to some ABS material which explicitly referred only to earnings. There was no reference to movements in the social wage, improvements in the social security system and changes in the tax system over the course of the 1980s. When those factors are taken into consideration, the situation changes quite markedly. How can we possibly talk sensibly about an issue like that, without taking into account the introduction of Medicare and the impact on people's living standards that flows from that, or the huge increases in the real value of family payments and other social security payments that have occurred over the course of the 1980s? It is ludicrous. There is no doubt that, if we factor those considerations in, the picture changes quite markedly.

It is interesting that the opposition is now professing concern about income inequalities and inequality issues and equity issues generally. What a piece of crass hypocrisy. Let us look at its record and compare it with ours. Over the course of our tenure of office, all social security payments directed to low income earners have improved significantly as against the Henderson poverty line. There is no question about that. The Henderson poverty line itself has risen by 16 per cent in real terms. If we look at the number of social security pensions, in our term of office they have gone up 15 per cent. During the Fraser years—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I have pretty good hearing, but when the minister turns around like that, I cannot hear what he is saying.
—The Minister for Social Security might address his remarks through the chair and the microphone.

—I was trying to address myself to a receptive audience. As I was saying, under us, pensions have risen 15 per cent in real terms. During the Fraser years—and let us emphasise that the Leader of the Opposition extols the Fraser years as a period of good government—pensions went down by two per cent. The real value of unemployment payments went down by 18 per cent in real terms during the Fraser years. Under us, with the changes in rent assistance, for an unemployed person renting privately, it is up 57 per cent in real terms. During the Fraser years payments to sole parents were down by four per cent in real terms. Under us again, if we take a sole parent with two children renting privately, real income is up by 32 per cent. That is the comparison, and these are the people who profess some concern about social equity and equality—and it is utterly hypocritical.

PARA.TAB: We do not know where the opposition stands on the current debate about family payments because the opposition spokesperson on this issue has not said anything of substance on it. I had my staff engage in a major research project today. We scoured all 95 of his issued press releases. We did a computerised search of the total corpus of his speeches. There was not one significant reference to a matter of substance. The nearest thing to a matter of substance that we could find was a disquisition extolling the virtues of both the therapeutic and social value of lawn bowls. That was the nearest thing we could find to a substantive comment on social policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This is the first anniversary of your admonition last month to ministers with regard to the length of their replies. This minister is making a mockery of question time with his conduct and his answer. I ask that you direct him to bring his answer to a conclusion.
—Order! The minister was responding to the question, but I would suggest that he look at the time that he is taking to do so.

—Just to wind up, Mr Speaker—this is the final point: we have no comment from the opposition spokesperson on social security; we have a variety of proposals relating to family issues. One is from the honourable member for Bennelong in relation to income splitting. It is unambiguously regressive; it severely affects people on low incomes. One proposal from Senator Minchin is to take all family payments and divide them up per child. Again, that is severely regressive. There is a variation on that theme from the honourable member for Warringah. Similarly, it is severely regressive. One of the things that all their proposals in this area have in common is their regressivity. Another characteristic they have in common is that they provide added disincentives for women's participation in the work force. It is absolutely farcical for this crowd to be professing any concern about social equity or inequality.

—My question is addressed to the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations. No doubt the assistant minister would be aware that the Goss Labor government in Queensland is supporting the Victorian government's current High Court challenge to the Industrial Relations Reform Act. What are the features of the legislation that have prompted a Labor government, such as the Goss government, to challenge it?
—The Goss Labor government is the only state government in Australia which has mirror legislation to our own. So the Goss Labor government—
—Why is it challenging it?

—I have no idea why it is challenging it. I am not going to speak for the Goss Labor government. Let me remind honourable members that the Goss Labor government is the only state government in Australia that has mirror legislation to our own. We have joint industrial inspectorates. We have joint courts and tribunals. In other words, the Queensland Labor government is satisfied with the Industrial Relations Reform Act. It is satisfied with the Commonwealth's industrial relations system and has mirror legislation.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Can the Attorney-General inform the House of progress on the review of the civil marriage celebrants program? Can he inform the House of other proposals regarding the institution of marriage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lavarch The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many honourable members no doubt receive representations in their electorate offices from those seeking to become civil marriage celebrants. There has been a system in place where the views of individual members of parliament have been sought on the suitability of marriage celebrants. This system has had considerable problems. The most particular problem has been a very large backlog in processing applications. As at November of last year, when a moratorium was placed on the receipt of further applications, there were something like 2,500 outstanding applications.

PARA.TAB: I have initiated a review of the program under the day-to-day control of the parliamentary secretary, the honourable member for Makin. That review is looking at the processing of a new system, including the level of charges imposed by celebrants, whether the existing restrictions on celebrants advertising their own services should remain, and whether possible changes to limitations on the style and conduct of ceremonies should be reviewed. It is expected that the outcome of this review will be finalised and that the new system will be in place early next year.

The honourable member for Banks also asked me if I have seen other proposals regarding the institution of marriage. Like other members, no doubt, I was drawn to the headline `Lib MP's plan to ban marriage for a year' in the Canberra Times this morning. The article said:
The latest idea from the Liberals' "save the family" Lyons Forum is to ban marriage until 12 months after intending spouses notify the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member for Menzies, who is also the parliamentary secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, said yesterday:
It was vital to make it harder to get married.

PARA.TAB: An impending child would not be an exception under Mr Andrews' scheme but the government could grant an exemption "in special circumstances, such as that a couple has known each other for many years".

ANSWER.PARA: I have always thought the honourable member for Menzies to be a decent fellow and a rather earnest member. But I do not know whether he really is one of life's romantics. He obviously is not one who subscribes to the idea of love at first sight.

PARA.TAB: I am, of course, very interested in this particular scheme and I would like to know how we could possibly operate such a one-year ban on marriage. No doubt there would be some sort of registration and licensing scheme for engaged people so the government is notified. Once we had that sort of scheme, no doubt a marriage avoidance industry would develop. Maybe couples after their first date, to cut the waiting time, would surreptitiously get themselves registered just on the off-chance that they want to be married in the future. Maybe we could get a scheme like that put into place.

In the past we have had the honourable member for Bennelong wanting to take Australia back to the days of the white picket fence and the Kingswood in everyone's driveway. It seems that the honourable member for Menzies wants to take us back a little beyond that—maybe back to the days of Jane Austen and her great novels and the joys of the very long engagement. This might be very good stuff for novels, but I do not know if it is a particularly realistic way to appraise what are very serious issues. The fact is that the average age for marriage in Australia is 27 for men and 25 for women. I think we can safely assume that Australian men and women are old enough to make their own decisions as to whether they think it is appropriate for them to be married, without the government deciding for them.

An important work by the Australian Institute of Family Studies on family formation indicates that Australia does not have a problem with hasty marriages. People going to Reno and having the weekend honeymoon in Las Vegas is not really an Australian experience. There is no evidence of people rushing into marriage. I think the scheme being proposed by the honourable member for Menzies would merely lead to more de facto relationships, which I gather the honourable member does not particularly support.

We have heard many statements from the parliamentary secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition saying that government should not be trying to control people's lives and should not be involved in people's personal lives. I suggest that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition try to get his parliamentary secretary in line and get some decent policies to address these serious important social issues.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cleary Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also have a question for the Attorney-General. Despite the offerings of former broadcaster Terry Lane and filmmaker Don Parham on the issue of violence against women, feminists continue to argue that the criminal justice system is biased against women. Contrary to the Victorian Law Reform Commission's 1989 finding that there was no gender bias in the law of provocation, critics, including myself, believe, as Dr Adrian Howe of La Trobe University said:

QUESTION.PARA: The commission suffered from its singular failure to address the key issues raised by feminist analysts as well as from a faulty empirical study.

Given your government's expressed concern for the rights of women, will you guarantee to put the issue of the defence of provocation, including its gender biased interpretation by some judges, on the agenda at the next meeting of state and federal attorneys-general?

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the longstanding commitment of the honourable member in this area. He has on other occasions spoken about this issue in the House. Clearly, the criminal system and the defence of provocation are matters for Australian states, given that the criminal law is a matter for state jurisdictions. There is an attempt to achieve some national uniformity in our criminal laws. There is a project which does report to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General on the process of achieving uniformity in criminal matters. This committee responded to the Gibbs committee, which did a very detailed investigation into the criminal laws of this country.

PARA.TAB: I certainly can give an undertaking to the honourable member that state Attorneys and the Commonwealth, at each of their meetings, discuss questions of the development of the criminal law. I will make sure that the particular issues which the honourable member raises are raised at the next meeting, which I understand is in the latter half of July.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware that in just over three weeks, on 1 July, it will be the first anniversary of the Concord Repatriation Hospital's integration into the New South Wales state health system? As this is the largest transfer of an institution between the Commonwealth and any state government since the end of the Second World War and as it has impacted on the welfare of over 100,000 New South Wales veterans, could the minister inform the House as to the success of the integration process and how it has impacted upon the health care needs of the veterans from that state?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. I am aware that 1 July marks the 12-month anniversary of the transfer—one of the largest moves of an institution between levels of government since the end of World War II—of Concord Repatriation Hospital into the state system. I will be attending a special ceremony to mark the occasion on 1 July. I am sure that, as the hospital is in her electorate, the honourable member for Lowe will be there.

PARA.TAB: Integration in New South Wales has guaranteed the hospital's future as a first-class teaching institution and its continuing role of caring for veterans and war widows as well as community patients. The changeover has also enabled some 120,000 New South Wales veterans and war widows entitled to repatriation health care to gain access to the repatriation private patients scheme.

The repatriation private patients scheme comes into operation when there is an integration to a state system or a privatisation of a repatriation hospital. That means that veterans no longer have to go to the appropriate repatriation hospital. They can go to their local public hospital and be treated as a private patient in shared accommodation without any authority from anyone.

As we expected, before integration the veteran intake at Concord was approximately 50 per cent of the total number of patients. That has now decreased to 35 per cent, which means that veterans are taking the option of going along to their own public hospital, the place that is closest to them, throughout New South Wales, and the ACT for that matter. I would imagine that they would do that because they would like to be able to have visits from their family, friends and relatives who are close to them.

I understand that since integration there have been approximately 50,000 episodes of care. From that 50,000 we have had only 50 formal complaints about the service. I understand that that represents approximately 0.1 per cent of the total episodes of care. More importantly, it can be said that there have been fewer complaints since the hospital has been integrated with the state system than before integration.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you done with Greenslopes?

—We can talk about that later on. In the event that a public hospital is not available in a veteran's particular area, that veteran can go to any one of 100 private contracted hospitals in New South Wales if he has to wait an unreasonable length of time.

PARA.TAB: As another backup, if veterans cannot find a contracted hospital and have to wait too long, they can go to a private hospital of their choice to get the appropriate treatment, provided they have the appropriate information. As I said, overall the system has worked well. In any transfer like this, there will always be some complaints. I am aware of letters of complaint received by honourable members in New South Wales. I understand that as soon as those complaints were put forward the Concord Repatriation Hospital staff moved very quickly to fix them up.

In conclusion, I reassure the House that this government remains committed to the provision of quality health care for veterans and war widows. We recognise their very special standing in the community that they have served so well. We will continue to be responsible for their health and wellbeing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it not the case that, firstly, there is already a bill before the House which will amend the IR act to allow the continuation of youth wages; secondly, you are about to introduce further amendments to that bill to amend its inept, unfair termination provisions and those amendments in turn are to be further amended as a result of your caucus decision; thirdly, employers attempting to use the enterprise flexibility provisions are being threatened and intimidated by unions or having their workshops unionised; and, fourthly, the states are challenging the legislation in the High Court, the employers are challenging it in the ILO and the OECD has condemned your policy as being too little too late? Why do you not admit that your new act is unworkable and against Australia's interests and that the most sensible thing to do would be to scrap the whole thing entirely?

—The amendments that we will be introducing tomorrow, which we will no doubt debate, relating to youth wages are amendments that employers sought. We thought it was a good idea to provide a three-year period over which we could have a shift in the system from wages based on age to wages based on skills. I think the amendments which we will introduce dealing with unfair dismissal have been well canvassed. I will be keen to debate those tomorrow also.

PARA.TAB: In the main, the entire nature of the reform act remains and stands solid. The signal issue which you and some of your friends have suggested was a great problem—that is, the question of unfair dismissal—and on the basis of which you have sought to paint black the entire reform act is wrong. On the question of unfair dismissal, we maintain that every Australian worker can be fairly dismissed; no Australian worker should be unfairly dismissed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs seen recent media reports about the incidence of female infanticide in India? Can Australia do something to assist India in its efforts to eliminate this horrifying practice?

—I have seen those reports. I think they were occasioned by an appeal launched by Plan Australia—the successor to Foster Parents Plan—aimed at eliminating this horrible practice. It is a custom which unfortunately has been known in India and other countries for a rather long time—indeed, in India since the days of the British Raj.
—And before.
—I acknowledge the interjection of the honourable member. It has arisen in response to economic necessity and, in particular, to the practice of providing dowries for female children.
—It was the fault of the Fraser government.
—No, I do not believe it was the fault of the Fraser government. I think the Fraser government had a lot to be blamed for, but I do not agree that it was responsible for that.

PARA.TAB: The practice is not confined to India. The horrifying thing about this is that these young children are not dying because of a lack of food, diarrhoea, malnutrition or a lack of health facilities; they are dying as a result of deliberate acts, often by the father of the family or the mother-in-law.

Making this practice illegal will not stamp it out. I emphasise that it is not a practice which is condoned by the government of India. As it is bred of economic necessity, we need to make progress by paying attention to the economic position of women. They and female children should be treated not as an economic burden but as an asset to the family and the community. The education of women and girls is central to that.

In support of Plan Australia's appeal, the government has recently made a grant of $122,000. That will be distributed through a number of aid agencies in India. Plan itself is appealing for $100,000 to put with that government subsidy. I take this opportunity to commend to all members of the House and the people of Australia an appeal which I hope they will respond to with their usual generosity.

Plan Australia, in running this program, is building on a very successful program which is already being run in India. It has resulted in the saving of the lives of 700 baby girls. There is a number of communities, particularly in Tamil Nadu, where the practice of female infanticide has been stamped out. The program will now expand that program to four or five times that number of villages, identifying women at risk. Having identified pregnant women, it will provide them with counselling, education and economic opportunity.

It will improve the capacity of women to earn an income, thus enabling them to become an asset to their family rather than a burden. It will have the spin-off benefit of providing a focus for the education of women, which, if maintained, can make a major contribution, in ways which AIDAB's women in development program supports, to the long-term development of India. I commend this appeal to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Finance admit that his backflip over the cabinet's original decision to sell ANL to anyone, including foreigners, is nothing more than a charade and that the government's real agenda is to sell ANL to the Japanese owned K Line whilst going through the motions of debate on the issue at the ALP conference in September? When will the minister admit that this current backflip is nothing more than a blatant act of dishonesty designed to quieten the unions and the Left of the ALP until the sale of ANL can be finalised?
—No; no; no; no.

—Has the Minister for Consumer Affairs seen reports that the Ombudsman is concerned about the implications of the growing use of the term `ombudsman' by companies and others? Do these reports indicate that the Ombudsman is particularly concerned that consumers could be led by the term to put unjustifiable confidence in the resolution of disputes they may have with sellers of goods and services? Can the minister advise honourable members whether or not she shares the Ombudsman's concerns on this issue?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. There is a deal of concern about this matter, and it is the growing use of the term `ombudsman' that is causing this concern. In fact, it has been expressed to me by the current Commonwealth Ombudsman, Philippa Smith, the previous banking ombudsman, Graham McDonald, and his counterparts in the UK, New Zealand and Ireland, all of whom visited Australia recently.

PARA.TAB: They all make the same comment that specific criteria should always attach to the appointment of an ombudsman. These criteria should include these matters: the ombudsman must be accountable to an independent body, such as the parliament; the ombudsman must be independent of the organisations being investigated; and the ombudsman's decisions must be able to be enforced. They all make the same comments. I will have to look at this matter. The general problem for consumers is that if—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ombudsperson. Say it.
—Order!

—If ombudsmen are appointed all over the place, the value of the term is downgraded—it becomes meaningless; people cannot trust an appointment which they should be able to trust; and it is extremely confusing for consumers. Other countries have dealt with this problem. The UK has an association that sets criteria. New Zealand has an act of parliament that sets criteria. So I will be answering Philippa Smith's concerns and looking at the best way to deal with this matter. We might have to have a set of criteria in a self-regulatory code and an agreement between ministers defining the appropriate use of the term. I will look at it.
—My question is directed to the Attorney-General.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Warringah has the call.

—I refer the Attorney-General to the Prime Minister's statement to the President of France that there is something seriously wrong with the Australian constitution. Why is the Prime Minister talking about republicanism to the President of France, whose country has had five tries at establishing a decent republic? Is the Prime Minister in need of French advice? Why does the Prime Minister always talk down our country overseas? Why is he talking about a republic at all, given that the Minister for Finance has said that no referendum should take place until at least the end of the decade?

—In my observations, the Prime Minister never talks down this country; he talks up this country and this country's interests. The honourable member might disagree—and I accept that he does—with the concept of Australia becoming a republic. I do not dispute the genuineness of his view that Australia's best interest is served by remaining with the constitutional monarchy. But he should not impute to the Prime Minister, as he does, some sort of bad motive or attack upon this country.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister is a proud Australian. He always promotes the interests of this country. He is fully entitled, as the Prime Minister of his country, to discuss with the President of France—as he is with any other foreign leader—matters of mutual interest. I am certain that the Prime Minister would be interested in the views of a country such as France, which has a long and proud tradition of democratic government. Given that the Prime Minister is there at a time when we are remembering the efforts of all allied and free nations to successfully fight the Second World War and the forces of fascism, it is inappropriate for the honourable member to try to score tawdry and cheap political points by even raising this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. What action is the government taking to ensure that dangerous weapons such as nunchakus and pistol grip crossbows are not brought into this country and endangering community safety?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. Two weeks ago I represented the Commonwealth at a meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council, at which I put forward a proposal on the Commonwealth's behalf to strengthen the provisions of the Customs Act that would prevent the importation into Australia of some dangerous weapons. The motivation for this action on the Commonwealth's behalf is that, currently, a number of dangerous weapons such as pistol grip crossbows, nunchakus, blow pipes and ballistic knives are capable of being brought into the country, transferred across state boundaries and sold into state jurisdictions where under state law their possession is illegal. That obviously represents a considerable threat in relation to law enforcement and community safety. It was a matter which state and territory governments were quite concerned about.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the discussions that occurred at the Police Ministers Council, police ministers agreed with the Commonwealth's proposal, and the situation is now clear. From henceforth, those weapons of the kind that I have described will be listed and prohibited from entry into Australia unless a specific lawful authority issued by the state firearms authority is made known to the minister for customs so that that particular weapon can be imported in particular circumstances. Legitimate collections and the like might be exempted in particular circumstances. Obviously, I believe this is a matter which goes towards better and more effective protection of the community's interests.

A number of other matters were followed up as a result of the police ministers' discussions of these issues. Most importantly, the decision was taken to look at the present situation where there are eight different jurisdictions, each with different lists of dangerous goods which are prohibited in state jurisdictions. That is confusing. It will also mean that, from time to time, dangerous goods can be brought into this country and be sold across state boundaries in those circumstances I have described. All police ministers have agreed to go back to their jurisdictions and to report to the next Police Ministers Council to see whether we can get greater uniformity so that that circumstance does not arise and community safety is better improved.

Finally, police ministers also agreed to look at the question of replica weapons. Currently, model or replica weapons are allowed to be brought into and possessed in Australia, some of which are extraordinarily lifelike and can hardly be distinguished from the real item on superficial inspection. Whilst the replica itself represents no danger, I think it needs no little imagination to realise the potential for tragedy that exists when such replicas are in the hands of persons. Mistakes may be readily made and lives may be lost as a result of mistakes being made. All police ministers have agreed to look at the question. They believe there is a real issue as to whether or not the importation, ownership, possession or sale of such replicas should be permitted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to you, Mr Speaker, relates to the Main Committee. Standing order 279 reads:

PARA.TAB: All proceedings of the Main Committee shall be recorded by the Clerk of the Committee and such records shall constitute the Minutes of Proceedings of the Committee and shall form part of the Votes and Proceedings of the House for that sitting.

QUESTION.PARA: Page 188 of the House of Representatives Practice, which outlines the provisions of section 38 of the Australian constitution, reads:

PARA.TAB: A Member's place becomes vacant if, without permission of the House, he does not attend the House for 2 consecutive months of any session of the Parliament.

QUESTION.PARA: Attendance in this chamber is recorded by the Sergeant-at-Arms, but I understand that no attendance records are kept in the Main Committee. While it is extremely unlikely that a member would attend only the Main Committee and not the House of Representatives chamber on any particular sitting day, and certainly not for two months, does attendance at the Main Committee constitute attendance in parliament? If so, how is this to be recorded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Fisher for his question. I can advise him that, while all members of the House are potentially members of the Main Committee, attendance in the Main Committee alone is not considered to be attendance in the House of Representatives chamber. This is also considered to be the case with other committees of the House or joint committees created pursuant to legislation, the standing orders or resolutions of the House or Houses. While members of the House are encouraged to attend the Main Committee for short or more significant periods, it is not proposed at this stage to record the attendance of members there. Therefore, the short answer is: be here.

—My question to you, Mr Speaker, relates to the time allocated to private members' business. It is my understanding that it has been a long tradition in this place for backbench members to jealously guard their time for private members' business. On Monday of this week, there were only three speakers in the grievance debate. Therefore, three members were denied the opportunity to raise issues which were important to them. Given the new arrangements for the operations of this House and the other chamber, how can you now guarantee that the time allocated to private members' business will not be intruded into by government business or other operations of this House?

—In response to the honourable member's question, I do not think that I can guarantee that. What I can do, however, since you have raised it as a question to me, is draw it to the attention of the Leader of the House and others who program the business, particularly on a Monday. I, like the honourable member for La Trobe, believe that the opportunities for backbenchers, through private members' business, should be protected.

—Mr Speaker, I wish to raise a matter of privilege. This morning I was advised that defamation writs had been served on a Mr Roland John Ellems and on a Mr Ayden Cross, both of whom are resident on the Gold Coast in Queensland. The writs were issued, I believe, by Mr Peter Laurance. Mr Ellems was the signatory of an affidavit that I read into Hansard on 6 June, the subject of which also involved Mr Cross. The affidavit I read into Hansard was solely sworn by Mr Ellems for use in this parliament and had not to my knowledge been communicated to anyone outside this parliament before I read it on 6 June.

PARA.TAB: I am advised, therefore, that the affidavit and its use attracts the full protection of parliamentary privilege. The issuing of these writs by Mr Laurance constitutes a prima facie case of contempt of parliament attacking the very basis of the protection of our parliamentary privilege.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Kennedy has the call.

—The testimony of Mr Ellems is vitally important to the continued performance of my work as a member of parliament in this matter and this writ will improperly interfere with my ability to do my job. Therefore, I would like to refer the actions of Mr Laurance to the privileges committee of this place.
—I will look into the matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence to provide an additional answer.
—The minister may proceed.
—On Monday the honourable member for Tangney asked me a question, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, which read:

ANSWER.PARA: The minister is aware that since 1982 the United Nations Working Group on Indigenous Populations has been drafting a Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. At the 11th session of the working group, in 1993, the draft was recast so that it states that indigenous peoples have the right to self-determination, including the right freely to determine their political status. In other words, the draft declaration provides for indigenous peoples to have the right to secede from sovereign states and to form independent nations. Will the minister confirm that while the draft declaration contains a provision to that effect the government will not be supporting it in any international forum?

The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question. The government supports the right of self-determination of indigenous peoples consistent with national sovereignty. This right was recognised by the Commonwealth and all state and territory governments in their response to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

PARA.TAB: At previous sessions of the United Nations Working Group on Indigenous Populations, the Australian delegation has called for the inclusion, in that part of the draft declaration dealing with self-determination, of a reference to the Declaration on Principles of International Law on Friendly Relations and Cooperation among States in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations. That declaration states that self-determination `shall not be construed as authorising or encouraging any action which would dismember or impair, totally or in part, the territorial integrity of sovereign or independent states', so long as the governments of those states are representative of their peoples as a whole. I note that that language was also included in article 2 of the Vienna Declaration adopted by the World Conference on Human Rights in 1993.

The Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples is in draft form only at this stage and will be the subject of a thorough process of negotiation which we expect will take some years to complete. There will be ample time for careful consideration of all the issues and for input from interested parties both at the national level and at the international level. When the Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples is finally adopted, moreover, it will not be legally binding on any country but will rather be an aspirational document which establishes standards that governments throughout the world can work towards. Given that the process of consultation will not take place until the draft is finally adopted by the Sub-commission on Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities, the government considers it premature to consider its final negotiating position in relation to this article and the declaration as a whole at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.
—In question time today, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) claimed that a family wage proposal made by me is regressive. Far from it, it treats everyone absolutely equally—

PARA.TAB: Mr McGauran interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he is not, and I do not need the advice of the honourable member for Gippsland.
—The minister neglected to quote the judgment of a former Labor MP: `I like the proposal of Tony Abbott.'
—Resume your seat. There is no personal explanation in that at all.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, Mr Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—Yesterday in the parliament the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) referred to me by saying, `The honourable member was a member of the former National Party government in his state.' Although in this place I was certainly privileged to be a member of the party now led in this place by my good friend the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), as I have never been a member of the Queensland parliament, it is impossible for me to have been a member of the Queensland National Party government. I am not suggesting anything sinister in the misrepresentation; I just want to set the record straight.
—In light of the comments by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), I also wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—Whilst I have a great respect for the Hansard reporters, and I am sure that they have reported what I said here correctly, it was certainly not my intention at all to say what is claimed. I am well aware that the honourable member for Fisher was not a member of the National Party government in Queensland. I would like to clear that up. As interjectors mentioned before, even Joh Bjelke-Petersen knew where to draw the line, but I draw to the honourable member's attention that the only former member of the National Party government in Queensland here is the honourable member for Kennedy—
—Resume your seat!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order simply because it is the only way that I can draw your attention to the second occasion within the last week in which the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) has failed to take proper account of the proceedings before this House. PARA.TAB: Last week, the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) advised the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and me that there was to be no further response to a parliamentary committee report on Indonesia from the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I totally accept that the minister was not aware of the circumstances, because the foreign minister had not advised him.

Today, we have the circumstance where technically there is almost a breach of privilege because the government's response to a report is to be tabled in this House before the report itself has been presented to this House. While I would accept that the Senate does have different proceedings and a different timetable, I believe it totally inappropriate for the Minister for Foreign Affairs to have acted in such a fashion that the report has not been presented here but that his response to that report has now been tabled. TALK.START.PARA: —I think all members of this place would certainly endorse the last part of the honourable member's comments.
