INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The shambolic conduct of industrial relations policy by the Minister for Industrial Relations.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on 28 March this year, there were a number of press reports about the imminent reshuffle of the federal cabinet consequent upon the sudden resignation of former Senator Richardson as the Minister for Health. One of those reports spoke of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton). It said that the minister had:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . first tried to unload his industrial relations job in the reshuffle last December, but Mr Keating appears determined to keep him in the post.

The truth is that in the last seven months the Minister for Industrial Relations has twice tried to unload his responsibility as Minister for Industrial Relations. We on this side of the House believe that the events of the past few days have confirmed the reason why the minister has wanted to unload his responsibility: that is, the conduct of industrial relations in Australia has degenerated into an absolute shambles under the administration of this minister. Industrial relations is, without question, the nerve centre—or ought to be the nerve centre—of micro-economic reform in this country. Unless you reform the industrial relations system of this country, you will never make the Australian economy the modern, progressive, competitive economy that it needs to be if we are to reap the full rewards of that enormous, burgeoning market in the Asia-Pacific region.

PARA.TAB: It is not enough for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to wander the highways and the byways of the world and say, `Asia is where our future is,' unless we are able to take advantage of that future. We are not the only country that sees the Asia-Pacific region, with 500 million middle-class consumers by the year 2000, as an enormous market. Unless we fit ourselves for the task of grabbing our share of that market, we will fall behind others who will get there before us.

There is no area that is more important in fitting ourselves out as a nation, as a modern, progressive economy, than the area of industrial relations. That is why it is a national disgrace that industrial relations policy has become such a shambles. That is why it is a national disgrace that you now have a disinterested, lazy, part-time minister looking after the industrial relations portfolio—a man who, self-professedly, is not interested in industrial relations any more. He wants to cut deals about the transport needs of this country. He is not interested in giving us a modern industrial relations system.

This shambles, quite appropriately enough, goes back to a speech made by the prime culprit himself, the Prime Minister of Australia. On 21 April 1993, just after the federal election in March 1993, he addressed a meeting of the Institute of Company Directors in Melbourne. He tried to persuade those company directors—and it was reflected in the columns of the Australian newspapers the following day—that the Keating regime after March of last year was going to be a regime that delivered a white-hot industrial relations revolution.

So the Prime Minister's acolyte in the Australian Financial Review reported `Keating's IR revolution'. That is what we were promised. He promised us that he was going to end 90 years of centralised wage fixing. He was going to unveil a major deregulation of the labour market to enable individual firms to negotiate wages based on productivity improvement. Would that he had done that. He would have been serving the national interest well if he had delivered on that high blown rhetoric.

The truth, of course, is that he never intended to do that. It was another case of `Keatingspeak'—say one thing and do the complete opposite. He is a past master at Keatingspeak—you say one thing, you tell the world you will reform the industrial relations system and then you set out handing over more power to those who got you back into power. As soon as the ink was dry on that speech and the presses had rolled with their reports of it, the telephones rang hot. Martin Ferguson rang up, Bill Kelty rang up, Jennie George rang up, Iain Ross rang up, John Halfpenny rang up and Michael Easson—he still had a job then—rang up too. They all said, `Hang on, brother, you can't do this. We bankrolled you back into office. We're not going to cop anything less than a 100 per cent down payment on our getting you returned to power.'

So bit by bit we saw this great retreat, this long retreat from Moscow, from the high water mark of this high blown rhetoric, this long retreat from those high ideals that Keating had given to the business community of Australia. Month by month those opposite retreated. The Minister for Industrial Relations said that he was going to negotiate with everybody. He did not negotiate with anybody; he took his running instructions from ACTU House.

Do you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that when the announcement of what would be in the Industrial Relations Act was made, it was not in the form of a press statement from the minister. It was a briefing paper from ACTU House on which all the press stories were written. The government was as blatant as that. It was not even shamefaced about it. There was not even a pretence of pretending that this government was seriously governing in the national interest.

I remind the House of those immortal, never to be forgotten words of Jennie George. When she was told that the employers did not like the act, she said, `What they have to understand is that they lost the election and we won it.' That is what it was all about. It was winner takes all legislation of the worst kind, and to hell with the national interest. That did not come into it. Instead of our being given a decent reform of the industrial relations system, a bad system was made worse. It would have been better if the minister had done nothing at all.

I did not expect the government to adopt jobsback after it won the election. I would have gladly applauded it if it had. At least I did not think it was going to make the system worse, but that is what it has done. It has confused the business community, discouraged small business from employing unemployed Australians, weakened our international competitive position, loaded already excessively high on-costs for the employment of people with even further burdens, and it has further hobbled our capacity to become a more productive nation with the introduction of this legislation.

The new law has made matters infinitely worse, particularly for small business. I have four objections to it and I believe that they stand without criticism or reproof by the government. They relate to what is wrong with this legislation and why it ought to be not partially scrapped, not amended in a tiny particular, but scrapped altogether. To start with, there is no genuine enterprise bargaining for non-trade unionists. When the Prime Minister made this speech and promised this white-hot industrial relations revolution, the key point he made was that he would make enterprise bargaining available to the non-union sector of the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened?

—I will tell you what has happened: his mates in the union movement, particularly the building unions in Victoria, said, `Look, if anybody thinks that non-unionists are going to be able to negotiate enterprise bargains, they ought to understand one thing, and that is that we are going to come down on them like a ton of bricks.' Of course, in the building industry in Victoria, that has a double meaning, literally and metaphorically. People do come down on you like a ton of bricks in the building industry in Victoria. That is the first objection.

PARA.TAB: Then there has been the continued use—illicit use in my view—of the external affairs power. I was absolutely delighted that the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Johns) at the dispatch box got up at question time in answer to a dorothy dixer and had a go at us over the external affairs power. If you think some article written 11 years ago by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) when he occupied a position with the Australian Chamber of Commerce is going to deter the opposition from attacking you for running cap in hand to foreigners to distort the domestic law of Australia, you have another think coming.

You have done more to give away the independence of Australia by the foreign debt you have run up and by the way you run off to these bureaucrats in Geneva begging them to change our domestic law than any invading army could have done. You have been the arch-sellers-out of Australian national pride and independence. You have done it not only by denigrating our symbols but also by subverting our sound currency and by handing over the control of our laws to foreign committees whose members are often from countries who have no regard at all for human rights.

What sorts of human rights records do some of the countries represented on the UN Human Rights Committee really have? What kinds of human rights are there for women, for example, in a country like Senegal? These are the sorts of committees that you are making this country subservient to and you have the infernal gall to talk about becoming a republic and ripping out of our flag the symbol of a country that has done more to defend human rights than most of the countries you now take your marching orders from. That is the measure of your respect for the institutions, history and culture of this country. That association to this debate is very basic—

TALK.START.PARA: —And obvious.
—And obvious.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the objectionable features of this act is the extraordinary lengths the government has gone to to use the external affairs power of the constitution. But worse than that is the way in which the destruction of the secondary boycott protections has placed trade unions, once again, above the law.

PARA.TAB: For 15 years it was possible in this country to say that if somebody, and that somebody was a company, destroyed my business, I could take it to court and get an injunction and damages against it. If a union destroyed my business I could do the same thing. You could proudly say that in Australia for 15 years; you can say it no longer. Now if you wreck my business I can take you to court, but if your union mates wreck my business I am wrecked, and I do not have any redress. If you think that is fair, if you think that is Australian justice, if you think that is a fair go Australian style, then your values and attitudes are completely different from those of most Australians.

The other thing that we strongly object to is the enormous burdens that this legislation has placed on small business in Australia. You will not get the unemployed back to work unless you get small business re-employing people. You must know that at the moment big companies are filling their order books but they are still putting off staff. If you go to any board lunch anywhere in Australia you will get that same story—they are still reducing their staff.

The only hope we have of getting people back to work in this country is to give incentives to small business to take on more employees. What does this act do? It does the exact opposite. It provides disincentives for the recruitment of more people. It makes it more expensive, threatening, dubious, doubtful and frightening to take on more staff. If you say to somebody, `Look, if you put a bloke on, you'll find it very hard, nigh impossible, to get rid of him if he proves to be unsatisfactory,' the reaction is, `I'll buy another computer. I'll get my existing staff to work a bit harder.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Use some outsource.

—They will use some outsource. They will do anything but take on a full-time employee. If you ask any small businessmen or businesswomen in the public galleries today, they will nod their heads and know exactly what I am saying. It is just ordinary, basic commonsense, but you, on the other side, do not seem to understand that.

PARA.TAB: You have this incredible shambles. You have a piece of legislation that is nothing other than a 100 per cent payback to the trade union movement. We even had the amazing spectacle of that great democrat Stan Sharkey screaming his head off on The World Today. He said, `The minister went ahead with these changes to unfair dismissal provisions without consulting me. We gave them $500,000.' They gave the government a nice round $500,000. What did our self-professed pay-by-results operator, Minister Brereton, say? Stan Sharkey's problem was that he did not give enough. A lot of unions gave a lot more and he has to understand that $500,000 only buys a bit of commission. It does not buy 100 per cent of the action.

This has become a shambles. The latest element of that shambles is the way this minister has twisted and turned like a weathervane. He said it was the last word. The Prime Minister said the amendment on the amendment was the last word, and now we have an amendment to the amended bill which will in turn be amended tomorrow when we debate another amendment bill in this parliament. It is a complete shambles. All along we continue to fail the most important exam for any country in today's competitive world, and that is we continue to have appallingly low levels of productivity because we have an appallingly old-fashioned industrial relations system that has now become a national disgrace and a complete shambles. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns The Hon G.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State, Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can agree with the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) on one point—and this is essential—that industrial relations is at the centre of micro-economic reform. The question is how we deliver the changes in industrial relations that will create micro-economic reform in the Australian community. It is not created by trying to legislate out one side of the game. It is not created by trying to damn the trade union movement and its right to represent Australian workers. We need to work with two groups: employers and those who wish to represent them, and employees and those who wish to represent them. That is precisely the way we have worked in the industrial relations system for more than a decade. We have had what we call a tripartite system of industrial relations in this country.

PARA.TAB: I will tell those opposite how it works. In significant areas of debate about the economy we invite employers and their representatives and representatives of employees to sit with the government—a triangle of interests—so that together we can work through the propositions. I will list some of the groups that operate in a tripartite system with the Commonwealth government of Australia. The Reserve Bank of Australia, a not insignificant institution in this country, has worker and employer officials sitting on its board. Some of the other groups include the Defence Industry Committee, the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, the Australian Manufacturing Council, the Australian National Training Authority, the National Labour Consultative Council and EPAC. Those sorts of boards are central to debate about micro-economic reform—that is, how we run industry in this country better—and each of them comprises representatives of government, employers and employees.

It is a culture, it is a matter of the mind, that we do not seek to deny one of the key groups access to this debate. All industrial relations matters do not take place in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission or before the courts; they take place in a myriad of forums. That is the essence of the system that those opposite have not understood. In a mature industrial relations system we can place people from both sides in all of those organisations.

The American system, whilst very different to ours, can from time to time be compared. There has been a recent review of the Australian system by some senior US officials, reported on in this morning's Australian Financial Review. I would like to read some of their comments. The Financial Review states:

SPEECH.PARA: President Clinton's commission into industrial relations has endorsed Australia's enterprise bargaining reforms, which it says have produced more widespread worker-management consultation than in the United States.
That is a decent enough thing for them to have said. But the key bits—I quote Mr John Dunlop, a key official in the writing of the report—are these:

PARA.TAB: "I think the most impressive feature of the Australian experience is the way in which they appear—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the Australian government—
to have aligned unions, the workers, management and the Government with a unity of purpose,"
He goes on to describe the purpose. He states:

. . . what they've done is they've acknowledged that what everyone is about is creating wealth and then distributing that wealth, not just the distribution but the creation of that wealth from the start.

That is a significant statement from a US official who now admits that the US cannot run an industrial relations system. Sure, it is a free-for-all and they have a fairly low level of industrial disputation, for instance. They have a low level of industrial disputation because of the bludgeoning that took place in the Reagan era and before that of organised labour, and we are very critical of that. Now in American workplaces there is a silent strike. There is now a lack of cooperation, a lack of desire to work.

PARA.TAB: American enterprises today are unproductive enterprises because they refuse to have this joining together of workers and bosses. It is the lesson that many OECD countries have learned. The Japanese have learned, the Germans have learned and we have learned that unless both groups are operating together in a culture of cooperation there can be on the surface a measurable lack of disputes, but no-one is doing anything. Not a great deal is being produced—certainly not goods of quality that would compete, for instance, with Japanese manufactures.

Those opposite do not understand the whole nature of the game. The honourable member for Bennelong had four specific criticisms of our bill and of industrial relations generally. He talked about non-trade unionists being excluded from the ability to bargain. That is not right. There is now a string of enterprise bargaining agreements called enterprise flexibility agreements. The trade unions cannot have a veto over the agreement. That system has been in place now only since 30 March. In those short weeks we have any number of EFAs up and agreed to—or in the process of agreement.

That was very difficult for the trade union movement to swallow because it had, I suppose over time, seen itself as the key player on behalf of workers in the IR system. It is still the key player, and my advice to any non-union worker in Australia is: `If you want to sit down with the boss and write up an agreement, then ring up someone who knows about the system. Do not bargain alone. Ring up an experienced advocate. Ring up your trade union. Have them, if not negotiate on your behalf, teach you how to negotiate so you can write up your own enterprise flexibility agreement. Remember: an agreement means that both sides have to agree. If you are not very experienced in the art of negotiation, if you do not understand your award rights and other rights of negotiation, make sure you learn about them first before you enter into an agreement.'

The proof of the pudding here really is how many agreements are being written around the country. Under the Commonwealth system, under our new act and the previous manner in which we have worked, 48 per cent of workers are covered in the federal award system for agreements. So we have had a good record so far and we would seek to reach 80 per cent coverage by the end of 1996.

Those who would seek to run a different system, somewhat like the jobsback program that the honourable member for Bennelong suggested at the last election, have a very poor record of coverage. The coverage in states other than those using our system is something like four per cent or less. That is the record under state awards in state systems run by conservative governments. The reason people will not agree to bargain is that they are scared to do so. There is no equivalence of power. So we have written in a system which clearly induces workers to get in and bargain. They know that by law they cannot be worse off.

TALK.START.PARA: —So they do not swallow it.
—They are entitled to bargain as freely as they wish so they might be better off and so there is a more productive enterprise in which they work. Point No. 1 has been rebutted.
—It is all those bricks they are worried about.

—It is a stupid remark you make. Secondly, I turn to the business of ILO powers. It really does not matter who else signs up to an ILO, a UN or other convention. The point is that we freely choose—that is, the representatives of the Australian people, the Commonwealth government—to sign up to a convention; that is, we like the standards. It does not matter whether an African nation or an Asian nation or whatever wishes to sign those conventions. The fact is that we want to do so.

PARA.TAB: It is normal practice when we sign an agreement to check with the states to see whether they have legislation which would contradict or contravene the convention. If they do, we ask them to bring their legislation into line. If they choose not to do that, we still choose, on the basis of our representing Australia's interests, to sign up. That is a matter of choice for us. That is what we have done in the ILO. We have been a member of the ILO for 50 years. You opposition people have always travelled to the ILO where we have sent a minister. You have always been in that forum. You want to pull out now because you are unhappy that we are making great progress with enterprise agreements. I am sad for you. You are left trailing five conservative governments whose record in writing agreements is pathetic. It will not get any better.

The third point involves the business of secondary boycotts and protections. Yes, they have been brought back within the guidelines of the IR act, but there are damages and protections to be awarded under that act. If damage is done by means of secondary boycott to an enterprise, the employer can gain access to a remedy. That is clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you mention the three days? You won't.

—We are happy with the system. We do not want to amend it. It is untrue to say that there is no access to a remedy and that we do not regard secondary boycotts as a serious matter. Point No. 3 has been rebutted.

PARA.TAB: Point No. 4 concerns small business. This is like waving the flag that small business is good and that whatever we can do for it is terrific, but you never detailed the provisions of our act that are somehow denying small businesses the right to go out and make a quid. I presume it might be the business of its access to enterprise agreements, or unfair dismissals, or whatever.

Keep in mind that most small businesses—I guess workshops of fewer than 10 people or whatever—will rarely write an agreement. They would tend to go along with the award system per se anyway. Within the award system now there is a great deal more flexibility to vary the provisions of the award. So in the case of small business an agreement is not necessarily needed, but there is the ability to sit down and enter into a more flexible agreement within the award under which workers are covered. It is not a difficult system to operate. Small businesses, which I guess are fairly ignorant of the IR system, should get to know the system better, because there is a lot in it for them and their employees.

I now turn to the area of small to larger sized businesses. One thing I have noticed as I move around—it is something the honourable member for Bennelong could never achieve—is that in larger enterprises of 100 or 200 workers, where any number of trade unions covers those people and they work under any number of awards, we have now been able to achieve not by dint of rules and regulations but by the culture that we have built in the last decade what we call single bargaining units. That is, the representatives of the workers in that workplace, perhaps coming from a number of different unions covering lots of workers, sit down as a single bargaining unit and, with great care and intelligence, together with the employer bargain for an entire agreement for the whole workplace. So, essentially, defensive practices that were written up and gained in years gone by to protect the plumbers, electricians, storemen and packers or whatever are now being put together and looked at as a whole to make sure that the plumbers, electricians, carpenters, clerks, et cetera, share the work and work together.

Employers say to me that perhaps the single most important entity of the last 10 years has been the ability to bring all those representatives together. We have created a culture of industrial relations in this country that will drive productivity in this country. Industrial relations is at the centre of productivity in this country. On that point alone I agree with the honourable member for Bennelong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say from listening to this debate and the other debates since the election this year that the actions of this government really remind me of a situation that occurred 30-odd years ago in one of our smaller universities. It had a vacancy for a single lecturer in mathematics. One outstanding applicant for it had all the qualifications under the sun. Unfortunately, the people concerned were not able to interview him because he was a Russian in Russia. They could not bring him out and they could not go over there. But they got some other objective academics in Russia to interview him. On the basis of their recommendation, he was given the job. But there was one thing wrong: he could not speak English. Even though he had security of tenure in that university, there was no way he could undertake the job.

PARA.TAB: The analogy is this: this government is theoretical and academic in its approach to the economy and industrial relations. To emphasise that, I am indebted to the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans), who a little earlier this week spoke about the background of government members. He said that, of the 108 Labor politicians who are currently in this parliament, we are blessed with 30 who have trade union connections—they have worked for a union, been a delegate or an organiser—28 who have been teachers; 15 who have a law background; eight who come from the party; a handful who have some business experience, such as working for a bank; but only one who has any small business experience.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true.

—It is true. Only one Labor member has any small business experience—the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods). He knows how to pull a beer, take a bet and count the till or the bookie's bag. Quite frankly, he would be a darned sight better minister than the present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), because, under him, at least the policy of the government would be consistent.

PARA.TAB: The Industrial Relations Act has come into being. Bear in mind that there have already been over 200 amendments to it. We believe that the government will come in tomorrow with more amendments to the amendments. It will increase unemployment. There will be no positive impact on workplace bargaining for non-unionists. It gives the trade unions a special position before the law. It is turning the clock back on fairness and equity.

While the onus of proof in unfair dismissal cases is going to be amended, it is still outrageous and unacceptable. As the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has made quite clear, the Industrial Relations Reform Act is a payback to the unions. He mentioned a gentleman called Stan Sharkey who runs the combined Forestry, Mining and Energy Union of Australia. He gave half a million dollars to Labor Party funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wasn't enough, Laurie said.

—It was not enough. But, as well as the money being given, everybody in Australia should be aware of the support the unions gave to the Australian Labor Party throughout the election campaign. Every sawmill in my electorate had a visit from the union organiser. He came along and spoke to all the employees and said not to vote for Garry Nehl or the coalition because we were going to do all these dreadful things.
—You would have.

—We would not have. The unions were telling lies. This is how the unions helped get the government re-elected. This is occurring at a time when regard for unions is at an all time low. People are voting with their feet. Fewer than 30 per cent of the private sector work force is involved with unions. I must repeat what the honourable member for Bennelong said in quoting Jennie George after that election:

SPEECH.PARA: What they have to understand is that we won the election and they lost the election.
That is a winner takes all philosophy. Quite frankly, it really is the political equivalent of rape and pillage. To hell with fairness and equity.

PARA.TAB: Where is this government's fairness to all Australians and all sectors? We believe that the government of Australia should represent all Australians and all sectors. Where is the equity and justice? It has gone out the door, particularly in the area of industrial relations.

The OECD report on Australia in April showed that productivity growth in the five years from 1987-92 was only 70 per cent of the OECD average. Productivity is the key to economic growth and economic success. It is the key to competitive success on the domestic and export markets. Quite frankly, the key to productivity is a sensible, fair and flexible industrial relations policy. This just does not exist with this current act or this government.

As the honourable member for Bennelong said just a short while ago, industrial relations is the nerve centre for micro-economic reform. He is absolutely right. Unless we get industrial relations right, we will not get anywhere. We are too highly regulated. The Industrial Relations Act is disastrous for small business. It removes the protection of the secondary boycott laws and it imposes penalties on small business wanting to employ people.

In the white paper, there is a $6 1/2 billion attempt to get small business to employ the long-term unemployed. Quite frankly, there is a black hole in that white paper that will destroy this government. The government says, `We want small business to take on the long-term unemployed.' The reality is that small businessmen really want to help this country. All of them do, and they would all welcome the opportunity of taking on somebody who has been long-term unemployed through the job compact.

But, as the Minister for Industrial Relations said in response to a question from me only a couple of weeks ago, those who put on somebody under the job compact have one week—that is the only time available—to make up their mind whether they want to keep that person. That is unfair to the employer and the employees. To make it quite clear, there will be one week before the unfair dismissal provisions apply. So a businessman can get somebody who has been unemployed for something like 18 months or two years. That person can be employed out of the goodness of the employer's heart. The employer then has to make up his mind in just one week whether that person will be satisfactory. That is not fair or realistic.

This government will go down the drain. Small businesses in particular, which could not possibly contemplate paying up to $30,000 in an unfair dismissal case, will not be game enough to do it. I do not blame them under those circumstances.

Some reference was made earlier by the honourable member for Bennelong to a retreat from Moscow. He was absolutely right when he said that. But we will have more than that. Very soon, we will have a retreat from Paris. The headlines in the press of the last couple of days have been very illuminating. One of them states `Brereton agrees to further review of IR bill'. Another states `Brereton firm as ACTU tries to lift compo'. He was as firm as a soft meringue. Another headline states `Leaked advice paper embarrasses ministers'. Were they embarrassed! A further headline states `OECD blames unemployment and failure to adapt'. Government members are cast in concrete in their attitudes, minds and policies. They cannot adapt.

Another headline states `OECD jobs paper casts doubt on policy'. Boy, are they big doubts. Others include `Bad report by OECD' and `Government tried to share accord'. This delightful little piece states:
Mr Keating was due to hold talks in Paris tonight with the French President, the Prime Minister, Mr Balladur, and French business leaders.
In the talks, Mr Keating was again understood to be ready to offer the French the White Paper's research and innovative solutions to the problems of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: He is going to offer them advice! My god, that is the blind leading the blind. The government loves to talk about fairness and equity. I remind the House and the people of Australia that over the last decade under the policies of this egalitarian government, this fair government, this government of the workers—goodness gracious!—the top 10 per cent of income earners have had their income go up by seven per cent but the bottom 10 per cent have had their real wages go down by 10 per cent. Where is the fairness and equity in that?

PARA.TAB: The other thing that I find totally distasteful about this government is the way it tries to bring in this class thing. Australia is really a classless society. The reality is that everybody in Australia has the opportunity to be a success. It does not matter where people were born or where they came from. My father started off as a steel worker and became successful. That applies to everyone here. Labor tries to drum up some form of class division. Its policies are divisive and anti-Australian. They should be thrown out. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not taken the coalition very long to revert to type. We had a couple of weeks of the new soft and cuddly variety. It lingered for a little while. Now we are back on familiar ground. It is led by the usual suspects—in particular the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). We are back to the familiar territory of hoeing into workers and unions and of putting forward 19th century industrial relations policy. At least we can deal with some familiar issues and some familiar approaches.

PARA.TAB: Today, in typical style, we have heard the arguments put forward by the honourable member for Bennelong. As usual, he is not letting the facts get in the way of a good story. Today, industrial disputes in Australia are at their lowest level in generations. Over the past 12 months we have had the most substantial reform of the industrial relations system in this country, introduced by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton). We have had a new enterprise bargaining system introduced which is delivering far more results at the federal level than the equivalents that have been introduced by conservative governments in their states have produced. Yet the matter of public importance submitted to the House is that the conduct of industrial relations is in a shambles—or shambolic, to quote the word those opposite have chosen to use.

We might look back in history to see what sort of a model we should have for an industrial relations minister. Perhaps we should go back to the Fraser government—the last time we saw a Liberal industrial relations minister in this country federally—and look at its track record to check the sort of model we should be looking at. Perhaps we should compare the degree of reform and change in industrial relations in our society between 1975 and 1983 with the degree of change that has occurred since 1983. I think the honourable member for Bennelong might concede that there was not a great deal of change in the time of the Fraser government.

Perhaps we could look at the level of disputes and the performance of people such as the former member for Stirling, Mr Ian Viner, as the minister who was responsible for industrial relations. Perhaps we could look at the level of confrontation and division in our society in that time. Then we would see the model of industrial relations that the Liberals and the National Party really represent and what they really are after.

A number of issues have been touched on in this debate. Unfortunately, my time does not allow me to deal with all of them. But I would like to make a few comments about the unfair dismissals legislation because, unlike the honourable member for Bennelong, I have a bit of experience in the area. In fact, I have been involved in 200 or 300 unfair dismissal cases.

The reality of unfair dismissal cases in this country is that the vast majority of people involved in them do not get very much out of them at all. Contrary to the image that has been portrayed by the media, by the conservatives and by the employers with respect to these recent amendments, most workers who pursue unfair dismissals in Australia end up either with nothing or with very limited outcomes, such as a couple of weeks extra pay, a reference or a change in the term `dismissal' to `resignation'.

In the previous Victorian system, under the Labor government, one per cent of applicants secured reinstatement. The vast majority of people under that system received, at best, a few weeks extra pay. This is the situation that the honourable member for Bennelong is suggesting is a great threat to employment in this country. It is an absolute absurdity. The vast majority of people come out of unfair dismissal proceedings still feeling that they are hard done by; that they have not got proper justice; and that the system dealing with unfair dismissals in this country is still substantially inadequate. Much as I would like to see it otherwise, I doubt that the new system that has been introduced federally will be greatly different. It will be an improvement. There will be workers who will be able to get some significant justice out of it. But, compared with the reality of the consequences that an unfairly dismissed worker suffers because of that dismissal, it will still be grossly inadequate.

Unfair dismissal laws exist in this country only because we have Labor governments. In Victoria prior to 1983 there was no redress for unfairly dismissed workers unless they were high-fliers who could access common law. Ordinary workers had no rights. If they were sacked arbitrarily or capriciously by an employer, there was absolutely nothing they could do. It was because we had a Labor government in Victoria, for the first time for 27 years, that we were able to introduce some justice and some protection for workers in that situation. The conservatives want employers to have the ability to sack workers arbitrarily and capriciously and to throw them out like they are a bag of rubbish, not to have to face any consequences for it and not to have to front up to any independent adjudication as to whether there was fairness in that dismissal.

Think for a moment what it is like to be a store person or a typist—perhaps somebody who is a bit older or does not have too many qualifications—who has been at a place for 10 years and suddenly is sacked for some arbitrary reason. It does happen. Many dismissals are perfectly justified, but many are not. Think of the position and the consequences that people in that situation are likely to suffer as a result of that dismissal, such as the prolonged unemployment that they could incur and the stigma on their record that may make it extremely difficult for them to get another job.

These are very serious issues for many Australian workers. We need decent legislation in the area of unfair dismissal to ensure that people have the capacity to get an independent judicially based hearing to decide whether or not they have been unfairly dismissed. Unfortunately, the coalition's position is based on a philosophical view that an employment contract is no different from any other contract: for example, it is no different from a contract to go down to the Victoria Market and buy a sack of spuds.

It is implicit in this view that parties to this contract have equal bargaining power. It is an equal contract with the checkout person at Coles New World and Coles Myer. It is an equal contract with the steel worker at Newcastle and BHP. It is an equal contract with the vehicle builder on the production line at Broadmeadows and Ford. They have equal bargaining positions. That is implicit in the philosophical position of the opposition, as advocated by the honourable member for Bennelong.

The reality is that the world is very different. The employment contract is one of the most fundamentally important socioeconomic structures in our society. It is not just a contract to buy a sack of spuds. Most people in our society live and die according to contracts of employment. To suggest that we should have a society that does not intervene to redress the imbalance that is implicit in many of those contracts of employment is bordering on a barbaric attitude to a contemporary industrial society.

In the vast majority of cases in the work force, the contract of employment is heavily weighted in favour of the employer. The balance of power, in most cases, is strongly in favour of the employer. Society intervenes through Labor governments in order to ensure that there is some balance in the relationship.

I refer very briefly to enterprise bargaining, which was also raised earlier. As I said, I regret that I cannot deal with all the matters that were dealt with by the honourable member for Bennelong. The Liberal position, again, is based on the notion of the individual as a contracting party. Ultimately, it represents the interests of the strong and the powerful—the people who do have bargaining power and whom it portrays as equals in a negotiating process.

Both of the coalition speakers in this debate quoted a comment made by Jennie George, and again the meaning of that comment has been very seriously misrepresented. I say to the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) that the meaning of that comment by Jennie George was very clear. Her meaning was simply, `We got elected. Don't expect us to implement coalition policy. We will implement Labor policy. We won. The people of Australia voted for a Labor government, and Labor policy will be introduced.' That was what she was saying. There were no suggestions of payback, graft, or any of the other ludicrous implications that have been thrown around. Jennie George's implication was very simple. We won the election. The Australian people voted for a regulated labour market. Believe me, in Victoria it won us a few seats.

The Australian people voted for fairness in labour relations. They voted for a regulated labour market. Jennie George was simply indicating that the ACTU expected a Labor government to implement Labor policy. Those opposite may not like that, but that is the outcome of the election.

It is instructive that the opposition is attacking the Minister for Industrial Relations. Those opposite did not mention their policy. The reason they did not do so was that they do not have a policy. We had Jobsback, or Throwback, which was the cousin of Fightback, but I suspect that is now on the backburner, as is Fightback, because it has failed and been rejected. Those opposite do not now have a policy.

We are not in a position to deal with the alternative, other than the opposition's basic core, atavistic and philosophical position, because it does not have a policy. If all those opposite can do is come in here and attack a federal Labor industrial relations minister who is presiding over the lowest level of industrial disputes in living memory and who has successfully introduced into this place the most comprehensive and difficult industrial relations reforms since 1904, then we have an absolutely absurd position that shows how politically bankrupt those opposite are.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the fourth report of the committee for 1994 relating to the further development of HMAS Stirling, Garden Island, Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The report which I have just tabled deals with the further development of HMAS Stirling, Garden Island, Western Australia. HMAS Stirling is located on Garden Island, which is offshore from the city of Rockingham and some 60 kilometres by road south of Perth.

PARA.TAB: The need to further develop HMAS Stirling stems from the government's two-ocean navy concept. This requires the provision of a secure base on the western seaboard to support major fleet units which operate in the Indian Ocean and minor fleet units which operate generally closer to the coastline. Additionally, HMAS Stirling will become the home base for the Collins class submarines.

The overall development of HMAS Stirling comprises three stages. Stage 1 was largely completed in 1978, with additional works progressing through to stage 2, which covers the development from 1989 to 1996. Stage 3 will extend the development from 1996 to the year 2000. This proposal, which continues the stage 2 development, will provide additional operational, logistic, maintenance and training support prior to the planned stage 3 development.

SPEECH.PARA: The works proposed in the development include a helicopter support facility, a small arms range, a power house upgrade, an aviation fuel storage expansion, training facilities, a trials and research support facility, torpedo maintenance facilities, and the extension of the Submarine Training and Systems Centre.

PARA.TAB: The House will note that, while recommending the construction of the works in this reference, some members of the committee are not yet convinced that a need exists for a small arms range at HMAS Stirling. The Department of Defence advised the committee at the public hearing that, following experience in the Gulf War, Somalia and Cambodia, it became apparent that naval personnel are in need of extra training in the use of small arms. Although acknowledging that simulation can never fully replace actual practice on a firing range, the committee believes that simulation could form part of training. This simulation could then be complemented by training at one of the army facilities on the mainland. The committee, therefore, recommends that the Department of Defence investigate the possible use of a simulated firing range at HMAS Stirling which could be used in conjunction with army firing ranges on the mainland.

Should the small arms range eventually proceed, the committee would like to stress that it has been assured by the Department of Defence that only 2.5 kilometres of beach would be unavailable to the public when the range is being used, which would be up to three days per week. Access would not be restricted on weekends or public holidays. I also stress that the public has access to some 84 per cent of the island.

The committee was told at the public hearing that operational safety measures would include sentries, warning flags, notices in local newspapers and personnel allocated to restricting public access within the safety template. The Department of Defence informed the committee that, following advice from army, the range is in accordance with military guidance and the safety template provided to it.

At the public hearing the committee was made aware by various environmental groups of the rare fauna and flora native to Garden Island. The fauna includes the tammar wallaby, the lined skink, the carpet python and the brush bronzewing. The Department of Defence advised the committee that it recognises that the native animal life on the island play an essential role in its natural ecosystem. Accordingly, environmental management is aimed at maintaining the behaviour, diversity and ecological integrity of indigenous animal species.

The question of preserving trees native to Garden Island, in particular the Rottnest pines, the Rottnest tea trees and the cheesewood trees, in which I took a great personal interest, was brought to the attention of the committee. The Department of Defence advised that every care is taken to preserve the flora on the island with exotic species being controlled and, if possible, eradicated. The committee commends the Department of Defence on action taken to preserve the unique environment of Garden Island.

During the public hearing, the committee received the impression that non-government environment and conservation groups believed that they were not adequately consulted or represented when decisions were made concerning environmental issues on Garden Island. The committee has therefore recommended that a representative of these groups be appointed to the Garden Island Environmental Advisory Committee.

The Department of Defence has assured the committee that, to the best of its current knowledge, the total development of HMAS Stirling, including stage 3, would remain at 17 per cent or 206.1 hectares of the 1,214 hectare island. This statement should therefore allay fears expressed by various groups that the navy plans to occupy the entire island.

While recommending the further development of HMAS Stirling, Garden Island, Western Australia, at an estimated cost of $40.54 million at December 1993 prices, the committee has, as previously stated, recommended that the need for construction of a small arms range be further investigated. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Bougainville from 18 to 22 April 1994. The island of Bougainville, a district which is part of Papua New Guinea, has for some five years been tragically subject to incredible divisiveness and a great deal of hardship and suffering. It would seem that there have been a number of occasions on which there has been a very tragic abuse of human rights.

PARA.TAB: It was in that climate that the members of the delegation were very pleased to accept the invitation by Prime Minister Wingti and his government to visit the island and to consult with members of the Bougainville community. The report I now table emanates from that visit.

There are three things I want to say. Papua New Guinea has a very special relationship with Australia. That relationship places a unique responsibility both on members of the Australian parliament in their dealings with Papua New Guinea and on those Australians working in Papua New Guinea. It is important that we understand that whether or not we believe that there is some continual causal relationship between events in Papua New Guinea and decisions and actions of the Australian government, nothing we say or do should intrude on the rights of the Papua New Guinea people to exercise their separate sovereign responsibilities.

Our report takes note of that special relationship. What we suggest in this report is no more than what we see as a possible process towards peace. So we are not laying down the law; we are suggesting a process. I believe this report does that effectively.

At no stage during our visit to Papua New Guinea and certainly not during our visit to Bougainville did the members of the delegation discuss the reopening of the Panguna mine. That, of course, is an issue peculiarly for resolution by the government of Papua New Guinea. It was not an issue which we saw as our responsibility, nor was it a matter that was in any way discussed by us.

As the leader of the delegation has commented, tragically there has been a series of rumours and innuendos which led to the physical abuse of Sir Paul Lapun and his family as a result of a rumoured gift to him by the delegation and the apparent determination by what appears to be a rascal gang of some 15 members to extract that sum of money from him. That, of course, was absolute rubbish. At no stage did we give or offer money to anybody, nor were we in a position to do so. We are pleased that since that incident the steps we have suggested in our report have in part been taken up.

I was delighted to read this morning a report from Mary-Louise O'Callaghan suggesting that already the Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of Papua New Guinea has initiated discussions which apparently have been held in Honiara with representatives of the Bougainville Revolutionary Army. All members of the delegation hope these discussions lead to a peaceful resolution of the tragic events that have so torn the people of Bougainville.

Visiting the care centres was the only real opportunity we had to see people who had been affected by the dispute—although, of course, we spoke to a number of people in the administration. It is important that the government of PNG understand that, while there are so many other issues with which it must be concerned, unless it settles the dispute on Bougainville unfortunately that will continue to dominate world headlines and a disproportionate emphasis will be given to that dispute over all other matters.

We therefore feel quite strongly that, unless a process somewhat similar to that which we recommended is immediately embarked on, all the other fields of assistance that the PNG needs will be neglected and the press emphasis will unfortunately distort it. For that reason, we trust that the Prime Minister and other ministers will give the priority to Bougainville that we see as essential. We hope, having allowed our visit, Papua New Guinea will open the province to non-government organisations, to the media, to other visiting missions and of course to representatives of the churches. We believe there have to be discussions between representatives of the BRA and the government and that process, which apparently Sir Julius Chan has already initiated, we trust will lead to some review.

On the matter of human rights, I was delighted to read from the government response given by the foreign minister that there is already to be a human rights commission constituted in PNG. I believe that commission should undertake the steps that we recommended to ensure that human rights abuses, no matter what side they have taken place, are investigated. Nonetheless, it is only by a process of reconciliation, such a process as we witnessed in Konga, south of Bougainville, that we believe that there can be a final putting to rest of the processes which seem, unfortunately, to have meant a continued series of retaliatory measures by members from both sides. Payback is not a process by which we are going to settle a dispute of this character. Unless there is a proper process of reconciliation taking account of the necessary formats and customary procedures, we do not believe that peace can be achieved.

I would like to pay tribute to a number of people, and quite demonstrably to the members of the committee—to the chairman, Senator Stephen Loosley; to my fellow members; to Margaret Swieringa, the secretary to the committee—and to the members of the Australian High Commission in Port Moresby, to whom we all felt particularly indebted, and in particular to those who accompanied us to Bougainville. It was not an easy visit; I believe their assistance was invaluable. I would also like to pay tribute to Prime Minister Wingti, to Sir Julius Chan and to each of the representatives of the government of Papua New Guinea who were inordinately helpful and willing to assist us, and above all, although we did not meet them, to the people of Bougainville, including the BRA, which I trust will pay equal attention to our report.

The report is not just to the government of Papua New Guinea, it is to all Bougainvilleans and it is for their sake and for the achievement of peace that we make this report to the Australian parliament and to the government of PNG. We hope it is a step towards a new era in Bougainville. If so, we believe that the care centres, where tragically so many today are suffering, can be disbanded and people can return to their villages and to their normal way of life. I commend the report to the parliament and to the people of PNG in the hope that it might achieve peace in that war torn province.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would like to thank those people I was privileged to join on this delegation, including one-time strongman, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). It was with a note of affection and with great respect and esteem that he was referred to in that way by the people of Bougainville. They hold him in high esteem and I can assure honourable members that my contact with him on this delegation has led me to hold him in equal esteem. I also feel that, based on our experiences, I have a long-lasting relationship and friendship with the others who were part of that delegation—Senator Bourne, Senator Loosley and Senator Calvert.

PARA.TAB: The first point that needs to be made perfectly clear, however, is that the federal parliamentary delegation to Bougainville did not at any point talk directly to the Bougainville Revolutionary Army. I assure this parliament that I made attempts at various points to talk to those aligned to the BRA and an attempt was made through Kevin Masive MP and Nakikus Konga MP to talk to those held in gaol in Rabaul.

I therefore reiterate that any references in the report to happenings in BRA held territory are anecdotal, implied or third-party accounts. No direct reference was made or should be inferred from the report as to our experience of BRA activities, as we had none. The PNG government cannot be held to account for this as it was not in a position to allow us to be in a position of danger, either real or potential—and one must remember that this is a war zone.

My first observation, which is not included in the report, is that I personally feel Bougainville Copper Ltd is responsible for the present situation. This is based on personal contacts in Bougainville before and during the conflict until the evacuation. It is my personal opinion that the lack of due attention to the local population and the environment and the massive dislocation thus caused to the social and economic structure of Bougainville are the cause.

Irrespective of any other responsibility, BCL should clean up the mess it has made with no thought of ever going back to Panguna. That is its moral obligation. In addition, I suggest that BCL make a large seven-figure cash settlement to the people of Bougainville for pain and suffering.

In the other place, Senator Margetts implied that the report in some way avoided the issue of the mine. I dispute that vigorously. The point is that the environment was not there to even mention the mine. The truth is that cessation of hostilities and return to normalcy are prerequisites to any hope of any discussion remotely involving the mine. I think Senator Margetts should think of this: if two blokes are taking each other apart in a pub brawl, you do not try to sort out what instigated the violence until you actually get them apart and stop the violence taking place.

The real issue for me, and I believe the delegation, was peace and—surprise, surprise—that is the main issue for the people of Bougainville. I ask all to closely look at the aid question, as the report clearly states that throwing money at the problem will not solve the problem. Indeed, whether that aid would reach its goal is questionable. The solution lies in the hearts of the Bougainvilleans to want, and reach out for, peace, realising that forgiveness may be necessary.

In terms of accountability for actions, I made it quite clear—and it is reflected in the report—that the PNG government security forces and the BRA atrocities need to be dealt with with equal justice. I will be painfully clear: either all should get amnesty or all should face the full force of the law, because the atrocities committed have been numerous and on both sides. I qualify that by saying that the worst atrocities were set in the period 1989-90 for the PNG security and defence forces and the period of sole occupation for the BRA. It is unclear whether these acts were from the leadership down or from direct combatants. Suffice it to say, it is my opinion that those most responsible will evade justice. I am convinced that the PNG political leadership should sincerely seek a just settlement.

I thank Prime Minister Paias Wingti, backed by Deputy Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan, for the personal undertaking to facilitate a visit of union representatives nominated by me. I place on record that Senator Loosley has delivered my letter nominating three representatives of the ACTU, along with Fay Campbell of the National Union of Workers representing the South Coast Labour Council. The union movement of this country, especially the South Coast Labour Council, has a proud record of caring for its fellow man.

I conclude by saying that we visited the war cemetery at Rabaul, and the ages of those killed were late teens and early 20s. It was truly a moving experience. I sincerely hope that the lives of Bougainvilleans and future generations of Australians may in some way be protected by the work we have undertaken, by the report and by the goodwill it will generate. I hope my two boys never have to don khaki 20 years from now because we have failed to grasp peace today. I commend the report. I truly hope in my heart that this is the beginning of, or is part of, a process which will deliver peace to our region.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has agreed to the sale of the Moomba-Sydney pipeline system on the basis of a sale of 51 per cent to the Australian Gas Light Co. and a competitive tender for the remaining 49 per cent. This tender has resulted in preferred bidder status for a consortium headed by a Canadian company, Novacorp International, with Petroliam Nasional Berhard (Petronas) of Malaysia. The government's agreement to the proposed sale to AGL was subject to a range of conditions, which included a successful outcome to the 49 per cent tender process and the approval of a sale structure by the Trade Practices Commission.

PARA.TAB: Part 6 of the Moomba-Sydney Pipeline System Sale Bill provides for a regulatory regime developed due to the deferral of the Interstate Gas Pipelines Bill and to apply specifically to the Moomba-Sydney pipeline system post-sale. This regime was developed with the assistance of the Trade Practices Commission, and key parties with an interest in the sale were consulted.

A particular condition on the sale was the resolution of various contractual rights held by Cooper Basin Gas Producers. The government has reached a negotiated settlement with the producers, which is presently being documented. The amendments to be introduced today primarily reflect the outcome of the negotiations with the Cooper Basin Gas Producers on its existing contractual rights and the resolution of residual Trade Practices Commission concerns. The remainder of the amendments are technical only.

Amendments 1 to 3 are of a technical nature to ensure that the provisions operate as intended. Some words are omitted from clause 32, and a provision is repositioned from clause 73 to clause 66. The amendments 4, 5, 7 and 8 proposed to clause 80 will provide the Cooper Basin Gas Producers, its successors and assigns with legislative protection of schedule A volumes of gas as calculated in accordance with schedule C which the Australian Gas Light Co. has contracted to purchase from the producers pursuant to the 1971 letter of agreement. This legislative protection does not operate to prohibit a re-examination by the Trade Practices Commission of its prior authorisation of the letter of agreement under the Trade Practices Act.

The amendments will also provide legislative protection for gas supply contracts between AGL and its downstream customers through priority protection to contractual rights and obligations already entered into and the contractual rights and obligations which will be entered into after sale and in force before an access dispute is notified.

In particular, the intent of paragraph 80(3)(ba) is to ensure that actual gas requirements under gas supply contracts entered into before a dispute is notified to the TPC have priority over access granted to a third party under any determination the TPC might make.

Nothing in the definitions inserted in subclause 80(8) by the amendments operates to remove the protection accorded to the producers' rights under the letter of agreement by subsection 80(3) should the producers assign those rights in the future.

Amendments 9 and 10 resolve residual Trade Practice Commission concerns with the legislation introduced on 12 May and provide for the TPC and the relevant party to be informed should the haulage services provided under a TPC determination be diminished through those services being required to fulfil an existing contract. The notice must be given within seven days of the time the decrease happens, and the provision can be enforced through a Federal Court action in the event of an infringement. Amendment 11 is a technical amendment made for clarification. I present a supplementary explanatory memorandum.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed amendments that have come through as a result of representations from industry and from the opposition are welcomed. They certainly sort out some of the drafting problems that were inherent in the legislation. They also go to meet some of the concerns of consumers and users of the pipeline. The big question to me has always been access to the pipeline by other producers within the gas fields around Australia, the appropriate compensation to be paid to the owners of the pipeline and under what terms and conditions access would be granted. I believe that the amendments go a long way to establishing this. However, in the future, we do have to think about a national grid, encompassing a connection between the substantial Victorian national gas grid and the Queensland national gas grid; and in the longer term no doubt an extension right across to Western Australia. When that occurs, a national regulatory body will be vital to handle the various component parts of, and access to, the line.

PARA.TAB: The regimes in which they will operate—which are essentially public monopolies becoming private monopolies—will probably now become the most important question for privatisation. It is worth pointing out that in the coalition's privatisation paper which was produced in 1988 this is one of the 10 items that were mentioned. We said it could not possibly be sold, and now here is the Labor government selling it. Those who have an even more acute sense of history will recall that AGL first proposed a pipeline at the end of the 1960s. Magnificent work was done by Connor when he nationalised it in the Whitlam government days but, 20 years later, the Labor government is turning around and privatising it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH LEGISLATION (POWERS OF INVESTIGATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank all members who contributed to this debate: the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop), the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland), the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile). I give due recognition to the work done by the parliamentary Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, chaired by my colleague in the Senate Senator Barney Cooney, in the examination of these issues. I also give due recognition to the work done by Senator Newman, the deputy chairperson of that committee. I am sure I speak for all members of this House in saying that we were very saddened to hear of her illness. We wish her a speedy recovery and hope that she will soon be back participating fully in the deliberations of the parliament.

PARA.TAB: I will spend a few minutes explaining some matters which were raised by honourable members. I was very impressed with the quality of the debate and with some of the issues that were raised. It is never easy to get the correct balance between rights and responsibilities. In an area like this, where some people can take advantage of rights given to them and not meet their responsibilities, the government obviously has a role to act to enforce the law. Exactly where one draws the line in enforcing the law in the area of medical fraud and overservicing is not easy.

I can attest to the fact that this matter has been around for many years. The first parliamentary committee that I served on in this parliament during the period of the Fraser government conducted a big inquiry into medical fraud and overservicing. You may remember that, Mr Deputy Speaker. From that time, this matter has come up again and again. Governments have struggled with the issue in one way or another to try to achieve the balance that is required.

It is unacceptable that estimates of $100 million or $200 million, or even more than that—up to seven per cent, according to the last report of the Office of National Assessments—may have been lost through medical fraud and overservicing. At that point, obviously it would have been necessary for the government to act to bring in new and better procedures. I think all honourable members accept that this is the case.

There are issues in the area of health policy and other policies that divide this House. I think very few members would wish to object to the general principle and thrust of the legislation: to create a situation where, on the one hand, those people who are abusing the system could be caught and made accountable and where, on the other hand, those people who are innocent could have their rights protected.

A lot has been made of the point that this legislation, from when it was first drafted, has been significantly amended following an inquiry by the parliamentary committee. Somehow this has been put forward as a kind of negative rather than a positive. It was not a negative. The government recognised that there was some concern about certain provisions of the legislation in the community—especially in the medical community—and by people who are interested in civil liberties, such as the honourable member for Tangney, for example. Because of the concerns of a number of people, including people within both the government and opposition parties, and indeed the Australian Democrats, it was decided to send the bill to the committee with the idea that it would examine these issues and report back.

The then Minister for Health, former Senator Richardson, need not have acceded to that request, but he did. As a result, we had a situation where officers of the department attended some of the hearings and heard some of the evidence and submissions and then decided, before the committee even reported, to put forward a series of proposed amendments in order to take account of the measures and suggestions that had been put up. In fact, as a result of the putting forward of those amendments, the parliamentary committee, by majority, accepted them. Not all committee members did. Opposition members did not because they wanted even more amendments, and I will get to that point later.

TALK.START.PARA: —The original draft was a mess.

—If the honourable member for Mackellar had been listening, she would have heard me say that, as soon as it was recognised that there were concerns about the original draft, there was no attempt by the government to say, `Look, we don't accept that in any way.' On the contrary, the government agreed to the whole question of having a parliamentary committee examine the issue and put forward amendments. After all of that process—
—It doesn't have to be.

—The honourable member says, `It doesn't have to be.' She cannot have it both ways in the parliamentary process. I have heard her spokespersons coming in here and saying, `You don't pay enough attention to our concerns; you don't pay enough attention to what we say.' When we do pay attention to what they say and when some ministers, and some parliamentary secretaries I might say, pay attention to what honourable members opposite say, what do we get from the honourable member for Mackellar? `Oh, it shouldn't have been like that in the first place.' She cannot have it both ways.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that we have listened to the people and we have listened to the opposition about genuine concerns in relation to this issue. We have wanted a bipartisan position and a position which is satisfactory to the community. As far as I can see, what has happened is that the amendments, as I say, were accepted by the majority of the committee; the opposition members on the committee expressed some further concerns; and, as the honourable member for Mackellar well knows, when these concerns were debated in the Senate, some of the opposition's concerns, not all of them, were also accepted by the minor parties and, as a consequence, they passed through the Senate.

The government has decided not to reject those amendments but, in fact, to accept them and, therefore, to accept the overall package as being a package that has come from the deliberations of a range of people, all concerned, as I said at the beginning, with this very issue of balancing on the one hand the need for enforcement and, on the other hand, the need for there to be protection of the civil liberties of doctors and, indeed, of the records of patients.

I believe that the legislation has achieved that result and the opposition, as it has indicated, is not opposing the result that has been achieved. I think we are entitled to see this as a very good exercise of parliamentary process in which we have achieved very good legislation and legislation which is absolutely necessary if we are to go forward and deal with associated problems.

The honourable member for Adelaide raised a couple of important matters. One of them was the question: to what extent would the officers of the HIC be capable of exercising, with discretion, the new powers that have been given to them? In order to take care of this matter, besides the amendments to the legislation, I would advise the honourable member for Adelaide, the shadow minister and others who are interested that the Health Insurance Commission has embarked upon a comprehensive training program for all its officers working in this area. It is being assisted by the Australian Federal Police training college in developing and implementing the training programs. Already this financial year the relevant staff have attended tailor-made training programs. Ongoing training in this specialised area has been given a very high priority. Furthermore, comprehensive policy and procedures are being established under which HIC officers must operate in relation to these provisions. All use of the new powers will be authorised and monitored by the HIC managing director to the national case management committee of the HIC.

I make those points on the record as an assurance to the opposition, to the parliament and to all interested persons, including persons from the medical profession, that these powers have been given but it is expected that the officers of the department will use them with the kind of discretion which I have mentioned; and that they will be used in such a way that they will not invade, unduly or without cause, the civil liberties of any doctors or interfere with patient records.

The honourable member for Lyne also raised a similar matter. He referred to the investigation of a pharmacist. This matter has been reviewed by the previous health minister. The whole pharmacy question and the behaviour of the HIC vis-a-vis the pharmacist have been reviewed. The issue has led to further strengthening of procedures followed by HIC officers and is well covered within the new comprehensive training programs of the HIC officers. So, again, there has been an effort on the part of the government to ensure that concerns which have been raised by honourable members in relation to these issues—which are important because of the balance between civil liberties and enforcement that I have mentioned and, in fact, even any suggestion of misuse of powers—are taken up, considered and reported upon.

However, having said all that, it is still an unfortunate fact that there is a very small number of medical practitioners who are indulging in medical fraud. As the AMA and other organisations of doctors have said, this gives the whole profession a bad name. It is important that these people understand that the government is determined to stamp out all fraud and to ensure that overservicing does not take place.

The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who spoke last in the debate, talked about the difficulty of judging overservicing. He talked about how it should not be a matter for police officers and other people, such as HIC officers, to be imposing on doctors who know what they are doing with respect to overservicing. Obviously, he has not followed the debate at all. This bill, which deals with fraud and does have a role for the HIC, is separate from the question of overservicing, which we have dealt with in an earlier, commensurate bill. In the overservicing situation, a tribunal of peers, doctors, will look at the evidence and make determinations as to whether this was unwarranted overservicing.

This question will not be determined by the HIC; it will be determined by an independent tribunal. The honourable member for O'Connor, by his comments, obviously missed the mark entirely. It is difficult in some cases to make a judgment of overservicing, but it is precisely because of that that the overservicing issue is going to be handled by a tribunal.

However, this is not the case with fraud. If a doctor claims that a certain patient appeared and the doctor made a claim for that patient when there was no such visitation, that is fraud. If a doctor claims that there had been six visitations when there had been only two, that is fraud. That is the sort of thing we are talking about in the distinction between fraud and overservicing.
