We will stamp out all medical fraud and reduce overservicing. This will be done by a process which includes advising and counselling doctors about overservicing practices. We are not going to come in heavy-handedly and say, `You have done this. Out!' We will counsel and advise them and try to reduce the level of overservicing by using the tribunals which consist of doctors. We will not put up with fraud. I make it perfectly clear that doctors caught using fraudulent practices will bear the brunt of the law, and I speak for the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and the government. Fraudulent exercises will not be accepted.

I thank everyone for participating in the debate. I am glad that this legislation is supported by all sides. I believe that it will not only help to stamp out medical fraud; it will also ensure that we protect the civil liberties of doctors and the records of patients. It has taken some time to get this together by way of a parliamentary inquiry and all the other processes. I think we have reached an excellent position with the legislation and I look forward to its sensitive implementation by the HIC. There will be a big saving for the people of Australia who will benefit most from this legislation. It will further strengthen the Medicare system, which we, on this side of the House, are very proud of. We believe that it is one of the basic precepts of social justice in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Dr Theophanous) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 9 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Ms CRAWFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to introduce amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Products (Collection of Levy) Act 1994, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992, the Quarantine Act 1908, the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act 1949 and the Rural Adjustment Act 1992.

PARA.TAB: The amendments will extend the sunset provision in the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988 from 30 June 1994 to 30 June 1996. This is a contingency measure in the event that the states do not pass legislation for the agricultural and veterinary chemicals code to commence in their jurisdiction on 1 July 1994. The 1988 act is repealed upon commencement of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1994, which was passed by parliament on 1 March 1994 as part of a package of agricultural and veterinary chemicals legislation.

Within this bill there are three amendments to the Quarantine Act 1908. Two of these amendments provide legislative support for practices developed to enable the resources of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, AQIS, to be directed towards higher risk imports and the third gives effect to certain recommendations of the Auditor-General.

Two of the three amendments of the Quarantine Act 1908 build on the successful partnership between industry and government in quarantine protection. They underpin arrangements entered into between AQIS and imported goods handlers, such as customs agents, freight forwarders, some importers of goods and those contracted to handle ships waste, to ensure an appropriate degree of quarantine surveillance is maintained over imported cargo.

The electronic entry and clearance of cargo for quarantine purposes is progressively being implemented at major ports around Australia. AQIS, customs and industry have worked together closely to develop and implement a system that provides necessary quarantine security but at minimal cost to industry. This bill, by inserting in the Quarantine Act 1908 provisions to permit the electronic entry of goods for quarantine purposes and the processing, recording and notification of quarantine decisions about those goods, gives legislative backing to the electronic systems being introduced. Existing customs and industry systems are used and no new administrative burdens will be placed on importers nor on the Australian Customs Service. The regulation making powers included in the new provisions are intended to allow the flexibility required to meet technological and organisational developments in industry. To ensure that the system can operate effectively, it has been necessary to require that all imports be notified. Again, existing practices will be recognised.

These amendments for electronic processing also clarify the responsibility for compliance with directions given by a quarantine officer in the importation process. A clearance system based on documentation requires compliance where the documentation indicates a possible quarantine risk. The importer, agent or broker seeking quarantine clearance who is given a quarantine direction will be responsible for meeting the direction.

These amendments also make provision for compliance agreements. These are arrangements effected between the Commonwealth and industry, on an individual basis, permitting industry to undertake certain quarantine procedures. Quarantine security is not jeopardised. AQIS conducts regular audits of operations and is responsible for final quarantine clearance of goods, and severe penalties are imposed for wilful non-compliance.

Consistent with debt management practice in the AQIS food inspection programs, this legislation will enable AQIS to withhold services where debts remain outstanding and to charge a penalty fee for late payment. AQIS will also be able to take a deposit or charge a booking fee, or both, for a place at quarantine stations. These measures give legislative effect to relevant recommendations of the 1992 report on the efficiency audit of the quarantine division of AQIS by the Australian National Audit Office. Incorporation of these provisions in the act is an interim measure pending the development, in consultation with industry, of a revised legislative basis for the collection of AQIS fees and charges.

The remaining amendments included in this bill are of a procedural nature directed to improving the administration of the issues dealt with in those acts. The amendments to the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act 1949 will remove gender specific terminology and enable the appointment of an acting commissioner, or acting assistant commissioner, for the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority for more than 12 months.

The Rural Adjustment Act 1992 will be amended to make the annual reporting arrangements for the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council, RASAC, more appropriate. I commend the bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that in this place you never quite know whom you are going to be confronted by, but it is always a pleasure to be involved in whatever capacity with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Ms Crawford). We enjoyed some good times together on a committee once, but the last thing I expected to be confronting her on was matters surrounding primary industry legislation. Life is full of surprises.

PARA.TAB: We have before us the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill, an omnibus bill which seeks to amend several pieces of primary industry legislation, including the Quarantine Act 1908, three agricultural and veterinary chemicals acts, the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act 1949 and the Rural Adjustment Act 1992. We will not be in any way opposing what is before us today, although in relation to some of these acts I would like to see some more profound and far-reaching changes.

I would like to say a few things about the Commonwealth's quarantine service. In relation to this whole question of fee for service, quarantine has been a vexed area, a very difficult area, for some years in this country. It is one of the areas where I would certainly like to see some more reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have raised it at all the local government association meetings I have attended.

—I am glad to hear that, and I can assure you that on this matter the local governments and we are in perfect accord. I hope that the government has the message that reform is needed. I want to focus on an incident that took place a few years ago which centred on the fact that customers of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service often find it very hard to pin down that service when it comes to establishing what prices will be charged for services delivered. When it comes to quarantine procedures this can be a real problem because they, believe it or not, can last for periods of up to 10 years and costs can blow out. One thing that needs to be clearly established is that people entering into arrangements with AQIS, or quarantine services, need to make sure that they have a very clear contractual understanding of what is likely to be involved.

PARA.TAB: A few years ago we had a case of the Commonwealth encouraging goat owners to import goats and to use AQIS's services by placing them in quarantine. I suppose the idea was that AQIS had something to do and the goat owners were able to improve the genetic quality of their herds. This saga began in 1984 when the Department of Health, as it was in those days, ran the quarantine services and sought expressions of interest from people wishing to import goats from North America. The original price for quarantine services was quoted as $50 per goat per year with a quarantine period of five years—that, by my maths, is about $250 per goat. Later the same year at an importers seminar in Adelaide importers were asked if they would accept a fee increase to $75 per goat per year and this, for reasons which escape me, was agreed to. In September 1986 the fee was increased from $75 per head to $311, and the importers were pretty excited to learn about this—they read about it in a newspaper!

TALK.START.PARA: —They felt like real goats.

—That is right. It was some three months in fact before the importers were advised in writing that the price had gone from the original $50 to $75 through to $311 per head. Unbelievably, in October 1987 the fee went up to $340 per head. The following year it went to $360 per head, and lo and behold it continued to rise with the CPI. This is an example, if you like, of the cost-plus culture gone wrong in a big way. It reflected the changes being made as the government moved towards 100 per cent cost recovery without any acceptable accountability, without any acceptable commitment to the concepts that would ensure that efficiencies germane to allowing private industry to be fully competitive—and to enjoy the cost effective services—would be duly allowed for.

PARA.TAB: The eventual cost blew out to $410 per goat, and instead of the quarantine period being five years it eventually became eight years. They became very, very expensive goats, I have to say. The problem was exacerbated because goats, like rabbits, breed. So the goats ended up costing a lot more per goat, there were a lot more goats and there were more years than originally estimated, which resulted in bills that the importers just could not pay. The whole thing got quite out of hand. In 1991 the government threatened to sell some of the goats to pay the bills. But the coalition combined with the Democrats to stop this and the government was finally forced to accept the compromise, and the goats, to the enormous relief of all involved, were released. The coalition does not sanction people not paying their bills; neither does it believe that they ought to be put into a position where they have no control whatsoever over the sorts of costs that might be imposed upon them and the sorts of bills that might be dropped on their desks at the end of what ought to have been a gentleman's agreement as to the eventual outcome.

It is against that background that I reiterate my earlier warning: people bringing animals, plant material or whatever into this country who wish to take advantage of AQIS's services ought to ensure that they know what it is up to; they ought to seek a written contract with a decent degree of understanding built into it. It is understandable that circumstances sometimes change and in the very difficult area of quarantine services it may be that from time to time extra services, facilities or time constraints come into play. Nonetheless, AQIS will these days agree to contractual arrangements, and importers ought to ensure that they avail themselves of those opportunities.

In relation to the legislation before us there is one very good feature of the amendments being proposed: there will now be a facility for the Commonwealth to enter into agreements with private companies or contractors as well as those government bodies mentioned by the parliamentary secretary in her address tonight which can undertake, or will be able to undertake, quarantine functions on behalf of the Commonwealth in the future. This agreement should allow for the maximisation of efficiencies, competition and the lowering of cost outcomes as far as possible for users of the services provided by AQIS. The amendments should also allow for quarantine stations to take booking fees and deposits for services in the future, which we also see as a very welcome development. This action seems sensible in that, if quarantine stations are to be run on a businesslike basis, they must be able to forward plan and must be able to ensure that they have sufficient work on an ongoing basis to keep them open, because it is important that those services be there. The times have changed. It is not goats that people are trying to import today; it is ostriches.

There will be room for AQIS to charge late payment fees—that is entirely fair enough—or to withhold quarantine services until fees and any deposits as undertaken by people using those services have been paid. The coalition, importantly, does not object to any of these amendments. All we ask is that the ground rules be clear and that the government continue to insist that efficiencies are maximised, inefficiencies are progressively eliminated and more efficient services are offered on a more cost competitive basis in the future.

As the parliamentary secretary mentioned, amendments to this act also legalise the electronic processing of imports for quarantine purposes and provide that notice be given of imports. That is moving us into the 20th century. Many of these amendments were recommended by Auditor-General's report No. 35 of 1991-92 on quarantine fees and charges and we welcome those recommendations being picked up.

Three agricultural and veterinary chemicals acts will be amended to extend the time available to the states to pass complementary legislation from July 1994 to July 1996. We urge the states to get on with the business of ensuring that that happens because the timelags here have been quite unfortunate. They have been touched on in this House before and I do not want to take up members' time, given that we have the opportunity to get away a little earlier than we had been led to believe.

Amendments to the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act 1949, which I suspect the shadow minister for resources and energy, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who is at the table, will be touching on in some detail and with great competence in a short time, remove gender specific terminology. This is very important. There was a lot of speculation in the House earlier about whether a certain minister on the other side could bring herself to utter the term `ombudsman'. We were working on `ombudsperson', but we did not get it. This amendment will remove gender specific terminology and will enable the appointment of an acting commissioner or acting assistant commissioner of the Hydro-electric Authority for a period longer than 12 months should that be necessary.

I finally come to the question of the rural adjustment scheme. The Rural Adjustment Act 1992 is amended to make the annual reporting arrangements for the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council, RASAC, more appropriate and streamlined. The government's new amendment to ensure that creditors cannot get their hands on re-establishment grants paid to bankrupt farmers is something I touch on briefly here. The government has—under some pressure, I might add, from the coalition—been forced to make those amendments so that those who have been forced to leave their farms do not find themselves in a situation of having their goods, houses or whatever seized by creditors. That action by the government is supported by the coalition. We hope that that has been locked in place and that it will work as the minister has assured us it will.

Whilst on the rural adjustment scheme, I say that the government needs to be aware that many farmers across this country are still hurting very badly and that the assistance scheme, which for many is the only remaining safety net, is still, frankly, letting too many through without assistance. I am particularly concerned that the government is removing the exceptional circumstances provisions for wool growers. The exceptional circumstances assistance amounted to interest rate subsidies of up to 100 per cent which have been available over the last 12 months in recognition of the extreme plight of the wool industry.

At one stage it was estimated that 90 per cent of the nation's wool growers were technically non-viable. That was an appalling situation and for three years wool growers were toting up average losses estimated to be around $30,000 to $35,000 per year. Yet we find that at the first whiff of recovery the government has knocked off the exceptional circumstances provisions, which, as I say, offered the only real hope for growers who are in the long term, in my view, by and large viable. The only hope of making it for some of them was the continuation of the exceptional circumstances funding.

The government seems in part to claim that that funding was no longer needed because the industry is in recovery mode. I point out that there are enormous accumulated losses out there. Although the market indicators hit a very welcome 628c or so in recent days, we need to remember that wool is many different products and many wool growers do not grow the finer wools, which is the area where the strongest recovery has occurred. Therefore they are still experiencing extraordinary difficulty.

Unfortunately, in the western divisions of New South Wales and the western districts of Queensland in particular, many wool growers really have no option but to grow wool. That is all they can grow. On top of disastrous wool prices, they have suffered drought in some instances for up to three years. Tragically, despite reasonable falls of rain in some parts of the continent over the last 24 hours, many are now facing the re-emergence of another disastrously dry winter, another winter when they will not be able to enjoy anything like a reasonable clip. They will be facing tragedies as severe in some cases as simply not having the feed to keep their livestock going on. Many of them cannot afford to feed any more. I really think this whole area needs very significant review.

The other reason the government seems to feel it was appropriate to knock off the exceptional circumstances funding is that it claimed the money was not taken up. Of the original $37 million made available last year, some $10 million or $13 million will not be taken up. The government seems to think this is evidence that it is no longer needed. The only reason that money was not taken up is that the eligibility criteria were too narrow.

Before wool growers became eligible for exceptional circumstances assistance, they had to be able to establish that they had been dependent on wool for 65 per cent of their income on average over the previous three years. Many wool growers found that their wool income was so disastrously low that they had perhaps sold off all of their sheep. That in itself may have created a distortion. They had sold sheep and that income was then not classified as wool income. Or perhaps the wife had to go out and work in a school teaching situation to bring in a little bit of money and that income became greater than 35 per cent of the family's income for a couple of those years and again distorted the figure.

I have letters from wool growers in desperate plight who have been ruled out because they could demonstrate that they were perhaps 64 3/4 per cent dependent on wool income and were therefore ineligible for this assistance. I just think that is absurdly narrow. I think it knocks out growers who desperately need assistance, who would have made it and who could still make it with some assistance. Worse than that, it devastates the communities that are dependent upon those wool growers. There are many country towns still dependent upon the wool industry, in terms of both their social and economic fabric, for their well-being, indeed for their very survival.

I register my very deep concern about the way in which the government has handled assistance to the rural sector. It is undoubtedly true that the sector has had difficult times in recent years. As a result of that it has been easy for the pundits to look at rural industry and say that it is not making the contribution that it once did to our economy, in terms of its percentage contribution either to GDP or to export income. Yet the fact remains that, despite disastrous years and disastrous prices, around a third of our total exports are still rural in origin.

About 450,000 Australians are still basically dependent on rural industries for their occupations, and Australia's biggest manufacturing sector is the processed food sector, a sector which obviously is well placed in terms of the available supply of quality, reasonably priced, clean agricultural products from our farms to spearhead a real capitalisation of the market opportunities that lie to the north and in the Pacific regions.

I think it will be a great tragedy if we underestimate the importance of the need to make sure that that actually happens. That will involve making sure that the rural sector does fully bounce back now. It will involve ensuring that costs are kept to a minimum. It will involve industrial relations and transport reforms.

I was horrified to read a few days ago in the Financial Times a review on food processing in this country which warned us that, if we are not careful, we will find ourselves importing processed foodstuffs from Asia rather than exporting them, because we are still not competitive. Our taxation regimes still discriminate stupidly—that is the only word I can use—against exports. Our industrial relations policies still place us at a disadvantage vis-a-vis Asian competitors in the food processing industries. It is not a question of Asian style wage levels. Asia's levels are rising very quickly. In many places in Asia they are now higher than ours. It is a question of combining our good fortune in the area of natural resources with the way we do things in our workplaces, with the flexibility in our workplaces and those sorts of things to ensure that we are able to capitalise on the opportunities that lie there.

So there is a range of issues. I come back to the immediate one at hand: the government's short-sightedness where rural assistance is concerned. In the longer term, in my view we need to move away from a reliance on rural assistance schemes and instead to put the farmers back in a position where they are obliged to, and have the incentive and capacity to, provide for themselves more sufficiently in downturns.

Given the interest rate and inflation regimes—the faults of government—and the impact of years of drought and low commodity prices, the twin bedevilling problems that are not the fault of governments but that have blighted the rural sector in recent years, we have no option but to insist on short-term assistance for the nation's farmers in the hardest hit areas and industries.

It is in the interests of the farmers, the communities that they live in and the broader nation that we ensure that as many farmers as possible survive and recover as quickly as possible in order to fully contribute to the economic and social recovery to which this nation so desperately looks in the future. On that note I conclude by saying that we welcome some of these amendments, and even those that we think are unnecessary or are not particularly important we will not oppose.

TALK.START.PARA: —I compliment the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) on his very entertaining speech, especially the part relating to the goat saga. The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus bill to amend various acts administered by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. There is no essential theme but a variety of amendments. I take this opportunity to address these and subsidiary matters dealing with primary industries and energy in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is one of the most vital groups in Australia. Our continent is substantially free of a great many diseases of animals and plants because of our historical insistence on high levels of quarantine. This amendment seeks to alter the act, first passed in 1908, which relates to the payment of fees for quarantine services.

It appears that some people with a sound knowledge of the debt management scheme of the quarantine system have been misusing the scheme by avoiding payment until just before their next use of the services of the system. This is unacceptable commercial behaviour, and the Auditor-General's report was right to criticise it. A further problem was some clients making multiple reservations for imported animals at more than one quarantine station. Obviously this sort of sharp practice is not helpful to the orderly and efficient running of that vital service. In the face of these acts, the quarantine service could not withhold its services. With this amendment bill, the quarantine services will be empowered to withhold services until payment and have the ability to use monetary penalties as an encouragement to proper commercial practice.

This bill also expands ministerial determination and discretion with respect to quarantine service fees. This is a good idea. In general, I am in favour of the powers of ministerial discretion being expanded. The Westminster system is one of ministerial government, departmental administration and parliamentary accountability. This is not a bad system and, as long as the department engages in administration and not government, we will do well.

This bill helps strengthen ministerial government, and that is good. It further expands compliance agreements. The government recognises that some quarantine procedures can be performed reasonably by industry, and this will enable the resources of the quarantine service to be concentrated in higher risk areas.

New section 66B, dealing with compliance agreements, will be inserted into the 1908 Quarantine Act by clause 7. The effect of the proposed subsection 66B(1) is to allow the Commonwealth to enter into an agreement—a compliance agreement—with another person for the carrying out by that person of certain quarantine functions in respect of certain goods.

Compliance agreements may contain provisions for the cancellation or the suspension of an agreement. The regulations may require a compliance agreement to provide for the security as a bond to ensure the proper observance of the agreement. It will be an offence, punishable by a maximum penalty of 500 penalty units—currently $50,000—or 10 years imprisonment, or both, for the non-Commonwealth party to a compliance agreement to intentionally or recklessly fail to ensure that any requirements imposed on it are properly adhered to.

I am glad to see that the government is aware of, and active on, matters dealing with our rural industries. Although I represent an inner western Sydney electorate, I am conscious of the situation of rural farm families and their prospects. However greatly we advance in our export drive and our development of elaborately transformed manufactures, we still have to eat and have to wear clothing. These things come from farms and the work of farming families.

I take this opportunity, while speaking on the primary industries bill, to call at least for a better deal for our farmers. I know that much has been done over the years, and I also know that much more needs still to be done. As quarantine deals with animals, and animals are found on farms, I would like to make a short point central to the concern of farmers in this debate on a primary industries bill. The National Farmers Federation has called on the federal government to extend the special investment allowance past the 30 June 1994 cut-off date to allow farmers to take advantage of it. It is vital that Australian agriculture be given the opportunity to invest in new capital equipment after several years of negative incomes when new equipment purchases were markedly down. There are 30,000 grain farmers. In 1985 about 1,000 combine harvesters were sold. In 1993-94 the figure will be 400 to 450. I urge this government to act to extend the investment allowance and to help farmers avoid running down their capital.

The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill will also provide legislative support for the electronic entry, processing and clearance of goods imported into Australia. This is a modernisation of the fundamental duty of citizens to notify the authorities of the importation of goods. In practice these provisions allow for the continuation of existing information, access and processing arrangements between the quarantine service, the customs service and industry.

In addition, in the future new developments in technology can be accommodated through the regulations making power. This legislative authority for electronic initiatives is a further step in redirecting the inspection resources of the quarantine service away from routine activities where alternative procedures are satisfactory.

This amendment bill deals with an important anomaly and improves the situation of farmers in a particular instance. The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill contains a technical amendment relating to rural bankruptcies. The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Act of 1994 amended the Bankruptcy Act 1966 to ensure that recipients of rural adjustment scheme payments are able to retain those payments or property purchased with those payments where the payment is received after 28 April 1994 and where the bankruptcy action is initiated after that date.

Some farmers are eligible for and receive the rural adjustment scheme payment, notwithstanding the fact that they have become bankrupt before making an application or are even receiving the rural adjustment scheme payment. The amendments to the Bankruptcy Act 1966 by the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 would not be effective to enable a farmer who became bankrupt before 28 April 1994 to retain a grant made after that date. The proposed amendment to the application provision of the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 will ensure that, where a bankrupt farmer applies for and receives a rural adjustment scheme grant, he or she will be able to keep the grant or any property acquired with it irrespective of whether the bankruptcy occurred before or after 28 April 1994. This amendment is very welcome.

Farms are not just businesses. Life in rural Australia is especially hard. Bankruptcies are a blow to rural communities, many of which are poorly populated and, thus, poorly serviced. This amendment goes some way towards preventing, in some cases, absolute destitution amongst farmers, who are often put into bankruptcy through no real fault of their own. The amendments contained in this bill help to modernise and humanise the administration of our society. They are small but useful steps. I am happy to commend them to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having the privilege, as I do, to be the spokesman on behalf of the Liberal and National parties on resources and energy, I am delighted to be able to speak this evening on the legislation before the House and, more particularly, the amendments to the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act 1949. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you and all members will appreciate, the harnessing of a great natural resource—namely, water—by that project has been a historical achievement which still gives Australians great pride today. Similarly, it is worth saying that land, like water, is one of the community's fundamental resources. How land is used determines whether it gains or decreases in value. It must be the goal of every government to use land for the maximum national interest and to seek to increase its value.

PARA.TAB: Since the alternative uses for a piece of land are rarely mutually exclusive, there is the clear potential for much of Australia's landmass to provide a number of distinct benefits. The coalition parties remain committed to the policy of multiple land use. We believe, on any sensible evaluation, that this allows the maximum benefit to be obtained from an area of land. For instance, locking up a piece of land solely because of environmental values may preclude considerable income in terms of tourism or mining. Yet it may well be possible to encourage responsible tourism and extract valuable minerals while preserving the environmental significance of the site. In this way, the benefits from a sensitive area are considerably increased at little or no cost to the environment.

It is the aim of the Liberal and National parties to ensure that decisions on the use of sensitive areas are made on the basis of the best information available. That is what is so disturbing about the report of the commission of inquiry on Shoalwater Bay which was handed down on 1 June last. The principal recommendation contained in that report against any exploration means that decision makers and the community at large continue in ignorance as to the mineral deposits located there. So the first priority in making a balanced decision in the national interest is gathering information. In this case, the report recommends that exploration be ruled out even though this could be arranged to cause negligible or no damage to the existing environmental values.

There will be instances where exploration cannot occur without threat to significant environmental or heritage areas. In such cases, it is appropriate that exploration be refused. However, they are few and far between. This report has not demonstrated that Shoalwater Bay is such an example.

The argument that mining is unlikely to be approved and that, therefore, there is no point in exploring is simplistic and illogical. We must know the scope of the mineral deposits at Shoalwater Bay to be able to make a considered decision on their future. At a time when 30 per cent of Australia is effectively excluded from mineral exploration and nearly 10 per cent of Australians are unemployed, the benefits of mining and harnessing our natural resources, as occurred in the Snowy Mountains hydro-electricity scheme, must be factored into decisions on land use rather than considered only if there is no other objection. These benefits can then be balanced against the need to preserve significant environmental and heritage sites so that a decision can be taken that is truly in the national interest.

Valuing each of the benefits involved is not simple, although some clear conclusions can be drawn. It is clear that different groups will place different values on the elements that interact in a particular site. Even where a pristine wilderness is involved and may be considered to have an immeasurable benefit in its preservation, it may be possible to allow mining in one small area and hardly reduce the associated value of the wilderness.

However, there is then a clear benefit from the income and jobs generated by that mine which must be weighed against the perceived decrease in value of the wilderness. Just because it may be difficult to balance the competing benefits to determine the maximum national interest does not mean that governments should shirk the responsibility to do so. Governments have a clear responsibility to take decisions based on a consideration of the relevant factors and not disregard or ignore information, as this government has done so often.

This government provides a perfect example of the consequences of not following a policy of multiple land use based on a decision made in the national interest. The opportunistic decision making that characterised Coronation Hill has no place for a country needing investment to create jobs. International investors around the world took note of that decision, and they have not forgotten it.
Earlier this year, Dr Max Richards, the managing director of Aberfoyle Resources, explained it as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has a 20 year history of gradual reduction of land accessible for exploration and mining . . . within the next ten years, 50% of Australia could be off limits to the industry, in the sense that too much risk and cost is attached to it. This surely reduces the country's prospectivity.
He went on to say:
Ore bodies rarely occur in convenient places;
Ore bodies and the facilities needed to extract them, occupy a tiny area and the whole mining industry occupies only 0.02% per cent of the total Australian land area;
The industry has excellent practice in environmental management and rehabilitation and there is little excuse for repetition of sins of the past.

So multiple land use is an important element of sustainable development, particularly where mining is involved. This is really a very simple concept. If a mine goes ahead, despite environmental considerations and concerns, there are jobs in the region and there is growth in the local economy, income from the mine to pay for environmental studies and measures, money for rehabilitation of the sites, company tax for the government's coffers and profit for the mining company and so on. If mining does not go ahead, there is simply the unrealisable environmental value of the site. It is clear which scenario is more in keeping with the principles of sustainable development.

PARA.TAB: It is vitally important that the states be partners in decisions on land use and that the views of state governments be sought and respected. These issues are too important to continue as the political football that they have been in the past. The heat must be taken out of the debate. Australia must have stable, long-term regimes which balance the encouragement of mineral exploration with the conservation of heritage and environmental sites.

The government must be accountable for its decision making on land use and be seen to take decisions based on all the available information and in the national interest. That is why I am so sorry that the report of the commission of inquiry into Shoalwater Bay failed to really balance the competing interests.

The inquiry did arise out of a political ploy by the Labor government to pacify the environmental lobby at the March 1993 election. By its outright rejection of any possibility of sensible multiple land use, the commission sets the sustainable development debate back several years. The concept of sustainable development should have moved the debate on issues such as Shoalwater Bay much closer to rational and balanced judgments.

The recommendation against any exploration was entirely predictable, given the political context in which the commission was operating. There is no possibility of ever making sensible decisions in the national interest without exploration data being available. So long as extremists equate exploration with development, governments will be virtually making decisions in the dark.

The commission's findings are a throwback to the Coronation Hill period. The commission, in effect, is saying that we should be afraid of the knowledge that exploration would bring. The absence of due process throughout the commission's hearings will have grave ramifications for the resources sector. I am deeply concerned that this was a report born out of political expediency. It was conducted over a long period—some 12 months—and involved great expense for the Clinton Lowland joint venturers. Many of the standard rules of conduct of commissions of inquiry were frequently set aside to pacify extremists. The resources sector is very carefully evaluating the conclusions of the commission of inquiry—as we are on our side of the House—before making representations to the government on the basis of balanced, environmentally sound multiple use of the Shoalwater Bay area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill now before the House. I noted with some degree of interest and amusement the speech that was delivered by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Anderson) earlier in this debate. He seemed to get strung out on the issue of goats. I was wondering whether it had something to do with the two prime goats who were sitting behind him at the time—the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson). I am only having a wee shot at the honourable member for Gippsland. I do acknowledge the interest of the Deputy Leader of the National Party in the goat industry.

PARA.TAB: I also congratulate the honourable member for Lowe (Mrs Easson) on her contribution to this debate. She has had a longstanding interest in working families, be they city or rural. I know of her particular concern for farm families, and it is most pleasing to see her participate in the debate here this evening.

I am pleased to lend my support to the legislation before the House. The legislation proposes amendments to several acts that are encompassed by this omnibus bill: the Quarantine Act 1908, the Agriculture and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988, the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act 1949—the amendment is basically procedural—the Rural Adjustment Scheme Act 1992, the Offshore Minerals Act 1994 and the Bankruptcy Act 1966.

I do not intend to canvass in great detail each and every provision of this bill. The amendments are basically technical and do not involve substantial increases in Commonwealth outlays. They are housekeeping amendments, designed to improve the administrative efficiency of the legislation. But I would like to raise a couple of specific matters that relate to the Quarantine Act 1908, the Rural Adjustment Scheme Act 1992 and the Bankruptcy Act.

Australia has one of the most efficient and professional quarantine control systems in the world. That is acknowledged not only within this country but internationally as well. Australia is regarded as a clean and a green producer of farm products. We have a burgeoning trade in both fresh farm products and value added food products. Our future exports and our domestic market development depend on our maintaining our position and our reputation as a clean agricultural producer. The word `clean' has various connotations to many people. It can mean produce that is free of polluting chemicals or produce that is free of disease. Our quarantine service has played a major role in protecting our country's great agricultural assets—land, plant and animals—from diseases imported from overseas.

The amendments proposed to the Quarantine Act authorise agreement between the Commonwealth and other parties for the performance of particular quarantine services. The government is acknowledging that some functions can responsibly be performed by industry players. It sets out measures in the legislation designed to guarantee quarantine security under any agreement that is made between the Commonwealth and other industry players.

These measures provide for the taking of a security. The bill provides a requirement that a quarantine officer clear the goods, provides for the imposition of additional procedures where circumstances change in this area and provides for penalties. These are reasonable provisions that will release resources within the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service for a greater control of supervision in the more critical and perhaps more troublesome of the quarantine areas.

Other amendments that are being proposed to the Quarantine Act relate to legislative support for the electronic entry, processing and clearance of goods into Australia. These measures are necessary to make sure that this particular service continues to provide the professional and expert function that it provides to the rural sector of Australia.

The quarantine service has undergone significant restructuring during the lifetime of Labor government since 1983. The measures that are being proposed here are simply aimed at streamlining this important service a little further. They are also aimed at reducing costs to industry users. Great play is made by the opposition of the costs of these sorts of services to the rural sector. It is pleasing to see that we at least have some agreement on the major elements of this legislation as they relate to the reduction of cost to industry users in the rural sector. These aims are undertaken while we attempt to maintain standards within this vital service to Australian agriculture.So they are logical and reasonable amendments that deserve the support of the House.

The bill introduces some amendments to the Rural Adjustment Act 1992. These amendments, I understand, are designed to simplify the reporting arrangements under the 1992 Act for the rural adjustment scheme advisory council. The amendments repeal the application of division 3 of part 11 of the Audit Act 1901 to the rural adjustment scheme advisory council. Provision is made to require the chairperson to prepare a report on the council's operations during the year ending 30 June and to submit the report to the minister for primary industries and energy for tabling in the parliament.

The Rural Adjustment Bill 1992 outlined the specific support that would be given by the federal government to rural industries to develop a strong and more competitive farm sector in Australia. The minister at the time recognised the need to balance the structural change that was necessary to ensure the survival of many rural industries with the social justice imperatives of federal Labor governments.

The Rural Adjustment Bill 1992, along with the Farm Household Support Bill of the same year, provided the means for farmers with no future prospects in farming to leave the industry with dignity. For those farmers without future prospects in agriculture, the bill enhanced the farm exit provisions and provided a re-establishment grant of some $45,000 to eligible farmers who leave the sector. That measure is the subject of other amendments that are being proposed in this bill here tonight.

I note the concerns of the Deputy Leader of the National Party for farmers who are still under intense economic pressure within the rural sector. This process of structural adjustment is certainly a continuing one within the Australian economy generally and nowhere is this process more evident than in the rural sector itself.

At this point I reflect on my own upbringing. As the son of a dairy farmer, I have observed the process of structural change within that industry with more than a degree of interest from the 1960s to 1994. There is probably no better example of the sorts of economic pressures that have been brought to bear on farmers and the structural changes that have taken place.

Many factors have led to this process of structural change and the massive productivity increases that have occurred in the rural sector over the last 20 years. We have seen the introduction of new technologies in the rural sector on quite a massive scale. That has had implications for employment within the rural sector, but it has also imposed some burdens on farmers as far as maintaining their relative position in the technology stakes, in maintaining their levels of productivity, is concerned.

We have seen better plant and stock breeding techniques that have wrought quite revolutionary changes in the rural sector and, once again, massive increases in productivity. The quality of financial management has improved to a considerable degree and there has been a great improvement in the farming techniques that have been applied and also in the accessibility of farmers to market information.

Farmers have faced a sea of change and there have been casualties along the way. I recall 1983 when I first stood for the seat of Corangamite, now occupied by Stewart McArthur. During the 1984 campaign I travelled with the Hon. John Kerin, the then minister for agriculture—he is probably one of the best agriculture ministers this nation has produced at the federal level—down through western Victoria. There we met with representatives of the farming community and local government. They were really out to lynch us and we had a harrowing couple of hours arguing around the table about the future of the dairy industry. We were at pains to point out to the assembled farmers and local government representatives that they really only had about 10 years to undergo a significant restructuring of their industry and to position themselves for the changes that were to occur in the international marketplace, especially the competition they would inevitably face from New Zealand producers of similar commodities.

At that time it was a message the farmers really did not want to hear. Many in the sector were walking that fine line, facing severe economic pressures, and there was going to be, in the natural course of economic events, a requirement for them to leave the industry. We understood that at the time, we sympathised with that at the time, and we developed a Commonwealth response that had at its core compassion for those who had invested so much in the rural sector and in their farms but for one reason or another were going to be required to leave.

I think history has proved us to be correct. If we look at the situation in the rural industry today, we find that the dairy industry is well positioned with higher than average incomes being earned in that sector relative to others. A degree of stability has been achieved. The restructuring has meant that this industry is positioned now to compete with its international rivals and to capture significant shares of markets in that international marketplace.

Against that backdrop I am very pleased that amendments have been made to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. The amendment being proposed here is a technical amendment and it relates to the application of amendments to the Bankruptcy Act 1996 contained in the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Act 1994. It is designed to allow a farmer who became bankrupt before 28 April 1994 to retain a grant under the rural adjustment scheme made after that date.

The proposed amendment will ensure that, where a bankrupt farmer applies for and receives a grant, he or she will be able to keep the grant or the property that has been acquired with it. It is a protection from certain bankruptcy proceedings and is designed to ensure that those who make the decision to exit a rural industry have some chance of resurrecting something from the ashes of that decision. The amendment reflects the compassion that we have for people who have to make that awful economic decision to vacate an industry where they have made not only an economic investment but also a significant personal investment.

I congratulate the opposition for the manner in which they have supported the amendments that are being proposed in this legislation. I am sure that in the course of this debate there will be areas of difference between us, especially relating to aspects of the quarantine service and some of the other provisions that are made in this legislation.

By and large, however, this legislation is necessary. In the main, these are technical and housekeeping amendments that do not involve the Commonwealth in significant outlays and I think they deserve the support of this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to get the opportunity to comment on legislation bills and amending bills with regard to the primary industries and energy portfolio. As the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) said, one cannot speak on a bill such as this without mentioning the vast progress that has been made in the dairy industry.

PARA.TAB: As in the electorate of the honourable member for Corio, the dairy industry in my electorate is about to face up to some more challenges between now and the turn of the century. Hopefully the industry, the government, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) and the opposition will be equal to the task of finding a way through the problems that will be faced by the dairy industry with the signing of the GATT agreement.

The bill before the House tonight is basically an omnibus bill which will amend several pieces of primary industry legislation, including the Quarantine Act 1908, three agricultural and veterinary chemical acts, the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act and the Rural Adjustment Act 1992.

To me, probably the most important aspect of this bill is that pertaining to the operations of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. Prior to entering this place after the 1993 election, I had a reasonable amount of exposure to the operations of AQIS, more on the inspection service side than on the quarantine service side. I believed that there was an enormous amount of scope for improvement in its operation and the cost-charge basis of its inspection services.

I turn to the amendments to the Quarantine Act. The Commonwealth's quarantine service has suffered many problems in regard to fee for service. Many of the customers of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Services cannot get an accurate picture of how much the quarantine procedures—which can last up to 10 years—are likely to cost. In recent years we have had a number of interesting cases. I think the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) and the shadow minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) earlier this evening alluded to the quarantine that must be undergone in the case of goats when breeding stock is imported, and the cost of that quarantine.

A few weeks ago the shadow minister for primary industry was in my electorate. We looked at the traditional industries that use the AQIS service: the fishing industry, the oyster exporting industry, the exporting of fish, and the local abattoirs which operate an export licence, as well as a domestic abattoir. We had a great debate earlier this year with regard to the change in the inspection service charges that AQIS applies to export and domestic abattoirs.

Probably the most interesting few hours that the shadow minister had with me in my electorate was spent visiting an ostrich farm. We have a number of ostrich breeders outside the city of Port Macquarie. They have faced enormous difficulties in trying to get fresh breeding stock into Australia. The South Africans will not sell ostriches, so our breeders are forced to import them from places like Canada. One breeder whom we visited, Kevin Gleeson, had to lease a jumbo jet and, in a roundabout sort of a fashion, had to get this breeding stock to Cocos Islands, which I think is where the AQIS quarantine station is located. He was not complaining—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do ostriches fly?

—No. The ostriches were not flying; they were inside the 747 which was flying. He had to lease the 747 and have it specially fitted out for carrying the ostriches. About $1 million worth of ostriches died on the trip. Of course, the cost of insuring that stock was prohibitive. Kevin Gleeson has a breeding stock of hundreds and hundreds of ostriches and he is trying to get different bloodlines into Australia. We have not got to the stage where the birds are starting to be slaughtered for their meat, their skins, or their feathers. We are still building up a breeding base across Australia. So it is very important that AQIS show some understanding and give a bit of assistance to the ostrich breeding industry. I kid you not, it is a multi-million dollar industry, and it is growing. It is right there in Port Macquarie. The honourable member for Gwydir was amazed—he comes from west of the range where it is predominantly beef cattle, sheep and grain—to see this industry that has been established in Port Macquarie.

PARA.TAB: Kevin Gleeson, the operator of the ostrich breeding facility, was certainly quite happy with the service he received from AQIS in his last exercise of bringing ostriches into Australia from Canada. But he has previously had a devil of a time bringing the ostriches into Australia and the cost of doing so has been rather expensive. The amendments to the Quarantine Act 1908 should be of assistance in this regard.

One very good feature of the bill before the House is that it allows the Commonwealth to enter into agreements with private companies or contractors which can undertake quarantine functions on behalf of the Commonwealth. This should allow competition and, with work being done outside the Public Service, should result in reduced costs. That is something that has been proven, day in and day out, in a lot of the institutions around Australia that use the Quarantine and Inspection Service, such as the export abattoirs that I was talking about before.

Through a number of different ownership changes of an export abattoir in my electorate at Wingham, that company has slowly and steadily built up its own quality assurance program to the highest level. People employed in the works can do all the work of the AQIS inspectors. The company is still obliged to employ a certain level of AQIS inspector at a very high charge-out rate. I think it was up in the $70,000 range; it has dropped back a bit since the domestic charges were changed, but it is still too dear.

The fact remains that the people the company employed in its own QA program can do the work. The operators of the company have recently changed hands from Anvic and Toman to the Nippon Meat Packaging Co. That is another story in itself. The local Australian owners could no longer afford to expand the abattoir to continue operating and competing on the international market without a massive injection of capital. That capital could not be produced in Australia. So who owns it now? The Nippon Meat Packaging Co. The positive side is that it has saved 350 jobs in the town of Wingham because the abattoir will remain there. It is one of the few remaining and very viable export abattoirs in New South Wales.

I turn again to the subject of meat inspectors. There is still an enormous cost which is passed back to the producers, because all those things are deducted before they get their cheque for the livestock that they send to the abattoirs or when they make purchases those costs are passed on.

We have had numerous inquiries into AQIS. The Auditor-General's report No. 35 addressed the quarantine service of AQIS. I know that AQIS is addressing a lot of these problems, but we have to keep pushing further down that path because enormous efficiency gains can be had in that meat processing industry. We certainly have to pursue them, because it is terribly important if the industry is to remain world competitive to get those gains. We can make gains in other areas with mechanisation. That is happening in the meat processing industry by the private sector, but we must do this side of it.

On the other side of the coin, if we talk to the export meat processors, they will acknowledge the need to have a Commonwealth inspection service of some sort. They acknowledge a need for Commonwealth inspectors on the plant, because they need to have that imprimatur on Commonwealth products going out of Australia. We need to streamline the cost of that service. I know there is a debate on whether to charge out that cost at 100 per cent or whether, as a community service obligation, it should be partially funded, or whether there should be some sort of cross-subsidisation from other sectors. That debate is healthy, but the situation can be improved for the cost of meat inspection services being passed back to producers.

Part of this bill addresses the rural adjustment act and the rural adjustment scheme. So many of our farmers have had to leave their farms in Australia because of financial and climatic circumstances—quite often circumstances not of their own making. We can do something about these levies and inspection charges on products going through the processing section of their industry.

Turning back to the bill, the amendments concerning the Quarantine Act will allow quarantine stations to take booking fees and deposits for services. That seems sensible in that, if these places are to be run on a businesslike basis, they must be able to forward plan to keep the quarantine station in work. There will be room for AQIS to charge for late payment of fees or to withhold quarantine services until fees and deposits have been paid.

The coalition does not object to any of these amendments. All we ask is that the ground rules are made quite clear. Another message that came from Kevin Gleeson, the ostrich breeder in Port Macquarie, was that, provided they know up-front what they are up against when bringing new bloodlines into Australia and what hoops and procedures they will have to go through, he is not concerned. As long as they know that they can budget and allocate time for it, they can start the process at the other end as far as the country of origin is concerned at the right time of the year.

The coalition does not object to any of these things. All we ask is that the ground rules are made clear to the people in Australia who will be using the service. Amendments to this act also legalise the electronic processing of imports for quarantine purposes and provide that notice be given of imports. Many of these amendments were recommended in the Auditor-General's report No. 35 of 1991-92 on quarantine fees and charges. Three particular recommendations in that report have resulted in the amending bill that is before the House tonight. One was recommendation No. 53, which read:

SPEECH.PARA: The ANAO recommends that AQISbe given the discretion in the new quarantine bill to withhold services in relation to quarantine items for non-payment of fees.
The response from AQIS was:

Agreed inclusion of an appropriate power in the Agricultural Quarantine Bill is proposed as part of comprehensive provisions for financial management of quarantine functions. AQIS notes that withholding services in some cases is not practical, for example, aircraft arrivals, overseas containers, et cetera.
The second recommendation this bill is responding to is recommendation No. 55:

AQIS make greater use of monetary penalties to improve its cash flow and encourage the prompt payment of outstanding accounts and give consideration to introducing a policy of providing discounts to clients who settle outstanding debts within a certain time frame.
Certainly, they are fairly well accepted commercial practices. The response from AQIS was:
Agreed.
The second part states:

AQIS has some concern with the implicit cross-subsidisation involved in this proposal given the 100 per cent cost recovery basis of all charges. Other clients would need to pay higher charges to meet the cost of the discount. Prepayment of charges is being investigated. There currently exist legislative constraints to the introduction of discounts and prepayment but the principle will be further considered.
I understand that under this legislation a booking fee deposit system is going to be introduced to quarantine stations, ANAO recommendation No. 56. The response was:

As acknowledged in the report, this recommendation was also made in the report of the review of animal quarantine stations. To implement booking fees, amendment of the quarantine legislation is necessary. This change will be incorporated in drafting instructions for the proposed agricultural quarantine bill.

So those things are to be implemented. I suppose the Auditor-General is trying to recommend that AQIS get itself onto a far more commercialised footing, which I am sure it is attempting to do. I am a member of the public accounts committee, which has been conducting an inquiry into the commercialisation of GBEs. We have had the opportunity to hear representatives from AQIS give evidence in that inquiry.

PARA.TAB: One of the major problems AQIS and a number of other GBEs face is a cultural problem in regard to the change of attitude involved in moving from a departmental or public service mode of operation, with the budgetary constraints and limitations that go with it, to a commercial type operation, with full accrual accounting and cost recovery. The problem AQIS confronted in the commercialisation process was not just restricted to AQIS; it tended to be across the board. I am sure that will be evident in some of the recommendations the public accounts committee will bring down when it reports on that inquiry later in the year.

Three agricultural and veterinary chemical acts will be amended to extend the time available to the states to pass complementary legislation. The Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act will be amended. The amendments to the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act 1949 remove gender-specific terminology from the act. Here we go again. When I was in my office I heard one of the previous speakers—I think it was the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh)—trying to get around the terminology of `the Ombudsman'. So it probably will not be long before we have an `ombudsperson'.

The very important rural adjustment scheme contained in the Rural Adjustment Act 1992 is going to be amended to make the annual reporting arrangements for the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council more appropriate. The government's new amendment to ensure that creditors cannot get their hands on re-establishment grants paid to bankrupt farmers who have been forced to leave their farms is supported by the coalition. Many farmers or their spouses have been forced to take part-time jobs or whatever work they can get just to put food on the table. Yet they often still have to pay interest bills amounting to tens of thousands of dollars.

During 1993, almost 13,000 farmers sought interest rate assistance, but about 5,300 of these applications were refused. Farmers are very proud people who do not like asking for help. Therefore, these applications are not made lightly. With such a high rejection rate, is it any wonder that people keep telling the coalition there is no point in applying? It is a wrong attitude to take with people in dire circumstances. This government continues to tell us through its policies that it has a safety net for everybody and that it will not let people lag behind in the slipstream and that, if they do, it will reach back and pick them up. We challenge the government to give a bit more consideration to those people in Australia who have provided Australia with a lot of its wealth in years gone by, such as those in the farming community.

Most farmers are trying to stay on their farms. But, last year, 811 applications were filed for re-establishment grants. This figure was up on the 634 received in 1992. The final answer is not in giving farmers assistance but in making them profitable. The government's indirect taxes on the rural sector cost around $1 billion per year. A handout of $40 million or $50 million in interest subsidies is small when compared with what the government collects.

We have a happy knack in this country of continually increasing the indirect tax take on the productive sector and the people who are producing the wealth of this country: exporting industries; small business; and the people who have the opportunity and ability to generate employment. We—I use that word in the collective sense, and refer to the government in particular—continually ignore that fact and continually increase indirect taxes. They are the easiest people to target because they are the people who are operating, producing profit and income and generating employment in Australia.

Since we are talking about AQIS, I will close by reinforcing the points I made earlier. It is of vital importance, particularly to the beef industry in Australia, that the current situation as far as inspection charges are concerned be reviewed and that the charge that operators pay be more reflective of what the inspectors actually cost on the floor of the abattoirs. We need to pay far more attention to those abattoirs that have a QA program in place which can be used at a far more efficient rate than the AQIS inspectors on the floor who cost $70,000 per year. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have assured the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Johns), who is at the table, that I do not wish to spend long on my feet. But I want to reinforce the remarks already made by my colleagues the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), particularly as they refer to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. Mr Deputy Speaker Snow, as you would be aware from your experience, I have an interest in the Snowy Mountains scheme, the ultimate result of that scheme and the storage of water as it affects my electorate. I would like an opportunity to also reflect for a moment on that section of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable member for Lyne has indicated, the debate about AQIS, its fee structure and the service it delivers goes on and on. I join my colleagues in expressing my concern about AQIS's fee delivery in the past and acknowledge those areas where AQIS has proved to be much more flexible than its reputation has generally led producers to believe it would be.

I had an experience in my electorate in the past few weeks with LVS abattoirs at Angaston in the Barossa Valley. LVS had found itself in financial difficulty as a result of what were accumulated inspection fees, particularly export inspection fees, that applied to the abattoir but which had not been paid.

I must in the parliament acknowledge that, while AQIS has a reputation for being ruthless, at this point it proved willing to renegotiate this fee structure on the understanding that a late payment and penalty would be met by the company. I hope that partially as a result of my intervention—certainly it was the result of some flexibility on AQIS's part—it was possible for LVS abattoirs to continue in business. Had AQIS stood by the letter of the law, LVS would have been closed simply because it did not have the cash flow to meet its outstanding debts to AQIS. So, in that sense, I acknowledge AQIS's flexibility.

I have to say though that the story does not have a particularly happy ending. Having some months ago negotiated this restructured arrangement with AQIS on behalf of LVS Meats, I subsequently discovered that LVS Meats was also behind in the levy collection obligations that it had, both for research and development and for AMLC. At this point I am critical because, without warning and without negotiation, the Attorney-General's office was brought in and LVS Meats was obliged to meet a payment that it clearly could not meet. In the last three weeks it has been bankrupted. As soon as word got out that it was in financial difficulty the tax office indicated that LVS Meats had some outstanding obligations; a local transport operator appeared, and it seemed on the surface that there was very little opportunity for this particular abattoir to be saved.

I rise to make this point in the context of this legislation because it is worth noting that the bank was not alarmed about LVS Meats, which had entered into a restructuring program. The bank recognised that it had entered into some new management techniques and that there would be opportunity for it to trade its way out. But such trading opportunity did not exist because, as a result of the actions of the Attorney-General's office, this abattoir is now in a bankrupt state and has been offered for auction. There is a real threat that the 20 or so jobs in the town of Angaston in the Barossa Valley will be lost. So I do not have quite the same gloss to put on this story as the honourable member for Lyne had to offer on the 350 jobs that were saved in the electorate of Lyne.I must, however, recognise that in this instance, as I said, AQIS was flexible.

I note that the legislation currently before the House makes some amendments to the Quarantine Act to allow for the late payment of fees in respect of quarantine service; booking fees and deposits for services to be provided at quarantine stations; the withholding of quarantine services until fees and deposits have been paid; the electronic processing of imports for quarantine purposes; the Commonwealth to enter into agreements with other persons for the purpose of carrying out quarantine functions; and notice to be given of imports.

I would hope that some of the capacity to negotiate that I experienced with AQIS is reflected in future with other abattoir stations that may well also find themselves needing to be flexible in order not to be forced to the wall, particularly in light of the government's commitment to regional Australia, to the development of regional Australia and presumably to job creation in regional Australia. There is no doubt that a number of the abattoir facilities around Australia exist, have export licences and have export opportunities largely because of what has been done to reassure those who are our major customers that the meat that is processed at our abattoirs leaves Australia in pristine state, and that in fact pesticide residues will not be a problem because of the inspection services that we offer.

It is in that context that I would like to refer to another section of the bill before the House. This section involves the changes proposed to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act. They are proposed as a contingency measure to allow the states to extend from 1994 to 1996 the time they have to put into place complementary state legislation to allow for fee collection and to allow for the evaluation and registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals around Australia. The opposition does not wish to frustrate the government in what has been an effort by the government to accommodate those states that have not been as rapid as they should have been in implementing the complementary legislation that the government sought.

I only want to comment that I am one who supports the judicious use of agricultural chemicals and who believes that the nation is the better for the careful use of agricultural chemicals. I would add that the dust storm that swept across much of south and south-eastern Australia about two weeks ago, dramatic though it was and disastrous though it was, would have been much worse 20 years ago when agricultural chemicals were not as widely used and when the opportunity for herbicide application was not as apparent. In fact, had those sorts of weather conditions been experienced 20 years ago we would have had an even more severe dust storm, disastrous though the one two weeks ago was, simply because we would have had more paddocks worked up and less paddocks left in a semi-tilled state, this semi-tilled state being possible because of the careful use of herbicides as part of the agricultural and veterinary chemicals currently available to our farmers.

On that note, as I weave the various parts of this act together, the dust storm that took up so much of the west coast of South Australia—much of which was deposited in the eastern part of South Australia, and some of which I know moved into the eastern states—was evidence of the sort of dilemma facing farmers, particularly farmers on the west coast of South Australia, as they watched their top soil disappear while they were simply waiting for rain. The House has been told of the disastrous drought that threatened to grip South Australia. That was broken by rains that fell only in the last week, too late I fear for some of our farmers.

It is worth reflecting on the fact that for much of the west coast it will ensure that there will be some sort of feed and some sort of paddock cover. But it will still be very difficult for farmers in the west coast of South Australia and in the Mallee areas of my own electorate to sow the sorts of crops that produce the harvests that keep bankruptcy at bay. The simple fact is that the further one gets inland, particularly in South Australia, the colder it gets and the harder it is to get a late sown crop to the point of harvest, and certainly a harvest of sufficient abundance that allows farmers to be recompensed for the outlay they have made on planting that crop.

Australia already faces a farm debt of some $18 billion. In a recent survey, almost 28 per cent of farmers said that, given a choice, they would choose to cease farming. It is in that context that we need, as we all know, some very effective rural adjustment scheme, and I note the commitment of the government to regionalising the present rural adjustment scheme. I also welcome the commitment covered in this legislation that suggests that farmers that are bankrupt will not be obliged to include as part of their payment to their creditors the money they receive as resettlement money from the rural adjustment scheme. Along with my colleagues, I welcome the changes that the government is proposing to the RAS so that farmers will have the capacity, even though they may be bankrupt, to effectively quarantine—for want of a better word—their RAS payments as a resettlement payment so that they will not be something that their creditors will automatically have access to.

Finally, I refer to the changes that are proposed to the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority to allow the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to appoint a commissioner or assistant commissioner for an indefinite period, and changes that will ensure that any areas that are gender specific in the act are amended to reflect what is seen as the politically correct thing to do in this day and age.

As a South Australian, as a member representing a state that has been threatened by drought and just narrowly spared what looked like being a 1994 drought, I am very conscious of the importance of Snowy Mountains water to my state. Not everyone in the parliament would realise that even in good years up to 50 per cent of the water that is used to maintain, not the irrigators along the Murray, but the people who live in the city of Adelaide, is sourced from the River Murray.
