In conclusion, I call on the government to look to the whole question of water quality in the Murray as part of what might be a bicentennial project. I know the Prime Minister has indicated an interest in this. There is a desperate need for some Commonwealth intervention to allow the sewage ponds of River Murray towns that are currently located on the river flat and within the flood plain to be relocated to higher ground. A very simple initiative that I would encourage the government to take up as it looks to this whole question of water quality is the question of what is done about the funding of the Albury-Wodonga Freshwater Research Institute.

I know, Mr Deputy Speaker Snow, that you are familiar with this institute given its proximity to your electorate. I would point out to the House that the institute is currently funded as part of a cooperative research centre involving La Trobe University and the ANU. Along with the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Forrest), I have been mounting a campaign to allow the Albury-Wodonga Freshwater Institute to establish a sub-laboratory which would be located in about Mildura and would allow further research into blue-green algae control.

I encourage the government to look to the uncertain funding that the institute currently faces, to give it a more certain ground for funding, and the opportunity to expand the work it is doing in freshwater research, because the provision of freshwater, particularly to my electors in South Australia, and to all Australians, is of paramount importance. I recognise what has been done in state cooperation and look to having that state cooperation further enhanced. I commend the bill currently before the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State, Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters)

SPEECH.PARA: The government's amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 will amend the Offshore Minerals Act 1994, the Quarantine Act 1908 and the Bankruptcy Act 1966. With regard to the Bankruptcy Act, the proposed amendment is a technical amendment relating to the application amendments to the Bankruptcy Act 1966 contained in the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Act 1994. This amendment relates to the position of a person who has already become bankrupt but has not applied for or received a rural adjustment scheme re-establishment grant. The amendment will ensure that a former farmer who became bankrupt before 28 April 1994 will be able to apply for and receive a re-establishment grant without the grant being taken for creditors.

PARA.TAB: Under present subsection 91(2) of the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Act 1994, a recipient of a rural adjustment scheme payment can retain the payment or property purchased with it if the payment was received after 28 April 1994 and if the recipient becomes a bankrupt after that date. The changes to the Bankruptcy Act 1966 introduced by the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Act 1994 were designed to protect farmers being assisted out of primary production with rural adjustment scheme grants. The changes to the Bankruptcy Act 1966 are currently expressed to apply only in relation to payments made after 28 April 1994 where the bankruptcy also occurs after that date. Former farmers who became bankrupt before 28 April 1994 and who would otherwise be eligible to receive a rural adjustment scheme grant would be precluded from getting one because the grant would vest in the bankruptcy trustee.

With regard to the Offshore Minerals Act 1994, the amendments to that act correct an error that relates to the preservation of exploration permits granted under the Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981. It was intended that renewal of a permit should be for 75 per cent of the area of the permit. The figure for the surrender of part of the permit upon renewal should be 25 per cent, not 75 per cent.

There are two amendments to the Quarantine Act 1908. The first of these amendments provides that a notice given to an importer by a quarantine officer requesting additional information will now also be able to be given to the agent of an importer. The notice given to an importer is deemed to be given by the principal quarantine officer in a state. A second amendment will provide that this be extended to the territories.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill (on motion by Mr Johns) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY GOVERNMENT SERVICE (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 12 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns The Hon G.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State, Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill contains the amendments that are required to Commonwealth legislation as a result of the arrangements being put in place by the government of the Australian Capital Territory for a separate public service. The ACT government has announced its intention to have arrangements for the new service in place by 1 July 1994. The Commonwealth government has undertaken to have appropriate legislation in place to facilitate the commencement of the service on that date.

PARA.TAB: The 1988 ACT self-government legislation provided, on an interim basis, for the `core' ACT Public Service to be constituted by a branch of the Australian Public Service called the ACT administration. The head of the ACT administration has the powers of a secretary to a department under the Commonwealth Public Service Act 1922. These were intended to be transitional arrangements pending the establishment of a separate public service for the territory.

In 1992 the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) initiated moves to establish a separate public service for the ACT on the basis that it had always been the Commonwealth's intention that the ACT should move, over time, to such an agreement. Funding for an establishment task force was made available to the territory by the Commonwealth to assist in progressing the matter.

Consultations between the ACT and the Commonwealth and the ACTU have taken place in accordance with subsection 21(7) of the ACT Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Act 1988. The new ACT Public Service will be established by ACT legislation to be passed by the ACT Assembly. Currently, there are two pieces of legislation before the ACT Assembly which deal with the general structure of, and detail associated with, the proposed service. This bill completes the arrangements from the Commonwealth's point of view.

I now turn more specifically to the provisions of the bill. Because of Canberra's unique position as the seat of two Australian governments, the issue of continuing mobility between the two public services is of particular importance to the thousands of Commonwealth employees who have worked to implement self-government and who will be transferred to the new ACT government service. The bill therefore provides for an arrangement where officers of the territory service are able to apply for and compete on merit for non-Senior Executive Service positions in the Australian Public Service which are advertised in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. All Senior Executive Service positions are already open to applicants outside the Australian Public Service.

These mobility arrangements will be reciprocated by the ACT. The arrangements will ensure that permanent staff movements between the services will be through the merit processes of the gaining service. Appointments from the losing service to the gaining service will be subject to the usual rights of appeal or review available in relation to promotions within the Australian Public Service.

The mobility arrangements in the bill also provide for the recognition of periods of probation served in either service. The package of measures will also provide for the recognition of prior service for the purpose of calculating most entitlements. In the case of superannuation, service will be recognised in accordance with the provisions of the relevant superannuation scheme.

The bill also makes provision in relation to the rights of staff under the officers' mobility scheme provided for in part IV of the Public Service Act 1922. This scheme currently provides for the rights of re-entry to the Australian Public Service where staff have left the APS to take up employment in other areas of the Commonwealth. Where staff, before participating in the scheme, held an office which was associated with a function that is now the responsibility of the ACT government, the ACT government will make provision for re-entry or re-appointment to the ACT government service. The bill extinguishes the rights of these people under part IV of the Public Service Act 1922 to return to the Australian Public Service. ACT government employment will remain within the federal industrial relations system as public sector employment under the Industrial Relations Act 1988.

In the spirit of cooperation, the Commonwealth will continue to make many of its services available to the ACT government. The ACT government will have access, on a user pays basis, to, for example, recruitment programs, training and development programs, arrangements for workers compensation, the Merit Protection and Review Agency, the Remuneration Tribunal and the Australian Government Health Service. The bill will make provision in relation to the application of the Privacy Act 1988 in the ACT public sector.

The bill will amend and modify the Privacy Act in two parts. First, it will make amendments to the act so that the information privacy principles will not have long-term application to the ACT public sector. In acknowledgment of the self-governing status of the ACT, the government recognises that the privacy laws that are to apply in the territory public sector are a matter for the territory.

Second, the bill will extend, on an interim basis until an ACT enactment provides otherwise, the application of the information privacy principles in the Privacy Act to ACT public sector agencies. This is being done at the request of the ACT government and will ensure that there is no erosion of existing rights ACT residents enjoy under the Privacy Act. The government expresses the hope that the ACT will, when it provides that the interim measures are no longer to apply, consider the enactment of privacy legislation for the ACT of at least an equivalent standard to that currently applying under the Commonwealth act.

As further legislative amendments may be identified as the arrangements for the separate service are put in place, a regulation making power has been included to enable the modification of an act in its application to matters arising from, connected with or consequential on the establishment of the new service. This regulation making power mirrors a provision in the earlier legislation providing for self-government for the territory, and a sunset period of two years has been provided for.

The regulation making power will be used to enable amendments that fall within the scope of the legislative scheme agreed by the governments to be made expeditiously. The power will not be used to make any significant alteration to the agreed scheme. This bill is just one element in the arrangements that need to be put in place to facilitate the establishment of the new service. Ongoing consultations between the Commonwealth, the ACT government and the unions will continue in relation to these remaining matters.

The establishment of a separate public service by the ACT government is an important milestone for the ACT and is a logical step following on from the implementation of self-government in the territory. The Commonwealth government notes the ACT government's commitment to the establishment of a cohesive and professional public service for the territory and looks forward to the continuation of the cooperative working arrangements between the two governments. I congratulate all of those people who have been involved in these negotiations. I wish the ACT Government Service well in its journey. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Capital Territory Government Service (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1994 enables the ACT to establish its own public service and amends the ACT Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Act 1988, the Public Service Act 1922 and the Privacy Act 1988. The coalition will support the passing of this bill as it stands and at this time. We believe that the formation of a separate ACT public service is an important step by the ACT on the road to total self-government.

PARA.TAB: Almost 23,000 ACT administration staff will become members of the new ACT Government Service. However, we would like to point out that, although much of the bill's content has merit, we are concerned at the number of issues in the bill which appear to be contentious and not easily resolved. Many of the contentious issues are a result of the Labor Party's well-known inability to keep its promises to the electorate, its inability to work on a Commonwealth-state level, and its inability to negotiate appropriate outcomes with unions.

In particular, I refer to the mobility arrangements between the APS and the ACTGS whereby officers of both services can apply and compete on merit for non-Senior Executive Service positions advertised in the APS gazette. This is consistent with the general coalition philosophy, which supports, firstly, improved performance and the rewarding of effort in the public sector; secondly, the introduction of greater flexibility into the APS by allowing recruitment from a wider base; and, thirdly, officers being encouraged to use opportunities to increase their experiences and abilities by moving between agencies and services. However, we note that this falls far short of what was originally promised.

When the ACT Chief Minister, Rosemary Follett, promoted the concept of a separate ACT public service, she promised that when a separate service was formed it would not disadvantage ACT public servants in any way. In particular, she promised that there would be full mobility provisions which would allow for unrestricted movement of public servants between the ACT and the Australian public services. This bill clearly does not fulfil this promise. Indeed, the issue continues to be the subject of much dissent between the government and the unions—so much so that it has been referred to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

The unions wish to hold up the bill until a determination has been handed down. The coalition sees no merit in this, as the government has agreed that it will make amendments to the bill if they are required. Furthermore, I understand that the Industrial Relations Commission will endeavour to hand down a determination prior to 1 July, when this bill comes into effect.

In conclusion, I stress the coalition's disappointment at the breach of trust on the part of the Labor government in going back on its much publicised promise to ACT public servants of full mobility provisions when the ACT public service was established. This is yet another issue which will further convince the electorate to vote no to Labor governments in the February ACT election and in the federal election which will follow not long after. The opposition will not oppose the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to know that the opposition supports the Australian Capital Territory Government Service (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1994. It is an important bill. In fact, it really is the last substantial phase in the movement towards self-government in the ACT. Whilst that was a controversial issue within the territory, it seemed to many people—and I was one of them—that, given that we live in a democracy, it was not appropriate for people to have the right to say, `We will not govern ourselves'; we had to accept that responsibility.

PARA.TAB: I think there are advantages for the ACT in self-government which are commonly neglected. One of the most important ones is that it leads to a more coordinated delivery of community services. Before self-government there were about a dozen departments and a dozen ministers involved in some aspect of ACT government in the provision of ACT community services. That was very inefficient. It also meant that at no time was there an attempt to set priorities within the territory as to which of those services should be given attention. Finally, it meant that there was no one person or one group of people responsible for negotiating with the Commonwealth government in the interests of the ACT.

Whilst it is true that the Commonwealth has cut the funding of the ACT, it has done the same with other states and territories. Whilst I do not think that is an appropriate policy, I think we have done probably marginally better than we would have done if there had been no ACT government negotiating on behalf of the people of the ACT. So on balance, with all factors taken into account, I think self-government has been an appropriate step. The purpose of this bill, which is to establish an ACT public service, is just a logical consequence of that. Clearly, no government can have responsibility for its own policies without also having responsibility for its own officers. This bill establishes that.

The preparation of the bill has taken a long time. There have been extensive negotiations, as the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) and the Special Minister of State (Mr Johns) have said. It is true that those issues are not yet entirely resolved. I regret that the bill has come into the House before these issues have been finally resolved. However, there has been considerable narrowing of the differences over the period of this negotiation. Many of the conflicts have been settled.

I understand that the outstanding issues will go before the Industrial Relations Commission on Friday. As the honourable member for Ryan mentioned, the minister has said that, if the commission determines that any issues are inconsistent with the bill, then the bill can be amended. I see the minister nodding in agreement with that. That is very reassuring for the people whose interests are being discussed here. The principal question involved relates to mobility; that is, the right to transfer between the two services—the ACT service and the Commonwealth service. But there are also issues relating to redundancy, sick leave and long service leave. Those issues are still under discussion and are being negotiated with and debated by the commission.

In conclusion, I think the Commonwealth government is doing the right thing by bringing this bill forward now. The ACT government does want to set up the service. It wanted to do so by 1 July. The bill could not have been left any later than this if that were to happen. Given that pressure from the government whose responsibilities are about to be increased, I think the Commonwealth really had to act in the way that the minister has outlined. As far as I can tell, I think there is good faith on the part of the Commonwealth government. I fully expect that these issues will be resolved through either negotiation or arbitration. We are fortunate in Australia to have a system that does allow that kind of fair judicious settlement of industrial conflict. So I congratulate the minister, the public servants who have been negotiating on and preparing this bill and the unions who have been representing their members effectively. I wholeheartedly wish the new ACT public service well.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 May 1969 in Santa Cruz, Trinidad, the youngest of seven brothers in a family of 11 children was born to a mother, Pearl, who is now 63 years old and a father, Bunty, who died in 1989. Bunty was an agricultural manager and he looked after his children well. The youngest child, about whom I am talking, is Brian Lara. His father bought him all the necessary cricket equipment. Only a couple of days ago, on the 50th anniversary of D-day, Brian achieved true greatness. I would like to pay tribute to that Trinidadian batsman here tonight.

PARA.TAB: Playing for Warwickshire against Durham, in 474 minutes off 427 balls he scored 501 not out, which is the highest first-class innings ever. This came only a few weeks after his scoring the highest test innings ever of 375 against the English at Antigua. Brian Lara beat the first-class record of Hanif Mohammed, who scored 499 for Karachi back in the 1958-59 season. That innings took just under 11 hours. Hanif Mohammed, one of four brothers who played test cricket, was run out off the last ball in a mix-up. Incidentally, in a 16 hour 10 minute innings, Hanif scored 337 against the West Indies in a test at Barbados.

On the way to that score of 501, Brian Lara beat Don Bradman's 452 not out in a game between New South Wales and Queensland at the SCG in the 1929-30 season. Bradman got to the 450 mark in 414 minutes, which was just over a quarter of an hour quicker than Brian Lara did. It is interesting that all those three batsmen made triple centuries in tests and that all three were short. Brian Lara is only 162 1/2 centimetres tall, or about five foot five.

One could say that this last innings was scored on a flat track. In the first innings, Durham declared at 8 for 556. One could say that the runs were scored against less than the best bowling attack. One could also say that Brian Lara was lucky not to be caught in a straightforward catch to the wicket-keeper when he was 18, in a hot chance he gave to mid-on when he was 238 and in a skied chance he gave to backward square leg, where the fieldsman was unsighted, when he was 413. But that only proves that he is human. By any standards it was an innings of breathtaking proportions. Not only was it the highest first-class score ever; Brian Lara scored the most runs in a single day. He scored 390. The previous record of 345 was held by Charlie Macartney when playing for Australia against Nottinghamshire in 1921. In fact, only 19 batsmen in history have scored more than 300 runs.

Brian Lara was the first left-hander to score more than 400 runs. He was the first West Indian to score more than 400 runs. He scored the most boundaries by a batsman in that innings. He scored 62 fours and 10 sixes. He made 308 runs just off boundaries alone. Those 72 boundaries exceeded the 68 scored by Percy Perrin for Essex back in 1904. Brian Lara started the day with 111 not out. He scored 174 runs in the morning session and 118 runs between lunch and tea. He slowed down to score only 83 runs in the last session.

Brian Lara has scored 1,551 runs in his last eight innings. In seven of those eight innings, he scored centuries. He is the first person ever to do that. He has scored 1,176 runs in his last seven innings in England. Only Bradman had scored 1,000 runs in seven innings in England, and that was back in 1938. It will be interesting to see whether he can match Denis Compton's 18 centuries in a season.

It is a magnificent feat by any standards. I think the world is just gasping open-mouthed at what Brian Lara has achieved. We look forward very much to the next 10, 15 or 20 years of test cricket before him. I fear for what will happen to the Australian team when it visits the West Indies on its next trip.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly tonight about the problems in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and particularly as they apply to Queensland. Moves have been made within the CSIRO to rationalise its operations due to budgetary constraints. That is well understood. The division of expenditure for research between the primary and secondary sectors has to be considered by this organisation when there is any reduction in research expenditure. No-one would deny that over the years CSIRO has made a very big contribution to both the primary and secondary industries in Australia. At the present moment the reductions in moneys have forced a choice between these two competing areas. As a consequence, the primary sector will be the major loser, and Queensland will probably feel the biggest brunt of the changes.

PARA.TAB: The CSIRO has a number of operations throughout the state. In particular, I refer to its operation at Indooroopilly, which is dedicated to research into rural diseases, tropical diseases and the development of adequate ways of protecting livestock against these diseases. The CSIRO is also very closely associated with the University of Queensland. It works very closely with the university, at its farm at Samford, on new developments. In Queensland, the CSIRO plays a unique role in the primary industry research area.

I am appalled at the prospective closure of the Indooroopilly branch of the CSIRO. It has some unique features. It has the facility to isolate and quarantine special diseases. Only one other area in Brisbane has the same facility, and that is Sherwood. I hope that those who control the CSIRO will give very serious consideration to maintaining the facility at Indooroopilly. Through its association with the university and the farm, CSIRO makes a very major contribution to the primary industry sector in Queensland. I hope that the management of CSIRO changes its priorities in that respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to place on the record the concerns of a local constituent regarding the government's current handling of child care. The irony of this situation is that I am really only a bystander in this issue. My constituent wrote a letter, of which I have a copy, to the then duty senator for the Labor Party in my electorate—Senator Richardson, as he then was. The letter is from a local card carrying member of the Labor Party, and she noted her membership number on the letter to Senator Richardson.

PARA.TAB: Since then she says that a follow-up letter has been sent to the relevant minister regarding the child-care situation. This local card carrying member of the ALP was kind enough to forward copies of her letters to me at the time she wrote them. Subsequently, I have made representations on her behalf to the minister to try to get some sort of response to her correspondence. The letter is not from a concerned parent of a child in child care. This lady is actually a professional in the industry and she has been a professional manager of child-care centres all her working life.

My constituent has not received a reply of any kind from the government. It is now three months since the letter was first written. I will read to the House some of the contents of and concerns in her letter. I call on the government to try to be a bit professional and immediately reply to her letter. One would have thought that a member of the government's own party should get some sort of immediate response to correspondence in such a sensitive area. I will read a series of questions from Mrs Smith's letter. It was initially written to Senator Richardson, as he then was, and was then forwarded to the relevant minister. I have subsequently made representations to that minister. The letter states:
re Federal Labor Government Child Care Programme Policy Changes and Problems since 1991 Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Richardson . . .
Some of the questions asked were:
* Why have there been so many changes to how Centres claim Childcare Assistance, (formerly called Fee Relief)?
* Why are so many of these Policy changes badly planned, labour intensive, often unsuitable and badly implemented?

* Why are these changes planned and implemented with little or no previous consultation with Services, who can so easily advise the Department on the viability and commonsense or lack of it, of the policy idea?
* Why is so little time given for implementation of changes despite the fact that Services and Peak Industry organisations keep requesting and indicating that more time and training is needed?
* Why is the communication between Policy makers and Services so poor, so minimal and often so close to or after the implementation date of changes?

* Why is Federal Labor Government incessantly undermining its . . . Child Care Programme—one that is a major electoral issue, one that is vitally needed and wanted by Australian families and one that the Government's stated aim is to provide `affordable quality care'?

* Why through these changes, especially this payment on hours of care used not a daily set fee, is the Government threatening viability of Services and therefore threatening to waste an enormous amount of taxpayers money in setting up and funding this programme?

* Why make changes to fee setting in Long Day Care in such a way as to force us to become similar to Occasional Care Services, unable to estimate income adequately in our Budget? Schools, Pre-Schools, TAFE colleges and Universities charge day or term fees according to their budget estimates. Doctors charge for at consultation times typically 15 minutes: if the patient is with the doctor for eg. 8 minutes the patient still pays the set fee for the short consultation.
* Why is the Government . . . determined to change the Long Day Care way of setting fees and so threaten viability?
In closing, Mrs Smith made the comment:

These changes are very concerning as Labor Policy seems determined to introduce payment, and therefore Childcare Assistance Claims, on hours used rather than as has been the case since the Programmes inception on a set day fee.
This is a major policy shift and is threatening the viability of both the non profit and profit sectors of the industry.
That letter comes from a professional in the child-care industry and also a card carrying member of the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the difficulties facing rural and provincial areas of Australia is access to tertiary facilities. I bring to the attention of the House tonight the Tweed Opening Learning Access Centre which operates from Murwillumbah. The centre is part of the Southern Cross University in Lismore. The centre began operating in 1991. It was opened by Senator Mal Colston, as the representative of the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training, now the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin).

PARA.TAB: The centre provides support to external students in the region. The coordinator and sole staff member of this particular centre is Mrs Margaret Hayes. The feature I point out to the House with regard to the Tweed Opening Learning Access Centre is the support it provides to people who would not normally have access to higher education facilities.

Last week I attended a celebration dinner for a number of graduates of different universities around Australia. The Opening Learning Access Centre is able to function in such a way that students from the area are able to maintain access to universities and tertiary institutions across Australia. The changes that are occurring within tertiary education are exemplified here. Most people traditionally think that to get access to universities and tertiary education facilities they have to go to a particular university location. Most of these universities are located in cities or very large provincial cities.

The nature of the changes in communication means that the Tweed Open Learning Access Centre is able to provide support for students studying at various institutions. It has compatible computers—obviously both IBM and Macintosh—but it is also, through the Southern Cross University, able to provide tutorial support for students who would normally be faced with quite a long trip to the campus at Lismore.

Apart from that, I would like to draw the attention of the House to the range of graduates who were at the recent celebration dinner. The good thing about this—apart from students being linked to a large number of different tertiary institutions—is that students who previously had to leave a particular city and break links with a particular university can now maintain those links and continue training through the university with which the student is familiar.

A prime example of this is that the spouse of a student who started out at a university in Perth was transferred to the north coast. I can understand that would be a good move, but it normally would have meant that the student at the university in Perth would have to stop and start again somewhere else or pick up the threads of his or her education. Through the Tweed Open Learning Access Centre, this person was able to continue the course—a Bachelor of Nursing degree—and was able to finish off that course. It would apply to many other different courses a person might be undertaking. In this case, the person was able to graduate with a Bachelor of Nursing degree without having to change institutions and therefore pick up the training that we require of most people.

Apart from that, another facility provided by the centre is that persons are able to access libraries right across Australia through E-mail, and therefore get hold of much more information than would otherwise be available. I pay tribute to the local community. Apart from being funded 50 per cent by the Southern Cross University, the centre is funded 50 per cent by the community. I pay tribute to the local business community and the Tweed Shire Council for the role they play there.

The centre assisted 1,700 people in 1992. In 1993, it assisted 2,300 people and, to date, there has been a 74 per cent increase on the 1993 figures. I mentioned Margaret Hayes as the manager of the Tweed Open Learning Access Centre. Last but not least, I pay tribute to Mr George Hanna, the chairman of the board of management of the Tweed Open Learning Access Centre, for the fine job, determination and leadership that he has displayed since the centre has been in existence. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to again draw attention to the meagre amount of funds—in particular, the allocation from the most recent budget—which this country is spending on medical research. We so often like to pride ourselves on being a clever country, but we cut people off at the knees—sometimes the very best people—when they are trying to achieve. As a nation, we spend $33 billion in trying to make people better once they are ill. The acutely ill we treat very well; those who are chronically ill, perhaps not quite so well.

PARA.TAB: There is increasing evidence to the effect that, if we wisely spent our research dollar and increased our research dollar, we would in effect save money in the long run. If we could allocate more funds for medical research, less money would be required to try to cure people. This subject is getting a little attention now. A small article in the Australian today states:

The Federal Government has effectively reduced spending on medical research as a proportion of health spending by almost $50 million over four years despite pledges to the contrary, according to a new analysis.

A paper presented to the Australian Medical Association says that despite the Government's announcement last month of an extra $92.8 million over four years for medical and health research, the effective change is a reduction of $12 million a year.

Already, the $92.8 million had been criticised by medical researchers because about half of the money was a restoration to the National Health and Medical Research Council base of previous government initiatives.
Dr Lawrence's predecessor, Mr Graham Richardson, had publicly pledged a doubling of the NHMRC's Budget by 2000 when he was in the portfolio.
But the president of the Australian Society for Medical Research, Dr Christine Clarke, said that by 1998 the funding base of the NHMRC would grow by no more than 10 to 15 per cent.

"To reach 2 per cent by the year 2000, or indeed to achieve a doubling of health research funding, which is what both the Government and the Opposition have indicated is needed, you would need to do much better than an increase of 15 per cent by 1998," she said.

SPEECH.PARA: This subject was highlighted recently for me, as a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which is looking at the management and treatment of breast cancer. There have been consistent arguments from a number of specialists who have given evidence about how essential the research dollar is, but I thought that Professor Forbes put it very well when he said:

There is no mechanism in Australia for infrastructure support for national research programs and that is why I find it very frustrating, when you are going to spend $16.4 million on a national breast centre, that one component of that is not infrastructure support and national research programs of relevance to the national strategy.

PARA.TAB: It is difficult, however, for many people to get funding. The cake is too small.

SPEECH.PARA: He then gave some figures comparing us with the United States, and said:

The single most important change that could be changed overnight would be to double the NHMRC grant allocation for all medical research. That would allow everyone who wanted to conduct clinical research better access.
I really must stress that it is a very serious worry to researchers. They have no lobby group—none.

He previously explained what a very wise investment it would be, because good clinical research is really measuring outcomes. Given the fact that there does seem to be no lobby group taking up this cause, any time that I have an opportunity to raise it in this place and hope that someone will listen, I shall do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before the Clerk of the Committee calls on the first item of business for consideration, it might be appropriate if I outline some matters of practice and procedure relating to the Main Committee deliberations.The proceedings of the Main Committee are very much proceedings of the parliament and, as such, warrant the same respect as those conducted in the House of Representatives chamber.As a general rule, the practice and procedure observed in the chamber will apply in the Main Committee unless the standing orders specifically provide otherwise. Consequently, for example, members will be required to acknowledge the chair on entering or leaving, will rise to seek the call and will address the Committee standing unless incapacitated.

PARA.TAB: Remarks must be addressed through the chair and members moving within the room in which the Committee is meeting must not pass between the chair and the member addressing the Committee. The speech time limits applying for consideration of business in the House apply in the Main Committee.

Where an extension of time is available under the standing orders it will also apply in the Main Committee. However, it will not be possible for standing and sessional orders to be suspended in the Main Committee for the purpose of providing for an extended speech time or for any other purpose.

One aspect of the Main Committee that differs from the House of Representatives chamber relates to the seating for members. No seats are reserved for specific members. It would be expected that government members would be seated to the right of the chair, and non-government members to the left.

Members should address the occupant of the chair as `Deputy Speaker', whether the chair is occupied by me, the Second Deputy Speaker or a member of the Speaker's panel. Other members should be referred to by the name of the electoral division they represent or the office they hold.

The standing orders provide that the quorum of this Committee shall comprise the occupant of the chair, one government member and one non-government member. Under the standing orders, if the chair takes note that a quorum is not present, proceedings are to be suspended or the Committee is to be adjourned.

Proceedings of the Committee must be suspended to enable members to attend any division in the House. The lights activated by the ringing of the bells will operate in this room, but the bells will be muted. Advice will be relayed directly from the chamber as to whether a division is in progress or a quorum is required and proceedings in the Committee will be suspended if a division is occurring. Committee proceedings will recommence when the chair here is resumed.

Should the House adjourn, the Committee must be adjourned forthwith by the chair. The Committee will be adjourned by the chair on completion of consideration of matters referred to it. Every question in the committee is to be decided on the voices. It is not possible for the committee to divide on a question and any dissent from the result announced by the chair is to be recorded in the minutes as an unresolved question for decision by the House. The Committee may continue proceedings on a bill regardless of unresolved questions unless agreement to an unresolved question is necessary to enable further questions to be considered. In this case the Committee shall return the bill to the House for further consideration. Any member may move at any time during consideration of the Main Committee for further proceedings on a bill to be conducted in the House, and the motion shall be determined without amendment or debate.

The official record of proceedings of the Main Committee will be the minutes of proceedings of the committee kept by the Clerk of the Committee, and will form part of the Votes and Proceedings of the House for the sitting during which the committee meets. A transcript of proceedings will be produced and will form part of the Hansard report of the House for that day.

A sub-table office for the purposes of the Main Committee is located at the rear of this room. Staff, advisers, members of the media and other passholders will be required to enter this room by means of the central corridor. Members of the public will also enter and leave by these central corridor doors. Members may, of course, use all entry and exit points. However, the door in the north-eastern corner—towards the House of Representatives side—will be reserved for entry and exit by members.

Given the significance of this first meeting of the Main Committee, permission has been given for the taking of photographs for official and media purposes. The same guidelines will apply to the taking of photographs by the media. The signal of proceedings will be carried throughout the building by the House monitoring service. As a general rule, the guidelines applying to television camera operators in the chamber will apply to coverage of the Main Committee.

The physical arrangements for the Main Committee enable members of the public and others to be much closer to where consideration of legislation and other matters is taking place than is possible in the House of Representatives chamber. However, the area allotted to members in this room is clearly delineated, and the integrity of that area must be respected at all times.

The first meeting of the Main Committee heralds a new era in the deliberations of the parliament. There has been much discussion about and interest in the proposed operation of this Committee. I am sure that, with the cooperation of all members, the Main Committee will make the positive contribution to the workings of the House of Representatives envisaged by the Standing Committee on Procedure.
Consideration resumed from 9 May.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I congratulate you on your launching of this very interesting innovation in the conduct of parliamentary practice in this country. I know that we will all take heed of the strictures that you have placed upon us in terms of our conduct in this chamber. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill amends the Superannuation Act 1976, the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act 1990, the Superannuation Act 1990 and the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990. These acts relate to the provision of superannuation benefits to civilian Commonwealth sector employees.

PARA.TAB: The main purpose of the bill is to make amendments to allow superannuation schemes for Commonwealth civilian employees to comply with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 and associated legislation. The bill also makes some technical corrections.

The Government decided that its own superannuation schemes that were at least partly funded should comply with the occupational superannuation requirements in the SIS legislation in the same way as private sector schemes. Commonwealth schemes that are not funded will be required to comply in principle with the major thrust of the controls, such as vesting and preservation.

Among other things, the SIS legislation requires that the rules of a superannuation fund may not allow the trustees of the fund to be directed by another person, nor may any other person exercise discretions unilaterally. In addition, the rules of the fund should not be able to be amended without the approval of the trustees. All these rules have some exceptions spelled out in the SI(S) Act itself, and some to be provided for by regulations under that act. The main exception relates to directions, discretions et cetera that would affect the employer's contributions to the fund.

Currently, the Superannuation Act 1976 provides that the Commissioner for Superannuation and a board of trustees share the responsibility for the administration for the scheme set up by the act, the Commonwealth superannuation scheme or CSS. The bill gives the responsibility for administration of the CSS completely to the board of trustees. All discretionary decisions that were previously made by the commissioner will be made by the board from 1 July 1994. The Minister for Finance also has a role under the 1976 act. Some of the powers exercised by the minister are to be transferred to the board. However, other powers which relate to employer costs under the scheme will remain with the minister.

Certain other powers were exercisable by the board after consideration of principles issued by the minister. In the case of these powers, the act generally has been amended to incorporate into the legislation any principles that were issued, and any remaining discretion is to be exercised by agreement between the minister and the board. Similar amendments concerning the powers of the minister are to be made to the Superannuation Act 1990. The scheme established under the provisions of that act is already administered by a board of trustees, so no transfer of power from the Commissioner for Superannuation is necessary.

I emphasise that no changes are to be made to the benefit structure or the scheme design of the schemes covered by the acts that are being amended. One of the technical changes being made is to allow certain delegated instruments to operate with retrospective effect and to put the validity of past instruments beyond doubt. These amendments are a response to concerns raised by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. The instruments would enable members to continue membership in circumstances where they may have inadvertently been forced to leave the scheme if there was no retrospectivity.

The bill also amends the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990. This act enables the Minister for Finance to exercise certain discretions to oversight and control superannuation arrangements established by Commonwealth employing authorities other than the Commonwealth itself. Consistent with the SI(S) Act, the existing ministerial discretions would be replaced with provisions preventing Commonwealth employers from establishing and operating superannuation arrangements unless they are able to satisfy certain predetermined requirements. An added feature of these requirements is that they will impose an obligation on employers to report annually to the minister in relation to those arrangements.

I now turn to the financial impact of the bill. As none of the changes result in any change to the benefit designed for superannuation schemes involved, there is no financial impact. Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend the bill to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Indulgence is granted.

—I join the Leader of the House, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), in marking the inauguration of the Main Committee. The opposition takes the view that it will give the mechanism of the Main Committee its best shot. If the Main Committee can add to the intelligent dispatch of business and, in this rather more intimate atmosphere, lift the quality of debate on some of the less contentious but nonetheless detailed pieces of legislation, the whole parliamentary system and the community will be the beneficiaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I add my best wishes to you and, through you, to the clerks, and I express the wish that this chamber succeeds in the objectives set for it by the government.

PARA.TAB: The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 was introduced into the House on 9 May after it passed through the Senate on 5 May. It was referred to the Main Committee on 2 June, making it the first of several bills to be referred to this Committee. The bill sets out to ensure the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, CSS, and the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme, PSS, are compatible with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, known as the SI(S) Act, and with associated legislation. This is a goal which the coalition agrees with, no matter what concerns we may have with the provisions of the SI(S) Act. Therefore, the coalition does not oppose the legislation. The SI(S) Act, which effectively begins operating from 1 July 1994, makes provision for the prudent management of certain superannuation funds and for oversight by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner.

In particular, the SI(S) Act aims to ensure that members' moneys are as secure as possible. Although the SI(S) Act allows for certain public sector superannuation schemes to be exempted from it, the government has nevertheless decided that all Commonwealth superannuation schemes with an invested fund will comply with the SI(S) Act. This is the first measure to ensure that Commonwealth schemes comply with the SI(S) Act. Further legislation, such as the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, has been introduced with the stated aim of bringing all Commonwealth superannuation schemes with the SI(S) Act. For the information of the Main Committee and others, this bill will bring the parliamentarians' superannuation scheme within the SI(S) Act. Those without an invested fund will still need to comply with the main requirements of the principal act, such as preservation.

In order to ensure that Commonwealth superannuation schemes can continue to be eligible for taxation concessions after 1 July 1994, the governing rules for those schemes, including the legislation, are to be amended. The main thrust of the proposed amendments is to give trustees greater responsibility for and control over the administration of the scheme. This results in the powers of the relevant minister in the role of employer being diminished in some ways and shared with the trustees in other ways. In other instances, discretions previously exercisable by the minister have been replaced by specific provisions in this legislation.

Importantly, the SI(S) Act provides exemptions so that employers are able to retain control of decisions, discretions and amendments which affect the cost to the employer of a scheme. The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill before us will amend four acts. They are: the Superannuation Act 1976, the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act 1990, the Superannuation Act 1990 and the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990. The vast majority of amendments are made to the Superannuation Act 1976, however, which is the act that established the CSS.

Several amendments are made to this act. They are mostly of a technical nature and include the powers and role of the trustees of the CSS, ensuring that the rules of the CSS enable the payment of certain unclaimed benefits to eligible rollover funds as required by the SI(S) Act; providing for the making of and saving of previously made retrospective regulations and other legislative instruments under certain provisions of the act in order to ensure continuing membership of the scheme in certain circumstances and certain other technical amendments that ensure that references to other legislation are correct and that the CSS complies with the SI(S) Act.

The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act 1990 amended the 1976 act as well as other acts as a result of the review of superannuation for Commonwealth employees that led to the introduction of the superannuation scheme provided for by the Superannuation Act 1990. This bill proposes to amend the amending act to correct a technical deficiency in one of its provisions. The Superannuation Act 1990, the 1990 act in brief, provided for the establishment of the PSS under a trust deed and rule. This bill amends the 1990 act in several ways, including changes to the power and role of the trustees that mirror the changes to the CSS, as stated, providing a regulations making power to enable alternations to the 1990 act so that it can easily comply with future amendments to the SI(S) act, its regulations and other regulatory laws and mirror the changes to the CSS so as to provide for the making of and saving of previously made retrospective regulations and other legislative instruments.

The Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act of 1990 allows discretions to be exercised by the Minister for Finance on the oversight and control over the provision by Commonwealth employees of superannuation benefits for their employees outside the CSS and PSS. The amendment to this act enables the Minister for Finance to maintain strategic control of Commonwealth employing authorities superannuation schemes in a manner that is consistent with the SI(S) Act.

Under these amendments, Commonwealth employers will not be able to establish and operate superannuation schemes, unless they are able to satisfy certain requirements that are predetermined by the minister. The amendments proposed in this bill do not alter in any way, shape or form, the financial entitlement accruing to members of the CSS and PSS. Overall these amendments benefit the members of the two Commonwealth superannuation schemes, because members will now have access to the superannuation complaints tribunal, with its low cost dispute resolution mechanisms. Fund members will also maintain access to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, giving members a choice of process by which they can seek redress if they feel hard done by.

These amendments are also reassuring for Commonwealth public servants because their funds will not be protected in the same way as private sector funds are by the provisions of the SIS legislation. This is especially important because invested funds in the CSS and PSS will be subject to the SI(S) Act's prudential standards, which become effective on 1 July this year. Though the SI(S) Act exempted certain public sector schemes from these controls, this legislation brings nearly all Commonwealth public servants under SIS provisions. Many state schemes are apparently unable to comply with the SI(S) Act at this stage, but are expected to be able to do so in the near future, I understand.

The legislation currently before us is fairly straightforward and does not involve a great deal of contention or controversy. However, some aspects of the CSS and PSS warrant discussion, as well as some more general superannuation issues which relate to the SI(S) Act. As honourable members are aware, no doubt, there are no employer contributions from the Commonwealth to meet future claims upon the CSS, and only very limited contributions to the PSS. On retirement, the employer component of the CSS and most of the PSS comes from consolidated revenue. That means, in effect, that, for the CSS alone, there was an unfunded liability of $33 billion as at 30 June 1992. That was a liability of $1,903 a head for every Australian man, woman and child. For the PSS, the employer contribution is only three per cent of salary. This leaves the remaining 12.4 per cent unfunded.

However, the government's potential liability does not end there. In the CSS, employee contributions are invested by Commonwealth Funds Management, CFM, with returns to employees based on investment outcomes. In the PSS though, employee contributions are invested by the CFM, but the return is guaranteed and not limited to investment returns. The Commonwealth thereby has to make up any shortfall that occurs, further exposing consolidated revenue in the future to the need to pay out PSS members on retirement.

A fully funded superannuation scheme is arguably the most desirable scheme to have in place. The strongest argument in support of full funding concerns the principle of inter-generational equity. Put simply, it is more equitable that the cost of liabilities currently incurred should be met by the current generation and should not be left to be paid for by future generations. Future generations may not have the capacity to pay the superannuation of their predecessors.

This lessening of fiscal responsibilities severely inhibits the ability of future generations to make the necessary decisions on where expenditure would be best allocated. P.P. McGuinness in two columns in the Australian of 1 February and 5 February amongst other things said:

SPEECH.PARA: The ageing of the Australian population is a problem that is attracting increasing attention as we look forward to the next century. What has now become quite clear is that the baby boomer generation has created a burden that will blight their children's lives.

This blight will occur because the children of the baby boomer generation will, according to McGuinness, be left to pay the unfunded superannuation and pensions of their parents, as well as the mounting bills for health and nursing homes. McGuinness, even if somewhat emotive, has mounted a good case for fully funded future public and private sector superannuation.

PARA.TAB: Superannuation is also an important component of labour costs, and governments should be recognising these costs and paying for them as they occur. This could have the added bonus of giving governments increased resolve to keep staff numbers under control and inhibit government from engaging in activities for which there is no real benefit to the community at large.

Fully funded schemes would also have the advantage that governments would need to keep schemes within economic levels. One of the few arguments against the full funding of public sector superannuation is that, while Australia is a net borrower, it does not make sense to borrow further in order to fund public sector superannuation. Although that is a valid point, and there are some others, the reasons for establishing fully funded schemes are more persuasive.

The government, when establishing the PSS in 1990, took the decision to partially fund that particular scheme to avoid a large increase in unfunded liability. So at least the government is aware of the problem. The government, when establishing the PSS, not only made it partially funded; it reduced the level of future entitlements due to fund members. This has been achieved by reducing the new entrant contribution rate—that is, average employer contribution expressed as a percentage of salary from 22.8 per cent to 15.4 per cent.

The Commonwealth is not the only government to reduce the level of its contribution: New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia have all created new public sector superannuation schemes that are partially funded with reduced employer contributions. As of 30 June 1992, Victoria's unfunded superannuation liabilities amounted to $18 billion, which is $4,063 for each and every citizen of the state of Victoria and it is the worst liability of any state fund in the nation.

New South Wales's unfunded liability was $13.9 billion, at the same level of employer contribution as Victoria—that is, 21.5 per cent—while Western Australia, after Victoria, had the highest per capita liability of $2,694. This is a reflection on the previous Cain and Kirner governments in Victoria that destroyed Victoria's fiscal base, in one of the worst examples of economic vandalism, by employing more public servants from 1982 to 1988 than all the other state governments and the federal government combined.

These extra public servants became an impossible fiscal burden to carry, in terms of their wages and on-costs, as well as the added future cost of massive increases in unfunded superannuation liabilities in that state. It is small wonder that, in those circumstances, the Kennett government has been reducing the size of the Victorian Public Service. Both the Commonwealth and the states as at 30 June 1992 had total unfunded superannuation liabilities of $80 billion, with this figure rising to $90 billion when local government is also taken into account. This is an extremely large burden that tomorrow's taxpayers will have to carry.
Queensland is the only state that has a fully funded superannuation scheme which, though a modest scheme, is affordable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—The former Queensland Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, should take credit for that, and I am sure the honourable member who just said, `Hear, hear!' would agree with me. He should be remembered as the Australian state premier who established Queensland's excellent financial state of affairs, which the current Goss Labor government has inherited. It is time that all government public sector superannuation schemes become fully funded and meet the requirements of the SI(S) Act.

PARA.TAB: Another superannuation issue that I have spoken about in the past is the operation of the superannuation guarantee charge, which discriminates against many casual, part-time and itinerant workers. The coalition has received many representations from working men and women in Australia who have been affected by the rules current applying to the SGC. These problems were acknowledged by the then Treasurer as long ago as August 1993, when he announced that the government would give high priority to resolving the problems experienced by casual and itinerant workers under the SGC scheme. I see it has surfaced again, and we are getting the same assurances as we had in 1993, but we still have very little to show for them.

This is a problem which requires a strong government response. If the government had addressed the issue in the past two years, or as long as two years ago, lower income earners would now have a rational superannuation system. Sections 27 and 28 of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 are at the heart of the problem that penalises casual, part-time and itinerant workers, and penalises them very severely, indeed. Casual and itinerant workers often work for many employers and change jobs regularly, resulting at the moment in membership of multiple and separate superannuation schemes. Administration fees and exit fees whittle away those funds because they take no account of the available balance. For example, a worker earning $600 per month would receive a superannuation contribution from his or her employer of $18 per month, or an annual benefit of $216. However, there is a contribution tax of 15 per cent that reduces the balance to $184, and there is a further administration charge of $50. The remaining balance is only $134—$82 is gobbled up by taxes and administration fees. What hope does this hold for a worker who works only a few hours a week or who can get only occasional work?

Many of these schemes, into which contributions are made by the employer, often lie dormant after a casual worker has moved on to another job. These dormant superannuation schemes, if more than $500—or less than $500, but not withdrawn from the super fund—will continue to be charged an administration fee of approximately $50 per year or, at best, a dormant account fee of $26. There are also the exit fees when workers decide to rationalise their superannuation holdings. These provisions penalise women disproportionately to men, as women are more likely to work in part-time positions and occupations that are less well paid. I have mentioned several solutions to that problem in the past in the chamber, so I am not going to regurgitate them here.

However, in his budget speech, and as recently as 26 May, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) announced the government will issue a statement before 30 June on superannuation including reference to this problem. Hopefully, Labor will not let down the poorer sections of the work force. They are seeking a fair superannuation system that gives workers the choice and flexibility they have long expected, and have been given reason to hope for. What hope does this hold for workers if they can rely only on what has been given to them so far? And I am talking about casual, part-time and itinerant workers. They are seeking a fair superannuation system and I hope, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the government will address that, and in an effective way, in the very near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence, could I congratulate you and all the officers and clerks who have assisted you in the preparation of this chamber which we know as the Main Committee room. I look forward to the debates we will be having in here. I think we have already seen this morning the closeness that we have to our colleagues on the other side of the chamber—or should I refer to it as the committee. The exchange that will obviously happen there and the closeness of the debate will help us.

PARA.TAB: The main reason for this committee is to deal with non-controversial legislation. I think the message is that it is often forgotten by many people out there in broader Australia—and it is an opportunity to say it this morning—that much of the legislation that actually goes through the parliament is non-controversial and goes through with the support of all members of the parliament. I believe that, as the debate goes on in this chamber, this is going to give us the opportunity to emphasise that more. Overall, the success of this place will be up to each and every one of us as members of parliament—not so much you, sir—in the way we contribute to this place. The success that will follow will be how we make our contribution to this place. I think it will be very important. I look forward to making my contribution in this place from time to time and discussing these matters that come before the parliament.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the matter before us today, the first day of operation of this place, is the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. The main purpose of this bill is to enable the Commonwealth superannuation arrangements for civilian employees in the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, the CSS, and the public sector superannuation scheme, the PSS, to comply with revisions of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, the SI(S) Act, and associated legislation which largely come into operation from 1 July 1994.

It will do this by amending the four acts dealing with superannuation for Commonwealth sector civilian employees. These acts are: the Superannuation Act 1976; the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act 1990; the Superannuation Act 1990; and the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990. The SI(S) Act takes effect from 1 July this year, and makes provision for the prudent management of certain superannuation funds in particular, to ensure that members' money is as secure as possible. This is understandably a matter of great concern to the public. It will also allow the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to supervise its operations, another very important aspect.

The government decided that its own superannuation schemes that were at least partly funded should comply with the occupational superannuation requirements in the SIS legislation in much the same way as private sector schemes. Commonwealth schemes that are not funded will be required to comply, at least in principle, with the major thrust of the controls such as vesting and preservation.

Commonwealth superannuation schemes with invested funds will consequently come under the supervision of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner, who is responsible for ensuring that superannuation funds comply with provisions for prudent management in the SI(S) Act. The Commonwealth superannuation schemes without invested funds will also comply with the requirements of the SI(S) Act such as preservation and benefits and vesting.

The main provisions of the bill are intended to ensure that the CSS and the PSS comply with the SIS legislation in the following key respects. Subsection 58(1) of the SI(S) Act requires that the trustees should not be subject to direction by any other person except to the extent permitted by subsection 58(2) and the regulations. This will require the removal or limitation of the power of the minister to issue statements of government policy and principles of various matters to be followed by the boards. Paragraphs 4.1, 4.6 and 4.16 actually apply to that. Subsection 59(1) and the SI(S) Act provide that a person other than a trustee must not be in a position to exercise discretion except in certain limited circumstances permitted by subsection 59(2) and the regulations in paragraphs 4.7 and 4.15.

This legislation is all about providing adequate control and supervision over money built up by members of superannuation funds. These amendments will mean that the Commonwealth funds will comply with the SIS legislation. This is a very good idea, of course, and to illustrate this I will remind honourable members of the nature and the intent of the SIS legislation.

Among other things, it requires that the rules of a superannuation fund not allow trustees to the fund to be directed by another person, and that no other person may exercise discretion in that group. In addition, the rules of the fund should not be able to be amended without the approval of the trustees. As you can imagine, this places a great onus on the trustees to provide the fund members with regular, quality information about the ongoing operation and performance of the fund. The CSS and PSS schemes are examples of funds that are doing this, and the managers of these schemes should be commended for their commitment to adequate protection for their members.

The main benefit that will flow from these amendments is that they will give trustees greater responsibilities for, and control over, the scheme. This implies, of course, that they will also have higher standards to match regarding prudent supervision of the funds. Mr Deputy Speaker, it is important to note that these proposed amendments do not alter the benefit design of the schemes provided for by the legislation, so there is no net financial impact of this bill.

The members of the Commonwealth superannuation funds will not lose any money from this, but they will gain increased protection. Under this legislation, the trustees of both the CSS and the PSS are not subject to any direction from any person except the minister, as provided for under the SI(S) Act. This is reassuring for Commonwealth public servants, as they will know that their funds will now be protected in the same way as the private sector funds are protected under the SI(S) Act.

This is a debate that has raged for some time now, but there is nothing wrong with that. We are, after all, talking about very large sums of money in these funds. The topic of the adequate supervision of superannuation funds has received a great deal of attention over the last few years. To illustrate the necessity for the changes outlined in the legislation currently before us, I take the opportunity to remind honourable members of what the parliamentary banking inquiry, which I was involved in, said two years ago. The report of the inquiry recommended that `a council of financial supervisors be established to facilitate closer coordination between the supervisors of the financial system'. Whilst the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill does not propose to set up any such council, the important point in that quote was the necessity for better coordination, and these amendments will help to achieve this.

As I said before, the legislation will place greater standards on trustees. This is a very important part of any superannuation scheme. This was another point that arose from the banking inquiry. In line with the need for the best possible supervision of funds is the control and management of investor's funds. It is essential that the trustees and managers of the funds be accountable to the fund managers. These amendments will ensure that this is the case, as the funds will comply with the SIS legislation, which requires that the trustees report down to the members and, as I said before, must not be directed by another person. It is one thing to have elected trustees of funds to represent members' interests. However, who those trustees authorise as the fund managers is equally important.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the government has made several significant and positive decisions to ensure adequate protection, and this process will continue as superannuation continues its rise into prominence in the savings pool of the future. The following are some of the significant main changes proposed by the bill to each of the acts setting up the CSS and the PSS.

For instance, clause 4 declares that the object of the amendments proposed by division 2 of part 2 is to ensure the rules of the CSS are consistent with section 58 of the SI(S) Act. Subsection 58(1) of the SI(S) Act broadly provides that the rules must not permit the trustee of a superannuation entity to be subject to direction by any other person. This general prohibition against directions to trustees is subject to certain exceptions provided in subsection 58(2). In the case of employer sponsored funds, such as the CSS, paragraph 58(2)(e) provides that the employer sponsor—or an associate of an employer sponsor—may direct the trustees in certain circumstances prescribed by the regulations.

Regulation 4.03 prescribes the circumstances where an employer sponsor or an associate of an employer sponsor may give a direction to a trustee. Subregulation 4.03(1) provides that such a direction may not be given if the implementation of the direction will result in the fund becoming technically insolvent and if the rights of the members to accrued benefits are adversely affected by the direction.

Subregulation 4.03(2) provides five specific circumstances where a qualifying direction may be given. These relate to the admission of new members, the category of members into which a new member or an existing member may be placed, thus the allowing of a person to become an employer sponsor of the fund, the termination of a fund and the appointment of a trustee to an entity that does not have a trust deed. Division 2 of the bill amends the CSS Act so that the minister may only direct the Commonwealth board of trustees No. 2, the CSS board, in circumstances authorised by section 58 of the SI(S) Act.

Subsections 27C(6) and (7) of the CSS Act provide for the minister to issue a statement of Commonwealth government policy in relation to performance of the functions of the CSS board. As the issue of such statements may be considered as providing directions to the board, contrary to the provisions of section 58 of the SI(S) Act, these subsections are being repealed by clause 7 of the bill.

As all sections currently providing for the issue of principles by the minister are being repealed from 1 July 1994, clauses 14 and 15 amend sections 153AL and 153AS to provide for a delegate of the board or the board itself to make determinations before 1 July 1994 on the basis of principles issued by the minister prior to that date.

Section 161 of the CSS Act provides for financial statements issued by the CSS board to be in the form approved by the minister. It also provides that the annual report should contain details of a statement or a policy issued to the CSS board by the minister.

Clause 16 of the bill omits these requirements and provides for the form of financial statements to be agreed by the minister and the board. Clause 17 declares that the object of the amendments proposed by division 3 of part 2 is to ensure that the rules of the CSS are consistent with section 59 of the SI(S) Act.

Subsection 59(1) of the SI(S) Act broadly provides that the rules of a superannuation entity must not permit any person other than the trustee of a superannuation entity to exercise a discretion under the rules except in certain circumstances. Paragraph 59(1)(a) provides that such a discretion could be exercised by a non-trustee if the rules require that trustee to consent to the exercise of the discretion. In addition, paragraph 59(1)(b) provides that, if the entity is an employer-sponsored fund, the discretion which a non-trustee may exercise must relate to the contributions the employer will be required to pay after the exercise of the discretion; or the discretion must relate to the termination of the fund; or the circumstances of the exercise of the discretion are covered by regulations made for that purpose.

Regulation 4.04 prescribes the circumstances when a non-trustee may exercise a discretion. Subregulation 4.04(1) provides that such a discretion may not be exercised if it will result in the fund becoming technically insolvent and if the rights of the members to accrue benefits are adversely affected by the exercise of the discretion.

Subregulation 4.04(2) provides five specific circumstances when a discretion may be exercised. These relate to the admission of new members, the category of members into which a new member or an existing member may be placed, the allowing of a person to become an employer-sponsor of the fund, the termination of a fund and the appointment of a trustee or an entity that does not have a trust deed.

Division 3 of the bill amends the CSS Act so that the discretionary powers at present exercised by the commissioner or the minister other than those exempted under section 59 of the SI(S) Act are transferred to the CSS board.
Section 60 of the SI(S) Act requires that the rules of a superannuation entity must not permit its rules to be amended unless:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the trustee has consented to the amendment; or
(b) if the entity is an employer-sponsored fund:

TAB.TAB: (i)the amendment relates to the contributions that an employer-sponsor will, after the amendment, be required or permitted to pay to the fund; or

PARA.TAB: (ii)the amendment relates solely to the termination of the fund; or
