(iii)the circumstances in which the amendment was made are covered by regulations made for that purpose; the amendment is made solely to confer on the trustee the power to consent to amendment of the rules.

SPEECH.PARA: (c)the amendment is made solely for the purpose of conferring on the trustee the power to consent to amendments of those rules.

PARA.TAB: Regulation 4.05 prescribes the circumstances under which the rules of a superannuation entity may be amended. Subregulation 4.05(1) provides that an amendment may not be made, if it will result in the fund becoming technically insolvent, and if the rights of the members to accrued benefits are adversely affected in consequence of the amendment.

Subregulation 4.05(2) provides five specific circumstances when an amendment may be made without the consent of the trustee. These relate to: the admission of new members; the category of members into which a new member or an existing member may be placed; the allowing of a person to become an employer-sponsor of the fund; the termination of a fund; and the appointment of a trustee to an entity that does not have a trustee.

Division 3 of the bill attempts to amend the CSS Act so that the rules of the CSS may not be amended without the approval of the board. With regard to investment of funds, section 42 of the CSS Act provides that the CSS Board must consult with the Commissioner for Superannuation regarding moneys that are required to be maintained for the purpose of paying benefits under the CSS Act, in the course of managing the fund. As the board will have responsibility for the payment of benefits under the CSS Act, clause 26 of the bill removes the requirement for consultations with the Commissioner of Superannuation.

Presently, subsection 42(3) of the CSS Act provides that the board may invest the money of the fund through an investment manager or managers. Subsection 42(4) requires the board, until 30 June 1995, to engage only Commonwealth Funds Management Ltd (CFM) as the investment manager, to invest any money of the fund. Section 33 of the PSS Act places similar restrictions on the board of the PSS.

Under the SI(S) Act the trustees are generally responsible for the investment of funds through an investment manager of their choice. This is a discretion vested in the trustees which goes to the essence of prudential management. It may therefore be argued that, as long as the provisions of section 42(4) of the CSS Act and section 33 of the PSS Act require that the trustees of the CSS and the PSS should only engage CFM as investment managers, there is a contravention of section 59 of the SI(S) Act, which provides that the rules of a fund must not allow any person other than the trustee to exercise a discretion.

There is, however, scope for the contrary view that parliament made a definite exception to the requirements of section 59 of the SI(S) Act, in the case of the CSS, on the discretion to appoint an investment manager, by not repealing the requirements of subsection 42(4) when it amended subsection 42(1), and that therefore the provisions of section 59 of the SI(S) Act are subject to the provisions of section 42(4) of the CSS Act.

Against that view, it may be argued that, as section 42(4) in the CSS Act and section 33 in the PSS Act existed prior to the enactment of the SIS legislation—which introduced an entirely new legislative framework for the prudential management of the superannuation industry—any exception to the key provision of section 59 of the SI(S) Act should be found in that act or regulations made thereunder.

If the CSS and the PSS, the two funds we are speaking about, are to be complying funds, it would be best to remove any doubts about whether the legislative measures to appoint CFM as the investment manager until 30 June 1995 create an exception to the provisions of that particular section, section 59 of the SI(S) Act, either by amendments to the CSS Act and the PSS Act or by regulations under the SI(S) Act relating to section 60.

As honourable members undoubtedly are aware, this is an extremely wide ranging bill in the work that it does, and I have by no means covered all the aspects of the legislation and its impact. In the short time left, I reinforce the importance of the bill with respect to supervision of investment by funds managers. While the thrust of this bill is to provide protection for funds, I make some short comments about some possible investment alternatives for the future of superannuation.

It is anticipated that growth in superannuation funds will continue and will in fact accelerate. It has been estimated that by the year 2002 more than $500 billion will be held in superannuation stocks. This huge pool of savings could provide enormous opportunities for Australian industry investment, and there is a good argument that a portion of these funds could be used for industry development. If such a proposal were to be considered, the primary concern would have to be the safety of the members' funds.

By adequately supervising the investments, and by ensuring that they are spread across different portfolios to minimise the risk, the safety of members' savings should be assured. The changes to trustees' reporting and supervisory requirements brought about by the amendments in this bill would already go some way towards this, in respect of Commonwealth superannuation funds but, of course, further complementary legislation should be considered.

It is not likely that the superannuation industry will suddenly move in that direction, and I would suggest that perhaps we will need to ensure that superannuation funds are legislated in some way, to encourage them to invest that pool of funds into industry development. I am very pleased to have the opportunity to support the bill before us today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence I take the opportunity to congratulate you on the setting up of this chamber. I also congratulate you on assuming the role of deputy speaker and on conducting the affairs of the Parliament of Australia in this chamber. I extend my congratulations to the clerks and the staff of the parliament for their preparation of this chamber and for transforming it from a committee room into the Main Committee chamber.

PARA.TAB: The size of the chamber reminds me a little of the size of the Victorian Legislative Council whence I came. However, it does not have the gracious adornments of that chamber, nor does it have any gold leaf. Nevertheless, I believe that it will be a very good debating chamber. I am sure that the close proximity of the government and the coalition will lead to some very good debates. I am pleased to be able to speak on a bill that is before the House on this historic day in the Main Committee chamber.

I want to address a few comments to the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill. Superannuation has changed quite dramatically in this country over recent years. Those changes have led to much confusion and greater complexity than we have ever seen before. There was a time when individual citizens could negotiate their own superannuation with comparative ease. They were able to understand the implications of what the superannuation requirements were, what their benefits would be after paying into it for an extended period, and what their net benefit would be at the end of that period. Much has changed in the field of superannuation since that time. Change upon change upon change has been wrought on the superannuation industry over that period. It is now such a complex area that very few people in this nation understand how superannuation works.

The superannuation guarantee charge continues to be a source of concern for many employers. Apart from being an additional impost on the cost of employing every worker, the administrative costs must be added to the already long list of the costs incurred over and above direct worker payments. One of the widespread concerns that I have picked up about the operation of the superannuation guarantee charge is the way in which small balances in superannuation funds can be eroded by administrative costs, particularly for itinerant, casual and seasonal workers, who often see their small balances disappear completely. The problem is also particularly serious for many women workers because of the broken periods they spend in the work force.

I recently had a complaint from a young man in my electorate. He was desirous of working and he had a friend who operated a fruit property in Sunraysia, so he went up there to do some fruit-picking. Obviously, he was paid for that work. The superannuation guarantee charge was deducted from his earnings and was paid into a superannuation fund. I think a sum of a little over $48 was paid into that superannuation fund.

After a period of approximately 12 months, this young man discovered to his dismay that the whole of that amount had been swallowed up by administrative charges. This situation is of real concern because that person may take on a number of part-time or itinerant positions and yet all of those small amounts of money would obviously be swallowed up more or less totally by the administrative charges of that fund. So the government has got serious problems with that. I should note that I understand that the Senate has requested that the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation take submissions and conduct hearings nationwide on the problems associated with that superannuation guarantee charge.

One of the other issues related to superannuation was the promise made by the government leading up to the 1993 election. That promise was that superannuation funds would be made available for housing. I am sure that the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) would be well aware of the election promise made that people would be able to use their superannuation funds for housing. Of course, the government has now reneged on that. It has disappointed a lot of young people who have paid into superannuation and who could have had access to those funds to provide a deposit on a house. The government has reneged on that promise and it is not going to implement the scheme.

Since then the superannuation for housing report was issued by the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. That was in mid-May. The committee took submissions from many interested parties on this issue and the report received unqualified support across Australia. I might add that for the benefit of the honourable member for Moreton. There were many people who were desirous of having those superannuation funds freed up for housing. The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation did identify a narrow but certainly a significant band of individuals who would be better off being allowed to use their superannuation money to finance the purchase of a home. There are many ways in which that could have assisted people, particularly young people, to get their first home. Of course, now the government has reneged totally on that promise and those funds will not be available to them.

The other issue that is related to that concerns a letter that I received from Mr Roy Wilkinson, who is a constituent of mine in the Bendigo area and who has spent a lifetime in the life assurance industry. His working life has been devoted to that industry. In his letter to me he expressed grave concerns about the direction in which superannuation and life assurance were heading. He believes that the industry is in danger as a result of a whole range of changes made by the government. They are so far-reaching that people simply do not understand the complexities of it all and the pitfalls that may be involved.

He does say that the savings potential of life assurance is one of the major factors that Australia needs in its economic planning and he has expressed his concern at the way the industry is going. He has implored me to put a case that commonsense be put back into the insurance industry and the superannuation industry in Australia.

The implementation of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act imposes an additional cost. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who was in the chamber earlier, expressed concerns about the additional costs that would be imposed and the administrative complexity of the superannuation changes that have been made. I can only reiterate them to the honourable member for Moreton, who is the government member present, in the hope that those issues will be taken up. There are also difficulties imposed on public offers of funds too. I think that there are a number of issues that the government needs to address.

Superannuation, as I say, has become more and more complex. People do not understand what is happening now with their superannuation, the extent of the changes varying from one year to another. There have been so many changes over the past three or four years that people are totally confused about the way that the superannuation industry does in fact operate. People who do itinerant work and are moving from job to job are suffering as a result of the administrative charges of the superannuation funds. I think that that is one issue that the government needs to address very quickly. It needs to do something to simplify the processes of the superannuation industry.

The other major issue which I drew attention to was the use of superannuation money for housing, on which the government has let down the public yet again, making promises in the lead-up to the election, building up people's expectations of being able to use their superannuation funds for housing, only to dash those hopes by reneging on its promise.
With those few remarks on this historic occasion, I will finish my contribution to the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this very historic day in the life of this parliament, after deliberating on the proposals that led to the establishment of this Main Committee over the past months, we probably take it a little bit for granted, but this first day of operation of this chamber will go down in the annals of history of Australia as quite an historic day. The establishment of the second chamber obviously was supported by both the government and the opposition and it seems, from its operation so far this morning, that it is going to be on occasions a rather more civilised place than the main chamber of the House of Representatives. That is the way it has been designed to be.

PARA.TAB: Ironically, the first bill that we are debating here today is a bill that deals with amendments to superannuation for Commonwealth parliamentarians. It will be interesting to see what the pundits say in 10 or 20 years time when they are writing about the first day's operation of the Main Committee and the first piece of legislation that comes before us.

Another irony in the first day's operation of this Main Committee is that the Main Committee was established primarily to hasten the flow of legislation through the parliament, particularly the lower House, to get the Senate to speed up the process of government in its part of the legislative process. It is designed to give the opposition a better opportunity to speak, to give more members an opportunity to speak, and therefore to give a greater number of Australians, through their representatives, an opportunity to be heard on different legislation that is being passed through the parliament, by transferring the passage of non-contentious items of legislation from the House of Representatives chamber to this second chamber.

Yet, on this first day of operation of this chamber, in the House of Representatives chamber the guillotine will be enforced all day on different items of legislation that are going through. That is the very mechanism that is at the disposal of the government from time to time the use of which we are trying to overcome by establishing this chamber. So let us hope that in the future it does have the effect of eliminating more often the use of the guillotine on legislation which members of the opposition would like to debate in the main chamber but which today a lot of us are not going to get the opportunity to actually debate. As we iron out the bugs in the establishment of this chamber and we get it running, I expect that it will help to overcome that problem.

I must congratulate the staff of the Clerk's office on the work that they have done over the last couple of months in getting this chamber, and all the technicalities that go with it, established. Obviously some finetuning changes will need to be implemented over the course of time to help smooth out the running of this chamber, but I am sure that it is going to work quite well. We recognise that, as one of the reforms undertaken by this government, it probably is going to be quite a positive move.

The main purpose of the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill is to amend the three acts which deal with superannuation for Commonwealth parliamentarians. The amendments primarily affect the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948, the amendments to the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Amendment Act 1981, and the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Amendment Act 1983. The proposed amendments to the PCS Act allow the superannuation scheme established under it to comply with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act and associated acts and regulations in relation to vesting and preservation of members' benefits and disclosure of information to members of the scheme. As well, inequities that exist under the current scheme will be corrected. They relate to former members who hold offices of profit, to invalidity retirement and to transfers between the Commonwealth parliament and state and territory parliaments. There will also be minor amendments to spouse benefits.

The SIS legislation provides for the prudent management—`prudent' is a very operative sort of word when we are talking about superannuation of any kind—of certain superannuation funds, particularly with regard to the security of members' moneys, and for certain minimum standards. Although this act provides the capacity for unfunded public sector superannuation schemes to be exempted from these arrangements, the government has decided that all Commonwealth schemes should comply with the main operative provisions of the SIS legislation, that is, vesting, preservation, and disclosure of information to fund members.

There are a couple of very important aspects. The SIS legislation and the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 require that all employees receive a minimum level of employer sponsored superannuation support. The pension benefits provided under the current scheme to parliamentary retiring allowances, where they are payable to a former member or spouse's annuities where the pension is a revisionary benefit payable to a spouse of a former member, will meet the minimum requirement in all cases. However, the lump sum benefits of persons who do not qualify for a pension will not, in some cases, meet the minimum requirement. This bill will amend the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act to increase the amounts of lump sums so as to ensure that they comply with the minimum requirements of the superannuation guarantee legislation.

There are no provisions under the present scheme which require benefits to be preserved. The SIS legislation requires that certain lump sum benefits be preserved in a superannuation fund or an approved deposit fund until beneficiaries reach the preservation age, which is currently 55, and retire from the work force, or that they be used to purchase a deferred annuity which cannot be accessed until the preservation age is reached. The pensions paid under the current scheme meet the preservation requirements of the SIS legislation.

There are currently no provisions in the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act of 1948 that require disclosure of information to members. This bill proposes to amend the act to require information to be disclosed to members in line with the requirements of the SIS legislation. The Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act currently provides for the reduction of a pension where a beneficiary is a holder of an office of profit. This bill proposes amendments to the act to provide for the decrease in the amount of pension reduction from $1 to 50c for each dollar earned from an office of profit, and to provide a threshold below which earnings from an office of profit cause no reduction of pension.

The PCS Act currently provides for the recognition of periods of service in a state or territory parliament and for the reduction of benefits payable from the present scheme where the beneficiary is a member of a state or territory parliament or is receiving a pension as a result of a such a membership. This bill proposes that the act be amended so that periods of service in a state or territory parliament are recognised in the scheme only to the extent that a transfer value paid from the state or territory scheme to the Commonwealth scheme is used to purchase Commonwealth service. If a transfer value were paid, the state or territory service would be recognised on the payment of a transfer value.

It is proposed that benefits paid under the act would continue to be reduced where the beneficiary is a member of a state or territory parliament or currently receives a state or territory pension, but would not be reduced where a new beneficiary of the scheme is also in receipt of a state or territory parliamentary pension. Transitional arrangements will apply to ensure that current members are not disadvantaged.

It is impossible to quantify the precise financial impact of the changes in this bill because of the limited application of the amendments in the small parliamentary superannuation scheme. However, the restoration or partial restoration of pensions to certain persons who currently hold an office of profit are estimated to cost about $80,000 in a full year. It is expected that in the longer term these additional costs will be more than offset by savings made by the Commonwealth no longer recognising prior state or territory parliamentary service, at no cost to the state or territory. Therefore, any changes in immediate budgetary outlays or change in long-term cost from the measures in the bill are expected to be relatively insignificant.

However, there are two contentious matters that need to be looked at. The first relates to the requirement in section 60 of the SI(S) Act that the trustee of the CSS must approve amendments to the rules of that entity. The CSS Act is part of the rules of the CSS, and therefore compliance with the requirements of section 60 will require the board of the CSS to consent to any proposed amendments to the CSS Act. The explanatory memorandum to the bill states that, as any express provision to that effect will be a restriction on parliament's ability to amend its own legislation, no action has been taken to provide for making the consent of the CSS board a condition for amending the CSS Act. This may be construed as creating a further exception to section 60 of the SI(S) Act.

In the case of the PSS, the bill introduces a provision that the minister may not amend the trust deed without the consent of the PSS board. Such amendment can only be made by the minister by signed instrument, which is a disallowable instrument. If parliament intends that only the CSS should be exempt from complying with the provisions of section 60 of the SI(S) Act, it should provide for this exception specifically in an amendment to the CSS Act or in regulations under section 60 of the SI(S) Act. A mere statement in the memorandum that it is not proposed to take any action to provide for obtaining the consent of the CSS board to proposed amendments to the CSS Act may not be adequate to exempt the CSS from complying with the provisions of section 60.

The second contentious point relates to the lack of discretion in the trustees to change the investment manager should that step be considered necessary by the CSS board, and the PSS board, as is in the CFM legislation, to be the sole investment manager until 30 June 1995. The removal of this key discretion, which is essential for the prudential management of the funds of a superannuation entity, would be contrary to the provisions of section 59 of the SI(S) Act. As the legislative provisions in the CSS Act and the PSS Act existed prior to the enactment of the SIS legislation, which introduced an entirely new legislative regime for the prudential management of the superannuation industry, the view may be taken that any exception to the key provision of section 60 of the SI(S) Act should be found in that act or regulations made thereunder.

This is a fairly pertinent point to wind up on. The key element and the key concern as far as superannuation generally in Australia is concerned is of prudential management. We have seen a number of areas where this has not existed. I suppose it would be fair enough to say that the honourable members speaking on this bill today would expect prudential management to be at a premium and at a very professional level for the Commonwealth scheme. A major concern being expressed by a lot of people right across the industry, particularly in the private sector, is how their funds are being managed, how the superannuation industry is being managed, how it is conducting its business and how it is looking after the funds of its members. I think there needs to be far more attention paid to ongoing changes to legislation and an ongoing review of the system so that we can get far greater accountability, flexibility and transparency within the superannuation industry.

As far as superannuation is concerned, the government is going in the direction that it ultimately wants to replace the current pension and social security system. It is terribly important to try to get people to provide for their own retirement, which at the moment is quite difficult. The private sector has been experiencing a lot of difficulties with the government legislation that relates to private sector superannuation schemes, particularly through the superannuation guarantee levy and the charge that comes as a result of that. Those difficulties are partially because of the concerns of employers about affording it. Employers are concerned about the implications of the extra costs and the paperwork that they will have to go through. They will have to deal with the taxation office in this regard.

Employers have had the opportunity on a number of occasions since the superannuation guarantee levy came into force in August last year to have representatives from the tax office in Newcastle, in my electorate, to try to explain it. Some employers did not anticipate the possibility of this charge. It was quite awesome to a lot of employers. Therefore, rather than getting caught in what they saw as another lot of bureaucratic and government red tape—and a further trap—they did not go ahead and extend their employment. They structured the people that they had employed in such a way that they were able to keep themselves below the superannuation guarantee levy threshold. Therefore, it had a counterproductive outcome in the community and that is something the government needs to address.

We heard the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) referring to the possibility of people who have been contributing to superannuation funds having access to those funds for housing, but that did not eventuate. That caused a great deal of concern and heartache within the community. A lot of people were relying on that. It would have saved them getting caught by higher interest rates for housing, because they would have been able to buy a house with funds that they had put aside for themselves. A lot of people do not have access to private sector finance through the banks or anywhere else. However, that did not eventuate and I am sure the government is certainly aware of the upset that has caused in the community.

It will be interesting to see the result and recommendations from the Senate inquiry that is taking place at the moment. My electorate covers a number of coastal resorts and areas where there is a lot of part-time employment. People work through the holiday periods in tourist resorts and tourist attractions, and their employers pay ridiculously small amounts into the scheme, which are never seen again. That brings us back to the aspect of the accountability and transparency of these funds. This money is only going to get gobbled up by the administration costs of these superannuation schemes.

I have had numerous representations from employers who have shown me foolscap pages covered with the small amounts that they have contributed on behalf of people who have worked on a part-time basis in their operations. These people will never see that money again. It is not going to help them in their retirement. It is not going to help alleviate any financial impact on future governments: all it is doing is filling the pockets of the superannuation fund managers. I know the government is in the process of addressing this problem but I believe it has been too slow in addressing it.

With respect to the public sector, I was interested to note some of the figures that the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) used in his address on this bill in relation to the unfunded liabilities of a couple of our state governments. That must be of great concern to the taxpayers in those states. A key element in budgetary strategies, when I was involved in local government, was to make sure that our employee entitlement reserves were always substantially cash funded. We have seen the diminution over the years of these funds at all levels of government throughout Australia. It must be of great concern where there is a heavy call on some of these state funds. The honourable member for Curtin used the example of the unfunded liability in Victoria, which is about $18 billion, and in New South Wales, where it is $13.9 billion.

We come back to the aspect that we have been discussing this morning of the prudential management of these funds. There is a big nest egg there and the temptation is very great for government to use those in a less than prudential manner as far as the fund members are concerned. In days gone by, people would invest in something associated with the government or subscribe to something supervised by the government and there was a reasonable expectation that it would be there the day people wanted to call on it. There was a reasonable expectation that it would be managed properly. Unfortunately, in recent times there has been an element of doubt cast across that aspect for people who contribute to these funds.

In closing, I would urge the government that, in all future considerations with superannuation, both private and public, it focus on that aspect of prudential management because, from here on in, these funds are going to carry enormous amounts of money. Without that sort of accountability there is a real risk of less than professional management, and the only people it will disadvantage will be the members of the funds.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Lavarch)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House.
Consideration resumed from 24 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill proposes a number of amendments to improve the operation of the Corporations Law and to facilitate the operations of the Australian Securities Commission, ASC, and the Corporations and Securities Panel, the panel.

PARA.TAB: I foreshadowed this legislation last year in introducing the Corporate Law Reform Bill 1993. At that time, and in the debate on that bill earlier this year, I also referred to the major long term process I had established to simplify the Corporations Law.

While I am pleased to report that good progress is being made with simplification, that process will take time. In the meantime, the current law governs the corporate sector and some reforms must continue to keep that law in tune with the rapidly changing commercial environment.

When deficiencies are revealed, they need to be rectified. When new products, services and structures challenge the boundaries of the law, those boundaries need to be moved. That is why this bill is being brought forward at this time. These amendments cannot wait for their turn in the queue for simplification.

As is the usual practice in relation to corporate legislation, this bill, or more accurately, most of this bill, was released for public comment in December 1993. The period of public exposure ended on 28 February 1994 and public submissions made during that period have been taken into account in finalising the bill for introduction.

I have qualified my comment on the extent of the bill's public exposure as there is one important proposal that was not, in fact, included in the exposure draft of the bill, but which has arisen subsequently and has been included in the bill prior to its introduction. The proposal in question is that to refine the law governing clients' segregated accounts maintained by futures brokers.

There is also a second proposal in the bill, as introduced, that did not appear in the exposure draft of the bill—namely, the proposal to enable trading on stock and future markets of new products which do not fall squarely within the current definitions of `securities' or `futures contract'. However, I wish to inform the Committee that the government will not be proceeding with this proposal at this time.

The amendments to the definitions of `securities' and `futures contract' were intended to enable trading on stock and futures markets of certain new hybrid products. In particular, they were intended to facilitate the trading of a new product by the Australian Stock Exchange from 1 July 1994. I have now been informed that the exchange will not be ready to trade this product until later in the year. In light of that I consider that it is preferable that the amendments have further exposure. The government will be moving an amendment during debate on the bill to delete those amendments.

To facilitate the public exposure process I have asked my department, as a matter of priority, to develop the proposed regulations that would govern the trading of these new products. I consider that this will clarify the situation and provide adequate information for a more detailed consideration of the policy underlying the proposed amendments. I intend, at this stage, to introduce a separate bill containing the amendments following that exposure period.

I will now mention a few of the most important amendments proposed by the bill. One of the most important reforms is the conferral of civil jurisdiction on lower courts—such as magistrates courts and district courts—to hear small civil claims arising under the Corporations Law. This proposal has been developed in response to concerns from the business community and the legal profession about court judgments over the last year which have held that civil jurisdiction under the Corporations Law is confined to superior courts, that is, the Federal Court, the Family Court and the Supreme Court in each state and territory. Concern has been expressed that legitimate civil actions will not be able to be brought under the Corporations Law because of the cost and delay involved in bringing actions before the superior courts. For very small claims, it will often be that the cost of the filing fees alone would prevent the commencement of civil proceedings in a superior court.

This government is committed to the principle that justice should be available to the community at an affordable cost and with the prospect of a speedy resolution. It is for this reason that it has moved to amend the corporations legislation to confer civil jurisdiction on lower courts in regard to those civil actions under the Corporations Law which are in the nature of debt recovery, monetary compensation or minor administrative remedies.

The legislative framework for the national scheme of corporate regulation means that effective jurisdiction can only be conferred on lower courts if complementary amendments are made by state and Northern Territory governments to the corporations acts of the respective jurisdictions. The Ministerial Council for Corporations has already agreed that the necessary amendments should be made as soon as possible and I anticipate that a uniform date can be set for the operation of these amendments in each jurisdiction in Australia.

These amendments are expected to receive widespread support from the business community, given that they will reduce the cost and delays associated with bringing small civil actions under the Corporations Law. It is important that these reforms be implemented as soon as possible.

The bill also proposes a number of amendments to support the introduction of the Clearing House Electronic Subregister System—commonly known as `CHESS'—to be introduced by the Australian Stock Exchange. CHESS will bring the settlement procedures of the Stock Exchange to world best standards. The aim of CHESS is to have transactions settled and delivered within three days after trade and to replace the current paper document of transfer with electronic transfer.

The basic legislative framework for CHESS was established by the Corporate Law Reform Act 1992. Since the passage of that act, and in progressing the CHESS project to its final stages of development, the Stock Exchange has sought a number of additional amendments to the legislative framework. These amendments are basically refinements of the existing legislative scheme. They are essential to the smooth operation of CHESS. They deal with such matters as the cancellation of certificates by brokers; electronic acceptances; off-market transfers before official quotation; and establishment of record dates to determine entitlement to vote and receipt of dividends and other benefits. The Stock Exchange presently envisages that CHESS will commence operation on 1 July this year. In view of this imminent start-up date, it is important that these amendments proceed as a matter or urgency.

Another important set of amendments proposed by the bill is the provisions dealing with the application of the Corporations Law to non-bank financial institutions, the collective term for such bodies as building societies and credit unions.

The enactment of the uniform financial institutions code by the states and territories in 1992 has highlighted the uneven and inconsistent application of Corporations Law and state and territory legislation to the activities of financial institutions. The resolution of the interface between the Corporations Law and state and territory legislation was a matter left for future consideration at the time the Commonwealth, the states and the Northern Territory entered into the heads of agreement on future corporate regulation in June 1990. This has resulted in doubts and uncertainties for financial institutions as to which law applies to their activities, as well as a degree of regulatory and administrative duplication.

Last year, the Ministerial Council for Corporations and the Ministerial Council for Financial Institutions agreed to principles on which the interface between the two bodies of law could be rationalised. A key aspect of this resolution was agreement that the fundraising activities of financial institutions, in their state of incorporation or elsewhere, should be governed by the Corporations Law. This reflects the Commonwealth's policy that there is a significant public benefit in there being a single regulator and uniform regulation of public fundraising in Australia.

In other areas, such as the duties of officers and charges over the property of financial institutions, the Corporations Law will be displaced by the financial institutions code as that is considered a more appropriate form of regulation for these bodies in those areas. In addition, the registration of financial institutions under the Corporations Law as registrable Australian bodies will no longer be required. These amendments, together with complementary amendments to state and territory financial institutions legislation, will not only reduce regulatory duplication and clarify which law applies to particular areas of activity, but will also promote investor protection and confidence. The certainty that these amendments will bring to this area of the law is also urgently needed.

Special mention should be made of the proposed amendments to the operations of the Corporations and Securities Panel. The panel was established as a peer review group, a body to examine conduct in takeover matters referred to it for review by the ASC. In particular, it was empowered to make declarations of unacceptable conduct and acquisitions in respect of a takeover and to make orders to remedy such conduct.

The panel's legislative charter was to conduct hearings with as little formality and technicality and with as much expedition as possible. However, the very first matter to come before the panel bogged down in legal argument over its procedures. Following consideration of this case, the government has decided that the panel should be restructured to remove the procedural difficulties that this first case disclosed.

The bill provides for the extension of the jurisdiction of the panel to takeover conduct generally, and specifies with greater precision what constitutes procedural fairness for the purpose of the panel's inquiries. Procedural fairness does not require that the panel behave like a court. Likewise, cross-examination of parties and witnesses is not a requirement of procedural fairness. The emphasis will, instead, be on written submissions by parties and strict time limits for submissions. After examining those submissions, the panel will decide whether a conference or oral inquiry is necessary.

Given that the panel's deliberations do not generally relate to technical legal matters, rather to matters of market behaviour and market standards, it is more appropriate that the parties rather than their legal advisers address the panel. The legal advisers may, of course, be present to assist but will not be entitled to address the panel. This is the approach that has been successfully adopted in predetermination conferences by the Trade Practices Commission and it should be equally successful here.

The amendments also provide for regulations to set out in a comprehensive form the procedures for the conduct of the panel's inquiries. Draft regulations have been released for public comment and the government intends to have the regulations in place at the same time these provisions come into force.

The bill will also provide for the establishment of retail screen based trading markets for collective investment schemes which are not listed on a stock exchange. The establishment of such retail markets is a significant development in Australia. Investors are currently reliant on the liquidity of scheme assets and the ability of the manager of a collective investment scheme to buy back the investment. The measures proposed by the bill will greatly enhance the liquidity of such investments.

As with stock markets, approved security organisations and exempt stock markets, the establishment of any such market will require the approval of the Attorney-General. Each market will be operated in accordance with business rules, relevant agreements contemplated by those rules, and any conditions which are imposed on special market approval.

The powers of the ASC to supervise the special markets will be similar to those which it currently exercises in relation to the stock market of a securities exchange. The business rules will also require the appointment of an independent and appropriately qualified person to monitor compliance with the business rules and to report a contravention of those rules to the ASC.

I now return to the first of the two amendments which, as I have already mentioned, were not included in the public exposure draft of the bill: that is the proposal to refine the law governing clients' segregated accounts. The segregation of client moneys from that of brokers is a fundamental investor protection rule of the futures industry. Thus, the Corporations Law requires that a broker maintain a client segregated account into which client funds are placed, and permits the withdrawal of funds from that account only in certain circumstances. Funds held in this way are immune from claims by creditors of the broker.

However, changes to the way the futures industry operates have highlighted the need for some refinement of the detail of the law governing such accounts, so that it keeps abreast of developments in the industry. In particular, the bill recognises that in a futures transaction involving a chain of intermediaries, moneys can be identified as client moneys and continue to be treated as such. The result will be that client moneys involved in such transactions will enjoy the full protection afforded by the Corporations Law.

Among other reforms proposed by the bill are the introduction of a modified regime for the notification of persons affected by ASC decisions of their rights of review under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act of 1975; the introduction into the Corporations Law and the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 of the penalty unit system for the prescription of penalties; and the transfer of unclaimed money functions of the Attorney-General under the Corporations Law to the ASC. A complete list of the reforms proposed by the bill is set out at the start of the explanatory memorandum.

The bill is not expected to have any significant financial impact on government or business, as the majority of the proposed amendments clarify existing provisions of the Corporations Law and will not result in additional costs. The explanatory memorandum details the extent of the potential impact on business.

Finally, I return briefly to the simplification program. It is now seven months since the task force first met. The task force consists of four experts, two of whom work in the private sector. It is responsible for developing proposals and draft legislation. A private sector consultative group has also been established to provide expert advice and assistance to the task force. This group consists of representatives of large and small users of the law.

In December, the task force released a plan of action which outlined how it proposed to go about the overall project. That plan of action identified seven initial priority areas where early practical gains for business are possible. They include streamlining the corporate structure for small business, facilitating share buybacks, rationalising annual reporting requirements and reducing the burden of maintaining company registers. The aim is for simplification to occur in manageable stages so that the benefits can be achieved as quickly as possible.

The task force's first simplification proposal, concerning share buybacks, was released in early March of this year. The law in this area is extremely complex, burdensome and expensive to comply with. Its cumbersome nature and complexity deters companies from using the provisions. The task force's proposal on buybacks involves an emphasis on the basics. The aim is to discard the excessive detail and technicalities in the current law. By the end of the consultation process we will have developed provisions that companies can actually use, consistent with the need for adequate safeguards for shareholders and creditors.

The same principles for simplification apply to small business structures. Our smallest companies are currently regulated under a scheme primarily designed to supervise our largest companies. Clearly, this not only makes life difficult for small companies but in many situations is simply illogical. A proposal to simplify the proprietary company structure to ease the burdens for existing and new small businesses was released for public comment also in March.

The twin emphasis on clarity and elimination of unnecessary paperwork continues in the task force's proposal, released at the end of April, to do away with many of the requirements for company register keeping. Where adequate information for investors and creditors is readily available through the Australian Stock Exchange or through access to the ASC database, unnecessary requirements to maintain registers can be removed. In other cases the information held is unnecessary. The proposal would make the remaining obligations easier to use by bringing them together in the law, streamlining the requirements and making them more uniform.

The latest task force proposal was released in May and deals with annual returns and financial reporting to shareholders. Under the proposal, the annual return would be streamlined by reducing the number of items of information it contains by around 75 per cent. In addition, companies which are required to prepare annual accounts would have the option of sending concise financial reports to shareholders. This would have the dual benefit of cost savings for companies and easier-to-read financial reports for shareholders.

The task force is working towards a first draft bill for public exposure about mid-year—I think early August is the latest date—but the process will not be rushed. In particular, the task force is determined to consult widely on its proposals before it drafts the legislation. This will provide an essential opportunity for business and other user groups to influence the basic policy as it is being developed. The first simplification bill would deal with buybacks, proprietary companies and company registers.

In conclusion, I confirm that, in accordance with the heads of agreement between the Commonwealth, the states and the Northern Territory on corporate regulation, the ministerial council on corporations has been consulted and, to the extent necessary, has given approval for the introduction of the bill into the parliament. In particular, the amendments proposed by schedule 3 of the bill, rationalising the interface between the Corporations Law and state and territory financial institutions legislation, has received the unanimous agreement of the council. Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend the bill to the committee.
The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—I understand that there is a supplementary explanatory memorandum. Does the Attorney-General want to present that now or when he moves the amendments?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to take your guidance on it, Mr Deputy Speaker. I can certainly present that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As will become apparent from my comments, the principles to be applied in choosing whether bills come before this Main Committee or come before the House may need some refining. This bill makes amendments to corporations legislation in a number of non-related areas. The explanatory memorandum states that the amendments are necessary in advance of the finalisation of the program to simplify the Corporations Law, which will `take some little time to produce results'.

PARA.TAB: The coalition does not oppose most of the measures in the bill. Those measures tidy up pockets of difficulty and facilitate desirable reforms. The coalition does, however, oppose an aspect of the provisions of the bill relating to procedural changes to the Corporations and Securities Panel. In our view, it is unacceptable that the government is seeking to prohibit legal and other representatives of the parties from addressing the panel. I propose to move an amendment that will entitle a person who appears at the inquiry to have another person address the panel on his or her behalf.

The bill in its current form provides that the rules of natural justice are not applicable to the panel. It was the government's intention to provide for procedures before the panel to be dealt with by regulation. To accommodate coalition objections, the government has agreed to proposed amendments to recast the provisions. I will deal with the Corporations and Securities Panel provisions and the unopposed provisions of the bill in a moment.

I would like first, however, to comment on the provisions of the bill which sought to alter the definitions of `securities' and `futures contract', which the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has indicated will be withdrawn. I welcome the government's decision to withdraw the amendments. As the Attorney has mentioned, those amendments were slipped into the bill after an exposure draft had been circulated. Given the potential ramifications of the amendments, this was somewhat surprising. Part of the reaction against the amendments has resulted simply from the limited time for adequate consideration, together with the lack of any initiation by the government of consultation with those concerned. It appears that the only industry body consulted by the government was the Australian Stock Exchange.

After the amendments came to light when this bill was introduced, considerable concern was expressed by both industry and commentators as to the scope of the amendments. The amendments would have given the government extensive powers to vary the definitions of `securities' and `futures contracts' by regulation, and without any necessity for industry or public consultation. The practical effect would have been that the government could direct that hybrid instruments which are presently futures would be traded as securities, and vice versa. This would mean that the safeguards of chapter 8 of the Corporations Law which apply to futures would not apply to the affected instruments, but the different provisions of chapter 7 relating to securities would apply—and vice versa.

The coalition accepts that there is a need for some flexibility to allow the Stock Exchange and the Sydney Futures Exchange to conduct markets in new products and to maintain an ability to compete with overseas exchanges. Any arrangement proposed for exchange-traded products should not have adverse consequences for over-the-counter derivatives; and any interim measure must be compatible with long-term reform presently under study by CASAC, the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee. The amendments which were proposed by the government go much further than is necessary or appropriate, and I am therefore pleased that the amendments have been withdrawn.

In his second reading speech the Attorney was a little more specific in relation to the purpose of the proposed amendments. He stated that the amendments were to facilitate the trading of a new product by the ASX from 1 July 1994. The exchange will apparently not now be ready to trade the products until the end of the year. The Attorney has also stated that his department will develop the regulations that will govern the trading of the new products. I welcome that opportunity for greater consideration.

The current concerns, however, will not be addressed simply by the government preparing in advance for scrutiny the regulations it intends to adopt to facilitate the trading of a particular product by the ASX. As amendments should be designed to facilitate flexibility in the interim, they should be limited in scope and they should be discrete. In the absence of a wider review of derivatives regulation, there may be significant difficulties with changes that widely delegate to the executive the power to regulate derivatives, no matter how strenuous the assurances that they would be exercised sparingly.

I note the announcement that the ASX is drafting new business rules to cover the trading of derivative products. This move has been made in anticipation of the reintroduction of provisions which are to be withdrawn. While suitably drafted business rules provide a step in the right direction, in my view it is very important to ensure that the developments in general do not hijack the benefits of a broader approach to the regulation of derivatives.

I will now deal with the coalition's objections to the provisions of the bill that deny the right of a person or body appearing before the Corporations and Securities Panel to have any other person address the panel on his or her or its behalf. I will also refer to a more general uneasiness I have with the thrust of the reforms in relation to the panel.

To understand the coalition's objections it is necessary to examine the nature of the panel and the impetus for these amendments. The panel came into operation at the beginning of 1991 upon the introduction of the Corporations Law. The role of the panel was to examine the acceptability of takeover conduct by reference to the so-called Eggleston Principles which are set out in section 732 of the Corporations Law.

The panel was required to conduct a hearing with the power to make enforceable orders it considered necessary or desirable to protect the rights or interests of persons in a takeover. The panel was established because the National Companies and Securities Commission, which previously examined such behaviour, risked being perceived as investigator, prosecutor, judge, jury and executioner. The establishment of the panel was also in part a move to bring peer review into the difficult area of acceptable behaviour and market integrity.

The members of the panel were chosen for their business, financial, legal and other experience relevant to takeovers. The panel has had one matter referred to it which concerned a reverse takeover of Titan Hills Australia Ltd by Precision Data Holdings Ltd. That hearing and determination process was criticised as being cumbersome and overly legalistic. Additional criticisms were that the jurisdiction of the panel was unduly narrow and that the panel was unable to enforce undertakings given by parties.

The amendments contained in this bill are in part an attempt to render the panel procedures as informal and expeditious as possible. This bill has addressed those concerns. My core difficulty is that the amendments pull in opposite directions. On the one hand they emphasise the peer review nature of the hearings by freeing up legalistic procedures. On the other they expand the court-like powers of the panel. The current power to make enforceable determinations is expanded by the power given by the bill for the enforcement of undertakings. There is a contradiction, in my view. It is not appropriate in the black-letter law world of Australian takeover regulation to create an informal peer review body that has the power to make binding determinations which materially affect rights and interests. While it is true that the panel will not be considering technical legal issues but market behaviour and standards, the background to any inquiry is the takeover law, which is highly technical. An appreciation of the takeovers background will be vitally important in making any determination.

Regulation through black-letter law and by peer review may well be desirable but the panel should exhibit the characteristics of one approach or the other but not both. In this regard I note with interest a report of an interview with Mr Tony Hartnell in the journal Company Director in December 1992. Mr Hartnell was asked about peer review in corporate governance. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The idea of peer review is to take the debate, the exposure to corporate conduct, much wider than the narrowness of the black-letter law, and debate precise situations, not general formulations. This would be done within a body that was set up as a peer review body, with no powers to punish anyone. But it would have powers to publish its views at the end of their examinations.
And continuing the quote:

An ideal vehicle for the development of this vision could be the Corporations and Securities Panel. That relatively inactive body presently has a quasi-law enforcement role within the confines of a strict legal process with a black-letter jurisdiction.

PARA.TAB: However, this body has always been conceived of, in policy terms, as a peer body . . . No more ideal body of persons exists in Australia with relevant qualifications for peer review of corporate conduct.
In fact, my perception is that the body, as presently staffed, is more suited to the peer review function than the quasi-judicial process it currently possesses.

SPEECH.PARA: The present amendments confuse even more the role of the panel. It is in this context that the coalition cannot accept the proposed ban on advisers addressing the panel. The bill excludes advisers—legal, financial or otherwise—from representing persons appearing before the panel by addressing the panel. Advisers will be able to be present to assist their client but may not address the panel.

PARA.TAB: Given the power of the panel to directly affect parties' rights and interests and the complex black-letter law background, this is unacceptable. In that context, it cannot be said that the presence of legal and other advisers will impede its work. The ability of legal and other advisers, who might include stockbrokers, financial analysts, merchant bankers and others, to make comments may well result in distillation of the complex issues involved and, in fact, serve to expedite the process.

Further, given that the adviser may be present but cannot speak, there will be the ridiculous situation of advisers whispering to their clients what they should be saying, or presenting written submissions and comments for their clients to recite. I cannot support the relaxing of the judicial type procedures in a situation where the panel has the power directly to affect interests by means of coercive powers. If the government were to propose the establishment of a body of the type envisaged by Mr Hartnell, that would be an entirely different matter and it would be considered in a positive context by the coalition.

The amendment that I foreshadow moving would omit the proposed subsection 194(4) and substitute a subsection in these terms: `A person who appears at an inquiry is entitled to have another person present to assist the person, and a person who so assists is entitled to address the panel.'

I wish to comment further on the provisions relating to the applicability of the rules of natural justice. Although those provisions are not opposed by the coalition, I am distinctly uneasy about the way they have been formulated. The bill currently specifically provides that the rules of natural justice do not apply in relation to an inquiry. The government has indicated that it was its intention that the rules would be replaced in a streamlined form by regulation.
As a result of opposition pressure, the government proposes to recast the provision to provide:

SPEECH.PARA: It is intended that this division and the regulations will set out procedural requirements that equate to the rules of natural justice.
In my view, there is little substantive change effected by that amendment. It is, in my view, unsatisfactory and it should not be regarded as a precedent for any other situation.

PARA.TAB: Before commenting further, I will provide a little background. Natural justice is a common law doctrine which safeguards the rights of persons who may be affected by an administrative or quasi-judicial decision to procedural fairness in the making of the decision. Examples of the rules of natural justice are that the person whose rights are affected has the right to be heard and that the decision maker should not be biased. The courts have clearly established that rules vary from one situation to another. That flexibility in itself causes me to wonder whether this amendment is required. If an expedited determination is inherently necessary for the process to be effective, as it is in this case, a court would take that into account in determining that more streamlined procedures were appropriate and met the standards of procedural fairness.

In any event, the government has stated that the content of the rules of natural justice is to be expressly set out in regulations and will facilitate quick commercial decisions. Prior to the coalition making clear its objections, we had no idea what the regulations would look like. There was no guarantee that the regulations would be promulgated before the relevant provisions of the bill entered into force. That was entirely unsatisfactory. The government has now seen fit to provide draft regulations. However, the regulations are extensive and the time within which they were provided has not allowed for a detailed study or any consultation.

The provision of the regulations does provide some measure of improvement, however; but I must say that it is my personal view that, if the rules of natural justice are eradicated or replaced, at the very least the principal substitute rules should be set out in primary legislation in the enactment that abolishes the rules that would otherwise apply. The coalition, however, is not taking that point in this case.

I should note that my views in relation to both representation and natural justice have been echoed by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The committee has expressed the view that the proposals may be considered to breach the committee's principles in that they trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties, and that they delegate legislative powers inappropriately. I simply repeat that, while it is not opposed, the technique of substituting a statement such as that in the proposed subsection 195(3) is unsatisfactory and should not be regarded as a model. But the coalition will move an amendment to substitute a subsection 194(4) to deal with representation.

I now turn to some of the less contentious areas of Corporations Law to be amended by this bill. The bill makes it clear that the lower courts have jurisdiction to hear certain claims under the Corporations Law. It is presently unclear whether lower courts such as district and county courts and magistrates courts have such jurisdiction. The inability to bring action in lower courts may have the practical effect of discouraging parties with legitimate but comparatively small civil claims from bringing action. This is due to the comparative cost of bringing action in superior courts.

The difficulties are compounded by a superior court reluctance to consider minor claims. The bill confers, on lower courts in each state and territory, civil jurisdiction in respect to corporate law claims relating to debt recovery or monetary compensation. Jurisdiction is not to be granted to lower courts where high-level discretionary powers are involved. The amendments are welcome and, although he has now been replaced in the chair by the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), I know that the previous Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), has a personal interest in seeing these amendments through.

The bill makes changes to the clearing house electronic subregister system commonly known as CHESS. The Corporate Law Reform Act 1992 provided a legislative framework for the electronic settlement of transactions on the ASX. It allowed for the creation of CHESS, which aims to have transactions settled and delivered within three days after trade and to replace the current paper document of transfer with electronic transfer. The bill makes further technical amendments to facilitate the introduction of CHESS. Those provisions are not opposed by the coalition.

The bill implements a decision of the ministerial councils for corporations and for financial institutions to rationalise application of the Corporations Law and of state legislation to financial institutions—principally, building societies and credit unions. At present, intrastate activities of credit unions are governed by state legislation, and interstate activities are governed by the Corporations Law. In broad terms the amendments are unobjectionable. However, commentators have made a number of specific criticisms that should be noted.

The bill removes charges over the property of financial institutions from the registration scheme of Corporations Law, part 3.5. That is to say, charges are to be regulated only under financial institutions legislation. This worsens the fragmentation of the personal property security registration systems in Australia. The Australian Law Reform Commission, in its report No. 64 in 1993, commended a move to simplify registration and searching using the register under part 3.5 as the base for a national scheme.

While it seems that the ministerial councils did not agree on a centralised register, it seems unfortunate that fragmentation becomes more entrenched as a result of these amendments. One practical question that I ask is whether there will be a transfer of charges over financial institution property registered under the Corporations Law to the state registers. If not, dual searches will need to be undertaken. This will be cumbersome, time consuming and costly.

The assertion in the financial impact statement that the bill is not expected to have any significant financial impact on business has been challenged by a commentator as ludicrous. Under the bill, the fundraising provisions of the Corporations Law will apply to financial institutions with certain exceptions. The view is expressed that it will be costly for financial institutions to comply with the complex and uncertain prospectus provisions for fundraising activities. It is doubted whether this will be offset by the elimination of duplication.

The section of this bill implementing these amendments contains a table to help in determining which provisions of the Corporations Law apply to financial institutions. While the inclusion of the table provides a useful tool to those seeking to understand the legislation, it does exemplify the ever growing complexity of the Corporations Law.

The bill modifies the way in which the ASC must provide notice to persons affected by its decisions to facilitate appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 requires a person who makes a reviewable decision to take all reasonable steps to give any person whose interests are affected by the decision notice of the making of the decision and the right to have the decision reviewed. This creates significant practical difficulties for the ASC. In many instances it is difficult to identify all those affected by broad-ranging decisions.

The Administrative Review Council, in conjunction with the ASC and the Attorney-General's Department, has examined all categories of decisions of the ASC to determine the extent to which exemption from the notification of the making of the decisions and the review rights may be justified. The bill legislatively implements that review. It should be noted that the bill enacts in primary legislation a regulatory scheme which has been in operation since 11 December 1993.

The categories of decisions excluded from the standard AAT Act requirements are subject to a modified regime for notification of persons affected by such decisions of their rights of review under the AAT Act. The changes appear to balance sensibly the need for notice to be given to those affected by decisions against the administrative difficulties in giving notice.

In implementation of the scheme it would be desirable if the ASC were to issue policy statements listing the sorts of persons to whom it would be likely not to give notice. That would enable representations to be made by interested parties at the exposure draft stage, enabling the ASC's final determination to be improved.

The bill allows companies limited by shares to convert to no liability status. At present, a no liability company can convert to a limited liability company, but there is no procedure for conversion in the other direction. No liability companies are generally mining companies. The no liability status allows the company to offer shares at a discount without a requirement to obtain court approval for the offer. This makes investment more attractive.

The amendments address a legislative irregularity which has created difficulties for the mining industry and are not opposed by the coalition. I have a personal interest in the amendment in that I was involved in relatively fruitless litigation in a former life as counsel on the very question which is now being dealt with. It was a matter that came before several courts on several occasions in recent years.

The bill provides for the establishment of stock markets in unquoted prescribed interests on which the interests may be traded by means of an electronic trading facility. Any market will be required to be approved by the minister. The bill, supplemented by regulations, is said to provide the necessary basis for the supervision by the ASC of any such approved market.

The ASX has submitted that the amendments do not provide a sufficient framework for the provision of an efficient market and for ensuring that the interests of the public—principally, the smaller investor to whom this type of market is directed—are safeguarded. The ASX is concerned that the legislation itself provides no minimum standards. Particularly, it is concerned that the protections in sections 774 to 779 are not necessarily applicable to stock markets and unquoted prescribed interests.

The ASX also has doubts about the proposed structure of the management company providing a market, surveillance work being contracted out to a supervisor, and participants in the market not necessarily being members of the management company. The exchange asks whether the proposed structure is capable of providing a comparable level of regulation and compliance. In the absence of other criticism of the framework, I am willing to accept for the present—at least until demonstrable evidence proves to the contrary—the proposed mechanism for screen based training systems.

I do, however, find it troubling that the legislative skeleton has no flesh whatsoever. No minimum standards are detailed in the legislation. They are left for inclusion in regulations, or to be determined on a case by case basis as applications to the minister are made for approval of relevant stock markets. There needs to be application of consistent standards. As the ASX points out, providing for substantive matters to be dealt with by way of regulation is undesirable, as it reduces opportunity for scrutiny and comment. The delegation of substantive policy making from the legislature to the executive has been a troubling theme in this bill.

It has been most seriously evident in the provisions dealing with the definition of `securities' and future definitions of `securities' and `futures contracts'. Thankfully, they are to be withdrawn. Had they come into effect they would have given to the executive government inappropriately wide policy making power. So too is the attempt to replace rules of natural justice with regulatory replacement. Laws affecting fundamental rights of citizens should not be made outside a parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I support the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 and the two amendments in the name of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch). As is the custom today, by way of indulgence, can I congratulate you and the clerk on the establishment of this second chamber. As people have been making their gratuitous comments for suggested improvements, I notice that an earlier speaker made the suggestion that there ought to be at least two clocks in the room so that honourable members would know more easily how his or her time was going. My suggestion is that, as within this building we are broadcast on channel 5, it would be convenient for viewers if the remaining time that a member had to speak was indicated on that channel, so that one would have a very good appreciation as to how much longer one had either to admire or to endure. My suggestion is therefore that, just as we have for the broadcast of the House of Representatives on channel 1, the remaining time of the member speaking should also feature on channel 5.
—You have 19 minutes left of your maiden speech in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—There are no such things as maiden speeches any more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Behave yourself, Tim. There are procedures.

—We are being very civilised in this chamber. Mr Deputy Speaker, there are a range of issues which arise from this bill, but I would firstly make some general points. As is the custom with corporations legislation, this bill has, in a sense, done the rounds by way of the public comment process. In the course of the exposure draft, comments have been received in the usual way from a range of interested parties: the Australian Institute of Company Directors, the Australian Securities Commission, the Credit Union Services Corporation, the Australian Institute of Credit Management, the Attorney-General's Department, the Law Institute of Victoria and the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants. So in this area, Mr Deputy Speaker, we very much are dealing in an area for the technical aficionado where the public comment process is very important, but where the general policy which applies is also important.

PARA.TAB: I support a range of amendments to the Corporations Law in the bill. There is one which is in the original bill, which the Attorney-General has indicated he proposes to withdraw. That relates to the definition of `securities' and `futures contract'. I agree with the sensible decision of the Attorney-General to withdraw and proceed with that on a later occasion. A third amendment in respect of the Corporations and Securities Panel has been the subject of some discussion and is the subject of two amendments, one in the name of the Attorney-General and one in the name of the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams). It is my view that the amendment in the name of the Attorney-General ought to satisfy those reservations which have been raised by the honourable member for Tangney.

I make the general point that the Attorney-General, in his second reading speech, referred to the simplification process. That is a process which I know is supported by members on both sides and is certainly supported by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Corporations and Securities, of which I am fortunate enough to be chair. I think it is important to make the point, which the Attorney-General did in his second reading speech, where he said:

While I am pleased to report that good progress is being made with simplification, that process will take time. In the meantime, the current law governs the corporate sector and some reform must continue to keep that law in tune with the rapidly changing commercial environment.
When deficiencies are revealed they need to be rectified.

SPEECH.PARA: So the simplification process goes on, and the Attorney is to be complimented for that, but life goes on as well and we need to consider these amendments.

PARA.TAB: I will start in the reverse order to the honourable member for Tangney and deal with some of the range of amendments before coming to those which have been more contentious.
