The first one to which I draw attention is the proposal to extend the civil jurisdiction under the Corporations Law to lower courts in areas of debt recovery and monetary compensation. I think this is adequately described in paragraph 7 of the explanatory memorandum, where it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The court jurisdiction amendments will facilitate business, to the extent that those businesses with legitimate civil claims under the Corporations Law will be able to bring those actions in any lower court in Australia if the claim is within the court's usual monetary limits, without worrying about technical jurisdictional issues such as where the cause of action originated or the State of Territory jurisdiction in which the defendant company was registered.

There are two important policy points here. One is the general access to justice, which relates to the cost of bringing actions in superior courts. The second is that this is effectively an extension of the cross-vesting jurisdictional arrangements.

PARA.TAB: I again draw attention to the Attorney-General's second reading speech. He summarised very succinctly the access to justice point when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: This government is committed to the principle that justice should be available to the community at an affordable cost and with the prospect of a speedy resolution.
That is the principle behind this amendment and the principle behind the access to justice action plan to which the government generally is committed.

PARA.TAB: So far as cross-vesting is concerned, we are very fortunate that we have in this chamber today the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy), the former Attorney-General. He and I were reminiscing about former lives, his as Attorney-General and mine as principal private secretary to an Attorney-General for Western Australia, Mr Joe Berinson. We were reminiscing about the cross-vesting arrangements. I said to the honourable member for Holt that the original cross-vesting arrangement, which was achieved at a meeting in Brisbane of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, was actually sealed over lunch between the Attorney-General for Western Australia, Mr Joe Berinson, who is also a predecessor of mine as a former member for Perth, and the former Commonwealth Attorney-General and Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Lionel Bowen. The comment that the honourable member for Holt made, with which I wholeheartedly agreed, was that that lunch no doubt brought with it some very clear drafting instructions for the parliamentary counsel.
On a serious note, this is an extension of those cross-vesting arrangements and I think it is another example of the great sense of that cooperative venture.

The second of the non-contentious matters to which I wish to draw attention concerns the amendments in respect of the CHESS arrangements. In very many respects, I think these changes have been understated. The effect of these amendments is that the Corporations Law will provide a legislative framework for the electronic settlement of transactions on the Australian Stock Exchange. It will enable the ASX to introduce a new clearing house electronic subregister system, CHESS, through the establishment of an approved securities clearing house and legislative support of its business role. The aim of CHESS is to have transactions settled and delivered within three days after trade and to replace the current paper document of transfer with electronic transfer. That is a significant improvement in arrangements so far as the ASX is concerned. The legislative underpinning will ensure that there is an appropriate legislative regime in place to effect those arrangements.

The honourable member for Tangney and previous speakers referred to those amendments which relate to the fundraising provisions of building societies and credit unions. As that is the subject of a decision of the ministerial councils for corporations and financial institutions, this chamber can be well assured that those amendments are worth while. In passing, I draw attention to the adoption of the penalty unit system to prescribe penalties.

The final amendment to which I wish to draw attention is in respect of the segregation of client moneys by futures brokers. This is an important amendment to ensure the protection of investor funds. It is an issue that cannot be understated. This is not an amendment that was contained in the exposure bill but it is not an amendment that has been the subject of adverse comment. On the contrary, it is an amendment that has been the subject of endorsement. It is sensible and is firmly based on the principle of ensuring that at all times, through either the Corporations Law or ASX arrangements, investors' money is protected.

I will move to that area of the bill which is the subject of the Attorney-General's amendment to delete the proposed amendments in respect of the definitions of securities and futures contracts to facilitate the trading of equity based instruments having the characteristics of both equity and futures contracts.

I think the decision to defer these to a later day are very sensible and, far from being a matter for which the Attorney-General should be the subject of adverse comment, it is a matter in respect of which he should be the subject of positive comment. The Attorney-General has, I think, a growing capacity to be taking sensible and wise decisions and taking them in a timely fashion. He outlined in his second reading speech one of the reasons why the need to place this amendment into the bill without it being in the exposure bill has now passed.

There are a couple of references that I wanted to draw attention to in order to reaffirm the point that this is a sensible decision by the Attorney-General. I refer to an article in Butterworths Corporation Law Bulletin under the heading `Wolf in sheep's clothing'. I must confess, when I first saw that, I thought it was article on the change of the opposition's leadership, but I then saw the subheading `OTC markets under the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994'. It is an article by Michael Hains, who is an author of Butterworths Australian Corporation Law. In his contribution in that piece, he says:
However, what appear to be fairly minor amendments proposed by the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill . . . may herald a wholesale change to the way derivatives are regulated—

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on in his article to make the point, at its conclusion:

PARA.TAB: It is evident that several important policy issues are raised by the amendments. It is imperative that the amendments be deleted from the Amendment Bill and that a considered, informed and consultative process be implemented.
If proceeded with, the amendments will create uncertainty and will confuse the regulatory regime in Australia. This will adversely impact on both exchange traded and OTC derivatives markets.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not necessarily agreeing with the final comment but that is one indication which supports the sensible decision by the Attorney-General to delete this particular provision from the bill.

PARA.TAB: There was a second reference that I wanted to draw attention to on this issue, which is an extract from an article in the Australian Financial Review by Mr Ian Rogers, under the heading `Law could give ASX derivatives'. It says:

A partner with Freehill, Hollingdale and Page, Mr John O'Sullivan said the reforms would `lessen the certainty that designers of new products can have about the regulatory treatment of the product at the time that the product is designed.'
He said the amendments were an `admission of defeat' by the legislative draftsman.
It would be easier for the Australian Securities Commission to ensure that instruments that were similar in economic substance had the same regulatory treatment.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I am not saying that is necessarily correct, but Mr O'Sullivan is a practitioner of some standing in this area and it is views such as these that I am sure that the Attorney-General has taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is an old friend of yours, isn't he?

—The Attorney-General has sprung me here. I refer to Mr O'Sullivan not only because he is a practitioner in the field but also because many years ago we were students together. In the tradition of many young lawyers, we went to London to do a masters at London University. He, of course, being a corporations lawyer studied Corporations Law. I, of course, being a labour lawyer, studied comparative constitutional law and human rights.
—This reminiscing does not indicate that you are about to retire, does it?

—No. Far from it, Mr former Attorney-General. But I reminisce in this way: in addition to being a very good Corporations Law student and subsequently a corporations practitioner, he was also a more than useful top order batsman.
—That is something very important.
—That is very important. The honourable member for Bennelong interjects and underlines that it is very important.

PARA.TAB: Returning to the futures issue, for those reasons, I believe the amendment which is listed in the name of the Attorney-General ought to be supported.

I will move to the issue which has been the subject of an amendment tabled by the honourable member for Tangney and by the Attorney-General and that is in respect of the changes to the Corporations and Securities Panel.

I think it is important to put the comments that the honourable member for Tangney has made on natural justice and procedural fairness into context. The Corporations and Securities Panel is established under part 10 of the Australian Securities Commission Act, and its powers are defined in part 1 of the Corporations Law. Upon application by the ASC it examines takeover conduct and may make declarations and orders concerning unacceptable conduct and acquisitions. These declarations and orders are enforceable by the courts.

The activities of the panel have been greatly curtailed following its examinations of conduct involved in the shares of Titan Hills and Precision Data Holdings. In the Titan Hills matter, the panel found that its jurisdiction did not extend far enough to cover the fairness of the amount of information provided during a related series of takeovers. In both cases the panel became involved in litigation which prevented it from reaching a rapid decision.

The amendments contained in the bill would have the following effect: to extend the panel's jurisdiction to cover matters concerned with takeover conduct generally; to allow a person appearing before an inquiry to have another person present to assist him, although they remove any right to be represented by a barrister or a solicitor; to allow regulations to be made dealing with submissions, the right to appear or be present at an inquiry and the matters to be taken into account when making a decision; to reduce the risk of delays through litigation; and to empower the panel to accept undertakings which are enforceable by the court.

The first of the two amendments that we have before this chamber is in the name of the Attorney-General. As the explanatory memorandum notes, this amendment will, in effect, omit the express exclusion of the rules of natural justice in relation to an inquiry in proposed subsection 195(3) and substitute a statement of the government's intention that the requirements of the rules of natural justice will be met where the procedural requirements set out in division 3 of part 10 of the ASC Act and the regulations are followed in the course of the inquiry.

The amendment which is in the name of the honourable member for Tangney has the effect of suggesting that a person who appears at an inquiry is entitled to have another person present to assist that person, and the person who so assists is entitled to address the panel. That is code for ensuring that a person is entitled, as of right, to have present a legal practitioner, in effect, who can address the panel.

The issue here is one of procedural fairness. Procedural fairness does not require that the panel behave like a court, and likewise cross-examination of parties and witnesses is not a requirement of procedural fairness. The emphasis of the panel will instead be on written submissions by parties and strict time limits for submissions. After examining these submissions, the panel will decide whether a conference or oral inquiry is necessary. Given that the panel's deliberations do not generally relate to technical legal matters but rather to matters of market behaviour and market standards, it is more appropriate that the parties, rather than their legal advisers, address the panel at any such oral inquiries. Legal advisers may of course be present to assist but will not be entitled to address the panel.

The issue which the honourable member for Tangney has raised is the ability of a person not just to assist but to address the panel. The rule of natural justice, which as a result of the amendment in the name of the Attorney-General will be incorporated, has the effect that a person does have the opportunity to be heard but not necessarily the right to be heard orally. The rule of natural justice does not necessarily require that decision makers hear arguments from a person's legal representatives. It does require that a person have an adequate opportunity to present his or her case and, while the bill has the effect that a person does not have the right to be represented by a legal adviser, it does enable an adviser to be present and to assist the person in the presentation of that case.

These amendments have been modelled on the system of pre-decision conferences under the Trade Practices Act. That is a system which, to my understanding, works very well. We ought to have every confidence that similar procedures adopted here will work equally well in this area. To return to a point I made earlier, I believe that will prove to be the case because the panel's deliberations do not relate to technical legal matters but to matters of market behaviour and market standards. One does not need to have legal representation to make those points adequately.

In conclusion, Mr Deputy Speaker, if I can, in a sense, conclude where I began, I compliment the Attorney-General on his simplification process. The amendments which he has put before the House are all worthy of support, and the important changes to Corporations Law which are envisaged by this bill reflect, once again, the ongoing commitment that the government has to ensuring that the Corporations Law operates effectively and efficiently, and that the interests of all players—and investors, in particular—are supported by an effective legal regime, which needs to change continually with changing circumstances. The bill and the amendments which the Attorney has put before the House effectively satisfy those requirements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the chamber long in my comments in regard to the matter which is before us, which is the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. There have been a number of matters that have concerned the opposition. The panel and the natural justice issues naturally come to mind. The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has sought to re-establish a process which covers the natural justice issue. It is not the opposition's proposal to press that matter, but instead to take up the matter referred to by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith). That is the area of the panel itself.

PARA.TAB: We just feel that, in the circumstances, despite the assurances that have been given, natural justice is an issue. I think the terms used were that natural justice need not be served by people giving oral expression to their concern. To me, it is a strange thing indeed that natural justice can be thought to be served by anything other than someone having the opportunity to, in any way they think appropriate, express their objection or concern about an issue before the government or before a court. So there should be no limitation on the way in which persons can express themselves. The limited process of expression being adhered to by the government is not something that is endorsed by the coalition.
I will quickly run through the main provisions of the bill. Firstly, there is the conferral of jurisdiction on lower courts, something that the opposition will not oppose.

The next is the clearing house electronic subregister system. I notice that government speakers have said this will have a massive impact, far wider than is supposed by many in the industry. The reverse appears to be the case, and there have been expressions of concern from various interests. To quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Several listed public companies have adopted articles which confer on their boards the power to refuse to register a transfer in favour of a company which is a foreign company for the purpose of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975. See, for example, Equiticorp Industries Ltd v ACI International Ltd . . . The justification of such articles is said to be that if transfers are registered in favour of foreign persons, the company may itself be classified as a foreign company and this may cause it to lose business opportunities in Australia.
The Australian Stock Exchange has expressed its view on this matter, and it is not the intention of the opposition to oppose this measure.

PARA.TAB: The third area is the application of corporate law to financial institutions. The bill removes charges over the property of financial institutions for the registration scheme in the Corporations Law part 3.5, and that will not be opposed.

The Corporations and Securities Panel is an area which is of concern. The bill seeks to remedy some of the faults by excluding the rules of natural justice in relation to an inquiry. Excluding legal and other advised representative persons before the panel, advisers will be able to be present to assist their client but may not be able to address the panel. The bill allows the court to enforce undertakings given to the panel, and broadens the jurisdiction of the panel to investigate certain conduct associated with a takeover.

This is the area of contention. My colleague the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) has moved an amendment seeking to rectify that problem. I have already said that it is my view that persons ought to be able to give expression in these circumstances in any way they see fit, whether it be written, by tape or orally. They ought to have their representative prepared in such a way as to be able to do it.

The argument presented is that this will work like a pre-hearing tribunal of the Trade Practices Tribunal under the Trade Practices Act. That is fine, except I point out to the Attorney that a court stands behind the panel and the court has the capacity to enforce undertakings given to the panel. Therefore, no-one could put any blush on the fact that the proceedings before the panel are not important. They are very important, both to the individuals and to their organisations. I submit that not to allow legal representation could inhibit the proper and fair pursuit of an issue being considered by the panel. I do not think anybody wants to get into a full-blown court situation but there is a court standing behind the panel. That makes it different from a tribunal or a dispute settling process which is not formal.

Before most tribunals or panels there is a process whereby one may not have judges present, such as in social security, veterans' affairs or immigration. There is a large range of processes whereby negotiations and settlement take place before a tribunal or panel. In all these instances there is no court standing behind the panel to enforce the undertakings given to the panel. That is the distinction we want to draw. In this instance there is a court behind the panel and therefore legal representation is valid and should be allowed. So we are moving our amendment along those lines.

I wish to refer to other factors in this legislation, such as the notification of review of decisions and the screen-based trading systems. The Australian Stock Exchange has submitted that the amendments do not provide a sufficient framework for the provision of an efficient market and for ensuring that the interests of the public, and principally those of the smaller investor, to whom this type of market is directed, are safeguarded.

Some of these criticisms are detailed and complex and appear to be influenced by the desire on the part of the ASX to ensure that markets are restricted to the existing forms of markets. That may or may not be right, but the ASX has offered a comment and a criticism. As the process develops we need to be very sensitive to ensuring that Australia can capitalise on its particular geographic location in South-East Asia and draw on the expertise and security our markets offer in this area. So the government will need to listen to the Australian Stock Exchange.

Finally, I mention the conversion of companies to no-liability status and the series of other less consequential amendments. I wish to raise two matters in particular—the program of simplification of the Corporations Law and the conduct of the investigation by two members of the Simplification Task Force. Comments were made by Miss Claire Grosse and Dr Robert Eggleson, who hinted that the company register paper would allude to the need to eliminate the requirement of companies to hold registers in multiple locations. They appear to be eminently suited to the task in which they are engaged. That leads me to the second matter—the Attorney-General's comments reported in the Australian Financial Review on 29 April—which basically say to the corporate world, `You get your act together and we will support you.'

I think that is a sensible way to go. I am pleased with the tack that is being taken in relation to this matter. The government could move in and be very prescriptive and use black-letter law and heaps of it. However, there is an adopted attitude or an inherited attitude about this. The former Attorney-General was very much of that ilk: he did not want to move to complete prescription. In the latter days of his term he tried to gain a mix—an interrelationship—between black-letter law and fuzzy law, and he did that successfully.

I wish to compliment the present Attorney-General. I hope his actions help to end the difficulties that the country has experienced over a long period and about which the government really failed to take action until the horses had bolted. It has been too little too late in some ways, but the Attorney-General is going about it in the right way.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed amendments to the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 require a brief examination of the history of the Corporations and Securities Panel. When honourable members look at this history, they will see that it picks up many of the points made by the previous speakers. The panel was established, as the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) pointed out, as a peer review group to examine conduct and takeover matters referred to it by the ASC. In particular, it was empowered to make declarations of unacceptable conduct and acquisitions in respect of takeovers, and to make orders to remedy such conduct.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the first matter that came before the panel was the one referred by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams)—the Titan Hills takeover case. In terms of peer review, it must be said that that case was a total disaster because, rather than a peer review, it became an exercise in legal technicalities. It was clear at that point to the government that the panel could not operate without changes to facilitate the panel's conduct of inquiries. That is what the government is doing in this legislation. The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and the government should be commended for that because I think it is an important panel. It could not work in the past and these amendments will make it work. That is the aspect of the bill that I particularly want to deal with. All of the other matters in the bill are matters of significance, apart from some consequential matters.

A large amount of litigation was directly generated by the Titan Hills-Precision Data reverse takeover. It is true that some of those actions—these points have been made by other people—such as the constitutional challenge to the panel's power, will not come back to haunt us. I think that that has probably ended. However, as I have indicated briefly, it did become clear during the Titan Hills matter that there were a number of other difficulties with the panel's operations. The most obvious difficulty evidenced by that case is that, despite the panel's legislative charter, hearings have to be conducted with little formality and technicality and with as much expedition as possible. There is potential for that process to be totally bogged down as a quasi-legal forum for legal representatives to present lengthy arguments.

The fact is that there is a precedent, which was touched on by other speakers, although they were not agreeing with it. That precedent is the procedures before the Trade Practices Commission in the early stages. The worrying part about all this is that when the government attempted to go for peer review there was only one case, because the exact opposite happened. It got bogged down in the most extraordinarily complex legal arguments, and something had to be done about that if we were going to make any sense of peer review at all.

The member for Tangney raised the issue which Mr Tony Hartnell, former Chairman of the ASC, pointed out in a fairly recent interview. I do not have the quotation in front of me, but Mr Hartnell said words to the effect that we should have a panel with no power to punish but merely a power to publish what it felt about the behaviour and the standards of behaviour that people had engaged in. That is all very well, but what concerns me about that is that there is nothing at all to stop corporate Australia doing precisely that now. There is nothing that the Attorney could do to stop corporate Australia doing precisely that. In fact, the contrary; and that was touched on in the latter part of the speech by the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman).

For a long while, if not for ever, there has been a total lack of a culture of peer review in this country. People tend to say that there has been an overreaction to the corporate excesses of the 1980s, and that is why we had so much legislation in the late 1980s and early 1990s. But it is not an overreaction to something that happened in the 1980s. The history of it, unfortunately, goes back a lot further than that. One thinks of Cambridge Credit, the Korman empire, Reid Murray and Poseidon. None of that happened in the 1980s. It goes back well before the 1980s.

There has been no history of any real attempt by those people involved in corporate Australia to deliver peer review. I well recall occasions on which I spoke to a man who can be referred to as one of our leading chief executive officers, the executive director of a leading Australian public company. He always became very concerned when it was put to him that the behaviour that we were seeing in corporate Australia was appalling. He would always respond—and it was particularly in relation to the general area of the Corporations Law concerning loans to directors that he made this response—that in the company of which he was the chief executive and executive director, none of those things happened.

I always had to remind him, time and time again, that no-one suggested that they did. As far as anyone could see, in that company there was a record of accountability along the lines that this government has said should be upheld in the area of corporate law in this country. This government has said right through its period of government that, where people are dealing with other people's money, a standard of behaviour is required which is far beyond that which might apply if they wanted merely to fritter away their own money.

I well recall having to say to that person on many occasions that if, at some stage in the future, he was asked by a judge, `When did you actually make a strong speech to the Institute of Directors, the Business Council of Australia or whoever, on what should be the proper behaviour in corporate Australia?' the answer from him at best would have to be, `Your Honour, I just happened to be passing by at the time.' In many ways that sums up the problem that the government has—and in particular the Attorney-General has—of getting it into the minds of those people that, if they want a culture of peer review, they have to do it. He as Attorney-General cannot do it. This government cannot establish it. The government and the Attorney cannot put a culture into the minds of people; they have to do it themselves. They have not done it.

The honourable member for Tangney quoted the eminent Tony Hartnell, for whose drive, initiative and energy as the first Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission I have the greatest respect; and one can understand what Tony Hartnell said, as quoted by the member for Tangney. But the fact is that that is not a criticism of the legislation that the Attorney is bringing before the parliament. It cannot be a criticism of it, because what they are appealing for—as much as I can understand precisely what the honourable member for Tangney and Mr Hartnell are appealing for—seems to be some body which does not punish but has to publish and, therefore, highlight misbehaviour of corporate Australia in a particular instance.

As I said before, there is no question that that is what this government has always been on about. If corporate Australia wants to engage in that sort of self-regulation through peer review, then it should go right ahead. I think there is no question that the last three Attorneys, including the present one, are on record as saying that, if people want to talk about peer review and if they really are serious about it, they should get on with it.

The other point made by many people was that this legislation was not necessary. The old, but correct, point was made by them that, if it is not broken, do not fix it. I can tell honourable members that this legislation was necessary because unquestionably it was broken. This panel had to be fixed. It could not operate in the way it did. The government, and in particular the Attorney, should be congratulated for attempting to bring it back on the rails. But again let me emphasise that it still probably will not work unless corporate Australia is prepared to give it a chance to work. If people wish to turn this again into a quasi-court, they will be able to do it through various means. Do not blame the Attorney-General, or the government, if that happens. Corporate Australia should not run around saying, `The government did not make an effort to bring about peer review'—because it has. That is what this legislation is attempting to do; it is attempting to fix something that was broken, and it was broken in a way which indicated that corporate Australia had not learned a lesson of allowing a body to take its course and, in a limited way, have that peer review.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this is only a limited way. The Attorney cannot do it; the government cannot do it. It is up to corporate Australia. I think I have reached the stage where, if I hear one leader of industry in this country again say that he wants more self-regulation or more peer review, I will become ill, because we know that people are not going to do it. If they want to go out and do it, we invite them to start right now. From the moment of this bill, let them show the Attorney and the government that they are capable of conducting peer review, because they have no culture or no record of it to date.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it being almost 1.00 p.m., I seek leave to continue my remarks at a future time. I understand that in this chamber, under the new procedures here, that has the effect of adjourning the debate, although I do not intend to come back and continue my remarks and take your time at a future date.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Motion (by Mr Lavarch) agreed to:
That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 June 1994 Mr Lloyd asked the Acting Prime Minister the following question without notice:

PARA.TAB: My question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister. He will be aware that the tomato industry, in November 1991, lodged an application for the imposition of dumping and countervailing duties on canned tomatoes from Italy. He will also be aware that duties were finally imposed in April 1992, successfully appealed by the Italians in June 1993, and then successfully counterappealed by the Anti-Dumping Authority in February 1994. My question is: why has the government only reimposed duties back to February 1994 rather than June 1993, as this would be the correct procedure and as this failure to do so has condoned the significant tonnage of canned tomatoes imported in that seven month period with a subsidy close to the total price received by Australian growers? Will the Government reconsider this incorrect and bad decision?
The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

Dumping and countervailing duties were initially imposed against canned tomatoes from Italy in April 1992. The Italian exporter subsequently applied to the Federal Court to have the duties set aside on the basis that there had been several errors of law in the inquiry process. The court upheld the application and the duties were removed in June 1993.

The findings were challenged before the Full Bench of the Federal Court and, in February 1994, the Full Bench upheld the challenge. Following a brief inquiry by the Anti-Dumping Authority into a particular aspect of the Court hearings, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction reimposed dumping and countervailing duties as from 10 February, the date of the orders that gave effect to the Full Court's Decision.

Turning now to the questions raised by the Honourable Member as to why the measures were reimposed as from February 1994 rather than from the time when they were removed in June 1993, the response is twofold.

First, in accordance with Order number 35 of the Federal Court Rules, a judgement or order of the Federal Court takes effect on the day it was pronounced or made, unless the Court orders that it take effect at an earlier or later date. In the canned tomatoes case, as the Court did not specify a date for the Full Court's finding to take effect, the findings came into effect on the date of the orders—10 February 1994. To have this date overturned and an earlier date imposed would have required an application to the Federal Court by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. Thus the Minister, in deciding to reimpose the relevant duties, was unable to apply them from a date prior to the order by the Court.
Whether the Minister should have applied to the Court to have the ability to impose duties earlier than February 1994 goes to the second aspect of the response to the Honourable Member's question.

Dumping that causes material injury is recognised internationally as a form of unfair competition. As all Honourable Members would know, this is explicitly reflected in the GATT. As a signatory to the GATT, Australia has upheld the right of all Australian industries to seek action against such behaviour. Duties are not imposed as a means of creating revenue for the Government. It follows that these duties should not be imposed if they do not have the effect of countering the effect of unfair competition.

In the case of canned tomatoes, if the Minister had applied successfully to the Federal Court and had the date of reimposition set at June 1993, how would this assist the Australian industry? Obviously, the vast majority of imports of canned tomatoes since June 1993 would have by now been sold to consumers by supermarkets throughout the country. To the extent that these imports may have caused material injury to the Australian industry, that industry would gain no advantage now in having duties imposed against these past imports.

In contrast, the Australian companies who import canned tomatoes would be faced with a substantial bill—amounting, I am told, to over $3 million—which could conceivably cause considerable hardship to them.
Under the circumstances, the Government is satisfied that the dumping and countervailing measures against exports of canned tomatoes from Italy should apply only from February 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 May, Dr Hewson asked the Treasurer a question without notice concerning the estimate of revenue to be raised from companies in 1994-95 as a result of the compliance enhancement measures announced in the Treasurer's statement on tax policy of September 1992. Dr Hewson also wanted to know on what basis this estimate was prepared.

PARA.TAB: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

In the then Treasurer's September 1992 Statement on Tax Policy it was estimated that an extra $750 million of revenue would be collected in 1994-95 through these compliance enhancement measures; it was estimated that $335 million of this $750 million would be collected from companies. The estimate for company collections through these measures was based on ATO research and experience that indicated the extra revenue could be raised by allocating additional resources to the following activities:
Large/Medium project which includes:
acceleration of large case audit through greater availability of high level technical advice;
expansion of rulings and determinations;
increased focus on international issues and contemporary commercial practices;
expansion of business audit;
expanded information reporting; and
increased record keeping audits.
It was estimated that the Large/Medium project would account for $250 million of the $335 million in 1994-95. This estimate was arrived at having regard to the following factors:

In their evaluation of the large case Audit program, Boston Consulting Group concluded that compliance would improve if taxpayers were made more aware of their tax obligations. It was conservatively estimated that the Large/Medium project would increase compliance by 2-3% by 1994-95, resulting in additional revenue of $200 million. This estimate was arrived at after consideration of the indirect effects obtained in other areas from compliance activity (eg improved compliance from the announcement of

ANSWER.PARA: TFN), and judgments based on the dollar value of the strategic issues which would be covered by the tax rulings and determinations.

PARA.TAB: In addition, the extra resources used in direct audit activity were estimated, based on past results, to yield an additional $50 million.
On the basis of past results it was estimated that the additional resources allocated to the expansion of business audit activities would yield an additional $25 million of revenue in 1994-95.

ANSWER.PARA: Record Keeping and Expanded Information Reporting

PARA.TAB: It was estimated that the record keeping and expanded information reporting component of the strategy would account for $60 million of the $335 million in 1994-95. This estimate was based on estimates of improved compliance due to better record keeping by business, and reduced opportunity for misreporting of income in industries subject to the expanded reporting arrangements.
